California. All of the organizations are in strong support of this measure. Thank you. Thank you.
Amber Kay with the Association of California Healthcare Districts in support.

Thank you Mr. Chairman and members. I thank you for having me here presenting SJR 15 which calls on Congress to remove the names of elected and military leaders of the confederacy from all federal public places including parks, buildings, and roadways. This legislation tracked with my bill that was approved by both houses last year.

Unfortunately, too many public places in our nation still honour confederate leaders who split the country in two as they fought to preserve the institution of slavery. It's been heartening to see that a national conversation about this has led to some public institutions taking down confederate names including an elementary school just last month in San Diego. I believe our search for racial harmony could be boosted if Congress were to act on this,

to take steps to remove these racially divisive symbols, the names of military and elected leaders of the Confederacy from all our Federal properties. It's my hope that this resolution inspires people to re-examine examples in America of where we honour those who led this confederacy movement.
Thank you, I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Thank you Mr. Chair. I was just saying closing that I thought the analysis by your staff was extraordinarily well done, historical, factual and compelling. I appreciate the work that was put into preparing it.
With that, I ask for an aye vote.

Mr Chair and member, Seth Bramble here on behalf of the California Teachers Association. We do believe that the legal rights and responsibilities of marriage belong to all adults regardless of gender, regardless of sexual orientation. I urge your aye vote. Thank you.

I want to welcome everybody here for the Joint Assembly Senate Informational Hearing. The subject of this hearing is the ballad initiative addressing changes to the juvenile justice system, adult parole for non-violent offenders and custody credits for state prison inmates. I would like to thank the witnesses who are here today to help educate us on the issues raised by this initiative. In terms of structure today, for today's hearing, we will start with a presentation on the initiative by the Legislative Analyst's office, there will be a panel of witnesses who are proponents of the initiative, and a panel of witnesses in opposition to the initiative. The proponents will testify first and legislatures will have an opportunity to ask questions.

We will repeat the process with the opponents to the initiative. In conclusion, there will be a period for public comment. This hearing is an opportunity for us as legislatures to gather information on the initiative but also a chance to get information out to the people of California who'll be voting on this initiative. This initiative addresses two policy areas within public safety that relate to how we as a state want to focus our resources within the criminal justice system. The initiative would limit the circumstances in which a juvenile offender could be tried in adult court. The initiative would also provide greater possibilities for state prison inmates to earn credits or parole from state prison.

My involvement with the Assembly Public Safety Committee and Budget Sub 5 has highlighted the impact that public safety issues have on Californians. It is critical, that we as a state provide effective tools to law enforcement, the courts, and Corrections and Rehabilitation, so that California has a criminal justice system that works for everybody. The Assembly and Senate Public Safety Committees are committed to that goal. We understand how important it is to ensure that the resources the State of California are used in the most effective manor to advance public safety. I am eager to hear from the proponents and opponents on the merits of this initiative in terms of achieving these objectives. At this time, I would like to turn it over to my esteemed colleague from the State Senate, Senator Loni Hancock for any comments she might like to make.

Thank you, we are joined by State Senator Joe Anderson, Assemblymember Bill Quirk, Senator, Bill Monning and Senator Mark Leno today. Any of you want to make any opening comments? No, hearing none. Then Mr. Drew Soderborg, our Managing Principal Analyst, Criminal Justice Legislative Analyst's Office, you may begin.
Are there any questions from the members? Mr. Quirk.
Ms Hancock, I know you have to leave soon. Do you have any?

And I just, just want you to think about what you said, because if we had your counterpart from the Department of Finance sitting next to you, would he or she say the exact same thing that you just said? Which goes to Mr. Leno's question, because we're very concerned, it's not about legislation, it's about implementation. And if we're back here and we read something in this ballot initiative that says the Finance Department, because some people have determined that the Finance Department has the sole authority to make the determination by August 1st. And that we don't have any input. And now you're saying we do. And so I don't want to get back to this If it should pass that we're now back again debating what that number is because your numbers are significantly different than the Department of Finance. So would you say your counterpart would be saying the same thing?
Okay, Mr. Monning.
Okay, thank you. And I see no more questions from the Committee. I want to thank you, Mr. Toliver for your testimony.

Okay, we're now going to bring up the proponents. Frankie Guzman, Attorney, National Center for Youth Law. Elizabeth Calvin, Senior Advocate, Human Rights Watch. Mary Butler, President-Elect, Chief Probation Officers of California.

Dion Wilson, Outreach Crime Survivors for Safety and Justice. And they said there was one more person whose name, Dion, okay? Thank you for being here today. You have about 45 minutes, I would say 30 minutes and
then we'll have 15 minutes for questioning.
Good morning.So however you want to break it up.
Thank you. No clapping.
Thank you Mr Guzman.
And thank you.
Thank you. Any members have any questions? Mr. Monning.
Any other?
You're welcome. Mr. Leno.

Thank you. Okay, thank you are there any other questions? I just have one and it's really about this research on juvenile brain development and I know Mr. Guzman is here and how it fits with the juvenile policy here. I remember watching a movie called The Bad Seed where the little girl just about killed everybody. The mom, dad, the handy man, but, and this is really kind of directed toward Ms. Butler who actually works, her members actually work with juveniles.

And it's just this notion, not only that we want vengeance, we want to punish, but is there a thing of there's no child that you can't turn around? There's no, no matter how heinous the crime, does every youth have an opportunity to turn their life around?

Especially if some of the research has shown that developmentally, their brains have not developed to a point where, I'm not going to say they don't know what they're doing, but they may not have full adult understanding of what they're doing.

And on that point, you also make sure that you don't let anyone out. They shouldn't get out to that. I mean, t hat should be noted that you, I wouldn't call parole officer if the probation officer soften the crime and let you-
Thank you. Do you want to say something, Mr. Guzman?
Thank you and I want to thank the panel for being here today. It's been very informative. Thank you and we'll bring up our next panel.

Larry Morris II, District Attorney Merced County. Robert Messman, Senior Deputy District Attorney, Orange County. George Hofstetter, President Association of Los Angeles Deputy Sheriffs and Mark Cloth, victims advocate. Gentlemen, welcome. Welcome.
Same rules, you have 30 minutes, you divide it up whatever way you want and then we'll have questions and answers.
Sir, you're about 10 minutes. Make sure we can hear from everybody.
Thank you, Mr. Yaryan.
Thank you, thank you.
Are there any members with any questions?
Are there any other questions? Mr. Leno.
Okay, Mister Glazer.

Thank you Mister Chairman, I'd like to thank the proponents and opponents for being here today. I know this is a newer process that we go through now with measures that are submitted for the ballot. It's an interesting one to participate in, I'm certainly, after hearing the testimony today, I'm left a little baffled, and I'll explain.

But we do know that enacting laws through initiatives, not necessarily the best way to do our business, because there's a lot of unintended consequences. And even though we know that there's difficulty in moving things through a legislative process where there are people with many different views, that there is great advantages in being able to correct mistakes or oversights, as policy progresses and lessons are learned.

That's not a healthy conversation that focuses on the facts. I think that we would be best served that if the Governor's representative was not invited to hold another hearing where they are asked to participate so we can get clarification on this very important question of definition of so-called a non-violent offender.

And if the Governor or his representatives decline to participate in that review, which we are now obligated to undertake. That we ask them to provide written testimony that would refute or affirm the assertions that have been made in regard to what crimes would be eligible or not should this measure pass the voters.

I know that I have been frustrated and many, many people on this panel have been frustrated that, in the course of an election campaign for an initiative, certainly one that's likely to be on the ballot filled with maybe up to 20 or more initiatives. That there was very little opportunity for dialogue and conversation and to dig down into some of these most very meaningful impacts that measures may have.

I think it's incumbent upon us in the Legislature to do our jobs as well as we can to provide that information so that people can be as informed as they're able to be. I think this session today has been helpful and productive and insightful. I hope given some of the serious points of confusion though, that we wouldn't stop at this point in time, and that we ask for clarification from the proponent of the measure in any fashion in which he would be comfortable.
Thank you. Mr. Leno?

Mrs. Hancock did you have any questions?

Okay. And so I also want to thank the DA's, ALAD's and of course Mr. Claus, we always want to hear your voice It's very important that we hear from you. I got here in 2012 and my first assignment was to be the budget chair, budgets of five.

And I noticed early on that we did nothing for rehabilitation. We had totally viscerated That whole operation. Not because we really wanted to, because we got 10 years of really horrendous budget cuts. I'm sure you felt it.

Yes sir.On the law enforcement end too. And so when the overcrowding started and we were forced to let people down, out, or push them down to the county level. I don't think we really had a well thought out plan.

And I think we just, we knew what we had to do and we did the best we could, as quickly as we could. A more well thought out plan. I think is what you see now in Prop 47 where you say to yourself, how do we release these individuals in a way that makes sense?

The way we can educate them, get them drug rehabilitation, where we can ge them out of criminalization. How we deal with their mental health. And we create whole holistic way of dealing with them. We started that process with Prop 47.

We're still working through that even now. I think you heard earlier, we even had a discussion on whether it's $29 million or $150 million. We're just now funding it, funding rehabilitation. And you're absolutely right, it takes time.

But more important, we have to do it. At some point, we have to start rehabilitating people who, as the members of these committees has said, they are coming out. Whether you want them to come out, totally criminalized in the system?

Or will you want to try and find an avenue in which they become better citizens? And they can feed their families and be productive members of our society. I believe that as we now move now, there's a concerted effort from the proponents of this. To try to not just do this thing of rehabilitation, but looking at it in a broader sense.

And I believe we're working toward that too. Our colleague here, this process of having hearings is also new to me. I'm not blaming anybody but it did come from the Senate. But I also think it's a good idea.

Having an open dialog where we invite everyone. And they can attend or not, is I think the only thing that this chair and this chair are committed to, is to invite everyone that's involved in this. And then they can make up their mind to come to this hearing,

this one hearing, and hear all of the issues. But most important, not only just for us here, but for the residents of the State of California. So, we have a full hearing, because I think that was what's missing before. If we didn't have this process before, we would have just gone straight to the ballot and straight to the campaign.

And so, I do see the merits in having this. Even though it's very time consuming. And so I think our responsibility. We fulfilled it. And we've allowed people to have a hearing. And in a little bit we'll hear from the public. Because I want to make sure we have time to hear from them.

And so, we've basically fulfilled our commitment to hear it and I think hopefully you believe you been fully heard. And hopefully the proponents have been fully heard, so that we can go ahead. And I want to thank you for coming here today because it's very, very important to hear from you.
And I genuinely feel your concern, and I think every member on this panel feel law enforcement's and the DA's concerns about this is not being taken lightly. Thank you.

The students that live within our communities are often are faced with bullying. People with developmental disabilities are at a heightened risk of such attacks.

This bill, very concise piece of legislation builds on existing policy and simply reflects current technology and opportunities for ne'er do wells to engage in bullying. A recent example from outside of state, one of the most horrific examples I can think of. A young man with autism was convinced by some individuals who purported to be friends to participate in the ice bucket challenge.

This bucket was not filled with ice, but human excrement. This attack was documented via cell phone video. In California, current statute would prevent that type of activity for being punished under bullying provisions obviously numbers of other offenses were committed here in our process so,

violation will be pursued but, this addition of the term video to this several term already enumerated. It's a simple fix to ensure that currently bullying law can capture these types of offenses and insure a safe environment for students. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I rise today and ask that we adjourn in the memory of the 49 people who were massacred on Saturday night at Pulse Orlando, and to keep those still struggling for their lives in our prayers. We adjourn in their memories, and our thoughts are with the families, friends and community, who are left behind to grieve and try to make sense of this senseless tragedy. They were mostly all young men, they were mostly all Latino, and they were out celebrating who they were, dancing and enjoying themselves in a nightclub where they felt safe. Ours has long been a gathering place for members of the LGBT community, a place where we could be totally free and open.

The Stonewall Bar, if you can recall where the LGBT movement was born. We are not welcome in your church or in your community or in your home or in your workplace, it's invaluable to find places where you can just be who you are. Bars and nightclubs have provided that refuge and generally understood even though sometimes they're in rough neighborhoods, if you could make it to the bar okay inside, you would be safe from harassment and that this happened during Pride Month, when we think of event the word pride, what does that mean? To be proud means you refuse to be ashamed, you refuse to deny who you are.

It's not enough to have people tolerate you, but to be proud about who you are, to be able to walk in freedom. Political dialogue and push back to the LGBT visibility and expanded rights, things like marriage equality, equal protections, laws about non discrimination. Which we still don't have in 32 states in this country, help fuel the fire of anger, distrust and hatreds for those individuals who are most vulnerable to become violent. Every parent who has had a child come out to them, their first thought always is, will they be safe?

All parents have told all of us, I want you to be safe. I fear for your safety. What will people do? What will people think? People will be mean to you. You shouldn't have to be brave to be who you are. You shouldn't have to be brave to publicly love who you love. People might say, why do you have to be so public? Why do you have to go out? Why do we have to have Pride? The question should be, why do we have to hide? Why do we have to hide from silent judgment? Why do we have to hide from bullying and why do we have to duck and cover from assault weapons?

You'll know I served in the military, I got a message over the weekend from someone I served with 35 years ago. 35 years ago, when I was a young 19, 20 year old, and I haven't talked to him in forever but through Facebook he contacted me and he said, "I want you to watch out and be safe." Notice your surroundings like you used to when you were younger and I just replied, I never stopped. Members, I ask that we hold the pictures of those young men's and women's faces in our minds and in our hearts. I ask that we embrace the photos of their weeping parents to community at risk and as we adjourn in their memory. That we recommit to filling our hearts with love, with acceptance, with embracing our diversity that is a very core of the freedom that we all hold so dear.

Everybody who wants to fix the Delta for us all talk about the peril, the danger, the peril. So this is a program that's in place, that's working. There is no question in anybody's mind that the levees must be maintained.

And to keep coming back and asking for permission or seeing how it works I think Doesn't make any sense. And, of course, it's interesting that the only people who are objecting to this are downstream people for whom the levies are the very lifeblood that keeps their water going.

And I don't know if the position will change if the sale of the three islands ever go through and you become one of our closer neighbors, maybe it changes then. But I think this is a very important bill. I think it makes sense.
I think it saves us having to come back and do the sunset again and again. The program is effective. It's evaluated, and I just think it's a good, common sense policy.

So, this legislation really hits close to home. We've had several years of really extensive problems trying to coordinate this program at our school district. In the State of California there are 6.2 million students, 50% of them are title one. Which means that's 50% 3.1 million are eligible to be enrolled in the Med Account program.

Good afternoon, I'm Jennifer Alley with the California Association of Health Plans. And our members currently provide contraceptives to women, the ACA, there's no co-pay for those. And we want our enrollees to receive the medication that they need in assisting them in planning their reproductive health.

However, we do support the amendments that were discussed by my colleague. And we think those are critical in ensuring that there isn't, that the benefit is rolled out as efficiently and as economically as it could be.
And we too have had an open dialog with the sponsors. And we appreciate that, it's just unfortunate that we haven't been able to reach an agreement at this time.

And then you add in up to 175,000 undocumented students that are recently added to the Medi-Cal program. And schools are kind of becoming the one stop place for students who were providing 50,000 meals a day in my school district.

But we're also doing a lot of health care services. This bill really helps streamline the process. DHCS to a really no fault of their own is really not the best place to help coordinate all of these different work and they need to have the assistance of the CDE.

And have the other workbase group that they put together who has been really a big, big plus on helping this happen. The complexities of the school districts and education mirror the complexities in healthcare.

So you put those two together, and you've really got a tough, tough system. This bill really goes a long ways towards knitting those worlds together. And I think it'll do a great service to our students and would urge your support today.

Mr Chairman and members, Sam Paredes, representing the Gun Owners of California and the authorized to represent the Firearms Policy Coalition with regards to this issue. Now we've heard one presentation about these ghost guns. We need to understand it in the proper context.

This is something that has occurred since the creation of the country. People under federal law and under California State law have had the right and the ability to manufacture their own guns for their own purposes. As long as they don't sell them to anybody, they can do that and it is perfectly legal.

The only time anything illegal happens is when they use them in the commission of a crime. Now if they are a prohibited person, then they cannot do that. They cannot build their own guns, so they have already committed a crime. So that just needs to be said.

The fact that so very few of these types of guns have been identified by law enforcement as a problem, as opposed to I'd challenge anybody to argue with me that there aren't hundreds of thousands, if not millions of those In America, and in California right now not being used in the commission of a crime.
People are complying with the law. Here's another thing. A criminal can get any gun they want and cut out the serial number in order to avoid identification.

Happens all the time. You talk to any law enforcement officer, DEA, they have crime guns all the time where the first thing the criminal does when they steal a gun is they cut out the serial number. They mill it out to the point to where it cannot be recovered. So they're already avoiding the privilege of this law.

Also, in the particulars of this bill, this bill calls for the use of 17 4 PH stainless steel in order to put a serial number on a gun if it's a firearm or a gun. 17 4 precipitation hardened stainless steel

is a stainless steel that was designed by aerospace, because it is a very easy stainless steel tube case. Now we are asking for a strip of this. Now, unless any of you are metallurgists, and I guarantee that there aren't any in law enforcement agencies,
they cannot tell the difference between a 440-C stainless steel strip, and a 17-4 PH or 17-2 PH piece of stainless steel.

So, in trying to get, I don't know, cute about how to require that these guns are identified, the bill is woefully problematic for law abiding gun owners to comply with. So, for these reasons, and many others that will be explained by our colleagues, we are in strong opposition.

Good morning, Chairwoman Gonzalez. Thank you, Committee Members, Pala Band of Mission Indians, Robert Smith, Tribal Chairman. We'd like to move this bill forward. Thank you Mr. Chairman, good morning. A couple comments to make and questions. First, I was pleased to see the $35 million appropriated to the California State Universities with focus on 2 and 4 year graduation rates.

As we all know, this wonderful University system does such great work in accessibility and affordability and quality. But in the area of student success, four year completion, it's unfortunately very, very low. And I'm pleased to see us and the administration joined together to enhance the budget in this fashion. My question is what are our expectations in regard to how the money will be used. Is there anything that's been put forward to clarify that $35 million and how it can be put to this good important use.

The worry is that certainly there's a good argument to be made that we have under invested in the CSU over many years now. And that there are many things that the institution needs to do better. And they are undertaking a lot of different initiatives to try to do that. Whether its hiring more full time faculty or you could even argue pay rises is a way to attract quality faculty or retain quality faculty could be connected to, a student retention or student success or student graduation effort.
So I do think that. And that's a challenge because I think that there are many members of this panel that would like to see us supplementing the state universities even more than what's here.

In fact I think this is significantly under-budgeted to what they have asked us of in the course of the budget hearings this spring. And so it is going to be a challenge given that it is an under invested system to look specifically in this area of graduation initiative and identify why this fits. And that we should expect that that is going to be an allocation that's just going to hit that sweet spot to make it so much better.

So another question is that we, is the allocation that we are making to the state universities unallocated to the extent that when the trustees put forward their budget to us, they had broken it down in terms of where they thought these additional monies that they had requested would be spent. My first part of my question is the allocation side of it.

And the second part of the question that they have recently negotiated new faculty salary agreements. Faculty salary agreements that are going to put pressure on the general fund. I'm not clear how that's being paid for. And so is there anything in this budget that helps in that circumstance, so those are two part questions.

Okay, well I think that's a big challenge for them. Especially since they still haven't got back to where they were five or six years ago, in terms of state funding. And I appreciate what a challenge that's going to be given inflationary demands, and salary increases, and all the rest. One final clarification, and I know there's been new practice in how we fund capital outlay at the state universities. Is that a whole different trailer bill, not spoken to here in this one? Is that correct?

Okay. So then maybe for its absence I'll make one brief comment, Mr. Chairman, which is that this change in how we find capital outlay is a very unfortunate change that the Legislature and administration made. It basically says that, given the significant capital allied needs of the State Universities, that they now have to use their existing operating budget to pay for any new debt obligation that they want to undertake to restore or rebuild these vast array of facilities that have been created by the taxpayers.

All of us, for decades in the building of that institution and so, they have to now make a choice to borrow themselves. And to pay for it out of their operating versus the old way that had been in place for decades, which is that the University would come to us with the capital needs a new library, a science building that's breaking down and we would make it a choice to fund it or not. And the whole general fund would have the under obligation and that now is changed now.

So, we are not seeing those capital needs here, because now they have to take it out of everything else that we provide to them. And that's it, that's I think very unfortunate. So in it's absence my comment is now made. I would hope that we would at some point have an opportunity to revisit that, because it means that now we're going to put on the students. And the University, the infrastructure that the taxpayers of California in their wisdom have provided for more than 50 years.
That is deteriorating and that should be an obligation that we all undertake. Not just the students; their families and the institution themselves.

Mr Chairman. Just to share some thoughts on the points that Senator Pavley's made. I know that's the narrative that's discussed and certainly in many cases, it's true in terms of obligations on kids. But here's a factoid for you.

Last fall, only 13% of the students at the CSU were taking less than 12 units. Okay, only 13%, 87% were taking 12 units or more and about 35% were taking 15 units or more. On track to graduate in four years.

So, there's a narrative about the CSU and part of it is true about the diversity of kids and the different challenges that they face. But we have kids going to our universities that do want to get through. Hundreds of thousands of them and they're not able to get through. They are not able to get their classes, they're redirected in a way.

So yes, I recognize the thoughtful comments from the Senator from Ventura. And it is true that it does apply, but for many, many more it doesn't and we need to find a way to find the pathway to success for them.
Mr. Chair and members Michael Pimentel here on behalf of Santa Monica's Big Blue Bus, Santa Cruz Metropolitan Transit District, Solano County Transit, San Mateo County Transit District, and Caltrain.
I want to echo the comments made by Mr. Shaw and thank the Chair, Wolk, for her work in the Subcommittee as well as the Committee staff and to voice our strong support for this bill. Thank you.

and with the wonderful people engaged to try to make some good choices on how we deal with the mentally ill, and I applaud that. I was pleased to be one of the many co-sponsors to join in January to applaud this effort. At the same time, I also understand that the detailed elements of this bill,

of this proposal, were not in print until just a couple weeks ago. And so understandably, certainly, my counties have raised some worry about what exactly is in here and how it matches up and the concerns that they have.

And so I know this has been somewhat of a fast-moving train, and I'm pleased to see that there's been some accommodation with CSAC and that we're taking amendments that respond to a number of things that they have raised, so that's all very positive. these changes that I get a letter this morning that says things that are quite hostile towards this proposal. then I'd also like to understand how important is this particular trailer be brought to the floor today.

Okay, thank you for that clarification, Mr. Chair.
Any different proportion of the money?
Right, but the competitive part creates an implication that it's competitive, which means that everyone's not treated the same, right?

That's a good thing, but do you understand maybe not just my confusion but others that when you take them out of the competitive pot where you're competing, it's not a per capita or per portion distribution. That it creates an implication that you're not that those
four large counties are no longer competing for the money. They're going to get it, and everybody else is maybe not be a winner, because they may not have a proposal as good as somebody else.

Right, and that doesn't apply to my counties and I appreciate that. And I think that's why maybe they create some level of confusion about whether theyre winners and losers on this than I use that language in their letter. But I think the fact that the Chair explained that this is not going to be something that's going to be voted on today.
It will provide I think that pressure release, it's more answers and clarifications, and I appreciate that.

Members, I arise today to present SB 1005 that serves to update our status and codes to insert the word spouse and spouse, where there was formerly man and wife. Husband and wife. This protects LGBT people.

Thank you Mr. Speaker. And I too rise in memory of Verna Dauterive. I'm just sorry that none of the members here had an opportunity to meet her. She was an extraordinary woman.

She and her husband the fact that they were able to give $30 million to University of Southern California so that we could do research in interdisciplinary studies so that we could look at human condition in our community is extraordinary.

The fact that in our community many of us didn't even know they had that financial capacity. But that's how humble and great these individuals were. I met Mr. Daughtry and Ms. Verna Daughtry when I was President of the Black Alumni at USC.

And I found out early on how committed they were to not only education of minority students, but how committed they were to the African-American students that were there at USC. The building that they built, a magnificent 30 $1 million building that they built on campus, a brand new building is their,

is an edifice to what it means to succeed in America, but more important, what philanthropy is all about. And those two individuals exemplify that in our community in ways that I think we may never see again. And so I stand with my friend just west of me,

the assemblyman just west of me, to honor the Daughtry family. They both will be missed, especially Ms. Daughtry. If you ever met her, you wouldn't miss her. She was one of the sharpest dressers in Los Angeles.
And and she was a force of nature. When she entered a room, you knew she was there. I, too stand to honor her at this time, thank you.

quarters of our colleges already have a policy, moving the rest of the colleges so that we all have a consistent policy is very feasible under the timeline that is outlined by the Senate Committee. Thank you. Thank you Mr. Chair and Senators, I'd like to accept the Committee's proposed technical amendments. AB 2385 allows Los Angeles based medical marijuana dispensaries that are in compliance with Proposition D to apply for and receive a state medical marijuana license.

That bill clarifies that the state licensing authority's determination of whether an applicant is in compliance with Proposition D is based on a written or electronic notification provided by the City of Los Angeles to the licensing authority.
Yes and it's very important for me. I'm from the City of Los Angeles, worked here for 25 years, was extremely important that we do not usurp local control.
Thank you very much, Committee.

Furthermore, AB 2385 states that a subsequent enacted initiative that allows the City of Los Angeles to issue local medical cannabis licenses will supersede the exemption for local licensing in Los Angeles created by this bill.

As such, this bill does not circumvent local control. In fact, a motion to support this bill has been introduced by Los Angeles City Council Member and former Assembly Member Paul Koretz, seconded by Council President Herb Wesson.
And, will be voted on by the entire City Council in the near future. I respectfully ask for you aye vote. My witnesses aren't here right now, but I had USC Sam Rodriguez if he ever gets here.
Mr. Chair and members, Betsy Armstrong on behalf of the EMS Administrators' Association, in support.

And also that this is simply a clarification, a clarification that's consistent with the existing law. Appreciate Senator Leno's legislation in 2010, which this very touches upon here, and we believe that providing trainees this ability that this will provide greater access for timely and needed access to Mental Health Care for minors. Thank you.
Amber King with the Association of California Health Care Districts, in support.
I'm simply stating the meet to Danielle Kando-Kaiser on behalf of Electronic Frontier Foundation and Privacy Rights Clearing House in support. Thank you.
My questions are to the organizers of CalGang. So could you tell me what the proportion is as those in that database that are juveniles or adults.
Less than 2% are juveniles.
Right, okay. So you're saying 2% of your database are juveniles.
Are you prepared to talk about, then, the effect of the Wright bill in 2013 on this designation, and what that did including or not including juveniles?
Well that's based on those that are in the database, and you said that the effect of that legislation was in designating individuals that may be put in the database.
Which would be similar to what would be in effect in this proposed legislation, is that right?
Hold on, let me just ask my question now, just to be clear on this.
So do you what the effect of that law was and this designation category has been and what's happened after that law was enacted three years ago?
Okay so, what you're saying is that, under the right legislation passed in 2013,
there have been hundreds of individuals that, juveniles, that have been designated. But only a few cases that you are familiar with, where that's resulted in appeal of that designation.
Eliminate. When, as it relates to juveniles at least, you've indicated that there's been, seems like, very little effect.
I appreciate that and I don't disagree with that view of minors.

And what we hope to accomplish with any kind of rehabilitative or conversation about where bad activities may lead to worse activities. But going back to my question, which is that there is an assertion that this legislation would eliminate, that's the word that's used in the letter from the Sonoma County Sheriff's Office, this tool eliminate.
That by communicating with someone who's been designated, you're going to eliminate this tool. That's where I'm struggling.
But now you're talking about different element of the bill and we can get to that in a minute.

But I'm dealing with the element that you have to notify them when they've been designated. And you feel that that's going to substantially undercut your ability here. And yet you don't see that with juveniles, so I'm trying to have you answer that question directly.

I understand that point. But you pull me over, you have reasonable suspicion, okay. You designate me now as an adult, to be on the list. Now under this legislation, you're required to notify me with that, right?
this communication erodes your ability to catch bad guys, which we all want to do.
You don't seem to be giving a defense for why this is going to create havoc in law enforcement and tracking down gang members.
Okay, but I would suggest to you that you pull somebody over and you take their information.
I think that they've got some indication that you might just be on their list for a while.
That maybe they're thinking about moving into a gray area of our society. That that's maybe not the nice, good thing to do. Some might suggest that. Let me ask you another question.
There's been some statistics offered up about race, and they're pretty stunning. I wanted to give you the opportunity to address that.
In terms of what that might suggest to you about the fairness of this database.
Do you dispute them? Excuse me?
Do you dispute the numbers?
Thank you for doing that.

All right, and finally, let me address a question that typically would be looked at at our fiscal Committee. But, there's an assertion that there's a big cost factor in relationship to this bill. When you put somebody in the database, do you have an address affiliated with that individual on the database?
Or that's not always the case? I'm sorry, what was? An address, a location where they live.
But would you say in the database that you have, what percentage of them do you have addresses for?
But you indicated, as it related to juveniles, there were very few of those appeals.
Thank you Mister Chair, before the close, I didn't get a-
All right, before the close, I didn't get a chance to follow up and I want to appreciate the opportunity.

I want to thank the Assembly woman for her thoughtful proposal that's before us. And for me, and I know for all of us, this is a challenge of balancing a lot of different issues. We certainly want our communities to be safe, and want people who engage in inappropriate gang behavior to be identified and prosecuted.

And I think that part of the element of this bill that we haven't really spent much time talking about is this three years, where they get bumped off after three years. And maybe because of time, we don't have the chance to pursue that further, but I think, because of how the opposition has presented their view,

I think it may be a shortchange, that conversation, which may be valuable still to have. But I don't see, I think this bill does try to strive for that balance, and I don't think that designating someone and letting them know is necessarily going to impede law enforcement and their ability to keep our community safe, and they have a tough job to do.

And for those reasons, I'm going to support the bill today. I do hope that further conversations can take place about this issue, it's three years, right? Or should it be shorter or longer, I don't think we gave the time it needed today, but I hope you'll continue to consider that.

Thank you Mr. Chair and members. Dawn Koepke with McHugh, Koepke and Associates, on behalf of Crime Victims United of California, in very strong support. which really bring home the fact that these young minors are impressionable. They're already struggling with relationships, feelings, friendships.
