work to elevate the accountability for those situations to hopefully deter. So for these reasons, we're very strongly supportive and really urge your aye vote, thank you.
Thank you Mr. Chair, members, Dawn Koepke on behalf of Crime Victims Unit of California.

In very stong support. We think this is a modest Modest bill that is critically important to help address the perverse incentive of fleeing the scene in these situations, and really just urge your aye vote on something we think will help address that issue.

Thank you Chair. I just wanted to address my appreciation to the leadership of the author for moving in this direction and then also for the great work of the Alameda County District Attorney's Office under Nancy O'Malley. I think It's a great work and making sure things are working well as they should and without it, I'd be happy to move the bill at the appropriate time.
Kelly Hitt on behalf of the Computing Technology Industry Association. We also echo the comments of the Internet Association and are in opposition to the bill. Thank you.

Chair, thank you. I want to commend the author for bringing this issue forward. I know simply as a consumer, the frustrations that all of us have when we can't reach somebody that's live. And that's a point of frustration certainly even more so if you're involved in a law enforcement matter, but I am struggling with this bill.

I don't have any problems with the issue of specific contact and I also do not have a problem with providing status updates, I think that's reasonable too. I think what the Internet Association has suggested in NC, has two elements to it. One is the status and one is this direct point of contact, and it's frustrating for me, because it seems like this has gotta be a place where we can find some common ground, where you achieve the admiral goals that you've set out, and yet you try find some level of accommodation. And that's what I'm struggling with as well. I don't know if you feel, Assemblywoman, whether that the issues and see it can be divided that the status update is something that seems reasonable to me. But the ability of law enforcement to have the potential, because there's so many. I mean, unless there's a dispute about how many requests that there have been annually are submitted, that certainly any information that in the analysis it talks about in some cases hundreds of thousands in the course of a year.

And I don't know whether the factual basis of that is or not, but it just seems that we're trying to find some balance here that's manageable, because I think your goals are very, very good. And I'm just wondering if there's the potential to divide, see in terms of what's in or what's not, or whether that would pull off the opposition or not that's expressed today.

I didn't have the benefit of participating in your hearing that you've engaged in, I'm sure that's been a great wealth of insight and information that's directed your efforts here. I don't know if it's helpful to identify the bad. I mean it'll be sad to have a couple bad apples now effect the entire industry in terms of measures like this and I don't see it in the record at least, the examples that might be insightful and helpful and I appreciate why that may-

But isn't there a way to, with technology, I mean, I can go up to the Secretary of States' website now and see who has unprocessed ballots, there's a status report everyday with every 58 counties, so electronically it's there for me to understand. I mean, isn't there ways to provide most of what you want without necessarily contacting that someone individually? If you require them to post under, whatever, confidentiality, or status, or how you identify the case in some way that no one could know, that allows the service providers to give a robust understanding of where things stand, even if it doesn't mean you get to have that same person on the phone every day.
Look it, I want you to be able to do your job, I want you to be successful in legally acquiring information, right?

Right, that's the contact issue, I don't have any problems with that. Right, the contact name, a contact, it's really about the status update, which I also don't have a problem with. But it's the second part of C, and a direct means of communicating with the individual, or group of individuals responsible for processing.
That's an e mail, does the opposition, does that address any of their issues if it said email instead of contact?

When you spoke with me, that's what you raised, but, does email, if it was specific to email, given that's how you typically communicate, and given that that would allow greater control of the information that you provide, would that satisfy you?

Thank you very much. We'll take a lot of your time. It's a simple little bill that we think is adds an extra deterrent against human trafficking. This AB 2147 simply allows cities and counties to be able to impound somebody's vehicle who is in the act of buying sexual favors.

Good afternoon Mr. Chair and members. Mr. Chair, Ignacio Hernandez on behalf of the California Attorneys for Criminal Justice Statewide Association. Criminal Defense Attorneys, we are opposed to the bill. Couple of things, I think it goes without saying, but we have the utmost respect for the author and I think also for the objective of the bill, to reduce sex trafficking and sex crimes is a laudable goal.

Those are the types of exemptions, other than that it is a clear violation of the constitution and then unfortunately the way this bill is drafted it does not articulate or recognize or embrace any of the exceptions. So, it would be blew per se violation to impound based upon the statute now to a little bit of background.

Such that anyone involved in this type of activity, or allegedly involved in this type of activity is contributing to a nuisance and it is the local government that is in that position to determine where that nuisance may exist or not exist and therefore, if someone is arrested for those crimes in those identified neighborhoods.

It is considered a nuisance or it is also constitutional. Simply, this doesn't fly. The 9th Circuit was very clear. I've actually used the 9th Circuit decision while I was in court when I used to represent folks a few years back and I've had searches thrown out specifically for that reason.

I will, and I'll let an attorney speak to an attorney. Thank you, but I will say that we believe, you cannot invoke this unless someone's been convicted in the last three years. So, this is somebody who is habitual purchaser of sex on the streets and we also believe that we have put in due process into the bill because if is the only car or it's their own family who needs that car.

There's also provision for due process if it's the only car in the family or if the wife needs to use it to get to work, that they can go and say is in a hardship and then they'll be able to receive the car back in impound through the judge.
The one that was used in the Commission of the crime.

Yeah, just I think it was referenced that the opposition letters referenced the due process proceedings. That is obviously post the seizure. Our position is that the seizure itself, the legal term of the seizure does not exclude impoundment, it includes impoundment.

So the ninth circuit is set, you just cannot do it preconviction now. Somebody may have a prior. But my reading of this bill does not necessarily require that it's some sort of probation condition of the prior offence, in fact the probation may have already been terminated.

If probation wasn't terminated then for that offence that could be a probation condition, but if probation is then terminated then there shouldn't be a reach beyond that original offense to then allow for law enforcement to seize the vehicle.

We simply cannot seize a vehicle because we don't like the offense that someone's been arrested for. It just, it is what it is. And again, current law is the only argument that potentially it's a nuisance. What you heard from the other witness, I think were good descriptions of certain specific facts that may justify nuisance.

But this bill does not narrow it to those facts. Where, it's somebody was driving around the neighborhood and the only reason why they were there, what if it was in front of their house? What if it was, they were in the neighborhood for some other reason. I mean, and that's the problem with this bill.

It's not fact specific. And so because you cannot do that, then it is going to be unconstitutional. Because you cannot say that every arrest for this offense is always going to meet the criteria for the definition of the nuisance. And that's the problem with trying to use nuisance.

The local ordinance was the only way to try to get to nuisance because the local government is going to know where those areas are that these activities occur frequently, and that was the argument and why it was passed and why it was signed. Thank you.
This is a person who has repeatedly offended, purchased young women for use in their cars, in probably a neighborhood that they have been a nuisance in. That's what this bill does. Okay.
Thank you, Madam Chair. Russel Novak on behalf of the California Fire Chiefs Association and the Fire District Association of California in support of the bill. Thank you.

Madam, Chair Members, Carl London here on behalf of the Recording Industry Association of America. We thank Mister Calderon for pushing this measure forward as he mentioned, This still is a devastating crime for industry. People are surprised to learn that only in the last year and a half have digital sales eclipsed hard sales, which means hard sales are still a fundamental source of revenue for this business venture of making music.

Thank you, Madam Chair. I wanted to ask a question to Mr Slrzillo. Could I ask him to come back? Thank you, I appreciate the good work of the author to try to create some reasonable standards and I think he's done a very good job with that. But I'm also sensitive to the point that you made about circumstances can arise where you cross jurisdictions.

Certainly it would, but it would create clarity in terms of what jurisdiction with their local control and their local judgement would exercise. So if you're in Contra Costa County and Selano says no, they won't sign that universal, now you know. There's no confusion that if you are using that type of an aircraft at any kind of surveillance activity that doesn't fit the definition of emergency, etc. That you know that if you cross over, that's inadmissible.
It's just not going to work. Now, there's no guesswork involved. That jurisdiction, with their local authorities, have said, no, they're not signing.

I see. I'm certainly just trying to find the way to accommodate your concerns, because I think the author is sincere in trying come up with something that's reasonable here. An area where there hasn't been any oversight or regulations, so I'm just trying to see where we could find some common ground, because I think you guys are close.
Right, okay, thank you.

Thank you, Madam Chair. The dilemma for me is, you had a bill somewhat similar to this last year, and I voted against it. And I did so because I felt that you were forcing a local jurisdiction to determine a policy in which they may have simply chosen not to have one. That was something that in their own wisdom and the sheriff's judgment and the Board of Supervisors judgement,

was simply that they didn't feel it was necessary to provide that type of guidance and that was their choice. And I felt that my concern about what your bill was that it was going to force that choice and in particular it was going to be on Alameda County. That Alameda County sheriff there did not favor that type of a formal policy, felt that the relationship and

the oversight was appropriate as it was at that time, and therefore I ended up voting against your bill. And that still is something that is clear, that you are going to require them all now to have a policy when they may not, in their own wisdom, want to have a policy. Am I reading that right?
I know that they, yeah, in the mean time. They now have-

You, I think correctly, identified the Wright bill as notifying a minor or his or her parent or guardian before designating that minor as a gang member. At designation. So it's not about what's in the database.

So what I'm having trouble with is the assertion that this is a big disaster, this legislation. That this is going to, according to the Sonoma County Sheriff's Office letter, eliminate a successful and proactive investigative tool.
I get that, that's a separate part of the bill, and we can deal with that. But I want to understand why you think this designation and
Okay, but you're not giving me an answer. I appreciate that you have other issues with the bill, but at least as relates to designation.
Fair enough, and I think that some people might suggest that notification might have the opposite effect of letting somebody know that they need to straighten up.
The pursuit of truth and justice, that's a good thing to do.
Okay, because there is an assertion here that there's a great administrative cost to this notification.
Okay, all right. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Rosa Aqeel with PolicyLink and the Alliance for Boys and Men of Color, very proud to sponsor this bill.

And this kind of bill is necessary because it helps at least in the case of a second offence Right? I'm talking about the first offense, but in the case of the second offense, have there be some kind of penalty. We run into that all the time. This industry has been notorious for doing its own self-help. We go out, investigate the cases. We bring them to law enforcement. We sit second chair in the courtroom with prosecutors.

And again and again, we find there are occasions where Treated very lightly where a person may get jail time served and that's the end of the sentence, that absolutely undermines the importance of this industry, particularly this State's economy and in this case, this Bill will at least save it. In every case in the second offense will at least get some kind of minimal fine, it barely takes away Any discretion from the courts, they still Reserve the right to impose fines, jail time, anything else they want to do and we urge your support on this. Thank you very much.

I'm so, and I appreciate that too because it may not be an emergency but it maybe something in terms of the work load that the police stations maybe engaging in. Isn't there an easier, isn't there a solution to this? Which is to simply ask all the jurisdiction, all the law enforcement jurisdiction in the State to sign some universal form, giving permission or

providing standards to some, some most like the common act when you are applying to college. Isn't there a way for you all to give them the parameters, that the bill if it was to go through and be approved and signed that you could overcome that concern pretty easily?
But the sheriff was opposed to it.
Michelle Gibbons with the County Health Executives Association, we represent local health departments throughout the state, in support.

So previously, you had to go before your county and get a special ordinance that just says that you are allowed under the law for one more deterrent against, hopefully, to people to be able to purchase sex for sale.
It already applies to people who are selling sex, we think it should apply for those who are purchasing it as well and I respectfully ask for your aye vote and we do have people here in support.

The problem is that this bill, we believe is squarely without question, unconstitutional and so, that's where we have some problems, in fact current law the way it's drafted and given some authority to look to local government to adopt an ordinance.

Was really an approach to try to avoid constitutional violations and I'll explain that in just a second. The 9th Circuit and City of Cornelius versus Miranda or Miranda versus City of Cornelius. Few years ago said very clearly and explicitly that any vehicle seizure pre-conviction at time of arrest is per se unconstitutional.

Very clear. In fact, almost the exact words from the decision. So, this would essentially allow for unconstitutional seizures of vehicles. The 9th circuit went on to say that there can be exceptions and the most relevant exception is if leaving the vehicle there. Or choosing not to impound the vehicle, results in some sort of threat to public safety.

In particular the 9th circuit articulated leaving the vehicle there blocks an intersection. It's in a red zone or perhaps the individual is on license to drive and so, then he or she would then have to drive the vehicle and it's not authorized to do so.

Current law has the trigger that local ordinance must be adopted in order for these impoundments to take place and that was something that was negotiated, I was actually involved in that bill, I want to say in 2009. Assembly Member Fuentes bill and while we still think there it's constitutional in firm.

It's not as black and white unconstitutional as this bill. The idea there was that the local government would be in a position to identify the neighborhoods or the streets that are riddled with crime.

They then, the argument would be that the impoundment is pursuant to the abatement of a nuisance as opposed to a penalty or a punishment upon the driver. We still think there's some constitutional issues with that, but it's more of a grey area than the way it is now.

I actually was involved in negotiations on that. Removing the trigger at the local ordinance, now puts the state Legislature in the position to say, no matter where it occurs, whether or it's on a street, or riddled with crime, or whether it's on a street that hasn't an arrest in 20 years.

So, I understand the intent, I think there's just no way to get over the constitutional infirmity and I think existing law at least puts it in a gray area and for those reasons, we're opposed, and definitely want to answer any questions.
They can go and say it's a hardship for us not to have the car and be able to receive it back. More than that I let are DA talk about it.
Prior conviction within the last three years.
Or would depend on the car.
It's not up to me.

So the seizure itself is what's unconstitutional on its face. The De facto violation, it's because it is preconviction, that holding it for a day, two days, however long it is, even if there's a hearing later, immediately it's a violation of the constitution.
So even if you allow it to be retrieved later on for whatever reason, in fact I believe, if I'm not mistaken, that the ninth circuit case dealt with a temporary seizure and impoundment.

It's inconvenient for law enforcement not to be able to do this, I get it but there have been cases and cases and there have been memos from law enforcement and DA's talking about, well there are restrictions on what we can do.
And I would say, this is not just an automatic impound anytime somebody drives through a neighborhood or parks in front of somebody's home.

I would respectfully ask for your aye vote for one more tool in the toolbox to try to deter the grand pit in human sexual trafficking that we have going on in this state. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
Michael Pimentel with the California Transit Association, I'll be equally brief. We encourage an aye vote, thank you.

Good afternoon. My name is Gloria Ohland, and I work for a non profit organization called Move L.A., and thank you for giving me an excuse to get out of L.A. today in our fourth day of 100 degree heat. Which I know is not a big deal to you in Sacramento, but-

Wow. Anyway, there are fires all around the city. It feels like Armageddon. It feels like we're doing something wrong. Maybe we're being punished, and I don't care if you call it climate change, or if you just think it's cyclical weather patterns, but, just please help us fund a solution for this ungodly, horrible drought, everything. And I believe that transit is a very important part of the solution because it reduces traffic, fewer idling cars, fewer impervious surfaces, better storm water absorption, less heat island effect, and that's why we're upping our game with transit in Los Angeles. I mean, the LA Times today said that voters are apparently willing to support a sales tax measure that will raise hundreds of billions of dollars for transit, polling is very high, but that's cool.

We also need to grow riders, we really need transit riders. And we believe that if we can make it so easy and so inexpensive for students to take transit that pretty soon they will start making decisions about where they live and work, based on whether there is transit nearby and they'll also start walking and biking to transit.

And that will result in land use and development patterns that will result in ever more walking and biking and transit use and it will fill empty seats on buses and trains. It will reduce parking demand around schools. It will make it possible for schools to use expensive land for educational purposes instead of parking. Help reduce the cost of an education. Increase access to opportunity. I'm almost done. Help create a more well-educated workforce. And how many public expenditures can get us that kind of a return on the investment?
Thank you, Mark Mcdonald. McGowan Group, on behalf of the Peralto Los Rios Los Angeles and San Diego Community College districts, all in support. Thanks.
Marina Wyatt with the California Housing Consortium, in support.

It's not really a question just as much as a comment. I just think we need to keep saying, every time we call the CPUC in here, we berate them for not doing everything that we've asked them to do. They tell us they don't have the capacity to do everything we've asked them to do and now, we're asking them to do something else. So I just think we should just discontinue to mention that, we keep tasking an agency with something that they tell us they can't do. We need to do something different.
Dane Hutchins with the League of California Cities, in opposition.
Dane Huntchings League of California Cities echo the comments of the chamber.
Amber King with the Association of California's Health Districts, and the Alpha fund, also associate our comments with CCWC and the Cal Chamber.
Seth Bramberger here on behalf of the California Teacher's Association, in support.

Mr. Chair and Senators, Seth Bramble here on behalf of the California Teachers Association. In CT land we call our classified stuff ESPs, Education Support Professionals. Despite the important and hard work of our ESPs, many do struggle to support their families with incomes that are often inadequate to pay for food, housing, and healthcare. This is a really important measure. We thank Assemblymember Garcia for introducing this important proposal, and urge your aye vote.

Good afternoon, Mr. Chairman and members. I'm Robert Herrell, Deputy Commissioner for Legislative Affairs for the California Department of Insurance. Despite our significant respect for the author of the bill we must respectfully oppose this measure strongly. First of all, I'd like to thank you and your Committee staff for a very thorough analysis. I know a number of the stakeholders have individually spent a lot of time with Ms. Ryan.

It's a very thorough analysis and we appreciate her efforts to try to improve this. However, if you would indulge me for a couple minutes, I'm joined by Brian Henley, the Assistant Chief Counsel. If I could speak for a couple minutes, and then he's got some additional points to make. Thank you very much.

So overall, this bill unfortunately is a faux solution in search of a problem. The mock up that is the genesis of some of the amendments that have been kind of flying around pretty quickly here is unfortunately, definitionally a bit of a muddled mess and further confuses situation. Right now, there's a bright line about what does have to be filed with the department and what does not have to be filed with the department.

That bright line was most recently revised and reconceived as of April 1 of this year. It's very clear what does have to be filed with the department and what does not. In fact Mr. Henley and others worked painstakingly to make sure that that line was very bright. So with all of two and a half months of experience under that bright line we've already seen a number of examples of these ancillary agreements filed with us that are illegal, unenforceable, and we've worked hard to fix them.
Let me let Mr. Henley answer that specific question in the brief experience under the new.

If I might Senator, I'm very glad you asked that question because despite getting on Monday, at 3:30. The official mock-up, finally from the sponsors of this bill. We have very quickly come up with a set of amendments, that among other things address your very concern. Which is to say, we also think the sunset outta be Shorter because right now,

currently, a lot of litigation out there relating to this issue. In a minute I'll get to the Shasta Linen case which the Commissioner just decided on Monday of this week. But with the Sergeant's permission if I may have this passed out to the members. This document is our proposed modifications to the mock-up, which we just got on Monday afternoon.

And towards the end of it, we include some very reporting requirements to try to get at the very question that you're asking. Because we think it is important that we have some data here. And that we have the relevant entities taking a look at what we're getting and what we're not getting. What's being set up here to a certain extent, Senator,

is that we would have to be omniscient about what we're not getting it and why we're not getting it. The definitional confusion that is being created with the mock-up in this bill. Is such that I would submit that almost any insurer can attempt to argue, you know we don't have to follow that with the department.

Based on what? Well, we think that the way that this definition interacts with that one we don't think we have to file that one. There is also a muddiness about what agreement actually does versus what it is called. You can call an agreement an ancillary agreement.

You can call it whatever you want. But, thank you sergeant, what it actually does is what should determine how it gets treated. And our reg which just went into effect two and a half months ago, did a very good job of not talking about it's titled this or it's titled that.
But here is what this ancillary agreement actually does. For example, to use the Shasta Linen Case. That's a sad example where we didn't get that agreement. Had we gotten that agreement,

we would've absolutely pointed out very quickly, there are major problems with this. It is contrary to California law, it is contrary to California public policy. So what happened? What happened is Shasta Linen has had to spend hundreds of thousands of

dollars on legal fees now because they had the temerity to stand up to this insurer a subsidiary of Berkshire Hathaway. So shame on the Oracle of Omaha for this one, to stand up to them and say enough is enough, this is not right.

We don't know, because to be honest with you, the small business test of three or four is pretty murky. Has it gotten a little bit better? It has, I would argue that when you're talking about $2.5 million or $3 million in premium, then you're starting to separate out, to begin to separate out the wheat from the chaff here.

Not 750 or now a million and I've even heard that from a number of private insurers in this room who really don't like this bill but are unwilling to say so publicly. So that gives you an idea of what's rolling around on this issue. But in Shasta Linen, they got a bait and switch.

They thought they had a deal with Applied Underwriters, which is the Berkshire Hathaway subsidiary. And then they used a sort of complicated reinsurance participation plan which was never filed with the department. Once it came to our attention, we're aware of at least 50 different lawsuits relating to that very agreement or the reinsurance participation plan.

By the way, they filed a patent for this reinsurance participation plan. And if you read the patent application pretty carefully, you can see the whole objective of the patent is to evade state regulation. Which is phenomenal in a way, when you think about it.

So, we have a patent and our invention is, we're going to avoid state insurance regulators scrutiny. This is why states like Oklahoma, Illinois, Wisconsin, Vermont and others have taken action in exactly the opposite direction. They are adding more scrutiny for these large deductible type policies, not semi-deregulating them.

Which is partly what's going on here today. That's also why the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, which is Commissioner Jones. And his fellow commissioners in the other 49 states and six territories to boot are all concerned about this enough where they've created a special task force working group.

I believe Ms. Ryan quotes a little bit of their preliminary findings in her analysis. That they're very concerned. This bill all it does among other things is it strongly encourages more of these large deductible type agreements. Which are very risky and dangerous for some types of employers.

If you want to be self ensured, then you have to go through that process file with AR etc, etc. These folks are getting none of the benefits of that self insured, and they're taking all of the risk. Under the reinsurance participation plan that was in the Shasta Linen case, what they essentially did was the insurer shifted all the burden and the risk right back onto the small,

and medium, and even large size businesses. That I would argue, is the antithesis of what insurance is supposed to be, which is assuming risk had an appropriate negotiated price. So, there are many, many concerns with this, that's why you're seeing other small business organizations oppose this bill.

Because with all due respect to the Chamber of Commerce, I think they trust their own small business organizations a little bit more. To look out for small businesses as supposed to the Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Henley might have a couple of-

Mr. Chairman, a point of order please, okay if I may. We're trying to have a thoughtful conversation here, okay. And do it in a very constructive way. I've now heard two cases where the witness has personalized, use the term, in my view, demonizing an individual almost by name.

By him referring to him personally, somehow it involved into illegal and shady operations and I don't think that's appropriate. And I also think it's healthy to characterize the motivations of anyone that's coming before us, certainly the Chamber of Commerce. So, I want to listen carefully to thoughtful testimony, but I think that we also need to be careful to conduct it in a civil way. And I would graciously ask the witnesses to try to do so.

Appreciate that very much, Senator, and I apologize if you felt like anything was personalized. I was merely pointing out that the business community is not unified on this measure. But there are a number of small business organizations that oppose this bill because they are concerned.
And many of those organizations that we have spoken with have indicated that they an extremely hard time interacting with the workers comp insurers.

I appreciate that Mr. Herell, but when you refer to Warren Buffet as somehow personally engaged in illegal conduct? I think that is not constructive or even accurate in terms of a publicly traded company. And somehow identified an individual involved and I think that's over the line.
I never, thank you Senator. I never said, it was illegal conduct. What I will say is that the judge ordered that, that agreement, that reinsurance participation plan was null and void.

Because it was not filed with the Department of Insurance. And that the Commissioner's decision and as of Monday of this week. Was to reinforce the notion that in a presidential decision that if it is not filed with the department. Especially this particular situation of Shasta Linen case that it is null and void.

Senator on that point, I would just note that we just started talking about this concept, a little bit ago. And I think we would be intrigued in pursuing that it wouldn't necessarily remove our kind of philosophical opposition. Because we do think that the line is pretty bright right now. But what you're referring to I think is what we would call sort of file-in-use situation in certain circumstances where it would be filed with us.

And at least we would be aware of all these kinds of ancillary agreements. Because the truth is that we, we feel like right now, we're not getting a lot of these that we currently legally should be receiving.
Thank you, Mr. Chairman, it's been an informative hearing for me. I had a very narrow question that I wanted to ask the representative from the Department of Insurance. Can we invite them back up?
Robert and Bryan, thank you both. My question is, is that, does anything that we're doing in this proposed bill affect the ability of an injured worker to get their health and their care?

I'll give you the very short answer then Mr. Henley, has much more experience on this. The injured workers are entitled by law to get the treatment that they need and deserved. However, what we have seen in many cases with insolvencies and the kind of litigation that some of the other witnesses testified to is, in some cases, a significant delay in that treatment beginning or continuing or finalizing.
And what we like to say is in cases like that, it's a bit of a justice delayed, is justice denied situation.
But you're saying that if I was injured and there was a dispute between my employer and the insurance company about who was paying for what or who covers what, that I wouldn't be able to get care.
Possibly, I don't want to make it sound like it's always that way, but it does-
Well, I'm going to ask you for substantiation, so go ahead and make your case and then I'll ask you to substantiate it.

Insolvency delays, meaning that as an earlier witness testified, there is coverage, there's a pool or there's a guarantee. I knew that worker, so the issue is, does an issue of insolvency create a delay?  (And the answer, Senator, is yes.) In their ability to be paid for the care, or the inability to get care? (In the ability to get paid for the care.)
Okay, so they could get care, and so, now, in the event of an insolvency, you have some case examples of where there's been delay in being paid for it.

Fair enough, now, and that's a big world out there. (If I may, Senator.) Our cases. So, I want to, now, do a follow up question. So, you're saying in the case of insolvencies, there's been a delay in being paid, not in care. May ask the question now. So, obviously, this bill is an attempt to narrow the field in which it would be applicable. Do you know of any cases that would apply to this class of companies that would be benefit from this bill, where you have a situation of insolvencies at that level?
Where was that company based?
And they have the same rules on review that we have here in California?
Well, if you had a Department of Insurance in that state that had the ability, and the right, and the obligation to review that policy, how did it ever happen?
[INAUDIBLE] what year did that occur?

So you're saying that that company, in that State of Illinois, did not have their policy reviewed. And that they became insolvent and that a worker who was injured had a delay in their ability to be repaid or paid for the care that they received.

Senator Glazer, if I might on that note Mr. Henly and I double checked after one of these assertions that were made a few moments ago. And according to the WCIRB, about 30% of the policies that were seen in California are large deductible policies, so, the notion that this is a tiny sliver of the marketplace is not borne out by the facts. Now, one can talk about where is the line and what is considered a large deductible, is it 100,000, is it 200,000, 250?
And we were double checking on that, but about 30% of the marketplace. That's a sizeable chunk, it's almost a third.
Okay, thank you both very much.

Mr Chairman, you're absolutely right. Just a little bit of context, in total fairness to the author and the sponsor. When we had our one and only stakeholder meeting on this issue in April, we raised the issue of some of these insolvencies that had occurred, Lilyco, Lumbermans, Park Avenue I think it's called, and a few others. And we indicated that we were very concerned about the potential risk for harm.

And so, in doing that, sometimes they're taking the kinds of risks without realizing it, that shifts the risk and the burden back on to them. That they may not realize and I don't know with Mr. [UNKNOWN].

We have seen, and again noting that we don't think that we're seeing nearly all of the ancillary agreements that were supposed to legally seen, and that's not a new thing pursuant to the reg taking effect, that predates that, but we have seen ancillary agreements that impact a whole host of a range of issues.

Mr. Rocksfield spoke to this a little bit, including cancellation provisions, which obviously fundamentally changes payments and extension, one way extension provisions, that at the insurers interest, they can choose to extend the policy or cancel it at a term that is Shorter than to say three year agreement that an employer may have signed.

So they can, and often unfortunately do not always, I am not sitting here saying that all ancillary agreements deal with that fundamental policy because they do not and we've never suggested that. We think we made the line clear.

Well, I was just trying to get to the heart of the matter for me at least. In that, I want to be sure that while we have this dispute about what should have the oversight of the Department of Insurance or not, that I didn't want there to be confusion, certainly unless it was my confusion, which is that somehow out of all of this, we've lost our eye on the ball, which is that we want to be sure that workers who are injured are taken care of promptly and appropriately.

So I did have some confusion in going through your answers. But it seemed to be more to me, to be honest, trying to find a defense for your overall philosophical point, rather than the heart of the matter, which i was trying to get to, which is that while we're arguing about where the department should have oversight or not, this isn't about making sure that workers are taken care of.

I think I want to caution you that if you have to case to make there, then make the case. But I don't want to misinterpret it, and I don't think we should try to stretch, to deal with a philosophical view as it relates to whether workers are being taken care of, irrespective of this legislation, okay?

This isn't about workers out of a job, okay? I don't want to confuse the issue. The issue is workers being able to get the care that they need, right? So, again, I don't like the fog. The fog of politics and of Committee hearings here. I want you to be germane to the point that I'm making.
Then defer, but if you want to make the case that this legislation is going to lead to injured workers not being taken care of, then be clear about that.
Then fair enough. Then we're done, right? Then that settles that question, right? Unless there's anything else to be clarified there?

Yes, Senator. And per the mock up, again, I think you're quoting from the bill in print, which is not what's going to be voted on today, because there's a mock up that I believe the author agreed to the amendments pursuant to that. So it's a three or four tests, the 500 is just one of those four tests, so it doesn't have to be math, right?

It's three or four. So and we do, in fairness, we do appreciate that the movement to a certain extent on that. However, we do feel like it's still, A, confusing, because this is a funky way to get there. And B, we think there is a number of other types of businesses and employers.

A roofing company for example, that because of what they do for a living has a higher incidence of workers being injured on the job. Where sometimes the traditional rules can be a little skewed or more than a little skewed. Mister Chairman and members, Robert Herrell with the department. I'm going to stand because I'll be much more brief than I was on the earlier bill today. We do currently have an oppose unless amended position on this bill. We are willing to go down the road, I think unlike almost every entity within the Department of Consumer Affairs, to having a license exam in another language.

How right now, we would just note a couple of things. One, only acupuncturists and nail technicians can take a professional exam in a language other than English. So we're willing to go down this road, and had some productive conversations with some of the supporters and the author's office.

Unfortunately, we feel like the scope of this bill probably needs to be scaled back a bit We think you want to measure things like past rates and a number of other things. And to that end we provided some detailed amendments that go back to the end of May to the author and the supporters. So we think you want to have a sunset on this.

You wanted sort of, whether you call it a pilot program or not We think you want to be able to measure how it's going. The reason in part we say that is twofold. One, when you look at some of the other states and there's a handful now, that do have the exam in Spanish. The differential and Mr. Slayton's pointed this out on the analysis.

The differential in passage rates It's kind of alarming, so that troubles us, okay? Number two, we worry about a consumer protection situation where you have an agent, who has passed the exam in Spanish, talking to presumably, a consumer and they're having that conversation in Espanol, okay? That makes perfect sense.

However, then they get to the actual, relevant, legal document and it's in English. and we worry that both the agent and maybe the consumer may have a difficult time understanding some of the provisions in terminology. Lord knows in English talking about a annuity contract it's hard for people to understand even in their native tongue.

This is a population that unfortunately in many areas has been historically prayed upon the difference in notario for example in Spanish and what they can, can't do versus notary public in English is stark in dramatic And this is a population that has been victimized time and time again by that. So those are some of the suggestions that we have.
We would be ready, willing and able to continue to talk to the author and supporters about some of those modifications. Thank you.
The official language-

If I might provide an example Mr. Chairman, in what's known as the pre-need burial business, which is, I think Mr. Desmond is quite familiar with The largest player in that market space is Assurant. Assurant assured us, no pun intended, in our meeting, that they do in fact have, on the preneed burial, English on one side and Spanish on the other. And so that doesn't seem to be a problem for that.

We think that would be appropriate. They can verify that's a true and correct copy. They're clearly doing marketing in the Latino community for this preneed insurance product. So we think for some of the insurers out there and some of the products that we're talking about, it does exist. And we think that's an appropriate consumer protection.
Otherwise, someone is looking at a contract they don't understand and the agent may not understand, fully, the implications.

Good afternoon, Mr. Chair and members. Sabina Tacker with the Consumer Attorneys of California. We have an oppose unless amended position on this bill. We have been working with Assemblymember Debabneh, and we think the bill is improved, but we still have some significant concerns, specifically too, that we think should be worked out before the bill is reported out of is lost, and Committee, which in this case will be judicial next week.

First, this bill sets out two tiers of standards for electronic documents, one lesser, one higher, and the documents are divided amongst the categories based on how sensitive they are. We think a few documents are in the wrong category and should be moved up to the proper higher category. Second, again is sunset issue, which we hope that we can continue to work on the author in judice that's already been spoken to.

We commend the author for working on this bill. I know it's an important bill, and the consumers are shifting to a preference towards electronic documents, but we need to ensure that proper protections are in place, because just because you opt-in to receive documents online. For example, I opt-in a lot doesn't mean that I would want to lose my coverage, because an email is missed or put in spam.
And so we think that when you make sure the adequate protections are in place for consumers, and we hope to continue working with the author in judic.

Good afternoon again, Mr. Chairman, for the last time. Robert Herrell with the Department, we are the sponsors of this bill. We want to thank both you, Mr. Chairman, for the time you spent discussing this issue, and your consultant for helping out here. We're trying to join the 34 other states that individually license so-called independent adjusters.
These are adjusters that have a contract with an insurance company. And with that, I'll ask respectfully for an aye vote.

We have and some specific areas we're willing to, for example, have previous experience, perhaps in other states, apply. That's one example where we're talking. We have made some memos already, we're having further conversations about that, such that you want to try to minimize any disruption.
Mister McCailey noted 40,000. We think the best estimate we have right now is somewhere in perhaps the range of 20,000 or 30,000 of these folks. We don't know. We are the outlier, unfortunately.

California, of the 35 states that licenses these independent adjusters, is the only one that does it, sort of, on this organizational basis. And we do respect That Mr. Ailey\g and his client prefers that organizational basis. But it's all the other states that license them, do so on an individual basis.

As this trade off for individual licensing, and then we would increase reciprocity with other states, that helps ease some of the issues as well, Mister Chairman. Yeah, many of them may not have to take the exam because of their previous experience, for example, but the other aspects of this that are quite important that the author noted in his open is things like a background check and fingerprinting.

We agree. Tread lightly there. Absolutely, we agree. And for example, with the 375,000, what I'm going to refer to as garden variety agents and brokers, the Vice Chair, I believe, is one of them that we take very seriously. Garden variety, yes. We take very seriously.

Perfect. Good afternoon. Thank you. Here in this bill today, AB 38, at it's heart is about improving access to mental health services for young children encountering early psychosis. And as you may know psychotic break for anybody but especially for a child is one of the most hard to treat and most expensive diagnosis somebody can have.

In kind of looking at how we do that, the reality becomes much more difficult than the ideal or the idea. So, we really looked at what was it that we could do. And so we're looking around. There are some wrap around programs. So, there's one in Sacramento called EDAPT Program, works between the UC Davis Mind Center but contracts with Sacramento County and uses the Mental Health No, Prop 63 funds.

Hopefully show other private plans that this is an effective model to be able to treat young people specially with early psychosis schizophrenia to have better life long mental health care. We are witnesses here and support.

I would just thank you for your support on this bill today. I think it's an important step as we move forward to really addressing mental health issues in the State of California. Eventually we'd like to take this statewide, but for now we're going to start with this demonstration project right here to prove that it's effective and it works. which means any of these changes may not be included in the 2016-17 Medi-Cal rate, which is always a problem for our members, when they have to absorb the cost for additional new benefits that are not in their rates. Thank you.

Good afternoon, Sharon Rapport with the Corporation for Supportive of Housing. As Assemblymember Chiu mentioned, homeless people incur disproportionate MediCal costs. They typically fall into the top 5% of those using MediCal for acute needs.

Evidence shows people who are homeless develop chronic health conditions which worsen as long as they remain homeless. While services to homeless people to get them housed, and remain stably housed, are critical, evidence shows that hospitalization is required among people are homeless, even when they're receiving a very rich array of services.

As long as they're homeless, their health conditions continue to deteriorate, housing is the solution to more effective use of our health care system due to homelessness. AB 2821 acknowledges what DHCS requested in their 1115 waiver application, which was the ability to use funding for rental subsidies to get people to achieve better health outcomes at lower cost.

In fact, this proposal is complementary to what DHCS has requested, as well as HCD, which would be the two agencies administering the program. HCD has also requested rental subsidies in the past through their suggested amendments to the No Place Like Home Initiative.
Unfortunately, that was not included in No Place Like Home, but we are hopeful that this program can provide the rental subsidies that they feel like we need to get people healthier and housed.
Data shows that Medicaid beneficiaries who moved from homelessness to housing can decrease their MediCal cost by up to 60% and save about $8,000 a year over the cost of the program.

The program would require an evaluation to determine changes in healthcare cost, and we would hope that this evaluation could lead to future funding and reinvestment in the program. We urge your aye vote to make a program, to create a program that would result in better health outcomes, better care, and lower cost.
Michelle Gibbons, with the County Health Executives Association of, California, in support.

20 of the state's 34 critical access hospitals are district hospitals. We were the sponsors of the original pilot program in 2003. Those hospitals that did employ physicians, it was very successful. Unfortunately, once the pilot program did expire, those physicians left the area and are no longer there.
So this guarantee of employment is very important for those rural areas, and we urge your aye vote.
Mandy Lee on behalf of Sutter Lakeside Hospital in support.
Michelle Gibbons, with the County Health Executives Association in support.
Michelle Gibbons with The County Health Executives Association in support.
Jennifer Alley with the California Association of Health Plans.

We've been working very closely with LHCP and the author and sponsor of this bill. And we do appreciate the work that's occurred so far. But with the January 1st implementation date, it's right in the middle of our rate year for 20. It would be right in the middle of our rate year for 2016-17.

And my members would be responsible to develop a network to ensure that transportation's available to their enrollees. However, they will not know what the reimbursement rate for that would be. And it makes it difficult to establish appropriate contracts and reimbursement levels.
For the providers that would be giving transportation to the enrollees. And hopefully continue our discussions with the author and sponsor. Thank you.

My MediCal members report that they do provide non-emergency, non-medical transportation in very limited instances. And that is not included in their reimbursement rate. This bill creates a new MediCal managed care mandate. In which our read on the bill is that all enrollees that

needed access to transportation, we would be obligated to provide it. And so, that is very different than what the current policy is. An example of the limitation on a plan that may choose to provide transportation. Would be to a MediCal beneficiary perhaps on dialysis.

Where it's critical that they get the appointment, and so the plan does cover that. But it is not included in the reimbursement rates right now. And so, it's now a cost that they eat. And so, when you create a benefit in the middle of the rate year.

Then the plan would be responsible to implement the benefit and absorb all those cost until could be included in their rate. And that's very difficult for some of our small local county plans to be able to incur those ongoing costs until they're added to the rate.

So if anything the evidence and recent history suggests that we're going the wrong direction in this bill. That we ought to be having more scrutiny on these kinds of deals. So when a workers comp insurer and an employer reaches some sort of agreement. There is this sort of magical, mystical notion being conveyed by proponents that it's this wonderful sort of negotiation with all kinds of back and forth.

I think the cold heart reality in almost all of the situations is that it's a take it or leave kind of a thing unless you're the biggest of the big of the big. And by the way, if you don't like it, don't let the door hit you on the way out. And you can go to my competitor, who has the same terms essentially.

Chairman, I'd like to give the proponents the opportunity to respond to this issue of, certainly, my concern, and I'm sure others, that if someone is injured, we want to make sure that they get the care that they need.

The author's office did indicate an interest in seeing if they could work to try to resolve that. In many cases, these are directly related to so called PEOs, which Mr. Henley can describe in much greater detail than I can.

So, yeah. Because, what then happened is, the author asked us if we would be willing to try to draft some language, despite them knowing that we oppose the bill, and we're philosophically at a different place on this threshold issue, that if we would draft some language to try to deal with the PEO issue.

We did draft some language, I think in late April or early May, thereabouts, and that language, a variation of that language, not the way we drafted it, but a variation of that language did appear in the bill. I believe it's in the June 13th set of amendments. It's one of the June 13th set of amendments.

So there has been, in fairness to the author and the sponsor on this, which obviously, we've have a philosophical problem with this, they have attempted to try to deal with that. Now, there has been a strong correlation, historically, Senators, between those kinds of operations and the insolvencies.

However, the broader concern that we have had is about the strong incentivisation that will happen presume to this bill for to more large deductible policies which raise significant risks because, as the Commissioner sort of said in his decision the other day, if it sounds too good to be true, it probably is. And I think what happened, for understandable reasons, is that many employers are very interested in reducing the premiums they pay. We get that.

So what we suggested among other things in our amendments is that the products that the agent who takes a Spanish language exam and passes it, that they can sell, be limited to those where there is an existing Spanish translation of the contract. The insurer would verify that that's a true and correct translation We believe that minimizes the situation where a consumer made not understand what they're doing.
They don't have to be.

One of the hallmarks of a psychotic disorder includes schizophrenia, mood disorders with psychotic features, and often that, by definition that individual could lose touch with reality. As you can imagine, this is incredibly hard both on the patient, the person experiencing this as well as family, especially were talking about younger children.

Book medication and therapy be can be affective at working with this, but often times are not sufficient for people engaged in a real psychotic breakdown. Programs in both the United States and Canada have show promise by really doing wrap around services. So, and I'll say that I started off this bill wanting to have a social worker in every single public health school in California, so that we could really begin addressing mental health at an earlier age.

So they have something called EDAPT, early diagnosis and preventative treatment. The MHS say, talks about this, the outcome data in this program really shows an improvement in clinical outcomes. One of the things you find in treating schizophrenia and psychotic breaks is the faster you get somebody into treatment to turn that around, the better the chances are for successful outcome for the rest of that person's life.

So the program currently treats mostly, only MediCal to its fullest extent. So MediCal pays part of it and the MHSA funds pay another part of it. They can do a full wrap around. They've got great outcome data. So what we're trying to do is encourage private insurances to offer these same kinds of treatment. And what we can't really mandate or encourage, we want to show through actual data that these programs work.

And in some cases, we simply don't ave that for people, and these are folks that, among other things, may walk into your home, and so we just want to make sure that those standards are met. So it's the combination thereof.

So this proposal is just to do a pilot program for a period of four years. UC Davis will then prepare a report for us. Deep tailing that back that if we include private insurances in that same pool, we're hoping their outcomes will be similar to the clients who are on MHSA as well as Medical. So this comes with a cost, so the extra services will come out of cost about 3 to 5,000 each client 8,000 each client for total of about a 180,000 to be able to pilot this program for period of four years.
I'm proud.

Madame President and members. Senate resolution 69 seeks to rectify the mistreatment of men, American men that served our country, but faced a terrible discrimination from our own military leaders. This resolution co-authored by three distinguished Los Angeles Senators,

Senator Hall, Senator Mitchell and Senator Huff, calls on the President of the United States to exonerate 50 African-American US naval sea men who were wrongly convicted for of mutiny more than seven years ago. After an explosion at Port Chicago in Concord, in my district that killed 320 men, most of whom were African American naval seamen.

Other African American seamen were ordered back to work loading munitions at the same location. 258 of these sailors refused the order. Because working conditions remained unsafe, the explosion had happened just a few weeks earlier. And they had not been trained to handle munitions.

After being threatened with the death penalty, 208 of these men reluctantly returned to work. However, the remaining 50 were court-martialed and sentenced to 17 years in prison. They were later discharged with honor, which shows that the US Navy acknowledged the convictions were unjust. Their convictions, however, were never rescinded and

the Port Chicago 50 would carry the mutiny charges until they died. And they all have passed away. It's hard to believe that I have to stand here today and make this plea after so many decades of delay and inaction. By exonerating these men, we can close an ugly chapter In California history, in American history.

These men and their families deserve to have their names cleared from this miscarriage of justice. They served their country faithfully and honorably. Exoneration would honor their families and act as a healing moment in the face of racism and discrimination that we continue to battle. I understand the President Obama believes he does not have the authority to legally overturn the convictions,

but he can clear their names, with an Executive Order that proclaims of these men who were unjustly convicted by a prosecution tainted by racism and an unfair justice system. With that members, I would ask you to support Sr 69.

I would thank Mrs. Senator from Berkeley, as well as my co-authors for their leadership on this issue and ask for aye vote. All debate having ceased. Is there any objection to substituting the prior unanimous roll call? Seeing and hearing none. Ayes 35, Nos 0. The resolution is adopted.

Thank you Madam President. Appreciate the support of the Senate in this effort to deal with an issue affecting our veterans. And I'm pleased today to acknowledge someone who is putting a lot of hard work on behalf of our veterans. It takes more than the work that we do here in the Senate to make things happen.

It requires people to have their voices heard, veterans stepping up into leadership to make a difference. And one of those hardworking individuals is here with us today. Her name is Lorraine Plaz. And as she kept this issue of the Chicago 50 along with her colleague, Ms.

Dixon who was not able to be here, on the radar and to bring it to the forefront right here in our chambers. She's and others were determined to ensure that time would not bury the memory of these men who suffered through the pain and injustice of this discrimination. So I'd like to present the approved resolution that we've just acted upon today to Lorraine, a distinguished veteran going back from the Vietnam conflict to Grenada.
On behalf of the veterans community, Lorraine Plaz and ask you join me in welcoming her and thanking her for all of her efforts on our behalf.
A warm welcome please. And as we know, it is never to late to correct injustice.
Okay, all right. Madam President and members. For purposes of an announcement. A friend of mine from Boston, his name is Matt Zypers, National Research Director for the Trusts for Pubic Land.
Made me aware a few weeks ago of a very grim statistic. That 22 American veterans take their own life an average of 22 times every day. 22 American veterans taking their life every day, 8,000 a year.

He joined a national campaign to raise awareness of this problem and he challenged me to take part. And what that challenge is to engage in 22 push-ups everyday for 22 days, and I've agreed to do that. And at the close of the floor session today, I'm going to start my 22 day awareness activity.

Now these efforts are going to continue with push-ups around the state with some very notable people. Not only veterans who specialize in mental health issues. But friends from the Trade Union movement and their veteran staff, with the secretary of the California Veterans' Affairs Department. Even our former pro temp mayor elect, Earl Steinberg,

who as we know is a leader on mental health issues is going to be joining me next week here in capital park. And finally, the soldiers from Camp Parks which is a Army Reserve training facility in my district are going to take part with me along this 22 day awareness effort. Our veterans have served this country with bravery and honor.

They are our heroes and they should be cherished and honored when they come home. A veterans need to know that we care. If they're having difficulties, there are people and resources that are here to help. And if one happens to be listening, and needs that help there's folks at this 1(

800) number that are there to talk with you and to help with your difficulties. It's 273-8255. I want to invite my fellow Senators to join me as we kick off this 22 day challenge here on the Senate Floor. We'll engage in 22 push ups if you can.

I know that there's some pretty buff Senators here that may be able to do many more. But for some us who are not, it might be difficult but we'll do the best that we can. So Senators who'd like to hang around after adjournment, we'll begin that activity here today and I thank you for listening. And thank you to the Senate, all that you've done to help our veterans.
They need it at times like this and we want them to know that we're there for them. So thank you.
Amber King, with the Association of California Health Care Districts, in support.
Good morning. Alex Graves of the California State University in support.

Madam Chair, Toni Trigueiro on behalf of the California Teachers Association. We support the bill. I think it furthers our fiduciary responsibility to protect those items that we've paid out of taxpayer dollars. So we appreciate your support, thank you.

We're in support. In terms of the specifics of the case, obviously the Attorney General's Office is going to be in a better position to comment on it. We didn't give legal review to the case, we gave a review to the reasonableness of the settlement.

my question revolves around this endangered species fee that we've talked about a little bit, because I'm left a little confused. On one hand it was explained that the reason we were doing this was because we had a deficiency in the fund. And that this is the place where a new fee could be established so it helps support the departments.
And what confused me about that, is that I thought these fees by law are required to be applicable to the actual work that's performed.
They are. And so that's what left me confused, is it that we weren't collecting it before, even though we had the right to collect it?
Okay, and so, is you conclusion that this new fee schedule's going to cover that $8 million deficit?

Right, so the the a the objection that I'm hearing from my county is that they don't have a problem with a fee that's tied to the work that's provided but that there hasn't been that information provided to them. In terms of the budget for this work, and how it's directly applicable to the applications that department's going to receive.

So they see this as a brand new fee, not tied to work involved, and they raise the issue of where you're basing the fee on project costs, when there could very well be projects that have high cost, but that don't have a lot of environmental impact because they're infill, or they're between freeway lanes, or things like that.
And so they're going to get a flat fee, which is being established here, without really direct applicability to the work that's involved. How would you answer that?
That's a broader, you just said that that's a broader look at your budget, not about a project. Not about the work that's directly attributable to that project application.

Okay, and Mr Chairman, I don't, maybe you can help enlighten a new member, which is our ability to provide any additional amendments to what's being proposed today. What rights or abilities do we have, if at all?

And that's something that would have been discussed by the budget sub-committee. Number four? No. Lois's okay, and the same with this Endangered Species fee, this was discussed in Subcommittee, great. Thank you very much.
Okay, so what was the deficit in the fund?

I understand Senator Nielsen's point, and I think that it's a good one, but we're, I mean, there's nothing that I can guarantee you on that, but I understand about wanting people to act in ways that don't get us into this sort of situation.

Thank you Mr Speaker and members. Today I rise and present house resolution 54, which declares June as lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender pride month. While we're not able to have our ceremony until later this year we didn't want June to go by without being able to recognize that around the world June is celebrated as Pride month.

That was the month that we began to encourage people to come out and to be who they are; we are your sisters, your mothers, your daughters, your fathers, your husbands your co-worker's, your team mates, your church members, your employees, your elected official. Indeed we represent all aspects, especially in this great State of California.

We also recognize the great progress we have made both in overturning things like DOMA, the Supreme Court, but we also recognize especially in the face of what happened this month in Orlando, that we still have a very long way to go. So I ask for the first roll to be open for co-authors and that we recognize June as LGBT Pride month in California.

The month that we recognize our collective journey towards dignity, understanding and mutual respect for all. While recognizing members that we still have a long way to go. This month, we started Pride's 47 years ago to say, enough is enough, and we shouldn't have to hide.

Thank you, Mr. Chair and members. Ignacio Hernandez on behalf of the California Attorneys for Criminal Justice. We are a statewide Association of criminal defense attorneys. We are unfortunately opposed to the measure. By way of background, I've been involved in legislation in this area for many, many years and was first hand involved in negotiation of the Pilot Project. So I'm intimately familiar with the background, why we came up with the Pilot Project, how that was agreed to. Some of the gaps in the Pilot Project and what the expectation was when the Pilot Project was initiated and what the hope was for the study.

I can tell you this, a few things; one, the bill was premature. We just read the DMV report that was issued I believe last week and there are still a number of gaps in the implementation of this. A few things to keep in mind, number one, we have a problem in the pilot counties. Less than 50% of individuals who are supposed to install IADs did not. So that is a major problem that needs to be reviewed and understand why there is this lack of compliance. It's something that we've raised back in whatever year it was when the pilot was adopted. That taking this kind of one-size-fits-all approach and removing discretion from judges was going to result in significant gaps. That Really undermine the objectives of the bill. Having judges possess full discretion to identify which individuals need IIDs or additional remedies or additional sanctions on a case by case basis is the best way to go.

50% of DUIs in California are Latino drivers. Right, somewhere between 46, 48 every year. There are unique circumstances to each individual. Some, the way other states have looked at this, is that when someone has a high BAC, then it's more likely that you need to require the interlock device. There's greater compliance, there's greater protections. This does not take that approach. We think there is a way to integrate IID into remedies we believe at case by case basis the best way to go. We think we need to look at the results of the study that was just released, we need to evaluate those, we need to come up with a comprehensive approach that we're actually looking into who are these drivers that one, are not complying with the current law and two, how do we actually stem it, let me just close by saying less than 5% of individuals who are arrested for the first time DUI will re-offend within the first year.

So to very small percentage those significant and yet we're trying to apply something 100% across the board, it just doesn't make sense. Let's look at this four county pilot results. Let's learn from it and then develop a bill that make sense then. I can address a lot of technical issues with their questions.

Thank you, Mr. Chair. Just briefly, let me state this just on a personal point. I completely understand the goals. All of our lives have been touched by DUIs in a number of ways. My family's been victims of a DUI driver. We get it, nobody wants that to happen. I've also represented folks who've committed DUIs, so I've kind of seen both sides. That being said on the questions of compliance, a couple of things to keep in mind. One is that the sliding scale that's in the bill, and we've put this in our letters for a possible amendment, the current statute needs to be clarified that all costs. That a business charges to an individual driver need to be subject to the sliding scale. I think that was the intent of the bill when it was adopted a few years back.

But what we have found is that the installation companies haven't necessarily done yet. They've limited the sliding scale to certain charges been answered and are ongoing. I think the Senator's been trying to address that. So we do appreciate that. That needs to be stronger two. I'm glad the proponents mentioned the DMV process and I have to remind you, if you're going to do this, part of the compliance issue is that we have a two track system and if you've never had a DUI, and hopefully you've never have, but if you know anyone, folks are shocked that there is a two pardon the pun, but there are two lane process on this. You go to court to deal with your DUI, but then you also to deal with DMV. Occasionally, they over lap for the most part.

Folks in the situation are trying to coordinate timing between the DMV and administrative action and the court, so that's where there's huge drop in compliance, because you may address one but not the other, or the timing may be off. I get calls all the time from attorneys that say, I got another guy who's trying to comply, but DMV went forward with a suspension and that's not going to count for the court. The court wants this timing and it's a disaster. So, if you are going to do something state wide what you need to do is frankly maybe get rid of the DMV process or limit it or somehow make it where the two processes work together, because right now it's a nightmare and that's part of the reason why you have such low compliance. The other thing, you have DMV hearings where the DMV officer is the prosecutor and the hearing officer. So, it...

Mr. Chair and members, Mel Assagai for the City of Compton and Mayor Pro Tem Janna Zurita. We want to thank the author for bringing this forward. We think it's a resolution that honors, properly honors law enforcement at its best. We urge your aye vote.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman and members. Pleased to present with you SB 1128, a bill that would eliminate the sunset date on a proven commuter benefit pilot program. This bill would authorize the continuation of the existing program which requires Bay Area employers of 50 or more employees to offer some form of commuter benefit.

According to the Joint Metropolitan Transportation Commission and the Bay Area Air Quality Management District Report, this program's been successful in reducing vehicle trips, greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution while having significant economic benefits for employees and employers. The bill enjoys bipartisan co-authors, support from both environmental and business groups, has no known opposition and has received no no votes.

For those reasons, I would respectfully ask for your aye vote. I'm joined here by two experts in this area, Tom Addison of the Bay Area Air Quality Management District and Rebecca Long of the Metropolitan Transportation Commission to answer any questions.
Michael Pimentel here on behalf of Solano Transportation Authority, Solano County County Transit, San Mateo County Transit District and CalTrain. I ask for your aye vote.
Respectfully ask for an aye vote. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Thank you, Tom. Thank you, Rebecca.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman. 1311, it's a bill relating to license plate confidentiality. A certain class of public employees, such as judges, public sector attorneys, peace officers, local elected officials, and their spouses and children have their home addresses shielded from inspection for their own protection.

This shielding of information occurs when a peace officer runs a person's license plate in a typically routine traffic stop. SB1311 will simply remove from this database any spouse or child that has been convicted of a felony. This will take away that confidentiality protection and will provide enhanced protection and safety for our peace officers. There's no known opposition. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
I'm joined by Cory Salzillo of the California State Sheriffs' Association to answer any questions.
Respectfully ask for an aye vote. Thank you.
Michael Pimentel, here on behalf of San Mateo County District CalTrain and Solano County Transit. Ask for your aye vote.

Good afternoon, Mr. Chair and members. I would like to thank you and the Committee staff for their collaborative effort with my office on this bill. AB 26 would require a state licensee to implement a training program for the licensees, agents, and employees regarding compliance with the Medical Marijuana Regulation and Safety Act and would require that an application from state licensure include a detailed description of the applicant's program.

The need for AB 26 comes from an unresolved issue following the signing of the collective bills which created MMRSA in 2015. At the time, there was not agreement on how best to handle the training of the workers who deal with ill patients, cultivate and manufacture the products for consumption.

Whether they are working directly with patients in a dispensary, cultivating on farms, or assisting in the manufacturing and processing of various products, medical cannabis workers and the general public need to know that industry employees are educated in the best possible health, safety and security standards set by the state.

Before I conclude, I want to accept the Committee's recently proposed amendments and I will continue to work with the various stakeholders to see that the language ensures parody between the labor and cannabis industry affiliates as it relates to the implementation of training program.
