I really appreciate it. Mr. Chair and members, Michael Pimentel here on behalf of the California Transit Association. We are here today regretfully in opposition of SB 882. As you saw in the analysis and as you heard Senator Hertzberg speak to briefly. The Association worked with Legislature last year, to create additional and optional tool for deterring fair evasion by minors by sponsoring SB 413.

The bill essentially authorised public transit agencies exercise administrative process for deterring fair evasion and collecting penalties from minors. Now despite interests in pursuing this path, only two transit agencies in the city have managed to set up an administrative process. They are as you heard LA Metro and SF Muni.

We are opposed to SB 882 because it takes a flawed approach to decriminalizing transit fare evasion and addressing the related issues of transit access and affordability. The bill does not, for example, examine or seek to address the real world barriers that prevent transit agencies from pursuing an administrative process. And these include the high cost of developing and maintaining the infrastructure necessary to meet the notice and hearing requirements for administrative process.

The lack of federal, state, and or local support for making a transition that doesn't require removing resources from other core functions. And frankly, the low incidence of transit fare evasion on many transit systems. The bill also doesn't acknowledge that the state's largest transit agencies have already instituted diversion programs. You heard of one of them today, LA Metro and their Metro Transit School.

San Diego similarly has a juvenile diversion program. And these are designed to limit the costs of citations to low income minors. And limited exposure to court systems. In fact, with LA Metro, they had a report in 2014 that found that the county office of probations actually files few, if any, criminal derivation citations. Despite citing for roughly 10,000. And often, these are handled between probation officers and minors and their families and resolved for $50.

Moreover, the bill doesn't acknowledge that issues of transit access and affordability are addressed largely by discount transit passes. LA Metro offers a 30 day pass for $24 and $16 for unincorporated cities like East Los Angeles, East Compton. SF Muni has free Muni passes for youth between the ages of 5 and 18.

And so we're opposed to this bill in closing. Because this bill would bar cash strapped heavily subsidized public Trans agencies from utilizing the existing cost effective tool used to recover nominal fares. We respectfully ask for your no vote.

Thank you. Mr. Chair, members, Shane Levine on behalf of the California Retailers Association. We must respectfully oppose this bill, because it discriminates against responsible retailers by eliminating the sale of tobacco at essentially all grocery, general merchandise, chain drug, convenience stores, and gas stations. According to this Committee's own analysis, close to 30,000 retailers will no longer be able to sell this product. What that really means is not just about the lack of sales any longer, but the viability and success of a lot of the small business owners in this state and that are here today and their ability to keep their doors open. What this bill will do conversely is shift sales of tobacco products to tobacco only stores.

Again, according to this Committee's zone analysis, to meet the new demand, we are anticipating 7,000 tobacco only stores to come online and that's just to start. This is problematic because according to the California Department of Public Health, in 2014 alone 18.4% of tobacco only stores sold to minors, while less than 7.5% of all over stores met the same criteria. Members we just passed this year alone a new age to purchase tobacco to 21, one of only two states that I'm aware of in the country to do that. Revenue from tobacco sales and products has dropped at all of our stores.  That being said, it's still a product we would like to sell responsibly to our adult customers. So with that I would respectfully request a no vote, thank you.

Good afternoon, Members of the Committee. I'm Jennifer Alley with the California Association Health Plan representing 48 public and private organizations that collectively provide healthcare coverage to more than 25 million Californians. CAP and its members are opposed to SB1034.

CAP member currently provide medical and applied behavior analysis services to their enrollees with autism. SB 946 of Steinburg shifted certain autism services out of the Regional Centers and required health plans to cover those services instead.

Since then, autism care has become an essential health benefit. Our members have built an extensive infrastructure network to comply with requirements of SB 946. Because this is part of a health plan fabric, we are not opposed to extending or lifting the current sunset of SB 946.

However, we are opposed to SB 1034 because of how this bill expands existing autism coverage in a manner that will increase costs on the private market and require coverage that contradicts medical literature and recommendations.

Unlike other mandates before this Committee, the premium impact on this bill is unknown. The expansions are so significant and outside normal benefit perimeters that they were unquantifiable by [UNKNOWN]. This bill would require health plans to cover services at any time or location.

Currently health plans allow contracted providers to set their own hours of care, which is provided in a clinically appropriate setting. How a broad and vagueness of any time or location standard will influence provider contracts in the cost of cost and accessibility is unknown.

What does time and location even mean? We interpret the any time or location standard as forcing health plans into schools among possibly other undefined places. This would be the first time that health plans would be statutorily required to cover services in schools.

It is unclear whether schools would want us there in the first place. Any health services received in schools are currently a special education benefit. Under this bill, the health care premium dollar will be used to supplement or replace special education, which will increase premiums.

We are also concerned that this bill may restrict a provider's ability to actively engage parents in participating in their child's care. Studies have shown that success in treating autism is dependent upon parents or guardians reinforcing behaviors Learned in ABA treatment.

While our members understand the time consuming nature of ABA treatment and are sympathetic to the commitments of working parents, we cannot remove parent participation as a part of the treatment plan. Otherwise the behavior modifications will not be successful.

In short, we oppose this bill because it is very expansive and vague. Most of these costs are unquantifiable due the vagueness of the requirements, and we believe it will be considerably expensive. A demonstration of how expensive this bill will be that the public sector, MediCal, is being excluded from the bill to avoid cost in appropriations, thus leaving the cost solely on private purchasers of healthcare coverage. For these reasons, we cannot support the expansion of autism services at this time and we are opposed to SB 1034.

Currently health plans are not required to go into school settings to provide any health treatments for example, physical therapy, occupational therapy, speech therapy and what not that's part of the free and appropriate Federal education.

My members report to me that they will go into a school setting to provide observational care to see what behavior is going on with the child. But that the treatment for that would take place outside of school.

We're looking at 48 different health plans in 1,000 different school districts that have the ability to determine who can and can't come on their campus. And so part of out concerns with pushing us into there is what happens to the health plan if we're required to provide something and the school says no, what is liability for that coverage.

Mr. Chair and Members, Ran Martin, on behalf of the AIDS Healthcare Foundation. You all know AHF is the leading provider across the globe in terms of care and treatment of people with HIV but, we're also a major player in the STD world since STD's are often a precursor to HIV.

We think they need to do more things, unfortunately the Legislature signed yesterday by the Governor included an additional $5 million, that was more than double what they had in their budget as of last year.

Thank you, Mr. Chair and members. Nick Louizos on behalf of the California Association of Health Plans. We would like to thank the author and the sponsor for the meaningful dialogue that we have had over SB 908, and while the amendments are being taken today improve the bill in certain key areas, we are unfortunately unable to remove our opposition at this time.

The health plans are not opposed to providing more information to consumers if it is meaningful, it can be implemented, and does not lead to market disruption at a time when our marketplace is still evolving. To that end, we did supply the author and the Committee with amendments that reflect our position that the notice in this bill should dovetail or run concurrently with the existing rate renewal notice if the regulators make an unreasonable determination before the open enrollment period.

In this way, the consumer can be noticed at the same time he or she receives the rate change letter at the annual open enrollment period. At that time, the consumer would be able to evaluate all of the information together and make an informed decision whether to stay with their plan or switch to a new one. We think that a one off letter might confuse someone into thinking that they must switch away from a plan that is currently meeting their needs.

While the language being offered today does include new timelines intended to help the situation, it still would require plans to send a one-off notice and comply with special enrollment requests if the regulator did not meet the timeline in the amendments. We do not believe that the requirements in the bill should activate if the determination by the regulator is made in the middle of open enrollment or after the new policy year is started which, in that case, would be particularly disruptive.

So, from a fundamental perspective, our issue is predictability. Predictability helps health plans develop the most accurate rates. Allowing people through the special enrollment option in this bill to come in and out of the market outside of existing enrollment periods makes it harder to price products accurately. So we have concerns around potential disruption there. We are happy to sit down with the author and sponsor again to continue the dialogue over this bill if it moves today. But we are opposed unless amended at this time. Thank you.

No, thank you, Assembly Member. And as the sponsor noted, there are times when the unreasonable determination does happen after open enrollment begins, and after the policy year starts. I think it's debatable whether it's due to a lack of responsiveness by one side or the other. I'm not disagreeing, necessarily, but I just don't know.

But in any case, the amendments that we put forward stated that if the regulator makes a timely determination, that we would include it in our notice. The amendments, I think, attempt to address that issue. The author amendments attempt to address that issue. That still leaves open the question that even if the health plan does comply with requests for information, and the regulators do not make the 60 day or meet the 60 day window, that the provisions of this bill, including what I would call the deterrents provisions of this bill, which is a special enrollment period, would activate.

And so, if everything was going according to timeline and going to plan, there would be no need for that deterrents provision in terms of the new special enrollment option, which we believe should be removed from the bill otherwise.

Thank you. Good afternoon Mr. Chair, Members of the Committee, Justin Oldfield, with the California Cattleman's Association, we're sponsoring the bill. First I'd just like to briefly thank the chair and also your staff for working closely with us throughout this process. I want to make just three brief points and I know that, we have a heavy bill load today, so just first as to the need of the bill.

Many of these vehicles that we're talking about are both a vehicle used on the farm, but also a personal vehicle. So while you may be out checking irrigation water, hauling a few cows, it's probably the same vehicle you're also going to use to take your family to church on Sunday, and go to the grocery store. So it's not uncommon for vehicles used in agriculture to be treated differently.

And given the fact that these same vehicles are both being used for a farm and a personal use, we do think certainly the bill is necessary. Relative to the exemption itself, the exemption is extremely narrow, it's specific to a gross combined weight rating of 26,000 pounds, between the tow vehicle and

the trailer that any point in time you exceed that, the exemption does not apply. It also is only based for people who are operating in a not-for-hire capacity, which means if you are physically being paid or compensated to haul, whether it's livestock or another product the exemption does not apply. Last and not least, the exemption is definitely enforceable.

The exemption is based on current language, and the commercial drivers license, portion of the vehicle code and all of the things in it, in terms of the criteria have been vetted since 1988 when it was passed into law. So this is a good bill and we respectfully ask for your aye vote. Thank you very much.

Good afternoon, I'm Will Barrett with the American Lung Association in California, and just wanted to thank you for taking this bill forward. We appreciate the intent and the Green sticker program, generally. We do suggest some recommendations or amendments to put a minimum of all electric vehicle range of 25 mile all electric range as eligibility for the bill.

We think that because of the wide range of ranges out their for PHEVs that this valuable incentive should be really putting to use to put the leading edge of the PHEV market in the HOV lane rather than all comers. I look forward to further discussion with you and thank you for taking the bill forward.
Move LA, Gloria Ohland, strong support.
Sharon Rapport with the Corporation for Support of Housing in Support.

Good afternoon, Sharon Rapport with the Corporation for Supportive Housing. We're one of the co-sponsors of AB 2821. Moving people from the streets to housing saves Medicaid dollars and results in improved health outcomes. For homeless people in general, study after study shows decreased Medicaid cost from moving people from homelessness to housing.

A control group study is one example, randomized control group study conducted over two years showed cost savings to Medicaid of over $8,000 per person, per year, after the cost of the housing program. The studies in general, across the country, show two consistent results, cost savings to Medicaid are significant and well above the costs of the program.

And these studies, these results come from housing and services, not just services. In fact, they show that providing intensive services alone to people who remain homeless do not result in any cost savings. In fact, costs, Medi-Cal systems and Medicaid systems in general go up. So we respectively urge your aye vote for this important measure. Thank you.

Thank you Madame Chair. I want to thank the author for her thoughtfulness and efforts on this issue. I think we're all frustrated when, just as consumers, we can't reach people that are important to us in doing our business. And let alone having that happen to law enforcement. I think that the intentions here are really good ones. I'm sorry that there's still some differences with brick and mortar. I think that they really can be worked out.
Caliph Assagai, California Public Defenders Association, I'm in opposition of 2533, as well as 1276 which was heard earlier. Thank you.
Can I ask a quick question?

I had a question to Mr. Salzillo and also to Mr. Ewart, if he could come back up. Mr. Salzillo, I'm struggling with this because you've argued that it's a burden, right, to have this requirement. Isn't it possible that you could have as a, just as a submittal on any kind of police report that involves video, an acknowledgement that this may be released by the department, and therefore three days notice is hereby given that that's a possibility. Right from the beginning, just from the submittal of a police report that includes video, isn't that something that procedurally could be done?

But the three day wait could occur in the midst of a PR8, right? I mean it could happen during that 10 day period, but what I'm saying is, why couldn't it just be as a regular course of business that if you are submitting a report that includes any kind of video, which I assume would be a common occurrence, that it would be part of the disclaimer, the waiver in some ways that they've received a notice that three days starting now, would run, and doesn't mean that anything's going to be released, but at least you've given the notice that's required by this bill.
Yes, sir.
Got it. Okay. And then to Mr. Ewart, if I may, Madam Chair?

Because they could, whether 3 days notice is given or not, the officers in those cases could have, and in fact they did, they didn't get 3 days notice. They took whatever action under existing law, to challenge the release and that procedure took months and years. But how would this bill affect those examples in any way?
Madam Chair, I have a follow up question.

I'm not sure that I heard a direct answer to how this legislation would affect that except that it is a new practice the body cameras are new, this video accessibility is a newer issue. I'm not sure I heard clearly that this is somehow going to create this enormous proliferation of officers going to court to prevent it. But, the other issue that you raised is that, and you said this is going to be a stranglehold over information, stranglehold.

And I'm, again, struggling to see how three days of potential delay, and I think that if the police station actually incorporated the fact that there may be video released right from the beginning, that there really would be no delay, that somehow that's going to procreate a stranglehold over information. So, struggling to see, I'm sympathetic to disclosure, don't get me wrong, but I'm struggling to see how the world is going to crash, because this bill would be put into effect.

Good morning, Madame Chair, members. Caliph Assagai on behalf of the California Public Defenders Association, in respectful opposition to this measure. While we understand the need to address human trafficking and to address the behavior of those directing human trafficking. We believe that this bill is over broad and would further criminalize street prostitutes, many of whom are vulnerable runaways, victims of domestic violence and substance abusers.
I think in that situation, with all due respect to the proponents discussion of service providers.

I think there are times when the person who's actually doing that is being recruited by the prostitute for her own protection and is not necessary the person who is involved in trafficking. So say there's somebody older who has a younger sibling or something that they're going to have drive them and monitor them. And so what we're looking for is this, particular type of conduct.

What we're concerned about is this particular type of conduct with people who are there assisting that are not actually part of the criminal act. They're not being prosecuted under this section. And the other thing again is if the same thing is happening with prostitutes working together in tandem to stay safe or avoid abduction or that kind of thing. Whether or not an officer not the DA, but an officer would be able to look at that conduct.
In affect an arrest because of that conduct when otherwise the person would not have been arrested.

Thank you, Madam Chair. I wanted to thank the author for bringing this bill forward. I'm pleased that through the amendments that you've taken, you've been able to work with the District Attorney of Alameda County in my district, and based on that I'm happy to support the bill today.
Good morning. Caliph Assagai, California Public Defenders Association in support.
Rosa Aqeel with the Alliance for Boys and Men of Color in strong support.

Madame Chair and members, Sam Peredes representing Gun Owners of California. A lot of the points important to this bill have already been made by my colleagues, but I had a conversation with the sheriff with regards to this bill.

And he was being questioned by a reporter, and his response was this. I ran for office committing to issue concealed weapons permits to law abiding citizens, if they passed all of the provisions of the law, and they did.

He charged the total level that the law would allow to cover the expense. He did everything he could to have volunteers and former law enforcement officers, former FBA agents to process the permits and to do everything completely above board, and he had to use some of his discretionary funds.

The sheriffs have a discretionary budget where they can allot resources to different things. Bottom line here is that some people don't want the sheriff to support that part of his responsibility. The sheriff pointed out, we fund all of our youth programs through these discretionary funds, and we aren't allowed to raise any money.

We can't charge a permit, a license, or anything to raise money to do those things. Does that mean we're going to stop doing those things? No, our commitment to the community is to do all of the things that are vital to the community, and we have the resources and the budget. And he has the responsibility, and he's answerable to the voters. For these reasons, we are in opposition to this bill, thank you.

Madam Chair and Members of the Committee, for the record, Dan Reid with National Rifle Association, also representing California Rifle and Pistol Association today. My colleagues here have really hit all the high points, so I won't reiterate them, but we're in strong opposition to this bill. This just seems like a bias towards permit holders, and an effort to price them out of the markets. Thank you.
Thank you, Madame Chair and members. Dawn Keopke on behalf of Crime Victims United of California in very strong support.

Yes, thank you Madame Chairwoman, I certainly support the bill. I think any District Attorney that conceals, destroys, withholds evidence that wrongfully prosecutes somebody is terrible. My question then to you is why aren't we holding defence attorneys to the same standard?

I can tell you that in Riverside County there was a public defender that was just fired for trying to manipulate an investigator's report on the accused. So if it's fair for the goose, it should be fair for the gander. And would the author be open to putting public defenders being held to the same standard?

Thank you Madame Chair, you know, these are difficult hearings to go through because you feel so much for those who go through these circumstances. And as I think of my year on this Committee and how many times we've dealt with issues of human trafficking, I think that on almost all of them I've been trying to do my best to show concern for those who have gone through those circumstances and to try and get their lives back together and not be re-victimized.

We have, in Alameda County, one of the nation's leading experts on human trafficking in our District Attorney Nancy O'Malley. It worries me and troubles me that she and her department are not in support of this bill. And I have not seen the amendments that were eluded to by the advocate for her department that testified a few minutes ago to know exactly her concerns with the bill. Beyond which, district attorneys have indicated in their letter.

But it concerns me that someone of her stature has not found a way to find reconciliation with the bill that's being proposed to us today, whether that it's too broad or whatever other reasons there may be. If this bill does move forward, I hope that the author will carefully consider that feedback from her because I know she has my respect, and for many in the community that cares so much for those who have been victims of human trafficking.

Thank you, Madame Chair. I think you make a number of good points on that. I'm happy to follow your lead and move the bill. I would say this though, it's a pretty new industry, everyone's looking for ways to make it safer than it already is.

I certainly have taken advantage of the ride sharing services. As I've talked to my wife and daughters, I think that this is the whole framework, that a driver comes to pick you up, and tracks you as has been explained by the witness today, makes me feel that it's one of the safest transportation alternatives that are out there today.

It doesn't mean we can't find ways to make it safer. I appreciate the author's efforts to try to move something even though it is late, but I appreciate his willingness to try to find a balance on how that's done, that we are going to continue to make progress, never going to be the answer. It's going to be done and we are done with it, no, it's going to be a continuous process,
as there is in all other aspects of our commerce, and with that I'm happy to move the bill. Okay, thank you very much.
Madam Chair and members, Shane Levine on behalf of the California Statewide Law Enforcement Association and the Fraternal Order of Police in support, thank you.

Good afternoon, Danielle Kendall Kaiser on behalf of Electronic Frontier Foundation, we are support as amended on this bill. We have works with the author's office, we thank them for their time. We urge the members to amend section 832.19 to require officers to write their reports prior to viewing body camera footage.

And to amend sections 832.19 sections 10 through 11 to require agencies to make their policies available to officers and the public. With these amendments, we will be in support of the bill, thank you.
Good afternoon, Danielle Kendall Kaiser on behalf of the Electronic Frontier Foundation. I'll echo the comments of my colleague at ACLU, we are still in opposition to this bill, thank you.

Thank you. Have you found it yet? I was going to say you can add me on too, but I think I'm in the wrong house. Right now.AB 2013, probable cause determination hearings. Public project. Madam Chair and Senators, AB 2013 responsive to the governor's veto message on AB 6. 96 from last year that suggests a pilot program be created.

Under current law, only misdemeanor defendants in custody are entitled to a ruling by a magistrate at the time of his or her arraignment to determine whether there is probable cause to support a charged offense. This bill establishes a pilot project that would, within a select group of counties, require a court to issue prompt probable cause determination hearings from out of custody defendants charged with a misdemeanor.

Such a change would save counties time and money, finally gaining the need for prosecutors and defense attorneys to prepare for trial. Including the subpoenaing of witnesses, extensive discovery of the opposing parties evidence, and defining of illegal motions. As the number of misdemeanor cases increases with the passing of Prop 47 and

with judicial resources continuing to shrink. The judiciary itself has a vested interest in screening out of custody misdemeanor cases before they become an unnecessary burden on our trial courts. As a pilot project AB 2013 is a modest step in ensuring our courts ability to identify and

disperse with baseless cases at an early age for the benefit of both the court system and the litigants. I respectfully ask for your aye vote. Here to testify on behalf of the sponsor is Mr. Chuck Denton. President of the California Public Defenders Association.
It would be in lay terms it would be a mini prelim with a much more, a much Shorter process.
Right, there's a 991 motion that's only for individuals in custody.
That would be up to the court, because- Well it- .. response... Sure.
Okay, unless the court requests it. But, typically, yes. It's supposed to be the four corners of the police report and any addendums, witness statements anything that was submitted.
Yes, and so LA isn't-

Los Angeles . Los Angeles County doesn't wish to bill in the bill, because like you were saying, because of the sheer size,the number of courthouses, the number of cases we file. The Governor, his veto message, asked for a small, I forget the other term.
Small concise- Representative number. At Los Angeles County we're generally not included in those pilot projects because of our sheer size, we're too big.

Those of us who especially who represent areas in the Central Valley where we don't have a whole lot of industry. Our small businesses are the back bones of our economy. I mean just virtually there's no argument that can be made that says they are not.
Because you know, especially if you've served on the City Council, it's going to be a constant source of code enforcement, and violations, and complaints, and just more issues.

The Senator has accurately conveyed our concerns about the statistics in this ongoing problem. But it's astonishing to us with all treatments available to control STDs that we're seeing a rise and not a reduction in STDs and that's because the state has not done enough, either statutorily or financially to get under control.

We're also beginning to see, from a federal and global standpoint, that not only are we seeing a rise in STD numbers but, we're seeing a rise in In strains of STDs that are not responding to traditional forms of treatment, and that is a very scary Proposition as we see the rise, as well as the rise in those that can't be treated.

We do know that, or are aware, that one of the concerns that I think you, Mr. Chair, raised in response to DPH's letter that you saw recently was whether this was intended to replace what DPH is doing currently.

It is not our intent to be a replacement in this vehicle for what they're doing now. It is certainly our intent to augment what they're doing. We think they are doing some good things with very little money.

We think that's a good sign, we think couple with this bill, we can make some real progress and we're happy to clarify Mr. Chair if you need clarification that this is intended as an augmentation and not a replacement. Thank you.
Danielle Kando-Kaiser on behalf of Common Sense Kids Action. We awarded this bill a star rating. We're in strong support. Thank you.

Good morning Madam Chair and members. Sabina Tacker with the Consumer Attorneys of California, in strong support. We align our comments with those of CELA. We think this is a common sense bill that ensure Californians are protected by California law.

Well, unfortunately I'm not sure it's going to be a very helpful answer, but I think there is some research, as you indicate, that children being well fed and healthy obviously affects whether they can be at school, whether they are well functioning at school.  We didn't do any particular analysis of that, so unfortunately we would just be speculating, but I think the general reasoning is sound.

Under the federal data lag so as of 2013, 14, California was 35th. It fell during the recession, from the mid 20s to the mid 30s. In 14,15 was a very strong year in California. And per people funding that year increased 14%. It outpaced what was happening in most other states.

Again, California tends to be hit more severely during recessions and to recover more quickly during recoveries. So we don't have data for the last two years, which were again, relatively good years in California. So we're probably sort of creeping back toward the middle.
Jennifer Alley with the California Association of Health Plans. We, too, have an oppose unless amended position, and I defer my comments to my colleague, thank you.
Thank you. Anyone in opposition?
Thank you. Witnesses in support, name and organization.

Mr Chairman and members, John White from the Center for Energy Efficiency Renewable Technologies. We thank the Committee for its thoughtful questions. We think that Commissioner Ferron has the potential to really help answer these questions and move the dialogue forward in the fullness of time.

We think that his experience has proven to be a help in moving the ISO towards greater sensitivity to the importance of reducing pollution in California, while at the same time, protecting markets. So, we think he's one of the finest appointees of this administration, and we look forward to his continued service. Thank you.
Thank you, thank you, Mr. White. Next witness in support.

And I hope that they could be worked out. I'm willing to support the bill today, but we just ask the author to continue her efforts to try to find a way to maybe just acknowledge that through brick and mortar there's certain circumstances that the bill would or would not apply to. I mean, I just think that you're really close, and it's my hope that you can find a way to close that difference as the bill moves forward if it does. Thank you.
Madame Chair, do you want to move the earlier bills we heardand vote on those? We heard 797 Steinorth and 1276 Irwin

It would but why would it preclude management? You could decide not to release, maybe no request has ever been submitted for 99.9%, a video that's taken no request ever comes in, but at least you'd have the sign off from the officer that the notice has been given and that the three day clock begins when the reports have been submitted.

You've said some things that are pretty strong here this morning. You've said that the threat to the safety of a community, and we're talking about this three day notice issues, that it threatens the Public Disclosure Act. It's going to take months and years of delay. This bill, how would this bill have affected the months and years of delay?
I know, but I'm dealing with the issue because you said-

The issue that we have is the clarity around what constitutes the conduct in this bill. What constitutes repeatedly speaking or communicating to an individual or individuals exercising their first amendment right to speech at a risk of being arrested super violation. If someone on a street corner talk for 5 minutes talking okay, but 30 minutes is too long.

Also what constitute assisting, if there's sociologist watching a prostitute as part of study, is that assisting? If a mother or a sister or a brother or somebody who wants to be protected by this individual is assisting them in order to protect them, does that constitute assisting? It's just too broad to directly address the issue that's really at stake here, and it will wrap up other prostitutes who are also victims into this conduct.

If an older woman is wanting to care for a younger woman and warn her of a potentially violent John, does that constitute a violation of this section? It's just too over broad to have the impact it wants, to have and it will further victimize the people it's seeks to protect. And so for that reason we are opposed.

I'm reluctant to go forward without more information. The Committee is going to move the bill forward. I just want to encourage the author to try to look into those issues more carefully, and hope that there can be some reconciliation before it gets to the floor of the Senate.
My apologies, okay, to clarify once again. The amendment that we are seeking for the author to take is that the officers are required to write their report prior to viewing the footage.
Madam Chair and members, Michael Pimentel with the California Transit Association, we support the bill, ask for your aye vote. Thank you.

Thank you. Have you found it yet? I was going to say you can add me on too, but I think I'm in the wrong house. Right now.>>AB 2013, probable cause determination hearings. Public project. Madam Chair and Senators, AB 2013 responsive to the governor's veto message on AB 6. 96 from last year that suggests a pilot program be created.

I'll talk very fast, Madam Chair. Seth Bramble here on behalf of more than 325,000 members of the California Teachers Association respectfully in opposition to Assembly Bill 934. Senators, you all have a powerful story that brought you here today.

In terms of my story, I started teaching at Mckinley Elementary School in San Jose, high needs community of color, low income. And I was an activist coming out of college. And so I did not hesitate when my local union asked if it would be okay if Channel 10, the local news, came to my house to interview me.

We were in the middle of a salary dispute. It was a teacher shortage, much like we face today. And the union was asking for salary increase in order to attract quality teachers to fill some of the classrooms that were really just being filled by substitutes at that point.

Channel 10 did come by my house. They saw a first year teacher and their family. I had my wife and child in a very tiny apartment interviewed us. And we were saddled with student debt. A first year teacher and his family all over the news in San Jose may not have painted the Franklin Mckinley School District in the best light.

I was not living well, but I loved my job, I loved working with kids, guiding their learning. I was non re-elected my first year of teaching. I was told we're going to let you go, and we're not going to tell you why.

And that's not right. I had no idea whether there was some professional deficiency, where maybe I could have sought some professional development that summer. I had no idea whether I just had selected the wrong profession. But the reality in California is that educators for the first two years can be let go for any reason or for no reason.

And this proposal is seeking to extend that insecurity and that instability for a third year. I heard the author say, why wait in reference to the dismissal process? I think we can agree that when you take on some drastic change, you should give it some time to see if you've achieved the desired result. This proposal around dismissal is premature.

The Legislature recently streamlined the teacher dismissal procedure, saving time and money while preserving due process. Just last year, Assembly Bill 215 took effect, making significant changes to the teacher dismissal process, the kind of changes we haven't seen in more than 40 years.

And I really appreciate the work of staff in outlining what some of those changes looked like in your analysis today. But AB 215 created two separate processes. One for egregious cases. And one for issues like unprofessional conduct and unsatisfactory performance. It required the process be completed in seven months.

It limited the number of depositions. And if we're in a State of making constant changes to the dismissal process excuse me. Wrapping it up. We would in fact make the process worst. As my colleague mentioned, we're in a moment where we need to figure out how to attract and retain new quality teachers.

This is the wrong path. In sum, the bill destabilizes the teaching profession, especially for new teachers. This will have long-term negative impact on school communities and on our children. And I ask you to join educators of California in rejecting this proposal.

Yes, I mean, just on that mentoring piece. We did see that in the first version of the bill there was a portion about Peer Assistance and Review. That's a program that has worked very well in different areas of the state and we did suggest to the author. I mean, I would respectfully disagree with the assertion.

We haven't had any conversations at all about what would work for us. We expressed that Peer Assistance and Review, this mentoring, is something that we value. And that if we wanted to put some kind of best practices piece together that folks could draw from in the state as a good model, that would be excellent. That's been a program that's great.

But, we have come to the table every time as requested by the author. I've personally sat with the author for an hour. So, I would respectfully disagree that we're not coming to the table, or suggesting alternatives or having discussions. We've been very active. In fact, initially the first couple times that we requested meetings with the author, we didn't hear back at all.

Hello, Madame Chair, Seth Bramble here on behalf of the California Teachers Association. We support Assembly Bill 1084. Great policy, good for kids. Thank you, Assembly Member. This Bill is, as the Assembly Member mentioned, very similar to a bill we co-sponsored, Assembly Bill 787 by Assemblymember Hernandez.

It sought to prohibit a charter school from operating as a for-profit corporation. It is a little more refined, as the Assembly Member mentioned so as to meet the governor's request and his veto message for a little more specificity.

The author also mentioned audits by the state Superintendent and California State controller. I would mention also that the Attorney General also looking into some of the practices that California virtual academy which is the largest operation of K12 incorporated in the State of California.

At CAVA their classes have been rejected by the UC and CSU systems meaning their students are not eligible to apply to these schools. And the NCAA will not accept their course work. The teachers at CAVA have been fighting for change from the inside.

But some guidance today by the Legislature could help catalyze that change, not just for CAVA, but for any publicly funded school that puts profits before students' success. CTA now represents more than 5,000 charter school educators. They've come to the capital to share their stories from their classrooms. They're powerful stories.

They speak to a need for accountability and for transparency in the charter school environment. They speak of the misuses of tax dollars and I'm especially empowered by their bravery in coming forward to try and change the conditions of learning by tapping into the power of the labor movement.

Two charter school educators are here to testify, and I would ask you to listen well to their stories as you consider this policy. They're on the front lines. And, if we are serious about every child's future, we have to ensure teachers have the resources to help children succeed in school and in life. If those resources are redirected away from the classroom, students suffer. We ask for your aye vote today.

Madam Chair, Members, Rand Martin on behalf of the California Charter Schools Association. We are currently opposed, opposed to the current version of the bill and we have been having conversations with the author's office.

First thing I would like to point out is the analysis correct that one of the issues here is relative to oversight. There are some real problems with oversight of charter schools by some school districts and it's an issue that must be fixed so we appreciate the fact the chair is holding a hearing in the first week of August to address that issue.

We have, CCSA has put forward a number of proposals to fix that problem. But there is a second problem which I know this bill seeks to address and we actually agree with the objective of the author. We think that there is a model out there that is not conducive to the best services for kids.

And we think that there are fixes that can be achieved, fixes that we have shared with the Committee, that we have discussed with the author, that we think make a more surgical approach to this problem. Number one, as we advocated last year with AB 787 by Mr. Hernandez.

We need to make sure that there are not any for-profit charter schools operating in the State of California. We currently only find six among the 1230 that currently exist. But even six is too many. We would like to put a wall up around California so that no for-profits come into California. And the way to do that is to simply say that every charter school in California must be a non-profit. Period.

The second piece of this is creating a firewall between the nonprofit charter school and any for-profit vendor in which it contracts. So that there is not a De facto control of that nonprofit charter school by the for profit entity. There are lots of good reasons why for profit should play a legitimate and substantive role.

It happens in school districts. It happens in charter schools and that should be allowed to continue, but we should not have a for profit operating in reality or a sense of De facto a charter school. We hope that if this bill doesn't move forward that the author will take seriously the amendments we have proposed.

We do think that they are amendments that could possibly get a better reception. In the governor's office than this more sweeping approach in AB 1084. And we urge you not to move the bill, but if it is going to move, we need to consider these kinds of events, thank you.

And I guess I would initially just reference some of what the San Jose Mercury News was reporting regarding, again, California Virtual Academy, which was K-12 Inc's largest operation in California CAVAs Average graduation rate in 2011 was 35% and had the lowest rate of 9% at Calla Los Angeles High School.

As I said earlier, their classes had been rejected by the UC and CSU Systems, meaning their students are not eligible to apply to these schools. And additionally, the NCAA will not accept their course work. Student turnover is very excessive at those schools, there was a larger port done last year by Stanford Credo that didn't focus specifically on for profit, they focused more broadly on virtual charter schools but had some very disturbing data.

I think some of the headlines in the Washington Post said things like it's as if kids did not attend school the entire year. In other words, they were receiving funding for the entire year and they weren't making any growth at all. So again the data here is pretty stark regarding student outcomes.
Thank you. Mark McDonald, McCallum group. On behalf of the Foothill De Anza San Diego Kern South Orange County in Los Rios Community College District in support.
Ashley Walker with Mal Smith on behalf on Northern Orange County Community College District in support.

Madam Chair and Senator, Seth Bramble here on behalf of the California Teachers Association. We ask your support for AB 575 to provide teachers across California with access to up-to-date state adopted supplemental instructional materials for existing subject areas. We urge your aye vote.

Good afternoon, Lizette Everett on behalf of California 72 Community College Districts, the Community College League California, here in strong support of this measure. It focuses on ensuring that we build a college culture, that we create partnerships between K-12, more importantly with our four-year public higher education institutions. And that we focus on efforts that allow students to persist so. Urge your support. Thank you.

Good morning, Melanie Cuevas on behalf of CalCann Holdings and California Cannabis Operators League. We do have concerns about the fines for illegal advertising. We believe those fines should be increased, but we are supportive of the bill. Thank you.

Dean Hutchins with the League of California Cities. I echo my comments with my colleagues from Special Districts Association. I feel the bill is redundant, the reporting is already going to the State Controller's Office. And the duplicity of this bill with websites being placed on our homepages makes it confusing for our folks in our cities to access the information that they need. So, we oppose.

Good morning. Steve Cruz on behalf of San Mateo County Board of Supervisor Don Horsley. Supervisor Horsley [UNKNOWN] supportive of 1362 and has advocated for more oversight of the San Mateo County Mosquito and Vector Control District. As Assemblymember Gordon stated the current 21 member structure at times has proven to be Ineffective and unable to maintain to maintain proper oversight.

This was highlighted by an embezzlement case a few years back which led to a grand jury report. The grand jury report actually recommended for the agents of the districts to be dissolved and for the county to take over responsibilities. That was ultimately not pursued, but I think it highlighted some of the concerns that the county has in that regard.

So 1362 would allow the county district to make a self-sponsored change, as was stated. And would provide the mechanism where the county, and it's 21 incorporated cities, can choose to shift the makeup of the board. From the unwieldy 21 member to a smaller board. Thank you, Madame Chair and members. Bob Reeve with Reeve Government Relations on behalf of the West Kings Groundwater Basin Coalition. Just very briefly, the Sustainable Groundwater Management Act tasks local agencies with coming up with the governance model typically as a groundwater sustainability agency pursuant to that act.

This bill takes a different path. It creates a special act agency to do so. The Legislature over history has created 141 such entities in the State of California. And they're typically created at the request of local agencies and interest groups, and stake holders, because one size doesn't necessarily fit all in California, and this particular basin, substantial acreage is covered by mutual water companies, and in order to get the coverage under sigma, to cover the entire part of the sub basin this governance model was decided as the best way for the locals to be able to implement Sigma. So I'd be pleased to answer any questions the Committee may have.
Okay, anybody else speaking in support today? Anybody speaking in opposition? Mr. Gordon.

That's correct assemblymember Gordon. Under the government code 6500 fset, joint powers agencies may include a mutual water company for example. But the sustainable groundwater management act put in a different definition for a joint powers authority and it limits it to local agencies only. So the challenge here would be we couldn't have a JPA with the mutual water companies as a part of it. And in excluding them, it excludes tens of thousands of acres that otherwise wouldn't be covered.
And so we're trying desperately to comply with the law, and this is the tool that they've developed to do so.

Half of all water used in California's urban areas is used outdoors, so it's crucial that new landscapes be water efficient. The state has set minimum requirements for the water efficiency of new landscapes whenever

landscapes are installed as part of a permitted construction project. This bill ensures that new irrigated landscapes installed by homeowners will meet the same efficiency standards as new landscapes installed by home builders. I was also asked to register support for clean water action. I urge your aye vote, thank you.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. SB 880 closes the bullet button loophole in California Assault Weapons Ban by redefining assault weapons to include military style semiautomatic firearms that do not have a fixed ammunition magazine. The bill requires such weapons to be registered with the Department of Justice and prohibit the future sale, purchase, or possession of such weapons in California.

For years, gun owners have been unable to circumvent California's assault weapons laws by using a small tool to quickly eject and reload ammunition magazines. These type of firearms have no legitimate use for sport hunters or competitive shooters. They are designed only to facilitate the maximum destruction of human life.

Such weapons have been used in a number of recent gun attacks, including the recent terrorist attack in Orlando that killed 49 people and injured 52, and the San Bernardino terrorist attack that left 14 Californians dead and another 21 injured. Members, too many of our sons and daughters, too many of our brothers and sisters, too many of our mothers and fathers have fallen victim to gun violence in California. We cannot afford to delay action any longer. The time to act is now. I respectfully ask for your aye vote, thank you.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. And I want to thank everyone's comment on this very important issue. As the Chair of Public Safety, my colleagues in here that have opinions about this. Whether it's mental health, whether it's the number of suicides. I welcome any bills that address specifically the urgency of dealing with those individuals to come before the Public Safety Committee. Because I think they are appropriate.

And we should begin to have that dialogue. Even if we want to have that dialogue about the second amendment, which is not what this bill is about. If you want to have the dialogue about the second amendment, and the part that says a well regulated militia, and how we should regulate that militia.

I am perfectly welcome to hear that within the Public Safety Committee. This bill simply clarifies the original intent of a previously approved California assault weapons ban which is to prohibit detachable magazines on military style assault weapons.

But most important, most important, anyone who currently legally owns one of these fire arms will have 12 months to register with the Department of Justice and most important, keep their firearms. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
Move the call.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I rise today in support of HR 56. As Chair of Assembly Public Safety, I rise in support of this resolution, which sheds light on the pervasive problem that we have with homelessness in California. When we as a state fail to provide money for housing and we continue to cut essential funds for social services. The amount of money spent to jail people for quality of life crimes increases. The legal challenges that result from criminalizing homelessness are costly for both homeless people and for those who prosecute them. Yesterday I met with my veteran of the year, and he told me in South Los Angeles, in the heart of South Los Angeles, many of the homeless people are former veterans.

And he's doing all that he can to help them. However, he said they have some very, very unique needs that not only if money need it but we as a community need to rally behind them to help them and so colleagues, I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you, Madam President and members. AB 1665 by Assembly member Bonilla, gives Contra Costa County residents a chance to weigh in on pressing transportation needs of our county. Existing law authorizes the county to seek voter approval of transaction and use taxes to fund transportation programs and projects.

This bill simply shifts the current authority of the county to the Contra Costa Transportation Authority. This bill is good for local government efficiency and allows residents of the county to vote on a measure this November. The Citizen District Bill has broad support, passed the Assembly 77-0, no opposition that I'm aware of. I want to thank the leadership for allowing this bill, which has urgency to it, to come up today, and with that I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Mr. Chairman and members, my name is Jeffrey Berman.

My name is Jeffrey Burman. I'm a lawyer. I represent a number of the California's religious colleges and universities. The reason, or one of the reasons, that we oppose the bill, and we only had a short time to review it, and less time to review the analysis, is that the religious schools are being singled out for special treatment, in this case it's not specially good treatment, it's especially bad treatment. For example, they are the only ones being required to give a Title 9 disclosure whereas other schools may have other exemptions from other statutes from state or federal, and the are not being required to disclose that they are giving, taking those exemptions. When we read the bill last night, and the analysis, it's not clear to us as to whether this is limited to students only.

We think it is, we think it's the author's intent, and AICCU has been told that it's the author's intent that this is a student bill, and the Committee analysis says the same thing, but there is a possibility by tucking this into 1135 that somebody could argue that it is also an employment bill, which it's not, and that needs to be clarified and we're working with Senator De Lara's staff to try and clarify that. There's also language exempting, there's no language exempting the schools from the prohibition against religious discrimination, which, for example, would allow them to choose coreligionists or to enforce their religious base rules.

Those were in prior versions of the bill, but they're not in the current version of the bill, and they need to be there, otherwise you couldn't, for example, have Catholic schools say they were taking Catholic students only, or giving preference to Catholic students. With regard to housing, restrooms and married student housing, again, the religious schools are being singled out on the violation of Federal law. They are the only schools that are going to have special rules in the government code that relate to these very issues. The impact on athletics is not clear. You can't tell from 11135 whether that's also going to regulate what happens in the locker room and on the field and admission to teams.

I know that some of the schools right now are working with the NC 2A on these types of issues, trying to make sure that they don't become issues, and we don't come back here again, but the direct stakeholders need to be involved in this, and it shouldn't be swept in by mistake under 11135. There's also a CalGrants issue. Everybody has understood that this bill is not intended to impact the ability of students who get CalGrants to chose the schools that they want to go to and there was prior language carving out Cal grants and making sure it's safe and we're going to be working again with the Senator's staff to try and make sure that that's taken care of.

Because I don't think anybody wants to tell the student that you can't go to this school. You can't use the money that we're giving you to go to the school of your choice. When you look at the federal case law on this, you can only do these kinds, take these kinds of actions with respect to religious institutions if there's a compelling state interest and here, it's really anecdotal. We've got six schools or less that have taken the Title IX exemption, and some of those exemptions are decades old and have nothing to do with LGBT students at all. We've got a single letter directed to one of the schools relating to immigration, which the analysis says it was a mistake and that the letter was withdrawn.

Tom, I'll show you that later on and then, there's also some unproved allegations like the one we heard today, so it's trial by allegation. Okay, the lead targeting case, which is not addressed in the analysis, is the Lukumi Babalu case, which says that you cannot target students and we also don't think the Smith or the Bob Jones cases add anything, because there was no targeting in those cases and they need to be harmonized with the Hosanna-Tabor decision and all religious institutions to determine who their members are, in this case the students, and to shape their own faith and mission.

And I think we all find your goal laudable, Senator. I mean we're all down with that. Right? And I think. But the issue of the proportionality that you committed in the previous hearing and then we talked a lot about it now. Before you get to the floor, that's got to be worked out.

Thank you, Assemblymember Olsen, Mr. Chair and Members of the Committee, Kenneth Capon with Legislative Analysts Office. And as you heard earlier the last authorization of this program required our office to look, examine certain aspects of this program and report back to you with our findings.

And so we're here today to answer any technical questions, like the one mentioned earlier about the program. So I think what I've heard is a lot of the concern is about the relative participation rates of students.

So in other words, how frequently do students transfer relative to their share of their home communities? Our data did show that White and Asian students tended to transfer at relatively high rates. Hispanic and Latino students tended to transfer at somewhat lower rates.

We're not exactly sure why that is, it could be different levels of interest in the program. It could be different levels of awareness of the option, different abilities to get to a different district. But stepping back from that for a minute, we found that the program is about 10,000 participating students.

About 3,600 of them are White, about 3,300 are Hispanic Latino, about 2,400 are Asian. So I think it's was encouraging us to, encouraging for us to see that all three of California's largest ethnic groups are represented among program participants.

And we think that's a sign that the program appeals to students from a variety of backgrounds across the state. In terms of the other part of your question, it might help to get a little comparative perspective that most transfers take place through the inter-district transfer permit system.

And through that system a district can really reject an applicant for any reason. Common reasons might be the student isn't doing well in school, they have poor attendance, or even the district thinks they're going to be more costly to educate than other students.

The District of Choice program is different than that in that a district that opts in has to agree to accept all students up to its locally approved limit. And conduct a lottery of it's oversubscribed. We asked districts of choice to describe how they administer students.

And interviewees did indicate that they admitted all interested students as the statute requires. We found that about a third of districts had enough applications to conduct the lottery. The remaining districts were essentially accepting all students who applied.

As really checked on that, we also looked at those districts board's policies and application materials. They also seem to be consistent with the statutory requirements, so hopefully that gives you some context about our findings.

I think that's a very timely question. By way of context, we found that most districts of choice, including most of the large ones, generally don't provide transportation, either to students within their district or students who are transferring in.

Some of the smaller more ruled districts did provide transportation. I believe we only found two that were actually sending a bus or a van or a vehicle into a neighboring district. Statewide transportation isn't provided all that widely.

Only about 1-in-12 students statewide receives transportation, so it's actually relatively uncommon for a district to provide it to any kind of student. It could be a factor in explaining some of the participation patterns that we see. If it's a topic that you're interested in learning more about, we could certainly look into that in our next evaluation that's included in this bill.
Cathy Raven with the California State PTA and we are in support of this bill.
