Mr. Chair, members, Steve Carlson. I'm California Government Affairs counsel for CTIA. We are the trade Association for the wireless industry. Members from wireless carriers and the suppliers to providers and manufacturers of wireless data and products. The Association brings together a dynamic group of companies that enable consumers to lead a 21st century connected life.

I'm here to address what the industry believes is an extremely important issue and one with which we have been deeply involved since the Inception of wireless, which post-dated a bit the 911 system, but has changed it dramatically. My testimony today is intended to really focus on two major issues.

The funding as California seeks to transition it's state and local 911 systems to the next generation 911. As well as discuss the location accuracy standards for 911 calls which obviously is a very important issue and on which a lot is being done at the moment.

According for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, over 90% of households in California utilize wireless service. That's 38.7 million subscribers, and as the Chair indicated there's a significant evolution from landline to wireless. People are cutting the cord.

There's an estimated 460,000 wireless 911 calls made everyday nationally, with an estimated 70% of all 911 calls being placed from wireless devices and that's only growing. And as I indicated, it's changing the very nature as Assembly Member Lackey indicated. The introduction of call boxes was sort of a step forward, back in the day.

We now have a situation where emergency calls can be made from virtually anywhere. And we've seen so many instances where people have been saved and located in ways that would not have been the case before. 911 funding  is an extremely important issue as the chair points out, and as we have been discussing over the years,

particularly as we transition to next-generation 911 and all the benefits that that will bring. We remain committed to working with state policy makers and public safety officials to help insure that 911 service is a coordinated and collaborative operation, and believe me I believe it is here in California,

between the private and public sector to provide quality 911 at a reasonable cost. As the Legislature looks at the funds it needs for 911 services in California and the potential for 911 reform. The wireless industry urges adherence to a number of principles that we will provide to the Committee and several of which I want to talk about today. As we look at the various options and as the chair indicated as some of the things that have been discussed is it a percentage or is it a flat rate.

Do we look at other devices, and how do we work at that? We'd like the committee to consider another approach. And it may not happen right away, but perhaps one that we should look at from the long term. Again, most states have funded 911 from user fees on telecommunications service customers. But as those services evolve from traditional telecommunication services using the old PSTN public switch telephone network.

To a host of Internet protocol services. We believe the states, including California, should examine whether the existing funding mechanism is still viable. And I think there's a question about that as we've been discussing. Since emergency communications may be the quintessential public good.

The quintessential thing that people want government to do. Maybe we ought to look at it as a general fund obligation as opposed to looking at asking the users of the communications to pay the fee. Because perhaps the beneficiary of the call,

of the 911 call, might not be telecommunications user. I think a strong public policy argument exists that these services should be funded through the broad-based taxes that finance general fund expenditures. We have made these comments around the country as this issue has come up, and it's an issue that basically comes up in every state. 911 benefits all Americans in the 21st century the need for

transparent, fully functioning, fully funded, efficiently run system is critical. And we'd believe, again, a good argument can be made that that cost should be born by all citizens. Not just those who are users of telecommunication services. One of the things we could look at is a long term goal of phasing out 911 fees on communication services and using general fund revenues as I indicated.

This will likely prove to be a more stable funding mechanism than depending on fees from an industry that is totally evolving. We're moving from land line to wireless, we're moving from contract wireless to non contract wireless prepaid. And for which there was legislation to bring the prepaid customers into the system.

And then we're talking about different devices. You maybe able to access 911 or NG911 from something other than a smartphone as we move further. In recognizing that the phase-out of 911 fees is a long-term goal, and revenue needs for NG911 may be near-term, as a matter of fact,

probably front-loaded in terms of the infrastructure that's going to be needed for the PSAPs to be able to accept the data that wireless phones can already deliver, we have to remember that 911 fees are not just imposed in a vacuum. They're part of the significant overall tax and fee burden that wireless consumers pay to federal, state, and local governments.

For example, your constituents pay local utility user taxes in some jurisdictions as high as 10%. California PUC public policy program service charges and other PUC fees of nearly 8%, 7.6%, all this goes on the bottom of your wireless bill. Federal universal service fund surcharges of 79% of interstate as opposed to intrastate charges,

and then the 911 fee of 7.5%, as Chairman Rodriguez indicated. Just this year alone, the PUC increased the Lifeline fee, United Uniform Lifeline Telephone service fee, from 2.4% to 5.5% of intrastate charges.

So the fee at the bottom of your bill just went up 3%. Again, I'm not making an argument as to whether it's a good program or not, and obviously, they feel it is. The point is that we have our wireless customers, and all telecommunications customers, are paying about 20% of their bill in taxes, fees, and surcharges.

We're the 12th highest rate in the country. Not number one, as some people think we are, but 12 out of 50 is pretty high. A second principle we feel very strongly about is that taxes and fees collected from wireless consumers under the auspices of 911

deployment are collected to advance specific public policy goals, and must be solely dedicated to the advancement of 911. Wireless carriers annually collect nearly $2.5 billion of dedicated taxes throughout the country for the purpose of upgrading the technical capabilities of the almost 6,000 PSAPs that exist across the country.

In addition to the nearly $2.5 billion, wireless service providers also invest billions annually to improve those networks, 32 billion in 2015 alone. Because 911 fees are intended to specifically support the costs to establish and maintain state and local communication systems, some policymakers, unfortunately in the past,

and those of us who have been around for a while have seen this happen quite a few times. Sometimes when there's a shortfall of money, sometimes the 911 fund says hey, let's go after it. California has done that in the past, and

we just want to make sure that you folks here understand how, with a shortfall already in being able to support the 911 system. I'm not saying that's going to happen or it's happened in this budget, and it's certainly happened. But we want to make sure that as we move forward on this, that those funds be dedicated to

the purpose for which they're needed. I want to talk a little bit about 911 location accuracy. The issue of providing PSAPs with the most reliable information about the 911 caller's location remains a priority for CTIA and its members. Most people call 911 from their cellphones because it's convenient, mobile, and reliable.

Accurate location information from a cellphone is critical to responding to a 911 call in a timely and effective manner. We are working hard with our member companies and public safety professionals to ensure that innovative location technology solutions can be harnessed to deliver accurate location information for wireless 911 communications, especially indoors. Wireless 911 location information is a carefully constructed balance and

FCC-regulated process developed between wireless providers and 911 professionals through our more than 20 years of partnership. In order to meet the FCC's rules, today's wireless 911 location technologies were designed for 911 purposes before the commercial location-based services, the Uber or GPS services, that used today for smartphone apps were more widely available.

As this Committee understands, the commercial location-based services that we use on our cellphones for maps and turn-by-turn directions, among other location-specific apps, have been extremely successful and reset everybody's expectations about the potential for location information, particularly indoors. For this reason, CTIA and the wireless carriers are working with the FCC and

911 professionals to harness these new LBS technologies for wireless 911 location information. Furthermore, the FCC, just last year, adopted new rules to further tighten up wireless location accuracy and standards. In that regard, CTIA is leading industry's efforts to develop the National Emergency Address Database, NEAD,

that will securely and privately store the location information for millions of WiFi access points and Bluetooth beacons, in order to improve wireless location accuracy everywhere, especially indoors. Through the NEAD and the associated technology standards currently being worked on by industry representatives, wireless carriers will be able to deliver dispatchable location that will provide first responders with information to more quickly,

effectively, and safely respond to emergencies, dispatch location being an address. Finally, CTIA and our member companies are also eager to evaluate innovative beacon barometric pressure sensor and radio frequency identification technologies that might one day help to further enhance 911 location by, for example, delivering vertical z-axis, you have x, y, and then z in a building.

These evaluations will be conducted through an independently-administered 911 location technologies desk test bed. The test bed is scheduled to launch later this year, one in Atlanta, and one, we're happy to say, in San Francisco. In closing, we thank you for the opportunity to testify today on this very important issue. We look forward to the discussion regarding 911 transition, and we commit that we will be a party and a partner in every reasonable way, to make sure this system is as good as it can be. Thank you.

Good question. And that's the purpose of the testing facilities, both in San Francisco and Atlanta. And the idea is to test every possible technology, not just the ones we have today, but we talked a location-based systems.

And the FCC has been, I think, pretty forward looking at that, saying look at everything that's out there and let's start to try it. The goals are within certain periods of time to get to 40%, 50% dispatchable location. That means x, y, and z.

They can tell you whether you're on the sixth floor, not just the sixth floor but also in what office you're in. And then 80% by 2022. This National Emergency Alert Database will combine the use of existing Wi-Fi networks, Bluetooth beacons, and then CTIAs of the lead, gathering addresses that are associated with

all these things to have in a database, so you use all the existing technologies that are there. So, over the next five to six years, the hope is that you get to a significant percentage using the addresses and combining them with the technology to be able to do that.

I think we can do it. We're doing it now, it can be done better and when you add in all the newer technologies, some of which you may not even know about today, I think we're cautiously optimistic that over the next five or six years, we're really go have some significant improvements then.
Totally with you, and working very closely with our first responder colleagues to improve that system as much as possible.

Well, because we are a rural county. The rural counties, the vendors look at Where are the population? And we just don't have the population. However, we have people that come up from the Bay Area that have that cell phone,

that are going to go into the back country, and they're going to pick up that phone and say, I'm lost, come get me. Well, you're not at 5th and Main. And so, that is a huge issue of having the proper coverage.

We talked about that we should have that everybody should be able to pick up their phone and we should be able to answer it. I don't know if that's completely possible today. Maybe in the future it may be, but we also need to do some education to our citizens of what the limits are of their phones.

But when you talk about getting a hold of my deputies, we just need to understand that there needs to be redundancy in the system. We still have a system that is cell towers that goes to a hardline. We've had several instances across the state where vandalisms were looking for
copper wire and have disrupted the 911 system completely. So, we need to look at redundancy systems when we're looking at the 911 system.

The one thing I would say is that as technology moves forward, my good friend here, Don from Southern California, he said it perfectly. And that is that the funding source, if we put it in the general fund, it's going to get lost. We have to make sure that 911 is a secure funding source.

Jamie said it perfectly. We're very worried, when we sit in our Committee on 911, about what's going to happen in the future. Not in the future five, 10 years, what has been said. But, what's going to happen this next fiscal year?

That's a problem. And so we need to have some type of protection. So when we talk about that money source, and as technology moves forward, the vendor also has to have some burden on that. Because our PSAPs, my cell phone is going to be done probably next year.

Okay, so I go the local cellphone shop, and I get a new cellphone. Well, we're doing the same thing with our PSAPs. The technology has moved forward, who's going to pay for that? We can't ask a small County of a population of,

I'll use Alpine, of 4,000, to ask to fund that source. So, it has to be a partnership with local government, state government, and the vendor to protect this funding source so that our PSAPs are getting the proper equipment. Not only the proper, but the cutting edge equipment.

Good morning. Ryan Andersen, Legislative Analyst Office. The sergeant has passed out a handout that I'll be covering this morning just giving some really 30,000 foot view of charter schools in California, their history, and there's the oversight responsibilities that they're subject to. Turning to the first page, this is just a brief introduction of what our charter schools, state first established charter schools in 1992 as the second state to do so after only Minnesota and at that time the intent was really to experiment with a new trade-off between on the one hand autonomy, and on the other, accountability.

So charter schools are public schools that are allowed substantial autonomy from state education regulations. They are not subject to most of the state education code and in return for that, they are subject to a unique accountability system that requires them to respond mostly to the demands of their authorizers and I'll get into that more later. All charter school must meet some basic requirements that are spelled out on this first page, but as you can see these are very basic requirements. They must provide non sectarian instruction, be tuition free and in the middle interested California students up to school capacity. The second page really highlights one notable aspect.

There's charter schools in California which is that they've been growing quite significantly since they were first established just in the last 10 years. Both the number of charter schools and the number of students served by charter schools has more than doubled in the state. The proportion of K-12 enrollment that has served in charter schools has increased from about 3% in 2005, 6 to just over 9% last year. Another typical aspect of charter schools, is that they tend to be smaller than traditional public schools. Many of them are, in fact, the median charter school has an enrollment that's a little less than half of the median, non charter public school and also, they tend to be concentrated in urban areas so just the nine counties that make up the Bay Area as well as Los Angeles and San Diego counties.

Just those 11 counties count for over 60% of all charter schools in the state. Turning to page three, there are several varieties of charter schools. In particular, some charter schools, about 85% of those currently operating, are what we call start ups. These are new schools that were established specifically to operate as charter schools. A smaller share of charter schools, about 15% currently, what we call convergence, they started their life as traditional public schools but if since being converted to operate under a charter. Another important division is that most charter schools about 80% currently focused on traditional classroom based instruction, but the minority about 20% offer some form of independent study.

This might be distance learning, or home study. On page four, we have a brief overview of how charter schools are authorized. When charter schools are established through a local petition process. Specifically, charter schools must receive signatures from either 50% of the teachers that they expect to employ in their first year of operation or 50% of the parents they intend to serve in that first year. Now, once these petitions have received enough signatures they are submitted to a perspective authorizer in most cases that will be the district where the school intends to locate. The authorizer has to make a decision whether to approve or deny the petition and they can do this for five specific reasons.

Some of these reasons are technical in nature. For instance, simply the petitioners did not receive enough valid signatures or the proposed school does not meet basic state requirements for all charter schools, but we believe in many cases when charter petitions are denied, it's related to the belief on the perspective authorizes part that the charter petition and one thing to note here is the petition itself lays out a comprehensive vision for the school. The authorizer will often reject the petition if they believe that that vision represents an unsound educational program or, if they believe the petitioners are unlikely to realize the educational program.

Now, if a petition is denied by a local district, the petitioners can appeal that decision to either their county Superintendent or to the State Board of Education. In some instances specific charter schools can apply directly to their county Superintendent or to the State Board to service their authorizer. I'm turning to page five. This is just a discussion of specifically the role of charter school oversight. Most ongoing oversight of charter schools is the responsibility of the authorizer and state law does spell out some basic conditions that all authorizers must meet. Maintaining regular contact and visits with the charter school.

Ensuring that the charter school is completing all of its state reporting requirements. Monitoring the charter school's finances. For the services, charter school authorizes typically charge a fee of up to 1% of the total revenue that comes into the charter school. Now, once every five years or so, authorizers must make a decision as to whether the charter will be renewed or not. This renewal process is very similar to the petition process, which is to say that the authorizer can decide to revoke a charter for the same reasons that it might deny an initial petition. One wrinkle to that is that state law does specify some very basic minimum academic performance requirements that charters school must meet to be renewed.

However, these minimum performance requirements are based off of the state's old accountability system. This is the academic performance index, or API, which has been suspended because these reference an outdated accountability system there is some ambiguity currently as to what these requirements really mean when authorizers are making their renewal decision. Our final page is just a table that shows some of the major legislative changes that have been made regarding charter school oversight since the Charter School Act was passed in 1992. I'm not going to go through all of them, but the big takeaway here is that the legislators has periodically reviewed these oversight requirements and made adjustments to them.

In particular, the Legislature has strengthened the fiscal oversight of charter schools since their enactment. Requiring more reporting from the charters to their authorizers on an annual and even semi-annual basis and also, most recently, when the state overhauled its K12 financial and accountability systems, charter schools were included in that and they are required to submit annual local control and accountability plans, or, LCAPs. They're very similar to those that are required of all districts. Many charter schools and authorizers believe that this was a significant change to how charter schools are operated. That's it's for my initial remarks, but if you have any questions my colleague and I would be happy to answer them.

Thank you, Senator Huff. It's a question that the state has had in the past. I think it gets a little bit tricky to get to answer because many schools, including the school districts, will rely on some for-profit entity to at least to some extent. For example, a school district might buy a textbook from a for-profit company just as a charter school would, but there's also greater levels of control that might be present in a charter school, too. A for-profit company could be more involved, say, in hiring teachers, in coordinating instruction. The latest data that the state has shows that the number of charter schools that are, sort of, legally, themselves, a for-profit entity, is quite small, perhaps only a handful throughout the state.

But that doesn't include charter schools that might rely on a for-profit company to provide some of their curriculum. So really, rather than being for-profit or non-profit, we think of it more like a continuum as far as how involved a company like that would be.  You have no data that separates out performance on a for-profit versus not-for-profit?

I don't believe we have any statewide data on renewal rates. Certainly, there are some charter schools over the years that haven't been renewed, but as far as the reasons for that, unfortunately, we don't have a great sense.

Sure, so the authorizer is the main reviewer of any of these reports. There are a few reports that do end up with the state. For example, charter schools undergo an audit and that audit ends up being reported to the S Controller's office and the Department of Education. There will be some follow up if the auditors note a finding, but In general, most of the reporting, like the local control and accountability plans, and the budget updates, those are being reviewed directly by the authorizer. The state doesn't have a big role in that kind of oversight.

Beyond the reports that go directly to the state, that Ken just indicated, charter schools similar, as you suggested, to many districts rely on really specific interventions, when problems are suspected. So authorizers can request that the fiscal crisis management and assistance team, or FCMAT, come in to perform an audit when they suspect that there's a problem that's similar to the process that we go through for district's fiscal side.

It's a timely question and I think you hinted at the answer earlier. It does seem to vary around the state. The charter school law sets up this plan, actually this part of that, a change Legislature created in the early 2000s, where charter schools are expected to apply directly to the school district where they're located and the statute includes a few exceptions, I think that's been a real point of contention the past few years, about whether some of these geographic exceptions are being used appropriately and I think that's something you're likely to hear a lot more about on the some of the subsequent panels.

So the API for many years was the main way that the state sort of looked at charter school academic accountability. Moving forward, there are going to be these evaluation rubrics that the state is adopting that might take a little bit broader look, but at this point it's a real challenge. The state doesn't have a real strong system of looking at charter schools and comparing them, right now, just given the limitations with our new accountability system.

I think for the past few years, it's been about maybe 70 to 80 new charter schools per year, so a little bit less than 100. I think there were a handful of a few years where it was above that, but the state, as you know, has a rolling cap on the number of charter schools that is currently up to around 1800 so with 1200 active charter schools, the state has been well below its cap for a number of years.
Madam Chair and Senators, Seth Bramble here on behalf of more than 300,000 members of the California Teacher's Association.

At the beginning of last year, CTA did partner with CFT, with CSEA, with ACLU, with Public Advocates, with the California Labor Federation to introduce a package of bills that were focused on student access, transparency and accountability in the charter school environment. Those bills did receive support in both policy committees, and I want to thank the Senate Education Committee for

holding this important hearing today on charter school oversight in California's charter schools and also thank Senate Education staff for bringing together such a thoughtful group of panels today. I'm hoping that a lot of the information we gleaned will teally help drive next steps with respect to charter school policy. What have we been co-sponsoring, what kind of specific proposals around charter school oversight have we been working on?

There was a lot of mention today about, well I know that Senator Monning brought up what happens with expulsion of students in charter schools, and there is currently a vehicle, Senate Bill 322 by Senator Leno, which establishes what level of due process should all students at charter schools get when they're being expelled,

so that's one of the proposals that we're co-sponsoring. Additionally, we're co-sponsoring a piece about requiring districts to look internally at whether they have the capacity to do charter school oversight. We heard from CARSNet that was it 600 of the 1200 charter schools in our state are authorized by small districts, many of which don't have even 1.0 full time equivalency person doing that kind of work.

So to do an internal look about capacity questions. Also a proposal about requiring districts to do educational and fiscal impact analysis of their entire school community before approving new charter schools and firm in the public interest mention the example of what a fiscal impact report might look like with respect to Los Angeles Unified.

Two more proposals, strengthening conflict of interest laws in the face of a recent report by the Center for Popular Democracy that identifies $81 million of fraud, waste, and abuse of tax dollars in the charter school environment in California alone. And then also ensuring that charter school governance is transparent, accountable to the communities they serve, and accessible to the public.

I've said this In Committee before, but I think it's relevant to this conversation that the establishment of charter schools was not us, the public yielding control to the agencies that serve us. We did not intend charter schools to do whatever they want with the tax dollars they receive. To the contrary, we insist on staying informed and on retaining control.

There is an audit currently approved by the Joint Legislative Audit Committee to look at tax dollars, specifically at alliance public schools to make sure that those dollars are being appropriately spent on children, and not on other uses. But aside from thanking you for your focus today, I also want to give a special shout-out to Senator Mendoza who's carrying three out of those five proposals moving forward.
So we really appreciate your leadership in the area of charter school oversight in the State of California and there is an immediate need to improve policy in this area. Thank you

Madame Chair and members, Rand Martin on behalf of the California Charter Schools Association Advocacy, and I'm sure you know I wouldn't miss this chance to testify before you one more time. Last word. So I just want to put a button on a handful of issues that have come up, some in questions from Senators, some that have come up in some of the testimony. One of the other early questions this morning was how many for profits and how many nonprofits. We actually do know that number. There are 6 for profits in the State of California out of the 1,238 charter schools. Most of the bulk of those are actually what we refer to as autonomous or independent charter schools that are nonprofits that are organically created in the community.

Some of them are also charter schools that are run by the school district or the County Office of Education and a handful of those are also nonprofits, but there are also district schools. So we're talking about 6 for profits, but it is an issue that CCSA Cares very much about. We're working with Ms. Bonilla as a speak on bill that would deal with that and we hope that we're going to, excuse me, find resolution on that issue before the Legislator adjourns this year. We are very committed to the whole concept of innovation and charter schools being laboratories of innovation. It's a two sided coin though, there are efforts by some charter schools to disseminate that information and to share best practices, but we also need school districts that are receptive to that information.

And we need to find a better way to meet both sides of that coin as we go forward and in fact, we've been texting during this hearing among ourselves and want to look at that issue a little bit more during the fall and see if there are some other things that we can suggest to this Committee in the future. On the issue of transparency and conflict of interest, there is a bill pending as Mr. Bramble indicated. We support Public Records Act applying to charter schools, we support the Brown Act applying to charter schools. We support the Political Reform Act applying to charter schools.

We think that if a bill moves forward with those three things in it, it will pass this Legislature and we can do everything we can to convince the Governor to sign it, and have that issue dealt with once and for all. We encourage all the parties to participate in that and finally, I just want to respond quickly to the ACLU report that was mentioned, fortunately ACLU and Public Advocates came to us before it was released and we have talked about it all the way up to our CEO level and we appreciate some of the findings, we are very concerned about academic exclusions, which only accounted for about 2% of all of the cases that they identified in their report.

We do dispute using terms such as interviews and auditions at a performing arts academy as exclusionary. So we don't think that is as big a problem from that standpoint as ACLU does, but we are very committed to working with them and with CDE to make sure that our schools that are definitely violating the law relative to academic exclusion are educated about how they need to deal with that and make some policy changes. So lots of things to do. Senator, we'll miss having you participate in these in the future. I personally will come and ask your opinion even though you're no longer in the Legislature. So we'll keep this dialog going next year.
Without objection. Senator Glazer. Senator Glazer?

Thank you, Madam Speaker. I would like to introduce the 2016 Improve Your Tomorrow, right here, Improve Your Tomorrow summer capital interns who are seated in the gallery. Improve Your Tomorrow, otherwise known as IYT is a nonprofit college preparatory program for young men of color in Sacramento.

The program purpose is simple, to get young men of color to and through college. As of September 2016, IYT will serve over 400 young men in six schools across Sacramento. All IYT students participate in weekly study halls, monthly institutes, college visits, and community service events, receive college advising, and are assigned a mentor.

92% of these students have been accepted into a four year University. The IYT Capital Summer Internship Programs provides a unique opportunity for young men to spend eight weeks learning about state government, policy management, and advocacy.

During the internship, these young men were challenged to develop fundamental communication, analytical, professional, and advocacy skills. In addition, interns who participate in weekly educational seminars, trainings, brown bags, career exploration trips, and to complete a policy research project during summer recess.

I'm also proud to say that this young man right here who's my legislative aid is the founder of this program, which has 400 participants. He's a new father, he works everyday, but he also runs a multi-hundred $100,000 operation here in Sacramento. Ladies and gentlemen, IYT and their extraordinary men, could you please give them a round of applause.
Thank you very much, Madam Speaker and members. AB 2910 is the local government omnibus bill. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you, Madame Speaker. SB 882 eliminates penal code infractions and misdemeanors for minors who fail to pay a public transit fare. Under current law, criminal penalties for failing to pay includes fines up to $400, mandatory community service, and jail time. Transit fare evasion by minors does not occur at high rates.

In 2015, BRT Rapid Transit arrested eight minors for a fare violation. Missed fares have a negligible effect on the budgets of most transit agencies, yet one fare citation can have a major impact on the life of a teenager. For one high school student in Los Angeles not paying for the train resulted in her arrest and once she was released, she was not allowed to attend continuation schools.

Under current law, it is too easy for a child to be made a criminal for not paying a few dollars for the bus or train. SB 882 does not limit the ability of transit authorities to charge a financial penalty through administrative process. We need to start looking at and using alternative forms of enforcement other than the courts and jails. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
Move to call.
Nick Louizos, California Association of Health Plans. Will just align myself with the comments, position, and amendments presented by ACLAC.
Thank you, Mr. Chair, members,

Nick Louizos, on behalf of California Association of Health Plans, in opposition to the Bill. We have supplied amendments to the author that would remove our opposition. We don't have a fundamental objections to the noticed provision of the Bill if it's crafted properly The primary focus of our opposition is the inclusion of a new special enrolment option for enrolees.

And the reason we're concerned with that is that some people that claim a special enrolment option outside of the current open enrolment period are obtaining coverage, racking up services, and then dropping their coverage. So there is some Misuse of that in this practice drives up costs for your constituents and for the businesses in your district. Nationally, people who enroll during the special enrollment period,

are showing that they a 10% to 40% higher health care costs than those that enroll during open enrollment. And quite frankly, what needs to happen is better enforcement of the special enrollment periods through documentation and verification in order to ensure that premiums are fair and affordable for everybody. This is an issue that has been raised not only by our health plan actuaries, but was recently raised by Covered California as well.
So unless that provision is removed, we continue to oppose the bill. Thank you.
Hi Madame Chair, members. Jennifer Fairing on behalf of the Humane Society Veterinary Medical Association also in support.

Nicole Wertleman on behalf of the San Bernardino County Board of Supervisors, in support. We are greatly appreciative of Senator Leyva and Assemblywoman Brown's work on this legislation. As well as our entire delegation's work on the issue. The full reimbursement on incidents is not unprecedented,
and under these unusual circumstances, we're asking for the full reimbursement to help our community recover from this trauma.
Question on the author? Will you also do it in Spanish? ...

Thank you, Madame Speaker and Members. SB 974 is a Senate Governance and Finance Committee annual omnibus bill. This adds amendments that are clarifying in nature. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
Testing, all right.
Sorry, I had some technical difficulties. Good morning. Welcome to the BOMC hearing, boys and men of color. I am Assemblymember Reginald Byron Jones-Sawyer, senior.

One of the Chairs of the Assembly Select Committee on Status of Boys and Men of Color. I represent the 59th Assembly District, which includes south Los Angeles, Walnut Park, Huntington Park, and Florence Firestone. My colleague, Mr. Bonta, will introduce himself after I say a few words.

Obviously, I want to welcome everyone that are here in the gallery. And most important, the ones that were unfortunately unable to get into the gallery that are in the Eureka Room in the building, which I believe it's about 200 young people and staff.

They're down there, want to welcome you here to this hearing. The American promise tells us that anyone, born anywhere, of any color or class, can get an education, live in a healthy community, and be rewarded for their hard work. But this dream comes with hard-hitting realities.

Too many young people, disproportionately young men of color, are trapped in a cycle of prison, poverty, and disadvantage. Deteriorated schools, neighborhoods, poor health, dysfunctional social support, and limited job opportunities hamper their progress. These circumstances leave communities in poverty, rob opportunity from our scholars of color,

and make the far majority of Californians unable to compete in the professional workplace. Our young people are growing up without a fair shot to be healthy and successful. That's not the kind of community we want to create. Now more than ever, it's not enough to just lower the barriers that have for

too long stifled the potential of our promising youth. It's time to break them. The good news is that programs and reforms have helped, but there is so much more to be done. We need to increase graduation rates, improve community health, stop criminalizing students,

and above all, we need to renew our vows to our black, brown and API youth. As I've said before, and I'll say it again, I am unapologetic when it comes to my support and my fight to improve the lives of boys and men of color in the State of California and this country.

And I say I am unapologetic, it's because when others come and say what if we slow the progress, what about this, what about that, I usually say, and I always say, it's time is now. We need to stop procrastinating.

We need to do a whole lot more for our young men and boys of color. Today is laced with more opportunities than in generations. I am especially glad today when we hear from not only speakers who are knowledgeable, but probably the most important speakers will be young people.

We made a conscious effort, my Co-Chair and I, Mr. Bonta, we made a conscious effort to hear from young people. All too often we hear from our peers, or people who are of the same age as we are. We need to start listening more to you, because you are experiencing it more everyday.

You have more insight on what needs to be done. And most important, the impacts on you are much more dramatic than ever before. So, for us as parents, I have two sons, one that's 22, and one that's 14,

both have been impacted adversely by the educational system. Both have had difficulties dealing with racism on a level that is hidden. I call it passive-aggressive racism, where people have good intentions, or systems have good intentions, but their outcomes have left our young people in a disadvantage,

and more or less have been racist to people of color. We need to stop it, and we need to do a whole lot more than we ever had before. For us a parents, as neighbors, as voters, and as policy makers, the greatest gift to our children is to ensure that everyone can access to a successful life.
With that, I will turn it over to Mr. Bonta, the other Chair of Boys and Men of Color.

Thank you very much. Good. So let us begin with out first panel, agency programs addressing the needs of boys and men of color. Tim Rainey, from the California Workforce Development Board. Jahmal MIller, Office of Health Equity.
And Christian Saunders, Division of Juvenile Facilities, Juvenile Acceptance, and Community Release Accountability Big office.
I see Mr. Miller's here.
Ms. Sander's here.
And I'll tell you what we'll do. We'll begin with you two and if Mr. Rainey shows up, we'll plug him right in. But since we have limited time, I want to make sure we don't miss anything.
So Mr. Miller, would you like to begin first?
Thank you. Mr. Rainey is here, so whenever you're ready.
Thank you. Next panelist, Sanders?
Is that working?
You're welcome. Are any members with any questions? I have a, hopefully a quick one.
The National Medical Association was recently in Los Angeles and that's all the African-American physicians across the country.

And I had opportunity to speak with Dr David Satcher. He was the 10th US Assistant Secretary of Heath. He was the 16th Surgeon General to the US as appointed by Bill Clinton. He is a retired Vice Admiral.

He's the Director of CDC, Center of Disease Control, Past President of Mary Medical College and Morehouse, and for our purposes he served in the faculty of UCLA Medical Center and I guess most importantly Martin Luther King Hospital and we discussed about gun violence in general. But about the impact of PTSD on our community, and

that maybe, just maybe, as we move forward we need to put a little more effort into the mental health of our young people and what they're going into. Because as he said, yes, we can go ahead and give them the best education. We can go ahead and provide them good medical care.

We can go ahead and provide them clothing and feed them. But if they're going into an environment which is almost like a war zone in Iraq or Afghanistan, it's really hard for a young person to concentrate when they've just seen someone murdered or killed, or there's drug activity going on, or they're being chased by gang members.

And we want to kind of put them into a silo in which they just mentally may not be able to handle because there's just so much pressure, that even an adult would have a problem with. And so, just generally, do you think that maybe our approach should be a little more
mental health related as opposed to we still need all the other factors in the program but that we probably need to step up our activities on a mental health side.
Thank you. If we don't allow expressions, except we do allow this. So if we want to express clapping, this is our sign for clapping. Thank you.

Are there any questions from Committee Members? And I, too, want to thank you for your testimony. Since I've been here, I've been working on continuation schools. I've had 2 bills, AB 570 and AB 1573 because I noticed that continuation schools seem to be out of the mainstream. Not only you're not properly regulated ensure that you get proper education and that you matriculate through the system.

I find that they are a vehicle to, as you put it, put young people from the school to prison. It looks like the deportation pipeline. I guess I'll need to add deportation to that list. It is something that I think you've opened our eyes up to, adding the deportation part, and if you have any additional ideas on what we can do as a Legislature to help curb that. Obviously we have people outside this room who talk about building walls and

deporting people, and we all have different ideas of how to handle that and some of us are vehemently against any of that and so in California we should do a better job. More important, we should be the shining light and should work to ensure that places like Santa Ana

is not the harbinger of continuing this practice. And so, I think I can commit members here that if you get information to us, addresses, we can definitely disseminate your struggle, Mr Julio, to other members so that we can get your message out and hopefully we can help in some way. Any questions?

Okay. Thank you very much, gentlemen, your stories were compelling, thank you for being here, I know it's hard sharing that, but you're two brave young men, and I'm proud that you're in the State of California. Thank you. Next panel is the Central California Private Youth report, Anthony your app armor, neighborhood thrift, Eddie Chavez, neighborhood thrift, and Jessie Plata, neighborhood thrift.

and I want the audience to know that we do see you. We do see your cards which says, free our dreams. You are seen. And I want to thank you.
