Mr. Chair and members, Rand Martin on behalf of the California After School Coalition and Las BEST. This is not a bill that we want to sponsor, but the reality is when you don't have enough money going into a program that has been facing increased costs for the last 10 years, you need to do something. We greatly appreciate the fact that Legislature has stepped up and tried to put money into this program to close this budget deficit. Unfortunately, we're not there.

The only solution is to find some changes to the program that will allow the program to be viable. We employ you, when this bill is heard on the suspense file on Thursday, to please support it moving forward. There was one issue relative to the 6 PM closure time. We have been working with your staff and with the pro tem staff trying to find language that obviates anybody's concerns about that provision. We think we're there, and we look forward to moving forward. Thank you.
Thank you. Mark McDonald, McCowan Group on behalf of the Los Angeles, Kern, Los Rios, San Bernadino, South Orange County, and West Kern Community College Districts, all in support. Thank you.

Excuse me, Mike Robeson tied up. On behalf of the sponsor, Thermofisher Scientific and just really quickly on the fiscal impact; in support of the bill. I want to point out that there is a note in the analysis about Medi-Cal saying that they might increase the number of test to 65 from the current 24.

We don't see any reason why Medi-Cal would need to do that and if the bill needed to say so it could say, you know, it could be amended to say to keep the current limit for blood test at 24; we'd be fine with that. And the only other comment I want to make is that on the fiscal we think this would definitely save the state a lot of money.

The analysis questions whether there would be more referrals to specialists for interpreting test results. And we think it'd actually be the exact opposite of that, is that this bill would result in primary care physicians getting test results and actually interpreting the blood test results in the primary care setting.
It would save the state a lot of money in that regard, and we hope this bill comes off suspense for that reason. Thank you.
Good afternoon, Danielle Kendall Kaiser on behalf of Privacy Rights Clearinghouse we are in opposition, thank you.
Is that okay?

Thank you, Mr. Speaker and members. As the Chair of LGBT Caucus, I would like welcome our guest today as we prepare for the 2016 Pride ceremony. Each year the caucus celebrates exceptional individuals who have made significant contributions to advance the full equality and justice for the LGBT Community. It is through their endeavours that California has made history on LGBT issues and serve as an inspiration for the rest of the country.

This year holds a special significance to the caucus. Today, we celebrate our formation In history of the caucus in addition to the accomplishments of those who have helped shape LGBT history with a special highlight on that work here in this Legislature. Those who have advocated for us brought attention to our issues in the press and

those individuals and groups who have been by our side since the very beginning. We have accomplished much but have a lot more to do. June 12th, 2016 in the Pulse Nightclub was a solemn reminder of that fact. Despite the setbacks we will one day achieve full equality, it is within our reach.

On your desk members you'll find swag bags as a gift from the caucus. Our traditional rainbow that celebrates our diversity as well as our pride. Also you'll find a tealight that celebrates or recognizes the losses that we have faced. You'll also find M&Ms in a color of the transgender colors,

to know that we still have brothers and sisters that still need more full awareness. And finally you'll also find a postcard from Pulse Orlando so that we never forget. I also encourage our guests and visitors to view a special exhibit on the second floor rotunda and following this ceremony and after session in room 317 we will carry on. Thank you very much and I hope you enjoyed our Pride ceremony this year.

Hi, I'm Assemblymember Susan Talamantes Eggman, Chair of the California Legislative LGBT Caucus. The 2016 Pride Ceremony, Honoring the Past, Securing the Future celebrates the caucus formation and history.

Formed in 2002, the California Legislative LGBT Caucus has a history of furthering equality and justice for all LGBT Californians. And hopefully, the nation. Our caucus was the first of its kind in the country and I am pleased to introduce the following video, Pride with Purpose.

Good Afternoon Madam Chair and Members. Gregory Kramer from Planned Parenthood Affiliates of California. We support this resolution, and we provide LGBTQ services, including hormone therapy, education and other resources to our patients, regardless of sexual identity or gender. And we just hope that you could support this bill, and hope that Congress could acknowledge and support the 14th Amendment. Thank you.
Thank you. Ally Fletcher with the ACLU of California, in support. Thank you.
Thank you Mr. Chairman. It is a long road. Chair Macarro, I was reflecting back. We first met 18 years ago. You don't look any older and I've lost all my hair. It's true.

I certainly enjoyed getting to know you and your tribal leaders and learning about the history of your tribe and the aspirations for self-reliance that we spent a lot of time working on together then. And to see the progress that has been made by you and your tribe, it's so impressive.

And you've forged such a great relationship locally with state leaders and of course, with leaders of our country. It's a lot to be proud of, and I think the compact reflects the really good feelings of how successful you have been and we have been together. I'm happy to support it when it comes to the Senate Floor. Nice to see you again.

Mr. Chairman, Senator Berryhill said it all. Those of us who've been involved, and Mr. Chairman, you have as well. Going back 20 years to realize what the rockiness of the start. It wasn't really their start because that's hundreds and hundreds and thousands of years, but our start together.

And there was such suspicion and it is worth noting. Because the thing that surprised me the most back then is that the critics didn't realize that it was always in the tribes interest to do these things right. Treat their employees well, to work well with their communities, that their concern about public safety equals or exceeded everyone else's concerns about public safety.

So it's great to acknowledge that progress has been made. And the fallacies that came out of the start in our early relationships. But it's a great pleasure to be here today to see this positive progress.
Thank you Mr. Chair. So, is there a proposal that you're considering to build a casino at this time? I know this gives you the right to have a gaming facility. Is there a proposal that's been?
And then, Mr. Chair, I guess I would note that prior to this presentation,

we heard from three other tribes that have very successful operations. And I hope that provides a lot of encouragement to you, that their start wasn't a lot different than what you have been going through. A rocky difficult road with opposition and challenges and all the rest and I know that's made it, particularly difficult to give in the economic circumstances for the tribe.

But congratulations on getting through this hurdle, it will get better. And I think that certainly I'm sure you've recognized this, that there's such great leadership in Indian country who have gone the same path that you go. And has a lot of lessons to be Learned in building these partnerships which I know that you can do and we want you to do.
And it's important that you do, but congratulations on getting through where we are today. Thank you.
Mr. Chairman, Nick Brokaw on behalf of the Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians, in support.
Thank you Nick Brokaw on behalf of the Agua Caliente Band of Quiche Indians, in support. Thank you.
Nick Brokaw on behalf of the Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians also in support.

Bill McGavin with the Coalition for Clean Air in support. I think you've heard today how knowledgeable Mr. Olsen is. And it's important that the ISO have his expertise on efficiency and renewables and operations of the grid. Thank you.

Sure. Good afternoon, Will Barrett with the American Lung Association in California. Thank you for holding the discussion today. First of all, California as you know is home to some of the most polluted air in the United States. But our air pollution control programs, our clean truck programs, our clean vehicle and fuel programs really putting a huge dent in that fact. The American Lung Association's annual report noted that in the 16 or

17 years since our report was first published the state or year. In the Los Angeles region, smog has been reduced, smog days have been reduced by 35%. In the Bay Area, it's closer to 60% and about 40% in the San Joaquin Valley. These programs are working or influencing air pollution controls around the country and around the world.

I'd also like to note today that the American Thoracic Society put out a new research project. Highlighting the vital role of air pollution control programs with saving lives in the Unites States. The report notes that by implementing stronger programs to control smog and soot, as the previous speaker said. Addressing our standards to what science tells us, we can save thousands of lives in Southern California with cleaner air.

And hundreds of lives in the San Joaquin Valley and San Diego and then Sacramento region. There's a real benefit to moving these programs forward. We think that California has the most innovative and strongest programs in the world really. And that we just basically need the Legislature and the agency to work together to really move the ball forward on protecting public health.

And that comes in the form of direct regulations as discussed today. Grant funding and the climate investments that are currently held in the State treasury. We need those to get out, we need to move forward together and look forward to working with all of you. Thank you very much.

Sure thing. Mr. Chair, Michael Pimintel here on behalf of the Pacific Merchant Shipping Association. Just want to thank you for hosting this forum, which I think is fairly unique, and really exercising the appropriate role of providing oversight over the Cap and Trade program, making sure that Greenhouse Gas Reduction Funds are used in a cost effective way. So we really do appreciate your work, and the work of your staff. Thank you.
I spent some time in Ireland over the summer and had the opportunity to meet with all 13 families, survivors. And very clearly, I heard your pain, your anger and your desire for us to be able to act.

I'm not going to tell other members who are sitting here, and Mr. Wagner as well, that certainly anywhere in the country of Ireland, which is a small, beautiful, welcoming country of 4 million. All you need to do is say, the work Berkeley and everybody shudders and crosses themselves and feels great sorrow about what happened. So I would just, again, like to offer our support, an ocean of condolences, and certainly will be supporting this bill when it moves off of suspense.
Thank you for your bravery and being able to come here and live everyday.
Steve Carlson, for CTIA, the Wireless Industry Trade Association, also opposed for the reasons indicated.

Madame Chair and members, Mike Bellot, represent a coalition of deposition services firms. The bill is quite complicated, it's largely a policy issue. The attempt is to export regulations which apply to the practice of court reporting to the business of court reporting. This has been the subject of litigation for many, many years, the litigation continues.

I think the bill attempts to stay away from the litigation, I'm not sure it's successful, I think further litigation is likely. I also think a very complicated regulatory process will be necessary to iron out the issues implicated in the bill, we are opposed and we are continuing to talk to the author.

Thank you, Madame Chair, members, Mark Mcdonald McGowan group, on behalf of the Foothill, DeAnza, Kern, Los Rios, San Bernardino, San Diego, and South Orange County Community College Districts, all in support.

Madam Chair and members, Beth Alasso on behalf of the Sponsor Inland Empire Utilities Agency. IUA is a waste water treatment center in the Senator's district that is looking to help San Bernardino county region meet its organics diversion and short-lived climate pollutant goals by taking food waste, co-digesting it with bio-solids in their already established digesters on their facilities. This bill will help the treatment centers use that existing capacity
in a cost-effective manner to accept food waste that would otherwise go to a landfill. So we respectfully request your aye vote.
Good morning, Madam Chair. Karen Lang on behalf of the Solid Waste Association of North America in support.
Lauren D. Valencia, representing the American Planning Association, in support.
Good morning, Matt Regan with the Bay Area Council, the bill's sponsor, and strong support. Thank you.
Steve Carlson, for CTIA, the Wireless Industry Trade Association also opposed for the reasons indicated.

Thank you very much, Mr. Chair, good morning. SB 1227 will be amended to clarify CalVet's role in providing access to supportive services, rather than providing them directly. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Danielle Blacet with the California Municipal Utilities Association. We moved from an oppose unless amended position to a neutral. And I just wanted to thank Senator Hill for all of his work to ensure that our members had the flexibility that was necessary to implement the provisions in this bill, so.

Thank you, Madam President and Members. I rise today to adjourn in memory of Second Lieutenant Michael Parros. Second Lieutenant Parros died suddenly and unexpectedly during his first day of training at the US Army Ranger School.

He was only 21 years of age. Michael had just graduated from the US Army Military Academy at West Point in May. And joining the Army Rangers School was a testament to his talent and his drive, he wanted to be part of something very special.

At De La Salle High School in Concord, Michael was a member of the celebrated football program, playing several positions including quarterback. His coach said this about Michael that he's a very good athlete, very, very bright, very intellectual. That's why he was trying to become an Army Ranger that takes a special young man.

Whenever we adjourn in memory, it's a somber moment. But it's especially sobering when the person we are remembering dies so early in their life. We do not know how long each of us has here on Earth, but if we live with a passion for life And an earnest desire to do better as Michael did.

We can rest assured our lives will have meant something. Michael's friends and families are grieving for this tragic loss. This adjourn in memory is our way of joining with him, his friends, and his family in this grief.

Madam President, I just want to join in sharing my deep regard that I had for Kris Shwankmeyer. I did have the opportunity to work with her over the course of many years on various projects. I know her husband Jim well, and it is a tragic loss.
But also in celebrating Michael's accomplishments at such a young age and his commitment to serving our nation and our state. He is survived by his parents Michael and Margaret and sister Alexis.
And thank you, Senator Allen, for bringing this to our attention, so that we can properly mourn her passing and celebrate her great life and join with her friends and family in that. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. Speaker and members. AB 2810 is back from concurrent from the Senate, which the technical amendment are respectfully as aye vote.
Thank you, Mr. Speaker and members. AB 2810 is back from concurrent from the Senate, which added technical amendments. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you, Madam President and members. This legislation provides a certification for code enforcement officers. As you know it's an important function of local government to ensure a community standard such as protecting property values and mitigating environmental issues. This bill establishes a framework through which code enforcement officers may receive state recognized certification.  If they so choose, it will foster greater uniformity and professionalism in this important local government function. I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Thank you, Madam President and members. I did vote for this bill in public safety. And I appreciate the thoughtful debate today, but I think that a lot of the comments have missed show. I think a misunderstanding of what this legislation really does. And I'd like to ask a question to the floor manager of the bill, if I may Madam President.

There's a suggestion that the confrontation, where this footage may have started would be something that would not be disclosable under this legislation. It's my understanding that it's only the moment of death that an agency would require Permission, not the confrontation, not the interactions, but only that moment in which it's determined that that person lost their life. Is that your understanding?

Right, so it's been suggested that there's some inconsistency in the application of this to others, and I would say that if these protections were extended to a public official, to anyone, I would have that same sensitivity that's being offered up in this legislation for our public safety officers.
That it's not the confrontation, it's only the moment of death that a limitation would be placed under this legislation, and accordingly, I'm happy to support it today.
Thank you, Madame President. I had a question for the floor manager.

So, I understand that the League of California Cities is opposed to this measure. And one of the suggestions that I have heard is that there currently is a requirement that this compensation information is provided to the state controller each year. But that this legislation would require additional information over and above what is currently provided to the controller. Do you have any further information on that?

So Madam President with your permission I'd like to try my question one more time. Which is that, to the author I support the transparency that's desired in this legislation. But the concern that's been raised is that it's not the information that's provided to the controller and simply posting it on your website, in which I support.

And I support that transparency. It's that this legislation's going to require information that is different than what they're currently providing, that then is required to be posted. And if it's okay with, if the author doesn't know the answer at the moment, maybe we could take a pause and clarify that.

I certainly support the intentions of this legislation and that transparency that we all desire. That I appreciate having it posted on the city's web page is more user friendly than the controller's web page. But the confusion is the requiring of additional information that's not currently prepared would be required under this bill. And absent that clarification I'm going to be reluctantly a no vote.
The Senators ask for a pause to get additional information. I would wonder whether-

It certainly would, there's confusion about what this legislation does. And I think that we would all benefit by clarifying whether or not the information that's currently provided to the controller is what would be required to be posted on your webpage. If that is in fact true, I'm happy to support the bill today, with that clarification.

But without that clarification, there is an additional burden that's being required in all of our local cities. And I think that clarification would make a lot of us more comfortable with the clear intentions and desires of this legislation.

Thank you, Madam President and members. This legislation provides uniformity to the concealed carry license program that we have here in California that will authorize local law enforcement agencies to issue concealed weapon and ID cards approved by the California Department of Justice that are more durable and secure than the the current paper permits. To counteract the issue of these current permits that are prone to water damage and tears. It will allow Sheriffs' offices to provide these ID cards that are similar to driver's licenses. This legislation will legalize the use of these cards. I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Keegan was a five year old boy who died after a long battle with leukemia. He touched the lives and captured the hearts of the entire tri valley. Keegan became known as the tri valley's valiant warrior. His difficulties brought many communities together, uniting friends and strangers who ultimately became family referred to as Team Keegan.

Kegan attended Cottage Preschool in Livermore, where he loved his classmates and teachers. He often looked forward to going back to school, upon his release from the hospital. This young man was stronger and braver than most adults. He had a very inquisitive mind and enjoyed taking things apart to figure them out.

Figured out how they would work. His sweet smile and silly giggle are just a few of the things he will be remembered by. Keegan brought life and love to his parents, Sean and Kimberly, younger brother Murphy, his 11 year old cousin Riley, and all the rest of his family.

Riley said this about his little cousin. I love him so much and I'm very sad I don't get to watch him grow up. He meant the world to me and will always have a special place in my heart that belongs only to him. Keegan will be deeply missed and fondly remembered.
Our heart is with his family and friends, and all those who knew him. Rest in peace valiant warrior.

Thank you Madam President and members. For 10 years it's been illegal in California to leave your pet in a car in harmful hot conditions. Unfortunately, many citizens don't know that it's illegal or even worse don't realize how quickly it heats up inside the car. Every year law enforcement receives hundreds of calls from concerned citizens reporting animals left in hot cars.

Emergency responders do a great job responding to these situations but sometimes a response simply takes too long due to other priorities. This bill addresses that rare scenario when law enforcement has been called and maybe on the way but an animal is in imminent danger of serious harm or death. The bill lays out various scenarios that someone must go through before rescuing that car.

We hope that this legislation provides a level of immunity for someone who needs to rescue an animal. It assures that they will not face legal repercussions. Five other states have enacted this policy, and this bill will ensure that heroic animal rescuers in California are protected, too. I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Thank you Madame President, members. This legislation updates various provisions of the California Credit Union law. Credit unions operate in a dual chartering system allowing them to be chartered either by the national credit union administration or the Department of business oversight.

This bill strengthens the California State charter credit union statute, giving credit unions new options in the way they're organized and allows them to better serve their members. This legislation's necessary to ensure state charter credit unions remain competitive with the Federal Charter. I respectfully ask for an aye vote.
Thank you, Madame President. I know it's been a long day. Madame President, I rise today to ask that we adjourn in memory of Keegan Axle Cowell Liance.

At this year's annual Alameda County Fair in Pleasanton, community efforts help promote awareness and Team Keegan raising a little over $150,000.00 to go towards his medical bills. He was a force to be reckoned with from the day he was born as his aunt Jennifer Cowl has said.
Mr. Chair and members, Nick Brokaw here on behalf of the Aqua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians, in support. Thank you.

Yes, and I'm really excited about the new California Native American Education Fund. As the assemblywoman from San Diego and I who went to very expensive universities where I think we're at $51,000 a year. We always look at the funding and I kind of want to know how you derive at 3 million.

Because for many of us that come from disadvantaged communities, we definitely believe that the best way for people to prosper and grow is through the educational system and more important for them to get higher education.

And so I commend you for this new fund and although the number is 3 million it's your opportunity to ensure that, as you start, do you have more and more? I'm very optimistic because you have more and more members of your tribe starting to take advantage of that.
We don't deplete that sum and we don't provide that opportunity there more and more individuals so that the entire tribe can benefit from. I think this is really, really exciting to do this.
And how did you arrive at the number?
Nick Brokaw here on behalf of the Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians in support, thank you.

There we go. Mike West, Director of Communications, District Council 16. One thing that I want to add to what Robert was saying is common pressures on the job site of schedule and cost and everything might result in accommodation of three things happening.

So if the containment isn't proper, we get environmental issues. The cost overruns and the infrastructure investment if the earnings aren't applied properly could be an issue of cost, corners being cut. But the worst would be if the worker's safety was compromised due to worker to worker,

the competition, or those kind of pressures from either the contractor or from the third party. So this would level the playing field among the workers, the contractors. Everybody would be on the same page for safety, and then the resulting benefits
on the environmental issues and our infrastructure investment would go hand in hand.

David Munez, Department of Finance. Mr. Chair, Members of the Committee. Every single bargaining unit that the administration has been in negotiations with in the past year or so all has different and unique issues to address. Some of which are recruitment and retention problems, major salary lags, extreme vacancies. Things of that nature and as part of that, specific to bargain unit seven, we identified a few classifications that have extreme recruitment, retention and salary lag issues and as part of this agreement, we've made a modest step for enclosing the gap on some of the salary lapse and addressing some of these recruitment and retention issues.

I would just point out that there was a special salary adjustment included in this contract for the ABCD agents, and also there was an additional special salary adjustment for Cal OES coordinators. Both of these particular classifications did have vacancy rates exceeding our statewide average, and also had some significant recruitment and retention issues. So, aside from those, the other provisions of this contract do have some similarities to the other recent MOUs. With that, I'd be happy to answer any questions.

Mr. Chair, yes, the classification structure that we have in state government civil services, it's very broad, and we have a lot of similar classifications out there that maybe working for different departments, but maybe doing slightly different work, but there's always an argument to be made that just because of the size and breadth of our classifications, that occasionally we run into nuances where we have certain employees working in departments that are doing very similar work to someone else in another department, yet their pay is substantially different.

And what that ends up creating is employees come in, work for one department for a short period of time, get the training they need, and they're immediately out the door to the next classification where they can make more money and what this agreement does is make a strong step forward in preventing that for these ABC agents and Cal OES coordinators. I know some of my colleagues, Senator Hancock included, are familiar with this.

Yes, absolutely Senator. So, a couple comments to that. The first, I would mention is that, and as this Committee has likely heard a number of times, our civil service kind of improvement measures that we've been endeavoring. As part of that we're looking at a massive, broad, class consolidation and as part of that we would be looking at investor agent classifications, and these salary differences throughout the state. That's the first piece. With regards to your question with insurance investigators, included in this MOU, we have made a modest step forward with this small special salary adjustment for the investigator classification across the board of roughly 5%.

So the issue that you're referring to now, we believe that this MOU will help solve that problem. It may not completely solve that at this point, but we're definitely making a strong step forward to address that.

Thank you for the question. So with regards to ABC agents, this special salary adjustment will bring them within 5% of the DOJ agents and that was one of our primary issues is that all of our ABC agents were then going to DOJ. So by bringing them that much closer there isn't as much as an incentive to leave ABC to go to DOJ with regards to the Callaway's coordinators, we are bringing them with imparity of a similar classification that works at CAL FIRE.
So Cali Char per statute actually produces a salary survey for every bargaining unit, I believe within six months of the expiration of the contract.
Exactly.

Some of these are sworn peace officers and are subject to a safety retirement, and I believe that in that case they would not subject to Social Security, but I'd like to double check that and I can give that information for you and your staff.

Great question, so anytime we're doing collective bargaining, and we're making some adjustments to the pay skills of our rank and file consideration is always given to how that impacts our excluded supervisor, managers and so forth. HR has the authority to make that adjustment, so for example if we do a 5% salary increase for a certain classification, CALHR will take a look at the impact or compaction to the next supervisor or the next direct report and if they make a determination that compaction is an issue, they have the authority to also send that pay raise up through the ranks.

Senator Stone, great questions. So couple comments on that is that the retiree benefit, the Op Ed benefit, is something that's highly valued by our ranking file, and actually all of the civil service employees and it's been a great recruitment and retention to all for us and as you have mentioned there are cases in which private sector and maybe some locals out there are paying more, but they're not offering the same total compensation benefit package that the state has and It's something that's important to us, to the administration, and to our employees and our Op Ed strategy that we have put forth will put it on a sustainable path and at some point, when we reach full funding, it will be a much more affordable benefit than it currently is today.

The short answer to your question is yes, about 30 years it will take. The key of the strategy is that we are continuing to do our pay as you go for healthcare at this point, but on top of that we continue to reach agreement with our bargaining units. We're actually free funding into a what we're terming a lock box, but a trust fund and for every dollar that the employee and the employer puts in that lockbox, a dollar for dollar reduction occurs to the unfunded liability and in approximately 30 years, we would have completely paid off the unfunded liability from an accounting perspective.

And then we can unlock the trust fund and use that plus the investment returns to start paying for our Op Ed cost, very similar to how we pay for our pensions. One other piece to your question is that annually we have a contract actuary that does kind of our evaluations for us and lets us know exactly where we stand in regards to the unfunded liability and this 30 year projection is based on our most recent evaluation.

Based on salary alone, I do not have an example for that right now and really, the reason for that is is that the administration looks at total compensation, because as some of the other members have stated here today is that the cost of the benefits we provide are very expensive. The define benefit program, OPAV, and so we like to include all of that into the total compensation package and when we measure that. Against public, private, other localities. It gives us a good apples to apples comparison.

There's so many classifications out there, Mr. Chair, that I am sure that there is an example of some classification that may be on a salary to salary comparison is at, or possibly above a market salary for a private sector, but I would say that, that is the exception, not the rule.

I'm tracking your question now. So let's just use the typical civil service employee that is pre-pension reform and can retire at 55. So between the age of 55 and 65, the employee is not eligible for Medicare at that point, so they're staying on what we term the basic healthcare plan. It's the same plan that all of our active employees are on. Once they hit 65 years old, statute requires that those employees enroll in basically a Medicare supplement plan and at that point, what happens is the state share of those retiree costs are roughly cut in half. So to your question, yes, Medicare does come in and supplement at that point.
Yes, for a lack of a better way to describe it, that's how it works. We have two funding sources providing the same benefit for the employee or for the retired annuitant.
This is my issue as well.
Thank you, Mr. Chair. And my questions are on the issue of ESCO, another new acronym that I hadn't heard of before. How much money's set aside for this program in our budget?

Mr. Chairman, members, Richard Marcus for the Western Electrical Contractors Association and Associate Builders and Contractors of California and a few other contractor groups. I disagree with the characterization on the ESCO from the Department of General Services. The language in this bill differ from Senator's Wolk's bill in particular,

Senator Wolk's bill allow the PLA to only satisfy their monthly reporting requirement in this measure if there's a PLA there is absolutely no requirement to use a skilled trained workforce. The Esco could go to loads or home depot to hire their employees if there is a PLA. The other important distinction is the previous measures had a phase in provision

that started out at 20 or 30%, had to be graduates from an apprenticeship program. This bill immediately goes to the 60% graduation requirement. We're suspicious that the escos will have a challenge satisfying that 60% graduation requirement and finally to Senator Moorlach's We

do firmly believe that the PLA language is a disincentive for fair an open competition. We think that the best result comes from fair and open competition, letting anyone without the extraneous issues associated with a PLA. And finally, I did appreciate the clarification on the 35 year contract.

But it would seem that if this program sunsets in four years that the State would not need the authority in the bill to enter into a 35 year contract with Enesco and might obvious gracious suggestion would be that the language should be consistent. And that whatever authority for the ESCO contracts should be consistent with when the program sends that. Thank you.

Mr Chair, I know this is in the weeds, but one of the witnesses did make the point that with 35 years still being in as the term of the ESCO, yeah, it expires in four years. Whether that would allow the state to enter into a longer term contract and what this bill would allow for the continuation of this- So it's just a point again, small one, but I don't know.

Thank you, Madam President, members. I'm pleased to carry this bill on behalf of Assemblymen Gatto. It's a bill to clarify the terms in which vehicles may be used by drivers of transportation network companies. This bill determines that a personal vehicle must meet these certain standards.
the opportunity to provide transportation network services while maintaining existing driver qualifications, insurance, and vehicle safety standards.

Thank you, Madam President, members. I'm pleased to carry this bill on behalf of Assemblymen Gatto. It's a bill to clarify the terms in which vehicles may be used by drivers of transportation network companies. This bill determines that a personal vehicle must meet these certain standards. They can't exceed a maximum passenger capacity of eight people plus that includes the driver, leased or rented for a term of up to 30 days, meet all inspection and safety requirements specified by the CPUC, and not be a taxi cab or a limousine.

This bill will ensure that short term auto rentals or leases provide all interested individuals the opportunity to provide transportation network services while maintaining existing driver qualifications, insurance, and vehicle safety standards. This bill has received strong bipartisan support in both houses and I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Thank you, Mr. President and members. This legislation establishes a process for notifying property owners that a new parcel tax has passed. If a property owner is a voting resident of the local jurisdiction, they learn about the parcel tax in advance when they cast their vote. By contrast, non-resident property owners, those who own parcels within a community but reside elsewhere.

Typically receive no notice of their increased tax burden until they receive their property tax burden in the mail. This bill simply requires the local government to notify these non-resident property owners when a new parcel tax has been approved by the voters. Notification could occur through a postcard or an envelope sent by the US mail. The bill is sponsored by the California Association of Realtors. Received unanimous support in Senate Gov and Finance and I respectfully as for an aye vote.
Thank you. Just to acknowledge the leadership of Assemblyman Daly in this measure and I respectfully ask for an aye vote.
Thank you, Mr. President, members.

I certainly want to join in thanking Senator from Tahima for bringing this to the floor today and the Assembly Member from Ventura. Members, we've talked about this in previous conversations, it's a sensitive subject. And I appreciate that 11 members of the Senate joining me in the 22 day,

saying they have anxiety, they have worries, they have concerns so that we can help. Think about those barriers and then in the military itself, how much even tougher it is when you potentially be prosecuted for coming forward and expressing your anxiety. So this bill is an important step forward in recognizing these challenges of showing and embrace by all of us.

I want to extend my condolences to her son John Warren, and to all those who are touched by her light embrace.

Thank you, Mr. President, members. I certainly want to join in thanking Senator from Tahima for bringing this to the floor today and the Assembly Member from Ventura. Members, we've talked about this in previous conversations, it's a sensitive subject and I appreciate that 11 members of the Senate joining me in the 22 day, 22 push-up challenge that I started in June. It was really a great eye opening experience because I learned a lot about this issue and about the challenges that we face and we know that this issue of suicide is a sensitive subject in our community at large and in the military even more sensitive and to think that the barriers that get in the way of someone coming forward and saying they have anxiety, they have worries, they have concerns so that we can help.

Think about those barriers and then in the military itself, how much even tougher it is when you potentially be prosecuted for coming forward and expressing your anxiety. So this bill is an important step forward in recognizing these challenges of showing and embrace by all of us. That those who have anxiety issues and challenges that we want to be there for them and supportive of them. Whether they're in civilian life or a part of our military service, that they're important and their concerns are important and I appreciate the author's efforts to clarify this in an important way and ti's an important change in our public policy and I certainly support it today.

Mr Chair, thank you. Now I appreciate the concern about the pension funds, and I know that's real, but I know that our responsibility here, there'll always be investors, and I can't speak to Stockbridge good or bad, I appreciate the positive comments from my colleague about the company.

But I know that that can't be the driver behind the work that we do here. That the driver should be about whether we're protecting the public's interest in this. That they had provided some guidance that because of an arrangement they had with the hotel, and with the card club, that it would not be in violation.
That, based on their conversations that their ownership of the Sahara Hotel, and their ownership of Hollywood Park would not be violation.

Okay, and that was based on an advice that because they were in a leasing relationship For one or both of the properties. I believe it is. Yeah, but the correction wasn't to come back in a provide that clarification within law, it was this period of time that they could divest, correct?

Are you aware of any conduct by the current owners that has been harmful to the public? (Not that we're aware of, no.) Anything in regard to harm to public safety?
Okay, have there been any questions in regard to the public honesty or integrity of the ownership group?

And we all want to be sensitive to those circumstances.  But we also know that we need to understand whether anything that this might happen within this legislation would affect his important questions with public health and safety.

And I guess what I would say it's as some of the opponents that have come here, is that where circumstances to be similar in their case where assumptions have changed, but as long as they've operated in a responsible way then I would have the same sympathies that I have today for this situation as I would for their situation. As long as we been assured that we are protecting the public's interest, it makes me comfortable in supporting this bill today. Thank you.

Madame President, this bill clarifies that security officers at all independent non-profit institutions of higher education can be deputized by local law enforcement as Reserve officers under specified conditions.

In California, unlike their counterparts at UC and CSU, security officers at independent non-profit institutions like USC are not classified as peace officers and therefore, lack equivalent power. The increasingly unique security situation present on campuses highlights the need for adequate campus security.

By allowing these schools to utilize Reserve officers under an agreement with local law enforcement, this measure will improve campus safety. I respectfully ask, on behalf of the Trojan family, an aye vote, thank you.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker and members. I rise to present amendments to Senate Bill 1054. These amendments will address technical concerns raised by the Assembly Public Safety Committee and clarify victim restitution. Collection requirements between persons who are inmates in custody and convicted defendants who are released from custody.

Mr. Speaker and Members, over the past few years, California experienced the emergence of a new, unpredictable and deadly category of drugs called spice. Spice is a synthetic form of cannabinoid that is marketed as a safe and legal alternative to marijuana. It is not.

The chemicals in spice interact with the brain in a similar manner to marijuana, but can be up to 50 times more potent and the effects are often unpredictable. Tragically, some instances of spice use have resulted in death. In 2011 legislation was signed banning a specific version of spice, but the industry has circumvented the ban with new iterations.

SB 1036 will expand the definition to a controlled substance analogue to include all substantially similar synthetic cannabinoid structures. This will keep California law ahead of the constantly changing chemical structure of synthetic marijuana and prevent further tragic consequences. I respectfully ask for an aye vote.
Thank you, Madame Speaker and members. This is the annual bill from gov and finance, I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you very much, Mr. Speaker and members. I'm proud to present SB 1227, which will require the California Conservation Corps to collaborate with the California Department of Veterans Affairs to make sure everyone is getting served. I ask for your aye vote.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. SB 1029 promotes fiscal responsibility by providing Californians with new information about how public officials manage and spend proceeds of public debts. Last year's embezzlement of bond funds demonstrated the need to improve public awareness of how debt proceeds are managed and dispersed. SB 1029's provisions represent a narrowly targeted and proportional response to that need. Codifying a broadly accepted best practice for handling debt proceeds that will benefit taxpayers, investors,
and public agencies by fostering greater confidence that public funds are being carefully protected and spent as intended. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you Mr. Speaker. I rise today to present Senate bill 139, which would define legal consequences for the use and or possession of a synthetic cannabinoid or a stimulant compound and update the list of prohibited substances. These synthetic drugs present a uniquely dangerous threat to public safety. They are concocted in labs and manufactured in warehouses. They have been associated with numerous deaths and serious medical complications. SB 139 protects our communities and takes synthetic drugs off the streets by defining penalties for the personal possession of these dangerous substances and updating the code section to include the chemical compounds used as synthetic drugs. The bill has enjoyed unanimous bipartisan support throughout the process. Thank you, I respectfully ask for your aye support.

Mr. Speaker and members, I rise today to present SB 955 which would ensure that state hospital patients are eligible for compassionate release. I am happy to report that the current version of the bill includes amendments to address the concerns of the California District Attorney's Association, and they are no longer in opposition.

For more than 20 years, California had a compassionate release program which applies to state prison inmates, but it left out a small number of people: certain state hospital patients, including those are not guilty by reason of insanity or incompetent to stand trial. Because those patients were not included, there are situations where a patient can be in a coma, unable to receive treatment, or they can't be placed in a more palliable care setting closer to their loved ones.

It also means that the Department of State Hospitals is responsible for the significant medical cost. If these patients can't be cared for outside of the state hospitals, they would be eligible for federal matching funds of their care. SB 955 would create a compassionate release program for these patients. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Welcome, Ms. Eggman. >>Good afternoon, everybody. It's my honor to be here before you today, and again apologizing that you have to come back to do this and I would never do a gut and amend unless it was absolutely necessary.

But over the last two years we passed a couple bills to expand pharmacists ability to provide some basic medications, those things like noaxin, tobacco suppressants, birth control. And so, while we pass that legislation, we did not further implement to be able to have MediCal pay for that. So while we have new bills on the books that will actually save us money because people will be able to get their medications filled in a timely fashion without having

to go to try to get an appointment with a physician or a nurse practitioner every time and do that through their pharmacist. But we did not make the legislation so the department was able to say that MediCal could pay. So that's all this does is to say MediCal can reimburse for the services that we have approved for pharmacists to provide and we have some witnesses here in support.

And what FEHA provides is the ability for Employees to seek compensatory damages, punitive damages, attorney's fees. Quite candidly, when we hear the proponents claim that this bill will affect 16% of the workforce, upwards of 2.7 million Californians, our concern is all the potential litigation that falls under that.

What this bill provides right there in the first subdivision, subdivision A is, in addition to the average cost through judgement for a business in an employment litigation dispute, they also found in California 40% higher opportunity to be sued and they pointed to the FIHA statute and now SB 654 is going to substantially increase those than could derive benefit under the government code.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. SB 1054 is sponsored by the Los Angeles District Attorneys Office and clarifies the procedures to be used in the collection of the victim restitution fines for different inmate populations, and to clear up ambiguities, and current law after inmates were shifted from the state to the counties with the passage of realignment in 2010. SB 1054 provides more direction to the counties about the timing of administrative fee collection from jail inmates and stipulates that only one agency may collect restitution fees. It allows counties to collect direct restitution from offenders instead of the State Franchise Tax Board and it ensures that the administrative fee retained by a county entity, covers the actual cost of collection not to exceed 10% of the total cost.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker and members. SB 1289 prohibits local governments for entering into new contracts or extending contracts with for-profit companies to detain immigrants and requires all facilities that detain immigrants to adhere to standards created by ICE in their operations performance-based national detention standards.

Which include access to medication, the right to file grievances and have visitation by legal counsel and family. SB 1289 also provides additional protections for the LGBT community such as allowing transgender detainees to be held in a facility corresponding with their gender identity and also provides a public right of action in the event that a detainee's rights are violated.

This bill relates exclusively to immigration detention, which is the process by which individuals are held during the deportation proceedings. SB 1289 would make the federal government's own standards enforceable under state law and create the right to sue if an immigrant's rights are violated. Thank you, and I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you, Mr Speaker. SB 1219 will help employment social enterprises compete for government contracts under the small business preference and create more jobs for people who might otherwise not have the opportunity. And provide those unemployed with a supportive work environment where they build their skills and abilities.

State and local governments are facing formidable challenges in supporting economic stability and security among some of its most vulnerable populations. Employment social enterprises, or mission driven businesses, focus on hiring and assisting people who face the greatest barriers. Including people who have been incarcerated, homeless, youth disconnected from school or work, and individuals with disabilities. There is no opposition and there is bipartisan support. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I'm presenting SB 448, a bill to address constitutional issues in Proposition 35. In November of 2012 with 81% of the vote and 10 million votes, California passed Proposition 35 also known as the CASE Act. Upon passage, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, the ACLU filed a temporary restraining order against the requirement for sex offenders to share their online identifiers for law enforcement.

Both the district and ninth circuit court upheld the restraining order and issued a preliminary injunction against the law finding that the language in the case act as drafted was vague and overly broad. The district court issued a stay in April of this year and gave this legislative body until the end of this session to fix the concerns of the court.

This bill makes clarifying changes to Proposition 35 in order to ensure that registered sex offenders who have used the internet to commit sex offenses will be required to provide their online identities to law enforcement. This bill is supported by law enforcement, victim's rights groups, and civil liberties groups and has received unanimous bipartisan support. I urge an aye vote.

SB 1054 provides more direction to the counties about the timing of administrative fee collection from jail inmates and stipulates that only one agency may collect restitution fees. It allows counties to collect direct restitution from offenders instead of the State Franchise Tax Board and it ensures that the administrative fee retained by a county entity, covers the actual cost of collection not to exceed 10% of the total cost.

1054 ensures that our state and county inmate populations are treated fairly while victims are justly compensated. It is supported by a variety of law enforcement organizations in the state and there is no opposition. I urge your aye vote.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. SB 1054 is sponsored by the Los Angeles District Attorneys Office and clarifies the procedures to be used in the collection of the victim restitution fines for different inmate populations, and to clear up ambiguities, and current law after inmates were shifted from the state to the counties with the passage of realignment in 2010.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. SB 1332 will ensure the safety of Californians by creating a safe-keeping program to store a firearm properly when a gun owner leaves their property.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. SB 1332 will ensure the safety of Californians by creating a safe-keeping program to store a firearm properly when a gun owner leaves their property. This bill allows an exception for safekeeping or storage purposes when a firearm is maintained locked or inoperable for a period not to exceed 30 days and requires the Department of

Justice to modify its registration form, so that both spouses and domestic partners may register as the owners of a firearm. According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, about 1.4 million firearms were stolen during household burglaries and other property crimes between 2005 and 2010. And although reports vary, stolen guns may account for roughly

15% of guns used in crimes. Joint registration has been occurring by default, as a result of some local jurisdictions issuing a license to carry to both spouses for the same handgun. Allowing for joint spousal registration in California will bring consistency to law for a practice that is already occurring in the state. This bill seeks to hate a greater
safeguard to prevent guns from falling into the wrong hands, it'll bring consistency to California firearm laws. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you, Madam President, members. I serve on the Senate Public Safety Committee strong supporter of law enforcement, but I was also a strong supporter of this legislation that's before us and I wanted to share some thoughts about that. In my view this bill furthers due process. The Cal Gang database and local gang databases have operated for 30 years in secret. Adults who are on a gang database have no way to know whether they are on that database. And no way to challenge their inclusion. It's very easy to erroneously label someone a gang member. Most people are added to the local database, the Cal gang database, without having been arrested or accused of a crime.

Law enforcement only has to meet two of 10 criteria to determine if a person is connected to a gang. Criteria that makes it extremely difficult in many neighborhoods to avoid designation as a gang member, associate or affiliate. this leads to a very high aerate of people entered into the database. A recent audit by the California State Auditor's office found 42 individuals in the Calgang database who are supposedly under one year of age. At the time of entry. 28 of whom were entered for quote, admitting to being gang members, unquote. Erroneously documented persons are left without recourse and can be left in this database for their entire lifetime whether or not they're involved in a gang.

Thank you, Madam President, I hope you're having a nice day. Assembly Bill 1708 by Assembly Woman Gonzalez will create a minimum penalty for purchasers of sex, 72 hours in the county jail and a fine of either $250 or $1000 depending on the age of the other person. Specific measures in this bill also include some flexibility to accommodate a defendant's work hours to avoid jeopardizing their employment. This bill has received bipartisan support in both the Assembly and the Senate, and I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Thank you, Madame President and members. I joined with my colleague, Berkeley in urging support for this. I want to tell you a pretty story. It's about two years ago, and as a member of the CSU Board of Trustees, we were hearing a report on this issue of mental health and I asked the question, if you were a student in distress and you needed someone to talk to, and on our campuses, what's the wait time to see a counselor and the report came back that the average wait time to see someone that was four weeks. Four weeks at our state universities. I don't know if things have gotten any better, but it was a distressing statistic then, I'm sure it's a distressing one today that for our students who are feeling great anxiety, that we have to be there for them.

And it's important for us to partner not just with our faculty, our administration, but with our student leadership to figure out a way through this because it's a very distressing problem and I appreciate the author's efforts to try to make it better.

Thank you, Madam President. And let me say I'm sure on behalf of many members here, thank you for your wonderful leadership with the floor today, it's been a long day, you've done a great job. Madam President, members, I'm here to present Assembly Bill 2258 on behalf of Assemblywoman Eggman.

It would preclude active bank accounts from unnecessarily transferring property to the state controller's office as unclaimed property. Currently, when a person does not have any live contact with accounts at the single financial institution for three years, the financial institution is required to contact the owner. But if they cannot be contacted, then the amount reverts to the State Controller's office.

This bill allows online banking transactions to count as a person's live contact with the bank, ensuring account holder's property is not unnecessarily transferred to the State Controller's office and curtailing excess notices given to consumers. I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Madam Chair and members, Steve Carlson for the Direct Marketing Association, and for CTIA, the trade Association for the wireless industry. We echo the comments made before. We are neutral with the bill in print, and pending these amendments, we believe that will probably be the case. Thank you.

In my view this bill furthers due process. The Cal Gang database and local gang databases have operated for 30 years in secret. Adults who are on a gang database have no way to know whether they are on that database.

And no way to challenge their inclusion. It's very easy to erroneously label someone a gang member. Most people are added to the local database, the Cal gang database, without having been arrested or accused of a crime.

A recent audit by the California State Auditor's office found 42 individuals in the Calgang database who are supposedly under one year of age. At the time of entry. 28 of whom were entered for quote, admitting to being gang members, end quote.

Erroneously documented persons are left without recourse and can be left in this database for their entire lifetime whether or not they're involved in a gang. Calgain policy requires that individual records be purged five years after their dates of entry but the recent state audit found that more than 600 individuals with purged dates that were well beyond the five year limit.

This bill creates a much needed process for people who are not Currently in a gang, not currently in a gang to request that they be removed from the database. Should a person later be found to meet the criteria for designation as a gang member, this bill does not limit law enforcement's ability to put that individual back in the database. With that colleagues, I urge an aye vote.

Thank you Mr. Speaker. I'm speaking on behalf of support for 197. And really, it is a personal one for me. And unlike my jacket, the disadvantaged community has been ignored in this debate on both sides.

Basically, they ignored me. In 2014, when I started asking the same questions, there were problems that were happening in my district and other places. And when I asked CARB again about what are we doing to improve the quality of life in my community, I was insulted again by CARB who told me, that eventually after we clean up the better areas of the town that air will be cleaner, that land will be cleaner, that water will be cleaner in your area.

That was taken out. But thank God, the Speaker Emeritus then brought it forward and then we passed it, so we can get more people who are actually Impacted by this environment that everyone's talking about, whether it's economics, whether it's health impacts.

They're impacted by it. Reason 197 is good for disadvantaged and for all of us, is begin this process of not only accountability, but even at the expansion, we have somebody at the table or more people at the table that can at least raise their hand and say, what about what's going on in my community?

Not somebody from outside the community, looking over their lofty walls, looking down us, telling us what we should and shouldn't be doing in this debate. But someone that can actually talk to the things that everyone here is talking about, being accountable to disadvantaged communities.

Here I am Mr. Speaker, thank you very much. AB 1577 is back from the Senate for concurrence, I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
Where was the chair on that?

In 2013 when I arrived here both sides bragged about the number of jobs that they were creating. I ask one simple question. How many jobs have people of color on it? Both sides promised they would provide me that information. Both sides provided me maybe one company that was doing well on each side.

Basically we want to clean up the wealthy areas first and then we'll get to you. And then when I had problem with an oil company in my district, where people were getting sick and I ask that oil producer who had a well in backyard to stop polluting and that children were being affected I was told that those were anecdotal stories and I said, I don't think you understand, it is true and it is happening.

Kids are vomiting, they're sick, they can't breathe, they're getting asthma. And I know this for a fact. And again, both CARB, the oil companies, and others said, we can't quite pin down what's going on.

And I said some things, in some words that I cannot repeat on this floor, but basically I said, that individual I'm talking about, is an individual you all know, was my 14-year-old son, who was getting sick, vomiting, because of the oil derelicts in the area.

In my backyard, literally in my backyard. And no one was listening to me. Eventually, they turned it off and they cleaned it up. But it should not have to come from an Assembly person to make that claim. To be able to stop an oil company from polluting.

So again, from both sides, from my perspective in 2015, when I was asked how we would vote on SP32 or SP350, I said I don't know. And I probably was going to lean toward a no vote. People then came to me and spoke to me about it. And for the first time, for the first time, the author of SB32 listen to me.

And started talking about environmental justice and putting someone from my community, from a disadvantaged community on the CARB board. That got taken out. It was taken up again in 350. Again, I was listened to by the author of that bill.

People of color. And so with that, I know I've made some derogatory statements about CARB being the whitest white board I've ever seen in my life. But 197 begins the process of making it fair to everyone in the state. I ask you for an aye vote.
Okay, good, thank you. Any other witnesses in favor?
Good, any other witnesses in favor?

Thank you, Mr. President. And to my fellow Aztec if I had an el bandoneon I would play it today because I know this has been a priority bill and cause of yours for a long time. And I know we all join in appreciation for your good work in this important area.

Thank you Mr. President and members. When you are arrested for a homicide, it's a very serious moment for the accused and certainly for our justice system. In California, we have had in place for a number of years, a requirement that if you're a juvenile, that the interrogation requires that it be videotaped, but that has been not in place for adults, which is what this measure does. The Assembly added some amendments that added exemption and encourages the use of video over audio when available. I want to thank my joint author, the great Senator from West Covina, who bleeds Dodger Blue for joining me in supporting and authoring this legislation.
And I certainly want to thank the Innocence Project, the great work that they do for being the sponsors of this bill and with that, I'd like to ask for an aye vote.
I said the people you're trying to protect are saying no, thank you.

Yeah, my name's Mike West with District Council 16, Painters and Allied Trades. And what I'd like to add with Assembly Member Levine and my colleague Robert Williams is that many people don't realize that the work environment in construction in California is at-will employment, so either you're making money for the company, or you're not.

And sometimes that can be perceived through pressure from your own coworkers or the schedule or the third party entities. So, in some of these cases, it would entail worker feeling like his job might be on the line in face of a layoff, save the company money by waiting until nobody's looking, lift up the containment and blow all the contaminated slag into the bay, or onto the ground below, an environmental crime.

The worst case could be catastrophic failure. Porter Ranch, I-10 freeway collapse, the San Bruno explosion, and the Elk River chemical facility that leached chemicals and contaminated water to 300,000 people out in the east are some examples of preventable corrosion.
Robert Smith, District Council 36, Los Angeles. We urge your aye vote, thank you.

The next thing that could happen is some of the hardest-to-reach areas are the bolted connections. And so, if those aren't treated properly, blasted, and re-coated, some of those connections could fail. Coating's job that should 10 years or longer might have to be recoded in these areas, after just a few years, due to further inspection.

But the final thing, and maybe the most disturbing, is when people would be compelled to forget their person protective equipment, putting themselves at risk, their coworkers, the rest of the workers and even the public. I've personally seen some of this work going on on a walkway within just feet of public women and children going by in strollers.

So with all that, this bill would level the playing field. Everybody would know what the rules and regulations are, and it would create a safer work environment, and also the environmental protections and hopefully no more catastrophic failures in the future. I'd urge an aye vote. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President and members. I want to explain at least my thinking about this issue, because it's easy to be misunderstood. The issue of money in our elections is seriously a problem at all levels and I also concur that I think one of the biggest ways to deal with it is in disclosure and rapid disclosure, and we have that at the state level, that contribution is given over $1000. We have 90 days before the general election, we have to report it within 24 hours and so whether you take that contribution or not, you know that it's going to be disclosed. The challenge we have with these campaign finance reform ideas is the work around and that you can say there's a limit, and then look at what happens with the interests that may want to engage in that election.

They create these independent expenditure committees and then they campaign in a way that you as a candidate, whether they're supporting you or not, you may not agree with, and there's very little accountability for that. So it's a challenging area to try to get your hands around when you realize we need to find ways to do these things better. I don't agree with my colleague from Santa Monica when he suggests that this is a true local control measure, because our local cities and counties, they have the ability to set limits today at any level without this piece of legislation.

If you're unhappy with how your city is handling this issue, well then, go and petition your government and encourage them to establish limits as you think are appropriate, but this answer from the state that we're going to tell everybody they have to take the issue up, to me, is not necessarily a healthy way of trying to deal with the problems that we see it. We may see later today, a bill on this floor that deals with the funneling of money from one Committee to another, and the ability for the voters to discern who's really behind it and another very well-intention bill that I think also has some flaws in it that worries me in terms of moving it forward to the Governor.

So with that, reluctantly, I'm not going to be able to support this bill today, not because I don't think that we have a problem with money in our elections, but because I think that there are ways on which the local government can responsively deal with it if they see it is a problem, and because I think the bigger issue facing the voters is the issue of disclosure, thank you.

Yes. Thank you, Madam President, again I appreciate the thoughtful advocacy by the Senator from the west side, but I thought that the two examples that were used were worthy of a response. Both of them dealt with elected leaders who were actually criminal, they were engaged in conduct that was criminal conduct and certainly that's not anything that I would sanction by indicating this legislation was not the answer that they would suggest. If you have criminal conduct, no laws is necessarily going to stop that from happening. So if someone wants to take a contribution under the table or take a contribution over the limit and fails to disclose it.

Or whatever other shenanigans that might take place, it's not anything that I would ever suggest as appropriate and this legislation will really do nothing to stop that. I know that each of us has to decide this issue of limits from what the state should tell locals to do, and what they should on their own right decide for themselves and I appreciate and respect that we will all define those boundaries in different ways under different issues, but for me, every local jurisdiction today can set their limits at whatever level. The Senator from Agoura Hills indicates that city in her district has set it at a lower amount, that's fine and in larger jurisdictions they may set it at a higher amount.

But is it really up to us to tell them that this is something that they must address. The good government folks, many friends of mine who are the sponsors of this bill could go to every jurisdiction in our districts, and ask them to set limits. We don't need this legislation to do that and that's why I think it's unnecessary.
Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Members, AB 2258 is back from the Senate with concurrence, extending the start date by one year. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Mr. Chair and members, Steve Carlson. I represent a couple of different interests here, I represent the Los Angeles and the Santa Barbara Rental Property Association who have worked very hard with Senator Wolk's staff. And tender organizations to come up with a set of landlord tenant rules that we can live with.

I also represent Conservice that is the second largest company that is the in the business of submetering and billing. And without which these companies, landlords would not do this. Landlords really can't do it on their own and these are the kinds of things that we've been helping out to in other states and we're very, very happy to ask you for an aye vote.

Thank you and if I may add Senator Bates, Steve Carlson. The way that all these have been done, there's plenty of sub-meters been installed. They have to be done by a registered service agent that's going to under the Department of Weights and Measure which is under the Food and Agriculture Department. That has always been the case and that will continue to be the case under this bill. There's no requirement for anything other than that.
Jena Price on behalf of the California League of Conservation Voters in support.

Mr. Chair and members, John White with the Clean Power Campaign. We strongly support this bill for the two principle provisions. First, the fuel cell metering provision, which provides opportunity for customers, such as waste water treatment plans in the universities that have fuel cells to be able sell some excess power back to the grid.

But they only receive the wholesale price, not the retail price that the solar industry get, so it's a more modest incentive but has been very important. Most of the fuel cells are built to size to the load so they're not sized for the purpose of exporting.

This provision is very important to continuing to deploy this technology which has unique value, particularly from a air quality standpoint. We also support the storage expansion, particularly in light of Aliso Canyon. Where we need to expand the use of storage to reduce our dependence on natural gas, we think that provision is also important as well.
Good evening, Melanie Cuevas on behalf of Oak Park Unified School District, also in support.

Rather, we want to do so in a manner that compliments the framework of Assembly Member Chesbro's AB 1826, and that provides reasonable goals and certain timelines. So when the bill was first introduced, we expressed our concerns with this measure to Senator Lara, and he listened to those concerns. SB 1383 provides that 50% goal by 2020 and 75% by 2025.

Importantly, it also authorizes Cal recycle to require local agencies to enforce the program under the AB 939 good faith effort provisions. And it requires an analysis of several factors, including markets, new organics recycling infrastructure, pipeline access and funding.

This measure provides exactly what businesses need, certainty. Certainty about the goals and certainty about the timeframe. And this bill provides us those goals in timelines now, providing us the opportunity to get moving. Without this measure, we will continue to debate this matter and it may be a year or more before we get to some agreement down the road. So, without this bill, it will delay the work that needs to get done. For all of the above reasons, we implore this Committee and the Legislature to get this bill to the governor's desk. We urge your aye vote.
Justin Oldfield with the California Cattlemen's Association, represent California's beef cattle industry, want to thank the author and staff for working with us on the bill. We remove our opposition.

Assembly Member McCarty, I just want to point out that as, since 1990 under AB 939, the State of California, as well as all the local agencies, have been able to achieve the 939 goals not because there's a single formula but because they have to look at what they have to do to accomplish those goals.

And then the local solid waste providers are being asked to do something. And an RFP goes out and that work is bid on. It is competitively bid where Republic Service competes against other companies. We all look to how we can best serve those communities that we either currently serve or wish to serve where we're not providing that service. So there isn't sort of a boiler plate where we can say, this is the formula, this is something that local agencies, along with the solid waste providers in CalRecycle will have to figure out as we go along.
Thank you, Madam President and members.

We don't talk about it very much here on the floor, but we have an extraordinary University system in our great State of California. Over 2 million students going to our community college. Do you know that, if you took all the community college students in the United States, one out of five are going to school right here in California?

That our state University, our 23 campuses are extraordinary in the fine quality education that they provide. One out of every 20 degrees, college degrees in the United States are awarded by our California State University. And it is a system that's acknowledged for its great accessibility, for its great affordability and for it's high quality.

But there is one place in our state universities that, I call it an uncomfortable truth, because it's not something that is talked about much. And that's our level of student success. It actually ranks near the bottom in the country in student success.
Only 19% graduate in four years. 19% graduate in four years. There was a study done by UCLA two years ago about incoming freshmen across the country, and they were asked about a number of things.

And in that survey, 84% expected to graduate in four years, 84%. But if you look at our graduation rate today, it's really an embarrassment. If you sent your student to San Jose state this year, the likelihood that they would get through in four years is about 11%.

And if you sent your student to our great Capital University here in Sacramento, the likelihood that they would finish on time is 9%. If they went to Long Beach State, only 15% get through in four years. If they went to Dominguez Hills, only 5% in four years.
Cal State, Los Angels 6%, Northridge 10%. And the numbers go on and on. Think about where you're from and your University. They went to Bakersfield, only 15% get through
