Cal State East Bay, 14%, Pomona, 18%, Fresno State, only 16% get through in four years. Now, there's a notion that the students that go to the California State University are non-traditional students.
And that explains why, they're not able to complete on time.
And they define non-traditional as a student that has other obligations.

Work obligations, family obligations, things that get in the way of taking a full academic load. And been able to, to get through in these four years but if you look at, a close look at this data proves that its not true. Last year, more than again 400,000 kids in our State universities, last year 87% took a full load of classes 87%.

So, from 12 units or more, so there are not, these are students that do have obligations. No doubt about that, but they are students that are trying to take the classes and trying to get through. Now, think about it for a moment the pathway that each of these students have had to get to our state University.
They had to take the hardest courses in highschool. They had to complete the A- G requirements. They needed to get the grades. They needed the test scores.
They had to graduate in the top third of their class. They had to be college ready in Math and English and then the Holy grail of all. They had to be accepted at one our state universities.
And now, look what's happened after that long path
to a higher education, every year eens of thousands of
these exact students with these exact stories drop out.
And now, [INAUDIBLE] do they drop out, but they drop out, for many, with debt. No degree and higher debt. Is this an absolute tragedy.
They know and we know that college degree is an important wrong on the ladder to economic success.
Yet, for tens of thousands every year its resulted in failure.
Now, there is work being done by the California State University System to get in front of this problem.

And they should be commended for these efforts. They have attempted to identify bottleneck courses and clear them up. They've look at classes with high failure rates to see if new teaching methods can help. They've looked at innovation and technology for online classes to be of assistance.

But mostly friends what I hear is complains about classes simple being unavailable. Many will agree that a critical missing element in our University system is the human touch. The touch between a student and their institution. Many students never see an adviser to chart a path and to monitor that path to students' success.

But we now how important that human touch can be. Friends, there are more human touches on getting a fruit to market, then the risk on advising a student about how to graduate in four years. A fruit is picked by hand, cleaned, sorted, weighed, measured, wrapped, packaged, loaded, unloaded, and displayed.

Some mechanized work, some of it by hand, but that piece of fruit enjoys more guidance than a student enrolled In our University system. And we need to turn that around. So here, we have before us SB 412.

It's called the Promise Program, and what does it provide? It provides a voluntary agreement between the University and the students, voluntary, for those who want to achieve a degree in four years. And in the case of a community college transfer student, it would be a two year agreement.

The student would commit to taking 30 units in an academic year and maintaining a minimum GPA, and the University would provide priority registration, and enhanced academic advising the human touch. This bill that is before you is modeled after some successful pilot programs at Pomona and San Bernardino.

They have resulted in doubling the graduation rate for students in the program that I describe here in SB 412. This bill would be implemented on 15 California State University campuses that accept community college transfers in 2017 and a minimum of 20 campuses in 2018.

And if you are an entering freshman, this program would be implemented at a minimum of eight campuses. The bill prioritizes community college transfers, lower income students, first generation students, and underrepresented minorities. But I'm convinced that everyone will benefit from a more efficient University system.

The bill will be implemented in the Fall of 2017, so the system in the campuses have time to prepare their promise program. If we met the national average and by the way the CSU is 25% below the national average of comparable universities in four year graduation rights. If we met the national average in four year degree program we would

graduate 130,000 more students in the next 10 years, 130,000 more students. Now, if we met our true potential as a University system the California promise along with other innovations, which can be implemented now, would allow us to graduate more than 300,000 additional degrees in the next 10 years. Think about that, 300,000 more students not dropping out of college by climbing a ladder
to middle class success, providing California companies with graduate to fill their growth and expansion and creating a more efficient educational system.
For it is important to note that we need to do more to invest in our higher education system.

Compared to almost every area of government, our higher education investment is substantially lower than it was in 2008. This has resulted in turning away tens of thousands of qualified students, and it also has meant that we are under investing in our faculty. We have fewer tenured faculty in our system today, the heart of every University.

We have great academic leaders who wanted to do better. They have been a little timid in setting real goals because they falsely think that that's how, that's going to be the sole evaluator of their performance. And let me say this since I wrap up members, there have been very few significant high education reforms in the past 10 years.

But let's look back at a couple, most of them led by members here in the Senate. When thousands of our students were discovering that their community college courses were not being accepted as transferable for degrees at the State University, the Legislature stepped in and passed SB 1440 by Senator Padilla in 2010, the Associate Degree for Transfer Measure.

And when student success at the community colleges were underperforming, the Senate led the way in 2012 with the passage of SB 1456 by Senator Lowenthal to provide enhanced support services, mandatory assessment, orientation and education planning. And finally, when economic need for new four-year degrees weren't being met by UC and

the CSU, the Senate, under the leadership of Senator Marty Block, passed in 2014, a pilot four-year degree program at 15 community colleges. So, today the Senate can lead again. With the help of our University presidents, faculty staff, and trustees,

this legislation will open up more pathways to student success and four-year degrees. And finally, Madam President, I have to say as I close that this legislation wouldn't be here today without the support and leadership of our great pro tem from Los Angeles. He has been a true leader in efforts to improve access and

affordability to our universities way before I came on the scene here in the Senate, and I owe a debt of gratitude to him for being a joint author on this measure so it can be heard today. And while I mentioned our great Senator from San Diego, I should also mention our wonderful Senator from Los Angeles who chairs our education Committee. Both of them departing here soon.

For their great leadership in the area of education and higher education. And it was critical to the molding of the bill you have before you. So with that, Madame President, I respectfully ask for an aye vote.
And in response, specifically-
Okay, thank you, Madam President and members.

Thank you for taking the time today to have this discussion about our higher education system and how we can make it more efficient. And one of the interesting things about this bill is while I talked about the underfunding of our University system, there is very little that's required in regard to new money in this legislation. I think it's less than $2 million, because it is about taking our system and trying to make it more efficient, more efficient for everyone.

Because what we do know is that for every extra year that you are in college, according to the Campaign for College Opportunity, it cost an average family about $26,000 more. So where we have these efficiencies in our system at whatever level hurts everybody, whether you're poor, whether you're middle class, wherever you come from. If you can't get through, you're hurt by that.

And so what we have been trying to do in this legislation is create this focus on efficiency without affecting quality, without affecting affordability, without affecting access. And if we are able to create this more efficient system, I think everyone is going to benefit from it. It is true, when we looked at the Pomona program and

the San Bernardino program, the success that came from those programs. And they doubled the graduation rate in those programs, the success was matched by the demographics, the entire demographics of the University. So if you took the demographics of Pomona and you matched that to the graduation rate,

those who were in this four-year program, it matched the success for everyone. It didn't single out any particular group for that success. I am committed to that. I want to make a rising tide raises all votes for everyone that's entering our higher education system.

We know with more money, they can accept more students. But we also know that if the system can be more efficient, it is going to create the spaces that will provide for more admissions for kids from all walks of life of our great state. So in closing, let me thank my friend from West Covina for his

Work through many of those issues. But it's brought to us today, a bill, I think, of great significance for the future of our higher education system, for student success. That's what we're all about, that's what this bill is all about. And with that, I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

I want to thank the good Senator from Long Beach for his leadership on this issue and working through these difficult issues. Members this matter came to light because of a tragedy affecting a Danville parent, the Pack family.

Where two of their children were killed by someone who was abusing prescription drugs. And at this moment, at the verge of the passage of this measure, I think of the Pack family and all that they went through. I'm happy that through the leadership
of our Senator from Long Beach that we have found a Jackson? And I certainly urge its passage today. Thank you.
Thank you very much Mr. Speaker. I rise to present AB 1419 for concurrence it addresses the issue of the CRT glass stock piling. This has a joyed bipartisan support and has no opposition.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. This came through public safety and we had quite a debate on it and we listened to both sides. From my perspective as someone from local government whose always considered about cost recovery on anything that we do. This bill simply allows local government to recover the cost of issuing the CCWs, that's it. If the costs are already covered within their administrative costs that they have right now in their general fund, you may not see an increase and so quite frankly, this is very, very simple. This is about government being able to recover the cost of processing the CCWs. I respectfully, ask for your aye vote.

Thank you, Madam Speaker. AB 2013 is back for concurrence. The bill establishes a pilot project that would, within a group of counties, require a court to issue prompt, probable cause determination hearings for out-of-custody defendants charged with a misdemeanor.

AB 2013 is a modest step forward in enhancing our court's ability to identify and disperse of baseless cases at a early stage for the benefit of both the court system and the litigants. I urge your aye vote.

No, thank you. I'd like to also rise and say goodbye, not goodbye but farewell for now to Shannon Grove. You were the only woman veteran on this floor until Ms. Melendez and I joined you. And then we had a little [UNKNOWN] of three female veterans on this floor.

Clearly, your service to this country, to the State of California, started when you were very young, it's continued on, and I can honestly say I truly believe that you are truly a citizen's representative. You come here representing you district every single day, you do it with passion, you do with conviction, sometimes you even do it with a sense of humor.

I remember when I first arrived, and was talking to you as someone who represents the valley, it can be challenging and we're talking about the issue of per diem and you told me, the first year I was here I didn't take it but then I realized the state was just pocketing it and spending it on something else.

But I didn't want to use it, but I pulled a trailer up here every week to park in a camp ground. And I thought, well that's a frugal person right there who pulls her own trailer to Sacramento, and then the next year she decided she would take the per diem and give it away to people in her district, so the state couldn't waste it in a way that they saw fit.

So I've always enjoyed talking with you, serving alongside you. I don't always understand how you get from A to B, but I know you understand and that's the important point and that your constituents do as well. This body will miss you.

Thank you, when I first got here, as many of us are given different things you need to know to be a good Legislator. And one of them that I've always tried to keep in mind is what epitomizes Rich, is being consistently honest. Having people understand and know where you are, whether it's on a bill, taking a position on a issue, or just where they stand.

Rich has always, always been consistent, when he tells you something you can take it to the bank. And that's one quality that hopefully I will always continue to hold and hold dear. The other thing is being an adult, being an adult among 80 is sometimes not always easy but Rich is always been the adult in the room.

And I appreciate that because sometimes you just have to have mature dialogue on this floor and you represent that to no end. And then finally your quiet strength. Rich doesn't say much, but you know where he stands.

You know what he's doing, and you don't need to hear a whole lot of words from him. He doesn't speak much, but you do know his strength is in his heart. For a long time, I was trying to figure out where those qualities came from and what made Rich, Rich.

Mr. Chairmembers of the Committee, Mark Oprea on behalf of our client, Republic Services, who is a major solid waste service provider in California and across the country. I want to take this opportunity to describe why SB 1383 merits your aye vote. Republic Services has never sought to stand in the way of addressing the issue of short-lived climate pollutants.

Madam Chair, John White with the Clean Power Campaign. We support this bill because the fuel cell net metering and storage expansion are important elements in expanding our clean energy distribution system. The fuel cell net metering will enable projects at universities, wastewater treatment plants, there's a project pending at UC San Diego that will be directly benefiting by this program. We also think that the storage is important because of the impacts of the natural gas leak at Aliso Canyon. This will enable more storage in that local area, and we therefore support the bill.
Shane Levine on behalf of Solar City in support.

Mr. Chairman and members, not in opposition, in support. I missed the beginning of the hearing. My apologies. Robert Harrell, deputy Commissioner with insurance Commissioner Dave Jones in the Department of Insurance. We support the bill.
While not perfect, we think it's a important step forward and we're pleased to continue to work with all our partners in fighting insurance fraud on a going forward basis. Thank you.

Thank you Chair, and I was taken away by some business, so I hope I'm not repeating a question that's already been answered. But, I thought I did hear that this agreement is similar to others that have come before us. When I look at the general compensation salary increase, it's at 554. Is that similar to the other agreements that have come before us because I recall something different.
So, this is 14% and so I guess that would be a little different.

The challenge Mr. Chairman, is that there's no really, a comparison provided in the analysis. I do remember that Bargaining Contract Seven was the last one we heard but I did hear a discussion about places where they needed to provide more increases in order to deal with competitive issues. But I also recall in the discussion that they pointed out that it applied to very few people. Was it 16 or 32?

So, I appreciate the witnesses explanation but it's difficult for us to hear that and then actually be able to make one's own independent judgement about the accuracy or the fairness of that. And that's the challenge that I find with the With what's before us here. This is a 14% over three years in relationship to an eight, yet it somehow all comes out equally.

That's a challenge for me, it may not be for the other Committee Members. The other question I had was on the issue of budgetary costs. They're laid out at the end of this analysis. But it's not explained in regard to whether or not this fits the budget that

we have approved for all the units that we have salary obligations for. So, my next question would be, that do this costs as explained here fit in? Are there other contracts that we may review that are going to be retroactive giving us some sort of an overall budget impact beyond just what happens with this specific unit application.
Where are we on the overall budget, if this contract was to go forward and approved?

Okay, but given the lack of that information in the analysis is difficult for me to understand that. I heard Ms. Costas say just a few minutes ago that our revenue projections are a billion short from what we expect. So, while it may fit some sort of longer range budget projection, again, we're looking for context. I'm sure everybody on this Committee would like to recognize the good work of our employees in this bargaining unit and others. The challenge before us is to balance all these things out.
Because there is a cost and an implication, both on the revenue side and in the expenditure side. And, again, it's challenging to put all that in context for what's being asked of us today.
Jena Price on behalf of the California League of Conservation Voters, we are in support.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. And maybe I'm just missing the point here of SB 1387 where it says, the bill requires that the new members reside in and work directly with communities in the South Coast Air Basin that are among other things disproportionately burdened by and

vulnerable to high-levels of pollution and issues of environmental justice. That's the bill. If you want to talked about local control, I will give you an example of local control and how the air quality can adversely impact that. As the Director of real estate for the City of Los Angeles,

we had properties that we had to take over, because of a mistake by the city. We used general funds to fix it. Then when we tried to recoup that money from the homes we bought, we had to wait years and years and years Because the air quality management group,

especially the bureaucrats there did not feel they had to listen to the City of Los Angeles, the local government and they'd decide when we would sell it. Even though it was a drain on the city budget, it was drain on the Department of Recreation and Parks who had to pay for

that, and it was a drain, because we could not help with the inner city and our lack of resources there, but most important and I know you've heard me say this time and time again about the number of board members that do not reflect people of color. And I know I jest by saying, I've seen some of the whites white boards in

the state on a lot of these commissions and it's not joke. People in disadvantaged communities who live by freeways, they may not understand what GHG means. They may not understand all these fancy environmental words are, but they do understand when their child has asthma.

They do understand when their child gets sick from the air that they breathe. They do understand when their kids can't go to school everyday. They do understand when their kids can't play in the playground, because of the bad air quality. And then when they make complaints to the bureaucrats or

when they make complaints to the board, it falls on deaf ears. This bill is about being able to talk to people who do not have the money, the resources or the time to fight with people who are elected or appointed at this board.

It is time we make this board representative of people who actually live in that area, who actually are impacted by what goes on with the air in Southern California. But most important, we need to have some compassion. We need to be able to move this bill on and do the right thing. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Mr. Wagner, as someone who's sat behind you when I first got here, and probably as someone who you've never voted yes on any of my bills, what I loved about sitting in back of you is I knew I had to be prepared.

So I studied my bills like you would, I mean I went over it again and again and again, because Mr. Wagner might ask you a question. And not only would it be a good question, not only would it be professional, my golly, it would be hard.

And you'd have to be on your Ps and Qs every time. But the thing that I admired about him the most, especially when I first got here as a freshman, he looked back, he came to me and said, I'm against your bill, I'm sorry, he turned and went back, yeah, and I'm going to speak on it and talk really bad about it.

That's the kind of professionalism that I've received in this chamber, and you don't know how much I appreciated it. In fact even, I was sandwiched between him and Ms. Melendez so I was always getting ping-ponged back and forth between the two.

But I stood firm in my belief and I think one time, one time, Mr. Wagner came back and said, you had a pretty good response. On that day, I knew I was a member of this Assembly. I knew I had made my bones. And I knew I was qualified to be here. Thank you, Mr. Wagner.

Steve Walker on behalf of the Alameda and Contra Costa Transit District and The Center of Transportation and the Environment. We also support SB 830, particularly the appropriation to car for low carbon transportation. The $150 million that's in there for heavy duty vehicle investments will go a long way towards the commercialization of zero emission buses. Thanks.

Thank you, David Munez, Department of Finance. Good question. So when the administration bargains with the various bargaining units, we always take a look at their individual issues and problems that we're trying to solve. And as our state salary survey that the Department of Human Resources performs every year,

what you all find is that our state attorneys in general have about 35% salary lag as we look at federal local agencies and the private sector. While this particular contract doesn't completely close that salary lag, we are wanting to make a modest step forward to addressing that issue.

The second point I'd like to make about that is when you look at the Bargaining Unit 2 contract as it compares to Bargaining Unit 7 in your example, there's a lot other things in the Bargaining Unit 7 besides just a general salary increase. They had some pretty significant issues with some of their classifications in which

we had to use resources to fix those, such as their ABC agents and other investigators. So, if you look at both contracts, kind of in aggregate, you would see that It's a lot closer in terms of value when you consider all of the other things that were included in Bargaining Unit 7.
Thank you Madame Speaker and Members. This is a bill back from concurrence that deals with psychosis and mental health in young children. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
Seeing no discussion the clerk will open the roll. All those vote who desire to vote. All those vote who desire to vote. All those vote who desire to vote.

Good afternoon Madam Speaker and members. I am here to speak on 1114, a bill that expanded the ability of pharmacists to prescribe things last year but we neglected to create a path for MediCal to be able to pay for that. So this fixes that, and I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

I too, have known Mike for quite a while, and I knew Mike with the Democratic Party, as secretary of the Democratic Party. I knew a lot of activists. And I shown you Mike's dad who Mike kind of, we all just worked on Democratic politic things for quite some time. And his dad was a great Democrat. And then I got here and found out that Mike was not so much a great Democrat. So I call him Dr. No, my aisle mate here because he votes no quite a bit on the floor.

And whenever any of my bills come up, I always gotta hear, so which Charles Manson family are we letting out with this bill now? So, he's always giving me a hard time. And I'm always giving him a hard time. And even when he was with the Approps chair, we battled like many if us in this room, battled a lot on whether or not he changed our bills or whether or not it didn't get through.

It was a magical mystery tour going through the Assembly Approps at that time. It wasn't until I got to really know Mike, one day, as some of us do, we go and have kind of a Bible study on Wednesday morning. And one morning, I kind of go down and there's no one in the room and there's a note on the door, go to this other room. So I go to the other room and I walk in, it's the pastor, and it's Mike.

So I wasn't sure if I was in the wrong heaven or what, but I looked, and Mike was there with his Bible and he was reading it. And we spent about 45 minutes, and I learned more about Mike in those 45 minutes kind of talking through some Bible verses and things of that nature, I learned more about his love of his family, and of his father, and his love of this Capitol, love of what we do here.

And that he genuinely, genuinely has not only a good heart but a great heart at what we do here. And even though I may disagree, I know that it didn't come from a place that I thought was not good, it really was from a good place. And if I had not stumbled into that room that day, I probably wouldn't have been able to change my mind about Mike.

And I think this year, probably the first year he ever voted yes for one of my bills, and I think I attribute it to the fact that we actually got to know one another. And we actually got to know where out true heart is. So I wish you luck, wherever you go. And hopefully you keep in touch because you know you're the line of the Assembly right now. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I also rise in support of this. I want to also thank the speaker and thank the administration and everybody else who's really come together, I think, to recognize. There's a lot of things in here, but the part about really working to save our forest is just imperative. When we finish tomorrow, some time today, perhaps, I'm going to head to the Sierras where I always kind of find my spot.

And I can look at part of those 70 million dying, dead trees and say, we're not going to throw you away like a hot potato that we're going to do what we need to do to save our forests. And also those of us who serve in the valley and have ag districts and people are starting to do open burns and fields again. That's not good for the environment.

But when we shut our biomass plants down, that's what happens. So, this is the kind of, I think, investment that is truly bipartisan, that we can all come together and say we are doing good things for California. And I strongly urge an aye vote on this.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker and members. I also rise today in support of SB 1383. I was a chair of Ag for two years, my first two years here. And one of the big issues that we worked on was milk pricing. Now, I don't know if you've seen a complicated thing before in your life.

But if you haven't seen dairy milk pricing, you haven't seen it. Did you know the price of our milk by the mercantile in Chicago on the price of cheddar? So we in California really have no way to set our own milk prices. It's what the market bears, and we are in competition with Wisconsin, and
Idaho, and Pennsylvania, as well as the rest of the world. Now, I happen to like milk. I happen to like cheese very much. Not that there's anything wrong with soy cheese, but I prefer real cheese.

And if we want our milk and dairy industry to be able to continue, we need to be able to enact smart policies. So currently, last week, we voted for SB 32, which would give CARB the unmitigated ability to regulate diaries and methane.

Now, if you think that's okay, members, then please vote no on this bill. But Gary has come to the table, the firm industry has come to the table to say, okay, we'll do this, but let's make a pass, so we can do it in a way that we can set some of the guide posts.

We can figure out a way to do it that can be done without it just being forced down on us. That's what's happened. And you can't drive down by a freeway, by a dairy, and not smell it and not know we should probably do something. So what has happened is that the industry has come together with Mr. Lara.

I've been involved in negotiations as well to be able to figure out a path. SB 1383 is that path. If you care about agriculture in the State of California, and we talked a lot about agriculture on this floor this week, members, and talked about its health.

But I can tell you, the numbers just came out this week, egg industry in California is down $10 billion this year. $10 billion, we've lost out of the agricultural industry in this last year. So giving CARB the unmitigated ability to regulate dairies, to make these reductions, if you think that's okay, vote no.

But if you think that dairy should be able to have a voice in their own future, about their willing to do it, but to give them time, to give them resources, to give them a path. Then I ask you members to join me in voting yes on SB 1383 to be able to save our dairy economy in this state and to continue to have cleaner air and make sure that we all remain healthy.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker, and as we all know, my doctorate is a PhD, not an MD, so I can't speak with the same authority as my colleague from Fresno. But I will say we don't practice medicine in this house, we pass laws. And so we talk about doing no harm. We need to expand our scope in how we think about that, I think. As my colleague said, there are nine

Currently physicians do not have to be standing by supervising. They just have to have a supervisual relationship. So think about that in our nine counties where there is not an OBGYN, who is there to help with the babies? It's often the certified nurse mid-wives who often times can't do that without the Doctor's supervision.

And if there's not one there, then what happens? So members I ask you as we think about providing care all throughout California and especially some of our poor places that aren't drawing hospitals in this, in the physicians in the same kinds of ways that we allow people to work to the highest degree of their, we're not asking for any expansion of scope.

They are doing the same work that they have always done, but they are just being untethered from the supervision of a physician and continuing to do the same work they have done. Again, we are only one of a very few states that don't already allow this in the way that we do, and I think it's time for us to really think about how do we expand healthcare.
Especially for women health care, poor women health care all across this state, and I respectfully ask for your Aye vote. Members, let's do no harm.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I rise as, our district's touch. We are two women who represent the Central Valley from different parties. And so people often think that we come from very different backgrounds and we do. I'm Latina, she's not. She's a mother, I am, but we've come to it in very different ways. But the ways in which we serve are so similar because our values and our hearts and

our beliefs are from the same shared fabric of hard work. And believing in people and standing up for what we believe is right not matter from the right or from the left who tell us that we're wrong. We believe that we touched the people that we represent.

And my belief has always been, if we want to serve the people, we have to know the people. And I think Kristin represents her in the way that I hope I do. She's been here longer than I am, but I am glad to follow in her footsteps. And as she moves away from San Joaquin county in her new role,

I hope that we continue to join each other in our shared values of hard work and making California the best state in the nation, as we know it is, and as we continue to help all families rise in whatever form they take to be the best that they can be.

We just want to say to you- Toni Atkins, we know you love God. We know you love gospel. We know you love this building. We couldn't think of a better way to tribute you than to honor your faith, your service. You have demonstrated hope and grace, and love, in a way that few people have.

And we could think of no better way to tribute you than to sing a little bit of gospel and to honor you as you have honored all of us with your service to the State of California and to our Lord. Amen. Amen.
Senate amendments reduced both the size of the pilot from five counties to three, and it's allotted time frame from five years to three years.

Obviously it's his family, his upbringing, but one day we were talking and he told me that he was a Trojan, University of Southern California, fight on. And as the unofficial chair of the Trojan Caucus we will miss you, we will miss you dearly.

And hopefully on one of these Saturday afternoons when you're down in Los Angeles, you can come by my office and we're having a home game. We can go both toast you, Denny, and your career, fight on brother.

Thank you, Madam President. I certainly wanted to provide a bipartisan point of support for our good Senator from Orange County for bringing this issue to our attention. It was great to meet her the other day when she was here and I appreciate you taking up the cause, the important cause that your resolution so identifies. I'm certainly happy to support it.
Yeah, I found a couple cards on the ground, one says L Baracho, and one says La Calavera. If you've lost these cards, I have them here.
Questions to the presiding officer. I'm not following the process that we're going through now. Could you explain where we are, and how we're proceeding, please?

There have been some explanations that matters will stay on call as issues get worked out. What you're saying to me is if those commitments had been made, they're irrelevant now. You're going to go through the roll call on each one, and close the votes. So that's the clarification that's a different clarification than I expected but I appreciate you providing it.

Thank you. This may surprise members of the Senate, but when I was elected to the Senate in May of 2015, the first member of the Senate to call and congratulate me was Bob Huff. And in that conversation, you talked about your willingness to welcome to the Senate, willingness to partner in things where we could agree.

And in fact, the first two of my most significant bills that I introduced, I stopped by your office and asked what you thought of them. And you gave me your feedback and you agreed to cosponsor both of those with me. I'm very grateful for that. Grateful for your willingness to cross the aisle and look for ways to work together. Thank you for your service.

Members, has anybody seen Isadore? Isadore, where are you? Jesus! Check the lunchroom. Check the well. Where is Isadore? God, that guy, he moves faster than anybody I know. Hey! My God! He's sitting down. I though you'd forgotten your seat. My God, it's so good to see you here.

It's a bitter sweet moment for me. I'm the newest kid on the red carpet, as some of my friends like to remind me, more often than I would like. But I got the last seat. Now, I don't understand why the last seat in the house was this seat. What were they thinking? I know what Pro Tem was thinking about Ricardo coming over here, but, really? Nobody wanted to sit with Isadore?

And you know what? No one whispered in my ear, hey, this is what you should know about Isadore. I got no tips from anybody, on either side of the aisle. Bob Huff is not helping me. He called me first but he wasn't helping me on this one. He was sitting next to Isadore. You know what that means.
Well, ebony and ivory.

We're like brothers. People don't know this, but Isadore says you are a brother from a different mother. And I love that, my friend brother Isadore. It's a bittersweet moment for me, because you've been a great mentor to me. I don't know if Kevin intended this or not. You're shaking your head, or no? He's not saying anything. I don't know if he intended it or not.

But Isadore, I had a lot of questions didn't I? I was trying to figure things out, and I wanted to make the right moves. And I wasn't sure whether I should be getting advice from you. But you were all I had. So I took advantage of it, and you were fantastic.

You gave me a lot of wonderful advice. For example, I know now that occasionally, this happened in public safety with our wonderful Senator Hancock, where there was a point in time where there was nobody there to chair the meeting because everybody was covering other bills. And they would give the gavel to me.

It's like I knew what I was doing. But I have studied Isadore's chairmanship very, very closely. As I know many of you have, as well. And so you may say if I get the opportunity to have the gavel, that was Isadore.

So one of my favorite Isadores is to say after the Senator or the Assembly Member, and this happens a lot more with Assembly members, I noticed Presents there as Isadore would say and now I'm practicing, I would say family member, your bill enjoys the support of the chair.

So I would suggest you guide your witnesses in regard to their testimony going forward. I love that. We all understood what that meant and I'm going to try to follow that wonderful guidance that Isadore has given me in sharing committees.

You know that if I did anything right in my first year and a half here, it was because of my good friend Isadore Hall's guidance. And if I did anything wrong and there might have been a few missteps, it had nothing to do with Isadore. You have full deniability my friend on all those things. Isadore's immediately agreed to co sponsor two of my earliest bills on the confederacy, name on public places and we jointly author the bullet button billed together, and that was a real tribute.

It wasn't such an easy street because there was a lot of hate that came our way, and I always could turn to my brother, Isadore, to see what kind of hate was coming his way and commiserate about that. And it was very supportive. Environment that you provided to me.

When you carry a tough bill, not everybody's happy and everybody has their own way of expressing it. But when you have Isadore at your back, you know you're in a really good spot. I loved our bowtie Thursdays. That was pretty fun. Yeah, my vote size ready to come out.

You're not going to be here. I don't want to forward, but I'm going to try to keep it going, my friend. Nobody has more style on this floor than my brother, Isadore Hall. Is that true, folks? Come on, you can clap now. No better style. No better grace than Senator Leno. No better style than Isadore Hall. Amen to that. I'll tell you what though, to put all the fun aside,

the thing that I will always remember about Isadore is that when it came to district issues that warm smile, that wonderful embrace that I'm going to miss so much is gone. He is one tough cookie when he is fighting for his district and they're going to have no better fighter for them than Isadore Hall in our great capital in Washington DC. So, he is a guy you want in his corner.

I love his warmth and affection, it's contagious. I love that fighting spirit when it comes to representing the people and getting things done for your district. I'm going to miss this guy, I'll miss you brother Hall.
Thank you, Madam Chairman.
So a challenge for all of us now, it's late in the evening and
we're getting stuff that we haven't had a chance to look at very carefully and review.
And that certainly applies to this bill as well.
I guess I'd like to ask how long as this, I guess questions to the author if I may.
So how long has these Amendments been out in prints?
We just got them a couple minutes ago.
Okay, so the challenge for all of us.
Okay, so the challenge is, and I mean this with all respect, but there's a lot of people that have an interest in this subject matter and
what is our ability to have their input to the deliberations that we're having now?
Well, certainly this affects almost every city in California, right. This applies to every city. So I don't know how many cities we have, but there's a lot.
So for example the league of cities. The league of cities. They had a chance to take a look at the bill? Yes.
And do they have a thought you could share?
I believe that the league of cities is neutral on the bill.
Are there any cities that are in opposition to the bill? Have you heard of other input from any other city?
And, has there been a cost estimate of what this bill would cost cities to implement this?
Do you have any sense of that?

Thank you, Madam President and members. I also reluctantly rise in opposition to this bill. I also appreciate the great work of our part time faculty, they are critical to our community colleges and our state universities. They're the ones that are more responsive to the changing interest of students. The ability to teach courses that kids want.

It's going to put those monies at risk if a community college district doesn't do what they can happen today. That there can be unionization, there can be collective bargaining in every one of these community college districts for part time faculty. We don't need this legislation to do that. But the analysis goes on to say that the laws of the SSS fee funds could be costly.

Specially given the significant investment state was made with these funds to implement strategies, to incentivize successful student behaviors. And they conclude by saying that this measure will dilute these funds which are intended for critical academic support services for students. So with that, I would reluctantly encourage a no vote.
Let's go Mr. Wilk, next, and then Miss Gonzales.

counties in this state that don't have an OB/GYN. Certified midwives, for decades, have been doing this kind of work in a safe way, with the same kinds of outcomes. The story that was just told about about the baby being born in a pool of blood was done by a GYN. So I'm not sure, it seems to me that a nurse midwife practicing in a same hospital arena as

an MD, who has the same level of support around them. Again members this, the outcomes have been studied across the country. There are no difference in outcomes of safety. The idea that mid wives are only giving birth at home is erroneous. They are also giving birth in the hospital. The same level of practice as anybody else.
All right, are there anybody else in opposition? All right.  Assemblyman, I want to give you the chance to respond to some of the concerns that have been raised.
Commenting on a bill is different than trying to construct, deconstructive and molding it and changing it to way you think it workable and resolves a lot of the issues that you have raised.

If you support state licensing and you think that there is some conflicts or overlaps, you need language to be proposed for him to consider, because none of us like this situation that we're in at this moment under deadline pressure with an inability to change this bill without killing it and then to hear that there was an offer made to consider changes. And yet, there were none forthcoming.

I think it was a missed opportunity. Assemblyman Stone, we've talked about what the feds may do that can create potential conflicts and I understand that and I understand how you want to handle it next year, but there are some other concerns that worry me a little bit in terms of existing rules being in conflict.

And I think about this in terms of the student's point of view, which again, you're deserving a great praise for trying to protect the students who are borrowers and are making sure that this is really all about them and how we can be sure that they can fulfill their obligations in a fair manner not be exploited.

One of them deals with when, if the conflict in your bill could set up a situation where a borrower has to send their payments to different parties and that the bills's requirements regarding the timing and content of the required notifications differ with federal regulation.
You don't necessarily have control over that right? That's them-

And I would hate to see your efforts lose a year, and lose at least a framework or a structure that you will then work within, and we will work within, to improve in the course of the next 18 months, before it goes into effect.

There's certainly, is a changing environment. But we are dealing with a very important function that goes on in our state that affects a lot of kids due to the many loans that are out there. I worry mostly about the confusion to the students and the borrowers.

That's the last thing we really want to do is to create that confusion for them. They're the most vulnerable to that, that problem. But I find myself being convinced by you that it's better to move now to create a framework to get the regulatory side focused on how to make it work.
I appreciate your flexibility and willingness to adjust and modify next year as this thing goes forward and we see what the feds are doing.
Purely coincidental. Welcome.
All right, we have one more bill on call. It's Assembly Bill 2251 by Stone. Chair is aye, the Vice-Chair is no, the current vote is 4 votes in favor, 2 votes against. Would you call the roll please?
Madame President, for purposes of lost and found.
So your intentions are to go through every bill on call and then close the roll on each of those bills?

Mr. Chair and members, Rand Martin, on behalf of the AIDS Healthcare Foundation. In respect to your admonition not to discuss Prop 61, let me start, on November 9th, the day after the election. Things will either be exactly the same or they will change dramatically. And we urge the Legislature, looking at the results on November 8th, to help guide it as it goes froward. We really appreciate your commitment to this isssue Mr. Chair and the fact that you're having additional hearings on this is a very promising sign.

But on November 9th, you may be given direction by the people of California. We urge this Committee and the Legislature as a whole to make sure that the State of California implements the will of the voters in as aggressive and a robust manner as possible, to insure that it's done with integrity and to provide tools to the State to implement the direction of the voters, effectively.

If the voters do not send any direction to the Legislature, the reality is this is not an issue that's going away. Kaiser Family Foundation issued a survey last week, said 74% of Americans think that this is the number one issue. 63% of Americans think that government needs to take action to lower drug prices. Those numbers are similar to numbers in California as well.

So it's an issue that the voters care about, and the voters would like to see the Legislature do something. So this is the beginning, Mr. Chair, and thank you again, to address this issue. We stand ready to work with you however November 8th turns out from the Oval Office on down relative to this issue and make sure that this is fixed once and for all. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. Chair and members, Nick Louizos on behalf of the California Association of Health Plans. Thank you, Mr. Chair, for holding this hearing on a very important topic. I wasn't going to say anything, but we did hear some very interesting testimony from a representative from one of the drug companies. Much of it was a deflection on everyone, including my trade Association members and much of that was also incompatible with the rigorous body of federal and state law that governs this area.

Particularly, copay limitations, benefit design rules, and the inability of plans and insures to change premiums or benefit structure throughout the policy year. Drug companies, of course, are allowed to increase their prices many times throughout the year. But in any case, we do look forward to a future hearing or our direct conversations with you to just respond to that presentation of reality, thank you.

Welcome to the front of the room my colleague from the Assembly, Chairman Matt Debabneh. Chair of the Assembly Banking and Finance Committee held a hearing earlier this year. Actually last month, which was very informative and Chairman Debabneh it's great to have you here.

I want to thank everyone who is in attendance this morning, especially the witnesses who have agreed to make a special trip here after the Thanksgiving holiday. I appreciate that, the extra effort to be a part of this hearing. I want to say from the onset that I have great appreciation for Wells Fargo's place in California's history, and for the vital role that they have played in our commerce and our economy.

Wells iconic stagecoach takes us back to a time when banks were held in high esteem and trust. Yet, here we are today wondering how one of the nation's great banks has come to such disgrace, how it failed its most priced asset, its customers. Wells Fargo set up an incentivized system of rewards and punishments through its staff at every level.

This pressure led to the creation of phony accounts, and illicit fees being charged to customers on a massive scale. This affected up to 2 million accounts. Nearly 900,000 in California alone. The financial cost to consumers was in the millions of dollars, but the loss in trust is untold.

The financial meltdown of 2008 showed us that when we lose trust in our banks, our economy moves towards the presuppose. Wells Fargo's actions go way beyond a few rogue employees and customer accounts.

The scale of abuse strikes at the heart of the public's ability to trust this bank and the banking system. I want to make it clear to you that I was not set on holding a hearing today. Especially after Assembly Banking and Finance chaired by Mr. Debabneh held his, but my questions for Wells Fargo still have not been adequately answered.

In fact they've fallen well short of the accountability that the public expects. As Chairman of the Senate Banking and Financial Institutions Committee, I have a responsibility to ensure that we have clarity on what happened, how deep the problem, who's responsible beyond the CEO who resigned under pressure and the 5300 employees who were fired.

And whether the changes that Wells Fargo has made are truly reformative, were just band aids to make the public relations problem to go away. So I'm here seeking answers to questions that Wells Fargo has yet to address, even during the September congressional hearings.

I did meet with Wells Fargo personally about six weeks ago. And I ask them the questions that everyone is asking, customers, regulators, law makers. Why did employees knowingly falsify customer counts? Who knew about it and when?

What actions were taken to hold those responsible? What did the board of directors know and what actions did they take? Why was there a failure to disclose material problems to customers regulators and investors? And why when all the information points to a breakdown in ethics by the management chain of the bank?

Did the directors appoint a Wells Insider to oversee the current investigation disclosure and repair? Despite follow-up correspondence between the bank and me, much of which is released in the Committee staff report, I remain dissatisfied on every material question. The bank has failed to provide complete information.

Let me address some of these questions in more detail. A Senior Vice President of the bank told me that he had no idea why so many employees at the bank cheated people, he pointed to sales incentives as a possible cause of the problem and reviewed the gradual elimination of sales goals. As a way to clean it up.

But he could point to no hard data collected by the bank to precisely identify why the chain of command within the bank failed to stop the abuse. The bank has made it clear that they knew there was a problem as early as 2011. But despite this information, and so called continued reforms including the creation of a sales and service oversight team in 2013.

Wells Fargo officials admit the reforms were ineffective but they still act as if they did enough to absolve themselves. In dense CEO stumps to remark to Congress in September, he gave every impression that the fraudulent behavior was predominantly by individuals at low levels within the bank and not part of a wider culture.

He acknowledged that some of the managers were involved but gave very few specifics. That tactic had obvious benefits. If managers of the bank cooperated or colluded in the fraud. Then the problems would touch much closer to the leadership and culture of the bank.

After my Senate Banking Committee staff and I pushed for more specific answers, we now have additional information about the extent of the scandal, and it clearly touches management staff. In response to our first round of questions, Wells now says, that more than 480 managers were fired in the last five years due to sales practice violations.

We're told these individuals were branch managers and above. This disclosure that 480 highly trained and competent leaders of the bank, engaged in this misconduct is deeply troubling. In it's written response to the United States Senate Committee on banking, housing and urban affairs, Wells shows that it employed 5,816 store managers.

We refer to them as branch managers. As of September 1st, 2016. The firing of 480 persons with the rank of manager and above seems to represent a breakdown of fair and honest dealing at an extraordinary scale.

And keep in mind that these are the only ones whose conduct Wells thought constituted a firing offense. We don't know what other conduct Wells excused by other leaders of the company. And I want to reference a submittal to Congress just a few weeks ago on page 44, in this regard.

And Wells said this in their submittal. Just one second here. So on page 44, they said this. The termination over the last five years have included 483 managers up to three levels above bankers and tellers. When investigators have found that managers engaged in or directed improper sales practices, or exhibited excessive pressure.

And then here's an important copy out that they included. And did not respond properly and decisively to change their behavior. So they fired 483 managers who directed or engaged in improper sales practices but they didn't fire additional individuals, who, perhaps, apologized for that conduct.

Basically, making the point that there are still people employed at high levels of Wells Fargo that did engage and direct this type of illegal activity. Now, I want to acknowledge that after Wells Fargo entered into a settlement agreement, with local and federal regulators, they've taken a number of important actions.

They retained an outside accounting firm to audit all of their accounts to identify and fully reimburse every customer for any fee associated with an unauthorized account. They have agreed to make whole any customer who might have had credit problems due to an unauthorized account.

They've also pledged to eliminate sales based incentive compensation goals for employees within their consumer banking arm. Additionally, Wells Fargo board of directors has taken some action to claw back executive pay and they've also announced their own investigation into some of these issues, which they claim will be lead by independent directors.

Clearly, one of the big disappointments of this entire scandal is the lack of responsible oversight by Wells Fargo's board of directors. I've asked Wells to detail actions by the board of directors who root out this problem. They've come forward with zero information.

How could a board of such distinguished individuals failed to monitor and hold management accountable for such a wide ranging scandal? One of my goals is to have Wells Fargo acknowledge the extent of the problem, to come clean on how pervasive that scheme was, that it was not a handful of renegade lower-level bankers going rogue to book unsuspecting customers.

This appears to have been company culture, an atmosphere of greed pushed from the top. And Wells Fargo must provide a blueprint on how it expects to clean it up. It's the only way to do right by its customers, but also to regain the trust of the public that is foundational to the existence of banks and financial institutions. Before i call up our first witness, I want to address the absence of Wells Fargo today.

Your agenda shows Wells Fargo President and CEO Tim Sloan as an invited witness. It does not show that Wells Fargo has declined this invitation. I opted to leave Wells Fargo on the agenda to give them the opportunity to change their minds and I hope that they would. If Mr. Sloan is here I'd like him to, I'd like to invite him to join us now at the witness table.

I checked with the Senate Historian a few minutes ago and I asked the question, when was the last time that a company refused to participate in an oversight hearing of the Senate? And the answer was the last company that refused to do that was Enron.

It's sad to see Wells Fargo join this elite hall of shame. Trust and honest dealings are fundamental principals in our financial services industry. It's our job as representatives of the people to ensure that those trusted with the public's money are accountable for adhering to the highest standards of conduct.

We need Wells to own up to their shortcomings. Their unwillingness to stand before this Committee is a sign of bad faith with their customers, and all of California. I know that my colleagues in the California Legislature will not be deterred by the banks duck and hide behavior as we seek answers at this hearing and at future hearings.

Who could imagine that a bank that represented the values of honesty and fair dealings for more than 160 years in California would now become an outlaw institution? With that I'd like to invite my colleague in the Assembly, Chairman of the banking Committee Chairman Dababneh, to make any opening remarks.

Thank you Chair Debabneh. So I'd like to invite Michael Bostrom, the Managing Assistant City Attorney, from the Affirmative Litigation Division Office of Los Angeles City, Attorney Mike Feuer to come join us with this table, thank you. Michael, Mr. Bostrom thank you very much for being here.

Thank you. Mr Bostrom, thank you so much for being here. And thank you, and your Boss, the City Attorney Feuer, for such good work in trying to get to the bottom of these problems. I wanted to ask a couple of follow up questions if I may.

You talked about the process that you went through in your investigations. Can you put some time to that? Actual date stamp some of those steps so I could be clearer, and we could be clearer about when you began, when you initiated your litigation, etc.
Does that mean that you didn't inform Wells Fargo of your investigation? They weren't aware of it at that time?
So, when did Wells Fargo become aware of your investigations?
So in 2015, you filed a lawsuit against Wells Fargo and you think that was the first time in which they became aware of your inquiry?

So Wells Fargo, they never in any of their SEC filings provided information of that investigation that was taking place. They determined that it wasn't considered to be material. Do you have any thoughts about that?
And did you find after you filed your lawsuit that Wells Fargo became cooperative in providing additional information about what had happened, from their point of view?
And do you have any observations through the work that you did about how far into the hierarchy of Wells Fargo this problem existed?
And did you use that in any judgements that you made in terms of what the appropriate fine that was put in effect in this case?
So your point there regarded the email contact was that there was a flashing red light that was easily seen by people throughout the organization in terms of the setting up of these accounts?
That they provided? So they had it in their possession, and this is in the 2015 timeframe?
So, why is it that you in the settlement that you agreed to that Wells Fargo avoided an admission of guilt?
Okay, there's been some questions raised about these sales practices in the retail bank, but there are incentive programs throughout the bank in other areas. Did you look at that at all?

So the fact that you didn't come forth with any charges doesn't mean that was, the fact that they didn't exist, it's just you simply didn't look into them to know whether those problems existed in other places?
Good, thank you. Chairman Dababneh, do you have any questions?
Senator Galgiani, welcome.

Yeah, that's a good question, Senator, and I don't know the answer to it. I do know that, and if Wells was here, they would testify to the fact that they significantly reduced their incentive program over the course of the last five years. And yet, it still didn't seem to change the problems of fraud that continued to go on in the bank.

But I don't know the broader question about the industry. Mm-hm, okay. There may be people here representing the financial world that would come under public testimony, could provide some clarification about it if they have some knowledge of that.
Any other questions from? You're good? Okay, Chairman Debabneh?

Thank you, any other questions? Mr. Bostrom, thank you again for taking the time to come up here. Thanks for all your good work.  Appreciate it very much. For those members of the public that are here, there are some additional information packets that have been placed on the desk here in the front if you'd like additional background for this hearing.

Our panel number two incorporates a number of distinguished individuals that I'd like to invite to come and join us today. Aeisha Mastagni, who is the Portfolio Manager, corporate governance California State Teachers Retirement System, welcome. Steve Juarez, the Deputy Treasurer, economic development and higher education policy.

Thank you, Ms. Mastagni. A couple follow up questions, you've raised this issue of unnecessary incentives, or incentives that can create too much pressure.  Do you have any sense of that in regards to Wells Fargo here in terms of whether their incentives have been set at the right place?
Thank you and do you recall what Wells Fargo's response was to your concern about KMPG being retained as an Auditor for 85 years at that company.
And do you know of other examples in the financial services industry where you have an Auditor retained for that long period of time?
And we appreciate you doing that. You mentioned the issue of being over boarded and you only mentioned the CEO as one example. Are there other examples on the The Wells Fargo Board?

Great, thank you for sharing that. In judging the effectiveness of a board, it's hard for us in the public space, because we're not sitting there in the room and these discussions for the most part, happen in private. So it's a challenging way to evaluate.

I guess that when you see a train crash, you start looking closely at who are the conductors. But until that point in time, you don't really know whether that oversight is appropriate. And it's part of the challenge that you have as a big investor and we all have as a public oversight group.

I'm going to ask you to get out of your comfort zone perhaps on this question, and I would understand it if you want to defer. But given the information that's come out regarding the extent of this scandal, of this fraud, the numbers being so high, 5,300 employees fired including 480 managers.

We are not presently aware of any document, any document or instance, prior to the settlement with the CFPB, that informed the Board of the total number of employees who had been terminated for misconduct relating to improper sales practices.

And Wells Fargo has previously testified that of those 5,300, they were firing about 1,000 a year, over the course of five years. And they have not provided the information showing the timeline of the firing of the management levels or above, so that's unclear.

But given that volume of terminations for unethical sales practices, does it surprise you that they never provided the board with any document, or as they say, instance, informing them of the extent of this problem?

And the board has said they're engaging in their so-called independent review. Do you have any observations about what would give us confidence in you as a a major investor, confidence that an independent review has been properly carried out?
Great, thank you. Any other questions from our panel members? Assemblyman Dababneh.
And you sit on the board on behalf of the treasurer of CalSTRS and CalFirst as well.

Mr. Schaefer, Mr. Juarez thank you both for being here. One follow-up question if I may to, I think it might be best to Mr. Shaffer you talked about the sanctions. And you provided a summary of the examples in which California has Wells Fargo securities or has used Wells Fargo as an underwriter.
Do you have a sense of the scope of that service that work that Wells Fargo does for other public agencies in California?

So I, and I don't mean to understate the financial impact of a California has done under the leadership of Treasurer Chiang. I was only trying to understand whether or not, while we've seen some individual entities act on their own, has the treasury given any consideration to communicating with the vast array of public entities that do exist in California, that are floating bonds, that are investing, and the like, to join him in his effort to make the impact of this kind of-

And do you have any thoughts, were there to be a law proposed that would say that if a financial institution came under some level of penalty, that rather than a choice by the treasurer or a local entity to avoid that institution, to put a provision in to law that would create those types of sanctions automatically, where some threshold to be reached, any thoughts on that?
Good. Question, Senator Galgiani?
Thank you, Senator, Chair Dababneh.

Great, thank you. And the panel members, thank you all for being here and for your insight. Much appreciated, thank you. Okay, we're going to go to the last panel, but nevertheless, an important one, before this Committee.

And I'd like to invite Joe Ridout, manager of consumer services for Consumer Action. Rosemary Shahan, President of Consumers for Auto Reliability and Safety, and Sean Coffey, who is the Media and Program Evaluations Manager for the California Reinvestment Coalition to join is. Thank you all for being here. Is Rosemary here? Okay. Joe, if you want to lead us off.
Great, thank you Joe. Rosemary, you are kindly introduced. Thank you for being here.

Okay. Thank you, Rosemary. Thank you for your comments. And appreciate your insight and the difficult experiences that you have had. Shawn Coffee welcome to the Committee. And thank you for being here, look forward to hearing your thoughts.

Drawing attention to the fact that the office of the Comptroller of the Currency has not given Wells Fargo a new CRA rating in eight years. The bank's last yearly exam was conducted in 2012. Shockingly, the grade from that exam has still not been shared with the public. In her op-ed she urged the control of the currency to downgrade Wells Fargo CRA rating.

Great thank you, Sean. Questions? Great, well thank you all for being here and sharing your insight. Appreciate your work that you do to protect consumers. Thank you very much. So with that, we've completed our formal agenda.

Thank you, Miss Stone. Anybody else have any other thoughts, comments to share? All right, with that I want to thank members of the panel. Senator Galgiani, thank you for being here. The wonderful staff of the Banking Committee for all the good work that they have done in preparing the background materials.

Certainly want to thank my colleague in the Assembly chair, Dababneh for his work in this area, and I know his concerns have been expressed as part of the hearing process today. Probably the most difficult thing about this hearing, is that we all know that Wells Fargo employs tens of thousands of Californians.

Made up of wonderful people working hard everyday to do their work and in an honest fashion. And I know that for them, this process that we're going through and then examining what happened and why, and who's responsible, it must be particularly difficult because they've committed so much to this institution that's so important to them, their families, and our communities.

And so, I want to acknowledge that, that this is difficult to go through. But I think that my message to them and to the bank is that it's important that we do go through this process, that we look at it in a transparent way, we're honest about the problems that we have found. So that we can fix them, and hope that they won't happen again.

That we're all in the business of building consumer confidence. And that comes from ensuring that when problems have been raised, that we thoroughly vet them. That we see what changes we can make, in order to continue the confidence that's so important in our financial system, so it is difficult.

I'm disappointed that Wells Fargo chose not to participate. It's my hope that they will find reasons to participate. And engage more directly and straightforwardly about the circumstances in which they have found their company. I know it's an awkward thing for them, as well.

But we're all better off if we can confront these problems and figure them out and do what's necessary to make it right. And unfortunately Wells' lack of participation in this process isn't a positive and I hope that they reconsider and turn it around as we continue to work in the Legislature to get to the heart of the problem, and that we can provide that confidence that we all know we want to have in our financial systems. So with that, thank you all for participating, and I wish you all have a great day.
Wells Fargo provided to the House Committee on Banking a statement that surprised me. And this is what they said in regard to the Board's, the communication to the Board.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker and members. I also rise in strong support of HR 4. I also stand before you as the granddaughter of immigrants. Most everybody in this chamber comes from immigrant stock and while we all know that the President hasn't taken office yet, we all lived through the election. We all heard the threats. We all heard the vitriol. We all felt the fear in our communities that people faced when they heard the threats. So, while we stand here today, we don't know what policies, since they seem to change every day, might be implemented, but, I don't know about you, but I was raised on a foundation of trust and that my word was my bond and when I said something, I would go to all means possible to maintain the integrity of my word.

And so, we have to trust that what we heard during the campaign might come true and so, we stand here before you today as Californians, to say our word is our bond and we say that all people were created equal and in the State of California will be treated that way and that we stand with our word. Pledging to Californians, pledging to the rest of the country, that equity, equality, diversity, immigrants are people that we value, they are us and I respectfully ask for your aye vote on HR 4.

Thank you very much, good morning Mr. Speaker, good morning members. We are here today to honor a longtime Assembly employee so if we can have your attention too, please, to give the proper honor. Members that we should, thank you very much. Here at the chamber at the back they're telling me where to go, but I won't, Mr. Jim Collins who is retiring as a Chief Consultant to the Assembly Committee on Agriculture. He began that in 1997. During his tenure as Chief Consultant, Jim has worked with eight different chairs. I don't know if he's happy about that or sad about that, but Assembly Members Cardoza, Flores, Matthews, Para, Galgiani, myself, Mr. Perea, and then lastly here Mr. Dodd.

As Chief Consultant, Jim was responsible for the analysis of agricultural policy, creating, and managing legislative proposals on behalf of the Committee and resolving conflicts, and building coalitions among opposing parties involved in policy affecting agriculture such as members of the Legislature, staff, industry leaders, and the administration. This is not always an easy job especially, it has been said that their agriculture as a body has one kind of party. California as a policy place has a different party and so to try to combine these two industries of both the politics of California and trying to keep agriculture as thriving as it possibly can in our state, I think has been a challenge that Jim has done beautifully.

Jim attended the College of the Sequoias in Visalia, he's a valley boy. Between 1971 and 1974, he then went on to get his degree and a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration and Economics at Oregon State University. He then began a banking career. Over the span of a decade, Jim advanced from appraiser to senior loan officer, to assistant manager, to assistant Vice President. 1986, he accepted a position with Senator Ann Buth. While working there, he managed legislation, staffed the Senator on committees. In 1993, he accepted a position as a senior consultant at the Assembly Minority Ways and Means Committee, where he was responsible for fiscal analysis, a budget review of agricultural, environmental, water, resource, transportation utility issues.

In 1994, he was appointed to Legislative Director of the California Department of Food and Agriculture, where he was responsible for developing all the departments, legislative package, testifying on behalf of the department at legislative hearings. So he has been a wealth of information in this building to the agricultural industry. He is here today with his family, supporters, friends. He plans to spend his first few months in retirement traveling to Oregon, Baja, California, and Utah. So for his long history in the legislature, on behalf of Mr. Dodd, Senator Dodd, myself, and to a grateful body, Jim, we appreciate your service and we wish you well in your well-earned retirement.

I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible with liberty and justice for all. Thank you, you may be seated. Reading of the previous day's journal.

Thank you, Mr. President and members. I'm pleased to be a part of this great celebration of the life of supervisor Edelman. I spent 10 years in Los Angeles in the 80s and when you think about the giants of Los Angeles, you think about the Tom Bradleys, and you think about the Kenny Hahns and certainly, you think about the Ed Edelmans who have through such long-standing work and passion have really carved out this wonderful place. Whether it's the open-space preservation or the things he's done for people or the buildings that are so important to our delivery of services, he was an extraordinary man and I think one of the things that hasn't been raised so far in this testimonial is the people that he has mentored in his life.

All the staff members and they're all throughout our great state that come up here in Sacramento and served in wonderful ways and they continue to serve in Los Angeles in wonderful ways. He was a great mentor. He led by example in a quiet way, as has been said, but in an extraordinary way and with enormous achievements that all of us have had the benefit of.

Thank you Mr. President. Member, I thank the Pro Tem for bringing us the sad news of Jonathan's passing. I think about one of my earliest memories in politics was calling up Jonathan Sanchez at the Eastern Group Publication to pitch him on the news of the day for the elective leader that I was working for and I did it over many years in the 80s, and he always was very gracious, and he was always passionate. He always had questions to ask, but you always saw in the newspaper the real community spoke in the pages of Eastern Group Publications and all those little papers. The community was speaking to us as staffers, as elected leaders because he had a great passion for connection and communication and he knew how important that was to creating cohesion.
And a power within communities, and so he was a great man in Los Angeles, and I'm glad that the Protem has asked that we adjourn in his memory today.

The time is now nine o'clock, hopefully everyone can hear me. Good morning, welcome to the confirmation hearing of the Attorney General held by the Special Committee on the office of the Attorney General. We welcome Governor Brown's appointee here today, Congressman Xavier Becerra, also the Governor of the great State of California, Jerry Brown.

Let me go over some procedural things today. As far as procedure for today, we will begin with opening remarks from the Co-Chairs Assemblymember Mark Stone, and myself, Assemblymember Reginald B. Jones-Sawyer, Sr., followed by introduction of the Governor, who will introduce the nominee, followed by questions from the Committee Members. Starting with myself, Jones-Sawyer, Dr. Weber, Gal--no, we changed it around. Sorry, Mr. Lackey, Chiu, Cunningham, Eggman, Gallagher, Reyes, and then Stone.

After the question and answer period, we will some time for public comment. Finally, the Committee will vote on Congressman Becerra's nomination to be our next Attorney General. And so I will begin and open. It's very important that we start on time obviously to finish on time. I will open with opening statements and then. So first, we will call a quorum. Madam Secretary.

Thank you, we have before an enormously important task. This Committee is not only historic, but may well establish a procedure and a precedent that will be used in the future. This is a time where our nation is facing dramatic change, at a national level, it is important that California takes position in the politics of in inclusion. The position of Attorney General is one that California relies on the spearhead the legal issues confronting us.
