We, in California, face a hard, cold reality that reflects both unprecedented uncertainty, an unconceivable and inconceivably a looming, long, and ferocious, and hard-fought legal war with bloodshed stretching from the Golden State to Washington DC. The reason: Trump and his incoming administration are dead set on building up legal barriers and walls around all those that we, as a state, have turned down in recent years.

Now more than ever, we need an Attorney General who will defend our values, and stand up to the next administration's backwards vision for America. The incoming President ran the most xenophobic campaign in modern history, and pledged to Deport primarily Mexicans, Muslims, undocumented persons in this country.

As the incoming President plans to fill his cabinet, Wall Street executives that killed the consumer protection bureau, now more than ever, we need an Attorney General who will protect consumers from financial abuses. As the incoming President threatens journalists and plots to establish a registry of Muslim immigrants, now more than ever, we need an Attorney General who will defend our nation's long established traditions of freedom of religion and independent press.

With so much anxiety and fear among Californians, stemming from the threat of Trump, this historic nomination, this record-making special Committee on the office of Attorney General present a unique opportunity for this nominee to make his case for how he will protect our state's interests, and be the legal leader that we need.

On a personal note, as someone whose ancestry goes back to the Little Rock nine, almost 60 years ago, where the State of Arkansas forbid my uncle the opportunity to attend school in Little Rock Central High School, where the federal government was the one that protected him and the other eight children. It's a little unusual for me to be in this position where, and most Californians, in this position, where we fear the federal government, where they provided the 101st Airborne to escort my uncle and those brave kids to school every day. We may be juxtaposed in an opposite position here today.

But let me be clear, this Committee is not for show, it's real. The governor's nominee is here today to answer tough questions necessary for him to prove to us as representatives of California, that he has the courage, the valor, the grit, and fortitude as well as the qualifications necessary to be our legal voice on behalf of every Californian. It is up to Congressman Becerra today to show us that he is not only battle tested, but ready for war on behalf of the great State of California. Thank you. Mr. Stone?
Let's proceed. And I believe the Governor. [Yes.] Will open.
Thank you Governor Brown. Congressman Becerra, you may proceed with your opening statement.
No, you can stay. I just don't want you to miss that 10 o'clock appointment.

Okay. So as I mentioned earlier, about we're in a unique situation where earlier on, for example, on gun violence, the President Elect, mentioned having reciprocal gun, reciprocal out of state laws, for example, open carry, so having a federal open carry so you'd be able to open carry in California.

Laws like in Florida, Stand Your Ground, which has obviously had some detrimental impact, not only on my community, but your community too, we do believe in responsible gun ownership. And we're in adjoining districts and we know what military-style weapons,

that kind of violence, what it means in our communities may not mean the same in other places, but it has been detrimental in our communities. So, as far as gun violence, and having federal laws kind of creep over into our state, and we've done a plethora of different laws on gun control,
how would you handle that if the federal government so decided to have a nationwide legislation?

Okay, good, and I also wanted to mention that each member gets about five minutes to ask questions and I probably should have mentioned that earlier, and so, as the first one, I'm going to try to adhere to that as best as possible. I know that's always tough as Chairman. It's always tough, on worker's rights, where we are free from employer

retaliation on derisive workers to organize, keeping jobs in California, trade agreements that would ship California jobs offshore, or mega mergers that could violate antitrust laws and ultimately eliminate jobs here in California, and companies that refuse or skirt around paying minimum wage or
overtime to employees like the most vulnerable, like farm workers or home care workers, where do you see the Attorney General's role in being involved in those types of situations?
Thank you. You know what? I'm going to go ahead and let Dr. Weber proceed with her next set of questions. And I will reserve my last two minutes, if I need it. You have two minutes?
I would
Thank you, Dr. Weber. Thank you. Mr. Lackey?
Thank you sir. Thank you Mr. Lackey. Mr. David Chiu?
Thank you, Mr. Chu. All right, Mr. Cunningham.

Thank you. Good morning and welcome. Good morning. I'm honored to be here, and our backgrounds also share a lot of similarities and I guess I'd like to say too, on this historic day, where we open the Yolo Bypass Weir and Xavier Becerra comes home to Sacramento. It's a historic day to be here. California has long been the place for, that LGBT people have seen as the Golden State, where they have come to feel safe, to be accepted, and we have worked hard to create that culture. With the passage of Prop 8, we saw that that was tenuous, at best and sometimes there were just pockets and neighborhoods where people were safe and where they weren't. So, we've worked very hard to extend our rights.

And many Californians in LGBT community are very nervous right now. The incoming potentially federal Attorney General has made very clear his positions on these issues and so, I guess I'd like to ask you, where do you think we are most vulnerable? And what do you think our recourse is?

Thank you, I appreciate that and that vigorous answer. As with the establishment and protection of LGBT rights, California has also been the leader in environmental policy. I take particular pride in knowing that we have the richest agriculture state in the nation, the most productive, as well as having the most vigorous environmental protections. We've been able to do both of those things together, to protect our water and our air and make sure that things can thrive and grow. What is your estimation of the potential threat? And again, what is our recourse in turning back our environmental policies that are tenuously, that we've crafted to be able to make sure our agriculture grows and thrives?

Just a followup to that. I think somebody else is going to talk about reproductive rights, but as far as Planned Parenthood and the federal funding that goes along with that. Most of our transgender women, that's where they get their healthcare, is through Planned Parenthood. So that'll also be a particularly, I think, especially something we need to watch very carefully.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Congressmen, it's such a pleasure to have you here in California again. Welcome back. Some of my colleagues have asked questions regarding immigration. As the daughter of immigrants, someone who has lived the American dream, received a great education. I also volunteered many hours with the Legal Aid and many students who because of the executive order, Obama's executive order applied for DACA protections. They provided sensitive information, which now is available. This is of great concern to many of our students. What efforts can the Attorney General's Office take to ensure some of our students that what they have done was a good thing at that time? And what can we do to protect them and to protect their information?

Thank you. Another area that I would like to ask a question on is on the environment. The Attorney General is the legal representative of a number of state agencies that have environmental public health responsibilities. I've represent a district that has been heavily impacted by poor environmental quality barrier. We've been the low income community as well as communities. We know that low income communities as well as communities of colour are the ones who suffer more when environmental justice issues arise. I'm very concerned that the environmental gains that we have made over the years may be lost.
What can you do as Attorney General to ensure our communities, our low income communities and our communities of color, that they will be protected with the same figure as any other community?

In my final two minutes, this thing called the cellphone has led to a lot of revelations. In this whole discussion of Black Lives Matter, we see where individuals are killed, is brought to a grand jury, or the police agency doesn't take any action or they find that the individual is not culpable. At the end of your predecessor's term last year, the Attorney General came to my office talking about if an elective body doesn't agree with sending these kind of discrepancies to a grand jury or not comfortable with what the police agency came up with, that the Attorney General would have some kind of special prosecutor or some special group, if the local agency volunteered to send it to the state government. What do you feel about that?

Thank you, and I want to thank the Committee for being brief, concise, to the point. We're now going to have public comment and I guess depending on how many people come to the mic, if it's five people, they get five minutes a piece. If 50 people, one minute a piece, if it's more than that, just your name and whether you support or not. So let me get a sense of how many. A minute, the committee says each person gets one minute to make public comment and the first person?
Give it to the sergeants, thank you. Thank you for your comments, next.
Thank you sir. Thank you Former Assemblymember Turi.

Hello, Marques Castrejon with the California Pan-Ethnic Health Network. It's a health equity advocacy organization. We're here to voice our support for Congressman Becerra for the next Attorney General of California. I want to kind of touch on a couple of topics that we felt were necessary to mention but weren't really talked about a lot. One of them is that California's going to be at the forefront of a political battle that's coming down from Washington, especially in regards to consumer protections in healthcare. In California since 2003 we've had some strong consumer protections here in California.

We believe that our next Attorney General need to take a strong stance in no providing the right battle for, not the undocumented groups, also them but the civil protections for our low income communities, our communities of color that are going to be so deeply affected by some of the proposals that new administration is bringing forth. We need to make sure that we continue to strive to keep the laws in place that we already have here. Such as, need to timely access and interpretation of the plans, the actual languages in California.

And we also want to be a voice that's going to try to repeal any laws that we have set here, especially the non-discrimination laws that we will not be able to discriminate regardless of your race, religion, national origin, ethnicity, age, sex, sexual orientation or disability. They believe that they have a great track record and we are proud to support them. Thank you.

Good morning esteemed Chairs and Members of the Committee. My name is Brian Allison. I represent 1.6 million members of AFSCME here to applaud the Governor's prudent nomination, someone who has spent his entire career in public service standing up for the rights of working people and standing up to protect disadvantaged communities. We are in strong support of his nomination and we think that it's prudent at this time in California's history and this nation's history that we have someone in the office of Attorney General who really understands the issues affecting Californians, and is committed to supporting and protecting the rights of all workers and Californians. So with that, we ask that the full body confirm him, but thank you for your time today.

Good morning Mr. Chair and members, my name is Seth Bramble. I am here on behalf of more than 300,000 educators, the members of the California Teachers Association. Congressman Becerra certainly has the experience and proven leadership to be a champion for all Californians as Attorney General and we urge your support. Thank you.

Good morning, Mr. Chair and Members of the Committee. My name is Christopher Sanchez with the Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights, in strong support for the Congress member's appointment, for his championship on immigration issues during his time in Congress and for his comments today as well. Thank you.
Thank you. Alex?
Thank you, are there any other public comments? Seeing none. Mr. Stone.

And I just want to make sure everyone knows that we received all the letters of support and the letter of opposition, and every member got a copy of it, so that everyone is fully informed. Thank you. Madam Secretary, call the roll, please.
So, that passes 63. We will be making that recommendation to the floor of the California State Assembly. You are battle tested, and you're ready for war. Thank you. I get to bang it.

Beyond the present electoral college being the antithesis of the fundamental values that we represent, Mr. Trump made numerous campaign promises that directly contradict the Constitution in California law. As a consequence, the stakes for California couldn't be higher.

Now more than ever, we need an Attorney General that will protect immigrants, and stand up to federal immigration authorities by defending sanctuary cities. As the incoming President is poised to nominate an anti-abortion Supreme Court Justice, now more than ever, we need an Attorney General who defend women's rights from right wing activist judges. As the incoming President nominates an Attorney General who has called the NAACP and ACLU an un-American, and pledges to implement nationwide stop-and-frisk, now more than ever, we need an Attorney General

who would defend civil rights and stand up to police abuse. As the incoming President nominates a climate change-denier to run the Environmental Protection Agency, now more than ever, we need an Attorney General that will protect the progressive environmental protections that we've enacted in California.

Good morning Madame Chair and members. Gregory Kramer on behalf of Planned Parenthood Affiliates of California. I wanted to thank Senator Atkins for continued support of reproductive rights in this state and across this country. For years now, Planned Parenthood has supported similar resolutions including this one defending and protecting a woman's right to choose and right now it couldn't be more timely.

Good Morning. Good morning Mr Chair members, Gregory Kramer again with Planned Parenthood affiliates of California. I'd like to thank Senator Jackson for more eloquently posing what we do here in California than perhaps I can, but I just want to be clear that the attacks on us are real and

amount to nothing more than an attack on women, especially an attack on women of lower socioeconomic status. As I was mentioning, we provide services to over 800,000 patients with over a million clinic visits each year, along with one and a half million tests for STI treatment and sex ed for

207,000 California youth, and I just want to point that out as well. So in addition to the services that we provide which in some districts are the only healthcare services that are around for many miles we do provide comprehensive sex education. And we are active in schools across the state. Schools are scrambling right now to be in compliance with the California Healthy Youth Act,

which mandates that all students obtain age appropriate comprehensive sex ed. The reality is that teachers are either not able to teach or are uncomfortable with providing comprehensive sex ed. That's where we help them out with materials, in addition to the services that we provide in our clinics, the youth of our state do rely on us for accurate information that may not come up elsewhere.

But the threat to our operations in California is very real. The majority of our funding comes from federal dollars. And specifically we are worried about a drug program called 340B which provides for heavily discounted drugs for contraception and STD's, and so

the federal government pays about 90 cents on the dollar for those drugs and the fate of that program is also up in the air as well. The reality is that other community clinics have gone on record year after year saying they cannot absorb the amount of patients that we have if we were to shut down. In addition we are a vital resource for members of the transgender community. Folks that feel like they have no were to go.

Even people that have doctors and private plans that may have a physician that may have personal issues or doesn't have the expertise with Health Care needs of transgender individuals. They come to Planned Parenthood. We give them advice, treatments, and services, and so on. With that I hope that we can continue on your support and we appreciate the Senators introduction of this resolution, thank you.

Mr. Chair, Members of the Committee, Brian Allison on behalf of the American Federation State County Municipal Employees. I just want to express our strong support for this particular piece of legislation. The services that Planned Parenthood provides on behalf of low income and disadvantaged communities across the State of California. We'd also like to thank the Senator for bringing this very important resolution forward. Thank you for your time today.

Exactly. So Planned Parenthood federally and statewide operates a 501C3 and a 501C4 organization, and so our C3 funding, which is the bulk of our funding goes directly and exclusively to patient care, comprehensive sex ed, patient services and the 501C4 organization is responsible for the political action but the revenues that are obtained for the C4 are separate.

So we receive about two thirds of our funding from federal sources and so without that our operations as they are today would not be recognizable. The vast majority of our planning does come from federal reimbursements, reimbursement for services rendered.

We are facing some threats at Planned Parenthood and for reproductive justice. We haven't seen, in the course of my life time and arguably some of the greatest threats that reproductive justice rights have seen ever in this country. So what's at stake for all of this? If there's an appointment to the Supreme Court that rolls back Roe vs. Wade, that could have impacts for women across this country for a lifetime.

What that means for us here in California is it threatens the contraception that we provide to over 600,000 people a year. It threatens the near 307,000 emergency contraception kits that we provide every year. It threatens the 1 million pregnancy tests that we provide, along with the 96,000 cervical cancer screenings that we provide.

And so, all of these services that we do to protect women's and men's right to choose and reproductive choice can be threatened and so, especially now with the millennial generation who is trying to get out of school, be part of the work force, people are delaying parenthood now, just so they could save up the resources and professionally advance and so I think with my generation, with millennial generation, that the Roe vs Wade decision is needed now more than ever and so again I thank the Senator for her support and ask for yours, thank you.

Put your right hand over your heart and begin. I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands, one nation, under God, indivisible with liberty and justice for all.

Thank you Mr. Speaker and members. I rise to support the confirmation of Xavier Becerra as California's next Attorney General. The national political conversation has left many communities feeling that the country that they love so much may turn it's back on them. In California one of the most diverse states in the nation, this feeling is magnified as immigrant communities feel unsure and anxious of their place in our nation due to the national rhetoric aimed at their communities. We must send a message that we are prepared to fight for our values. Values of fairness, inclusion and equal protection under the laws. California needs a fighter, a fighter who will defend the rights of those with out the means to fight for themselves.

We need a fighter who will resist efforts to harm our efforts in the Docker program. We need a fighter who will prevent the use of California resources to engage in mass deportation activity. We need a fighter that will resist the creation of a Muslim registry or any other religious based registry. As a member of the women's caucus we also need a fighter to protect reproductive rights. Xavier Becerra has demonstrated in the special Committee hearing earlier this week that he is the fighter we need. He is the fighter we need to defend our legal rights and ensure that our communities feel safe. No matter your political affiliation, religious background or legal status, Xavier Becerra will be your Attorney General and the last line of defense that California desperately needs. In closing, I urge your support, strong support for the nomination of Xavier Becerra, as California's next Attorney General.

Thank you Mr. Speaker and colleagues. Today I'm proud to rise in support of the confirmation vote for Congressman Xavier Becerra to be the next Attorney General of the State of California. As Co-Chair of the special Committee on the office of the Attorney General, my fellow Co-Chairs and the other seven members from San Diego,

San Bernardino, San Francisco, San Luis Obispo, Stockton, Yuba, San Bernardino, Santa Clara, and Los Angeles, we were really proud to serve on this first Committee. The Committee did a complete and thorough job of vetting and questioning Governor Brown's nominee. After that process from which many people, both in this chamber and

outside this chamber complimented the Committee for its work, we are eternally grateful for your compliments. Everyone on the Committee, you need to understand, was honored to be the first Committee to hold a hearing for an Attorney General. While each of us went through our own vetting process, what became abundantly clear to us, that the Governor got it right. The reason that the Committee did so well is because

Xavier Becerra is the candidate that should be the next Attorney General. Most of the people that were looked at out of all of Californians, Congressman Xavier Becerra is the only person to fill this position at this time in California's history. Quite frankly, maybe he is the only one equipped to handle the major challenges facing us in the future.

I know there were several comments made in objection. The only thing I can say since in this forum, we're talking about qualifications. Probably one of the best qualifications that you may have or you need to understand that Mr. Becerra is willing to talk to you.

Congressman Becerra is willing to have a beer with you, and Attorney General Becerra is willing to talk through all the myriad of different challenges that we will face. The reason that he is qualified academically, intellectually and legally, and me from another University, he went to an outstanding University,

Stanford University's undergrad and got his law degree. I want to have someone that really understands the problems of immigrants. As a son of working class immigrants who produced a college graduate who went to one of the elite universities, who else will understand the plight of immigrants more so than Congressman Becerra?

During the hearing, we talked about civil rights and racial profiling. Congressman Becerra shared with the Committee the time that he was racially profiled. So he personally knows what it's like to be racially profiled and how he felt. Who better to defend the rights of people who are racially profiled than Congressman Becerra?

As the top cop, we talked about human trafficking. Congressman Becerra has three daughters, and you could see emotionally. He told us that would be one of his main priorities to stop as the top cop, to get rid of the scourge in our community. He is honorable and respected, and I joked with a lot of people,

when you look in the dictionary under honorable, you see Xavier Becerra's picture. He is well respected, not only here but everyone in Congress and in California. He also has the political acumen to deal both here in California and in Washington. As the former assemblyperson, and I also have a special love for this,

from the 59th Assembly District, Congressman Becerra served on this floor. He cut his teeth in politics on this floor just like you are now, and went on to Congress to serve an exemplary example of what a Congress person should be. He also knows what it's like to not be in a majority house.

So he also understands both sides of the political spectrum. And then this discussion about being a fighter. Don't mistake Congressman Becerra's kindness for weakness. He will be the tip of the spear for us in California.

Yesterday, when the California Legislature Black Caucus had its Martin Luther King event, we had Roland Martin. And he ended it with a quote which I think fits perfectly for the kind of fighter that we want here in California. He said, he wants the kind of fighter that will fight until hell freezes over, and when it freezes over, he will get on the ice and fight again.
That's the kind of fighter that we're going to get in Xavier Becerra. going to protect everyone in here today. So today is a historic vote. I believe that Congress member Xavier Becerra can go down,

possibly could go down as one of the best attorney generals California has ever had. Colleagues, you do not want to be on the wrong side of this vote. You do not want to be on the wrong side of history. I strongly urge everyone in this chamber today to vote in the affirmative for the confirmation of Congressman Xavier Becerra for the office of Attorney General.

Thank you, Madam Speaker and members. Today I rise on behalf of the LGBT Caucus to commemorate Dr. Martin Luther King and to urge your aye support on ACR 5. We don't really know where Dr. Martin Luther King stood on the position of LGBT rights, but we do know since his death, he has been seen not as an African American hero, but as a hero for all people.

For all Americans, for everyone who looks for a place where God's love touches us all, where possibilities are there for the taking if we work hard, and if we find the love in our hearts that should be shared with everybody. That there is enough room for all of us.

We know that Rustin was a core person in his staff. A close friend, who stood side by side with him. And we know that the LGBT community has taken him on as our hero and used a lot of the tactics of love, and moving forward, and standing together as we fight for that more perfect union that we all search for.

One of the other things I think we know, that Dr. Martin Luther King probably would have issued this new doctrine of prosperity religion in place of what his was more around a sacrifice and doing for others and not just doing for yourself. And I think as the propensity towards looking about if I am rich, that means I am powerful, I am successful, and that God loves me to go back to the time when we looked at God's love as who we were as a person and

what we had in our heart, not just towards ourselves and towards our family but towards everybody. And for me, one of his most powerful quotes was, use me God, show me to take who I am, who I want to be and what I can do and use it for a purpose greater than myself. On behalf of the LBGT caucus I'd urge a strong aye on ACR 5.

Mr. Chair and members, my name is Seth Bramble. I'm here on behalf of Theresa Montano, the Vice President of the California Teachers Association. She was here earlier. She wanted to be able to speak. Unfortunately, she had to get on a plane to our nation's capital. But on behalf of the 325,000 public school educators in this state, we urge support of this appointment. Congressman Becerra certainly will be a champion for all Californians. He shares our values and we urge your support.

Good afternoon. Gregory Kramer with Planned Parenthood Affiliates of California. On behalf or our 115 health clinics within this state, we are supportive of Mr. Becerra's nomination. He's earned, for the last two years and over his career in service, 100% scorecard with Planned Parenthood, our federal branch. And he is a strong defender of women's rights. So we appreciate your time.

Mr. Chair, members, Brian Allison on behalf of the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees. Just wanted to inform this committee, but also make it clear that on behalf of the 1.6 million members that we represent across the country, we are delighted to support congressman Xavier Becerra's confirmation and nomination for this position.

First, we'd like to give a tremendous amount of credit to the Governor of this state for having the foresight to nominate someone as eminently qualified as as Congressman Becerra is. We stand behind his commitments to workers protecting the rights of workers in California and we urge this body to approve his nomination and would urge the Senate to do so as well. Thank you all.

Good afternoon, Chair and members. Christopher Sanchez with CHIRLA, the Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights. Stand in stong support for the appointment for Congressman Becerra. Mainly for the reasons that him being a champion in Congress on immigrant issues and a lot of his comments today. We appreciate him. So thank you.

I'm very proud to stand up and speak in favor of a former classmate here at McClatchy, Congressman Xavier Becerra. And it still fits, people are asking. I don't know if I'm going to button it up, but we'll see about that. But members, with all respect, there's a lot of politics that swirl around nominations as serious as this one.

But I always like to look at issues of character first. And I think, as other members have spoken about the Senator from Sacramento, that Congressmen Becerra grew up, parents of immigrants, working class area here in Sacramento. Went to a wonderful public, diverse high school, CK McClatchy High School.

I did just check out the yearbook, he was an underclassman of mine, and I guess always an underclassman. And he had a full head of hair back then, and as did I, but somehow he's been privileged to keep that beautiful head of hair. But on a more serious note, he's a man of great character. And as I said, as politics swirl around our world, I think one of the things that we

can all look to is the character of a person who takes this important office, that they do it honorably, responsibly, professionally. And I'm very confident that he'll do all that. He had a wonderful upbringing.

And I know that We all want to make our parents proud and we want to make our teachers proud and the mentors who helped us get to where we are and I know that for all of us CK McClatchy counselors and advisors and teachers I know, join me in feeling very proud about our local young men making good and
I'm pleased to support the nomination.

Thank you very much, Mr. Speaker. Members, today I'd like to adjourn in the memory of Esther Fong, who in 1950 became the first Chinese American teacher in the City of Stockton. She enjoyed a decades long teaching experience and didn't retire until her husband died in 1981, in which she took over the family business. Her family came to California

and to Stockton in 1878, some of the first settlers. Her uncle opened a small market. When she started school, she still didn't speak a word of English living in the downtown Chinatown area in Stockton. And, when a teacher suggested to her she could be a teacher too, she had never seen an Asian teacher or anybody who wasn't white teaching before,

and didn't think it was possible. But, she took that opportunity and got her teaching credential at San Francisco State, and became the first teacher, enjoying decades of work. One of her mottos was to do your best, have a goal, work at it, and when the opportunity comes you'll be prepared. It's no use having opportunities if when they come you are not prepared.

She died on December 31st after suffering a stroke. She is survived by her older sister, May, a younger brother, David, her sons, Les and Paul, her daughter Leanne, seven grandchildren, numerous nieces and nephews, and the celebration of her life was held. I ask that we adjourn in the memory of Esther Fong of Stockton.

Sylvia Solis Shaw, on behalf of the city and County of San Francisco and the office of Mayor Ed Lee. Mayor Lee is in strong support of the nomination and we ask for the Rules Committee to confirm it, we look forward to continuing our partnership with Director Metcalf, thank you.

Thank you, Madam Speaker, members. I appreciate your indulgence doing two adjournment memories this week. But I'm adjourning a memory today of a close personal friend. My friend, Byron Roberts, died on January 14th of this year. Byron was born in Mobile, Alabama, January 2nd, 1945. He was an early civil rights activist.

He made his way out to California in the early 70s with his lifelong partner, then came to be husband, Dennis Merrill. They spent 47 years in a relationship together. Byron was a child protective service worker. And he worked for over 30 years in CPS, in the county, working to improve children's lives.

He spent the last couple years of his career doing transitional, so he was working with teenagers as they went out into the world. And during the 70s, 80s, and 90s was a time when LGBT rights was not something that people talked about. And being in the closet was a way of life. And Byron is one of those guys who was just effervescent in his southerness and

his charm, and his ability to disarm people with his flamboyance and his willingness to engage in conversation. And I think it's those kinds of people living everyday lives, that have brought us the level of acceptance and equality that we enjoy today.

Not making big deals about things, but just living your life as who you are, doing public service and really helping generations of people around you understand that LGBT people are just like everybody else, and civil right really are for everybody. After he retired he was an activist in the community.

He was one of the early founders of the San Joaquin County AIDS foundation. He was an early founder of San Joaquin Prides Foundation. He was an early founder of the Stonewall Democrats. He was a huge advocate for children, for civil rights, for the environment.

He could walk a precinct better than anybody else. I'll never forget my first election. He and my 80-some year old dad were putting up signs together and I can't imagine who was talking more. So Byron enjoyed conversations.

He will be terribly missed in our community. As we get ready to celebrate Mardi Gras, which was his favorite southern holiday, and he led everybody with a king dance to start it off, we will miss him this year, as we will every year going forward. And we offer our condolences to his husband, Dennis Merrill.
One of the proudest days of their lives, when I was able to perform their marriage ceremony in 2013. So State of California today, please honor our southern son as we say goodbye to Byron Roberts.

Greg Kramer with Planned Parenthood Affiliates of California. I'll keep it brief. Just want to highlight that the Roe versus Wade ruling does nothing but provide women with greater health outcomes and provides for additional financial and physical health outcomes that were not seen in the days of back alley abortions when it was illegal.

The right to an abortion is under attack, as you all know, by Congress, but luckily California ensured the woman's right to privacy and the woman's right to choose before the Roe ruling, and we're anticipating that that will remain the same, notwithstanding any type of federal interactions, so with that, we respectfully request your aye vote.
Thank you. Thank you. Anyone else in support? Seeing none. Any opposition? Seeing none. Bring it back to the Committee. Questions, comments? Seeing none. Ms. Garcia, you may close.

I feel like I just got thrown under a bus there. Hello. Good afternoon, members. I'm Melanie Paren, Legislative Director for Caltrans. Caltrans is in strong support of AB 28, and we express out appreciation to the chair for authoring such an important measure for our department, for the state. Just to be brief, as the other speakers in the act have already indicated.

We've already seen significant time saving when it comes to delivering environmental documents for projects. It allows us to approve more projects, to deliver projects faster, which also creates jobs faster, and it's also a quicker delivery of project benefits for the community and for the users of the system. So, with that, we ask for your aye vote.

Thank you. Speaker and members, it is my privilege and honor to rise to introduce an international delegation from the State of Aguascalientes, Mexico. Joining us in the rear of chambers are Honorable Martin Orozco Sandoval, Governor of the State of Aguascalientes, Mexico. Honorable Manuel Alejandro Gonzales Martinez,

Secretary of Rural Development of Agri-Business. Honorable Julio Cesar Medina Delgado, Secretary of Environment. Mr. Rolando Garcia Alonzo, Advisor for International Affairs. Honorable Martin Alcala Salgado, acting Consul General of Mexico in Sacramento.

Miss Yuriko Luisa Garces Lee, Consul for Political Affairs. The delegations is meeting with California officials to learn about California agribusiness and best practices for collaborating with the State of California to promote their competitive agricultural industry.  Members, please welcome our honored guests.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker, members I respectfully request the Assembly adjourn in the memory of Dr. Manny L. Brody, Jr., pastor and founder of Principles of Faith Christian Center in Fontana who passed away last week at the age of 61. A staple of the faith community since 1998, Principles of Faith Christian Center has been a foundational piece of the Inland Empire, serving over 1,000 members, although it was founded with only eight members

Throughout his life, Dr. Brody worked tirelessly with the community leaders in order to aid those who needed it most. He partnered with the Public Defender's office, the District Attorney, and Probation Department to help establish the expungement program and community plea program, resources created to deal with various legal issues affecting the community.

An advocate for education, Dr. Brody was a graduate of California State University, San Bernardino where he earned a bachelor's degree in Criminal Justice and worked closely with local community college districts to increase minority enrollment. He spent time working with the NACA and Union Bank to ensure the availability of affordable housing and provide essential resources to first time home buyers.

I had the privilege of going to one of his conferences for first time home buyers where he provided counseling for every aspect, whether it was for your credit, he had realtors, he had lenders, he had every resource available because he felt that was the best way for members of his church to enter into the middle class, to make that one purchase which was their home. the American dream.

Dr. Brody was a true force in my district and will be missed by all who's lives he touched, especially those he touched through his ministry and beyond. He is survived by his wife, Winifred Brody, as well as his two sisters, Loni Hatchet and Wynell Vaughn. Mr. Speaker, colleagues, I ask that we adjourn in memory of this great friend of mine, Dr. Brody. Thank you.

Thank you Madam President, members. I want to first complement the pro tem for bringing this resolution before us and I wanted to direct my comments to my friends across the aisle, our friends across the aisle. We just came through a very difficult election season, and the partisanship is at a heightened place. And there is a feeling that that

contentiousness Continues on. And so at a moment like this, we don't have to look at the facts, we can look at the, maybe the spirit in which you think it was brought before us. Or the hyper partisanship that still envelops us.

And there's concern that somehow acts like this, resolutions like this, deal with the issue of the legitimacy of our current President, and for me and I think for others, that's not a fight that this resolution presents. And it's also not a situation where it's about campaign rhetoric. He said this, she said that. That was the campaign. Okay, well those times are done. Those times are beyond us.

And I know how difficult it s to speak up or act up against the leader of your own party. We have those issues here in California on our side of the aisle when we speak up against something that the Governor has proposed. And you now face that same circumstance, where you might not agree with the President of your party, but you feel this pull and this tug that somehow you should defend what he has done, even when you may disagree.

And so I'd like to share with you some thoughts from members of your party. Madam President, may I have permission to read? Without objection. This is a statement that was issued yesterday by US Senators, John McCain and Lindsey Graham.

Members of your party. And they said this about the executive order in which we debate today. Our government has a responsibility to defend our borders. But we must do so in a way that makes us safer.

And uphold all that is decent and exceptional about our nation. It is clear from the confusion at our airports across the nation that President Trump's executive order was not properly vetted. We are particularly concerned by reports that this order went into effect with little or no consultation with the departments of state, defense, justice, and homeland security.

Such a hasty process risks harmful results. We should not stop green card holders from returning to the country they call home. We should not stop those who have served as interpreters for our military and diplomats from seeking refuge in the country they risked their lives to help.

And we should not turn our back on those refugees who have been shown through extensive vetting to pose no demonstrable threat to our nation, and who have suffered unspeakable horrors. Most of them women and children. Ultimately, we fear this executive order will become a self-inflicted wound in the fight against terrorism.

At this very moment, American troops are fighting side by side with our Iraqi partners to defeat ISIL. But this executive order bans Iraqi pilots from coming to military bases in Arizona to fight our common enemies. Our most important allies in the fight against ISIL, and the vast majority of Muslims who reject this apocalyptic ideology of hatred.

This executive order sends a signal, intended or not, that America does not let Muslims come in into our country. That is why we fear this executive order may do more to help terrorist recruitment than improve our security. So do these United States Senators want America to be less safe? I don't think so.

But these United States Senators, as hard as it may be, know that their obligation is to our Constitution and our laws. And that's a very difficult thing to do, especially with the new President. But I do agree with my colleagues that, in moments like this,

the history will not be written about what just he did. It's about what you do. And these aren't things that you can hide behind because of a convoluted debate about, Sanctuary cities, or about the politics of the presidential election. No, this is your moment. This is your moment, and it will be written into history. And I believe this resolution is deserving of support.
Danielle Kando-Kaiser, on behalf of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, in strong support.
Marcus Mckinney with PICO California, policy director, on behalf of our half a million members, in strong support.
Christopher Sanchez, with CHIRLA, the Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights, in strong support.
Rosa Aqeel with Policy Link and the Alliance for Boys and Men of Color in strong support, thank you.

Mr Chair and members, Rand Martin on behalf of Consortium Management Group and CALIVA. It's a large dispensary manufacturing and cultivation operation in San Jose. First, I want to echo the compliments paid to this Committee and to the members of the regulatory agencies for all the hard work that's being done. CALIVA comes from a history, with its leadership of a highly

regulated industries in other fields under Medicaid and Medicare. So they have a lot of respect for strong regulation. They would like to see strong regulation here. Regulation is not always agreed upon by even the people sitting at this table.

And Mr Conway's comments bring to mind one point about where should cannabis be cultivated. There are some people who believe it should only happen in rural areas. And some who believe that enclosed, odor-free urban cultivation is a reasonable approach as well. So I respect the fact that the regulatory agencies have some work to do with the industry,

and figuring out exactly how to thread these various needles. I do want to point out a few things, just relative to the very specifics of regulations, and won't get into any detail. I do want to echo some of the things that Ms Jenkins said about aligning Amma with MCRSA. We agree with the points that she made, we would add one additional one.

And that is the issue of ownership. Ownership in MCRSA, at least where publicly traded, is at 5%, under Amma, it's 20%. We'd like to see alignment there as well. Another ownership issue, that is something that you may have to deal with this year in order to be helpful

to some of us in the industry, is how quickly you can become a for-profit entity. MCRSA anticipates that happening January 1, 2018. Businesses that want to get geared up for January 1st, who are looking for investments, need to know that they can

transfer to a for-profit ownership structure earlier than January 1st. Again, anticipated on January 1st, but if we can get it earlier, perhaps as an element in the budget trailer bill this year, that would be hugely helpful to a lot of entities out there that are looking forward to converting. The only other point I want to make, and one that has not been raised at all this evening,

I've certainly not heard it discussed much, is what it is the Department of Public Health expectations relative to implementation of its version of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act that applies to cannabis. For those who have spent time with the Sherman Act in years past know that there are issues in which people get mired.

The core issue here for us is what is considered misbranding of a product? Is a product misbranded if you make therapeutic, beneficial claims about the product that cannot be backed up by the science? Course we find ourselves caught between a rock and a hard place, because the science is not there, because it's been illegal. And so nobody has been able to study some of the therapeutic benefits.

There is an operation down at UC San Diego that has made some initial overtures in that regard, but they have a long way to go. It's going to be very important for the Department of Public Health and others who are enforcing the Sherman Act to be more liberal in their interpretation of what therapeutic benefits are. Otherwise it could be used as a hammer against the people who are actually seeking licensure and

seeking to turn this into a well-regulated business. It deserves a lot of attention, not at this time. But certainly hope that the Legislature will spend some time looking at this issue over the next few months. Thank you.
Danielle Kando-Kaiser on behalf of the Electronic Frontier Foundation in strong support.

Probably, my colleague, the Vice Chair, will probably tell you that one of the problems that we have with budgeting, and I've worked for government for quite a while, we don't have real time technology to show what we actually have. If you have a question, it has to go through the Department of Finance and LAO.

Then it go to the secretary who then asked the department head, who asked the deputy department head, who asked the bureau chief, who asked the section head. And then it gets down to the person who actually who actually has to get the answer. Then it's gotta get scrubbed right back through that process to the Governor, who may have another question, and it goes back down through the process.

What I'm saying here is, most governmental agencies do not have a system in place, where you can actually see real time expenditures. Now I would suggest as I have suggested when I worked for the City of Los Angeles, that we invested sometimes in Technology. So that we could actually see real time expenditures,

on what we're spending and most importantly accurate expenditure. With that in mind my question is really, it's really about direction. Since this Governor came in, he's made some strides in insuring that we don't have as many people incarcerated in our state prisons, and

I've heard a lot of different estimates of what that number could be. Whether it's avoidance of bringing people in or we're pushing. We pushed a lot of people down to the jail system, which means either cost avoidance, or we're not spending that. I've heard numbers as high as 40,000.

I've heard estimates as high as $2.9 billion in either cost avoidance, or money we don't. We didn't have to spend on corrections. However since I've been here, the correction budget has gone up, and up, and up every year.

And I've asked corrections when I was on Sub 5 to kind of give me some understanding. Of why you probably now have empty cells and in fact, I'm being told we have an opportunity very soon to have all the people who are out of state in prison in places like Mississippi and other places, back in to California.

I know they're not building extra beds to bring them in, they're bringing them in to empty cells. And so there's obviously some cost savings, but it's never seen to be reflected and it's problematic because, I mean we could take half of that, 1.5 billion, and we could.

Cut that budget by 1.5 billion and restore some of the funding that we want. I would say let's start with Prop 47. That's woefully unfunded, as the LAO has said, and bring that back up to $150 million. Give some money to the courts so they can do their job so we can continue to keep people out of prison.
And I'll leave the rest of the money to the members of this Committee to decide how to divvy that up.

So those expenditures are investments that will further reduce the amount of people in prison, which will give you more savings, which means again, your budget should not go up. It should go down. To sit here and tell me that the programs that we have for rehabilitation is increasing the budget.

When we made a concerted effort from everybody on this Committee to do that to reduce the budget. And then to tell me it's my fault, or our fault, because we believe in rehabilitation, that it's going to go up? I do not accept that, I do not accept that at all. And so, again, I've asked for verification of why the budget's gone up.

You don't have to do it now, you didn't do it two years ago, so I don't expect you to do it between now and the May revise. But I am going to continue to ask this question, until I get some accounting. And I don't care how many different levels of bureaucracy you have to go through in corrections. We need an answer to that, I think it's fair.
You don't have to answer if you don't have it.
Thank you. I look forward to seeing it.
Thank you, Mr. President and members.

I join with my colleague from Sacramento in asking that we adjourn in memory of a dear friend of mine. I had the opportunity to spend a couple years with Sutter Brown when he first came here to the capital. It was a try out, because the Brown's didn't have a dog at the time of his election. And the Governor's sister had Sutter but was traveling to Chicago and

felt that Sutter wouldn't be an appropriate place for him in Chicago. And asked Jerry if he would consider being a part of their family. So that happened right at the transition here at the Governor's office. And Sutter was a part of that transition and I wanted to mention a couple stories

that I found humorous during my time with Sutter for the benefit of all of his friends. One of the things that Sutter got at the early part of his time was full rights to the governor's, what we call the horseshoe. His suite of offices. So he would run around throughout the day and foraging for

anything he could find in folks trash cans and around and behind their desks. And one of the things you Learned very quickly with Sutter is you could never have a closed door. Because if Sutter saw a closed door, he would bark. That included the Governor's door and so it was important that all the doors be open at least in the early stages of his time here.

At some point, he got frisky enough where he wasn't given the full reign of the office. But that was a great way to bring levity to the start of the administration. I thought that one of the most enjoyable times with Sutter was right before March Madness, the college basketball championship.

And Sutter through his way of communication decided he wanted to have a bracket just like everybody else. And everybody knows how difficult it is to pick the winner of the March Madness. I personally went through those choices with Sutter and at the end of the day decided that the Huskies of Connecticut was the right pick for him to go all the way. And low and behold in that 2011 year, the Connecticut Huskies did go all the way.

And that was Sutter's charm and foresights shown in interesting ways. But we also had some serious time as the Senator from Sacramento eluded, we had the dodgy diplomacy of Sutter. And I enjoyed bringing Sutter up to Senator Dutton's office was the minority leader of the Senate. Engaged in serious negotiations with the Governor on the budget crisis that we faced in 2011.

And Senator Dutton loved Sutter and his staff were charmed by his fiendliness and willingness to cross party lines. But not everything was about state business for Sutter. We received a lot of communications from friends and fans throughout the state that wanted Sutter to engage.

And one poignant moment was a woman who was undergoing cancer treatments. And her friends to make her feel better, they would all wear green wigs. Because this young woman had lost her hair and she would wear a green wig. And her friends thought it would show camaraderie in that what she was going through, they all wore green wigs.

And so we got a letter asking would Sutter wear a green wig to send out a positive message to this young woman who was going through that treatment. And certainly one of my favorite pictures of Sutter is Sutter in the green wig. He, as animals will in a human environment, there were times in the day where he had to do his business. And I was always the first to volunteer to take him outside to take care of those matters.

And it was on those walks that the charm of Sutter showed itself where he was always willing to take a picture with anybody he saw. Staffers, visitors, members, you would just have to stop for a moment. Say his name and he would immediately turn over, so he could get a tummy rub and an instant picture for everybody's Facebook page. And he did that with great grace and charm.

Thank you, Mr Chairman and members. And thank you, Mr Thurmond, for your activity and your extreme interest in this bill. It's been an honor, actually, working with both of you. I'm Gary Cooper, I represent the California Association of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons.

And basically that is the group of professionals that you're really discussing today because that was specifically the provider that was involved in Caleb's Law. So today you're obviously going to be hearing about whether the questions about the safety of whether or not the provider should be doing the anesthesia at the same time as doing the procedure.

So I'm not going to take a lot of time, because I have a lot of professionals here with me. But the one question that's going to be answered is, the reason why we are absolutely convinced, not because we have good intentions, not because we are considering ourselves just so professional that we don't make mistakes. But the folks that I deal with every day on this specific issue have been so well trained over the years,

their training is so extreme and their results have been so professional. And there have been so many cases where nothing, absolutely nothing, adverse has happened during the course of the procedures and this has gone on for 50, 60, 70 years. It's very unfortunate that every now and then there is an adverse reaction and an adverse action and unfortunately this happened to Caleb.

And again, we have no idea what the parents are going through because we can only imagine. But what our concern is today is that as we've heard previously, the access to care issue by having another provider in the room. If we truly thought, and the folks sitting to my right and to my left truly thought,

that that was the best way to save another patient, we would certainly support it. To us, that would be tragic.

So I will let my professional colleagues here speak. But I just want to let you know that we are absolutely concerned about the safety of children and the safety of the public that the oral surgeons treat. But we'd like this particular recommendation to be studied a little bit further. As a recommendation was made in the board report that they should take a look at how
it affects access to care, how it affects personnel, and how it affects economics.

Thank you Mr. Chairman.  We all sat through the hearing a moment ago and heard the overview which I thought was very informative, I'm sure to you and to me. It's certainly a program that is in turmoil, it's not new. 500 recycling centers closed in 2015. We now know another 500 in 2016. We've heard about the structural deficits that are in place.

There's some optimism that it's going to get better. Only losing $6 million in 1819. We've heard about the lack of data and transparency in some of the financials. And in terms of some of the recycling facts that can inform a thoughtful long term policy changes in the law.

And we've also heard from the grocery stores, unprepared to accept to allow this product, unclear as to whether they're paying the consumers or not paying the consumers, whether they actually lose money when they submit that product for recycling by the pound. So all of that was what Senator McGuire and I were facing last June.

When we engaged in conversations with the administration about the program. And I applaud Senator McGuire, who was actually involved a much longer period than I was in terms of seeing the impact of these centers closing throughout his district. As we have seen in many of ours. And so that's the background for what happened next.

In our conversation with the administration, they acknowledge the deficiencies in the program, the problems in the program as I have identified. They acknowledge of the grocers have been constructive players, in trying to work with all the stakeholders and how we can reform this important program and they were sensitive to the fact that the groceries were stuck in the middle facing these letters

that indicated they were going to begin to be fined a $100 a day if they were not in compliance with this 30 year old law. The administration agreed with the extent of this problem, and they committed to Senator Mcguire and I, that they would work with us, and with the Legislature on trying to craft a solution going forward, but they acknowledged that it was complex.

And it required a lot of thoughtfulness and care but they also acknowledged that grocery stores were stuck in the middle. They committed to us, that rather than try to do something through an urgency in August, which was the final month of the legislative year, that they wanted the time to develop their own program through the fall. And that they wanted to propose what they saw as a potential solution with the Governor's Budget in January.

And that they would be willing to take a grace letter, 90 day grace letter to put forward during that period of time so that the grocers weren't stuck in the middle as they have been. And we, both Senator McGuire and I, heard those proposals and we both agree that if they would provide those 90 day extension letters through the fall.

And as long as the grocers continue to operate in good faith. As their proposal went through the process, the beginning of '17, that they would be held harmless, that that was a reasonable path forward. Now, what ended up happening was, the stakeholder meetings that the administration held in the fall, some of them did take place.

Both Senator McGuire and I were not consulted, informed about any of those. We Learned in November that the 90 grace letters that had been provided to groceries had changed. And now the letters that were going out were that they had to accept the product or face a fine. And that was a change in course in what had been promised to us.

So we'll looped back to the administration to ask for what happened, what changed. And they indicated that the law allowed them to provide a 90 day grace letter but nothing further than that. And that in order to provide an additional decision grace period that they needed a change in the law. And they didn't feel that they had the authority to do that.

And that is what led to Senator McGuire and I's decision to submit this piece of legislation that gives the administration that change in the law. So that they could provide what they had promised to us in June of 16. As you can see, this bill is very narrowly crafted

to provide the legal authority of the Governor to provide these waivers. It's a very small relief for a very short period of time, were this bill to move through the legislative process. And it's why we have it before you and we hope that it will garner your support. Senator Mcguire.

Mr. Chairman before you close it, I know that Mark Murray from Californians Against Waste, hasn't taken a position for or against. But he has some observations that, if it's okay with you, I would invite him to share his thoughts. Sure Mr. Murray.
Senator, I don't know the exact number, but it would provide the opportunity for the Governor to give that grace period, were this to become in effect for those that would need it.

Well Mr. Chairman thank you for the opportunity to have the bill heard before you. And I think as you have heard we are not trying to fry this bill is necessarily the big fix for the program. Although we're open to working with you and Mr. Chairman and the Committee. And with the stakeholders that if there's a way to find a consensus point along the path ahead that we would be very open to trying to do that.

This bill has a long ways to go. It would go to appropriations next as I understand it. That there is an opportunity to slow this process down as we try to work together to find common ground. And I think that would be a constructive way forward.

We can't have perfect be the enemy of the good. And we know these retailers and grocers are in the middle. But this isn't meant to resolve the issue of the budget process versus the legislative process. I recognize that and I'm as sympathetic as you are about that.

It's really a tempting to provide a little window of opportunity desgression for the administration if they choose to use it. So that would be the narrow and way it when was crafted. And it would be I think our intention to try to work with you and you chair as it goes forward to make sure it's still fulfilling those important purposes.

Thank you Mr. Chair and Mr Chair, and staff. Jeff Vaca representing the Riverside County Superintendent of Schools and the 23 school district superintendents in Riverside County. Helen Christine with the Legislative Analyst's Office. So, our understanding is that the administration is proposing to create one regulatory structure. We think in general that is a good idea. if you have different license types under the two different structures and different ownership requirements for those license types.
