And so, we think that there's a lot of logic behind having one regulatory system where it makes sense in order to or at least in terms of regulatory structure to deal with the industry.

Good morning, Madame Chair, Members of the Committee. My name's Richard Miadich, I'm a partner with Olson, Hagel and Fishburn. Our law firm in consultation with the Drug Policy Alliance, Tamar Todd, who I know will be speaking to you later. We were the primary drafters of Prop 64.

I just want to take a few minutes and give you sort of a brief overview of what our thinking was in terms of the allocations. And what limitations we faced when we were doing that, the first in terms of a legal restriction, we were mindful of the single subject rule that we have in California. That requires that initiatives, all the provisions within an initiative, are reasonably germane to each other.

And so from our purposes as the lawyers, we wanted to make sure that where we allocated the tax revenues had some connection to the main purpose of the initiative which was to decriminalize marijuana. If we violate the single subject rule, the entire initiative is invalidated. So we made a risk assessment there and we wanted to make sure we were careful on how we allocated that money.

From a policy perspective, of course the members of the coalition had significant input on how we allocated those monies. We had significant outreach with various groups that includes social justice groups, drug policy alliance and others, environmental groups. A number of environmental groups gave us extensive feedback which we incorporated by and large into the initiative. And then the state and local governments also provided input which was incorporated into the initiative.

In addition to that, at the time we were drafting the initiative, the Lieutenant Governor's blue ribbon Commission on marijuana policy was holding stakeholder meetings around the state, receiving input. We looked at other states, and one of the lessons we felt that we Learned was that it would be a mistake to treat the new revenues we generate as sort of a panacea for all of California's financial woes and instead the best approach would be to direct it at specific purposes.

That's in the Blue Ribbon Commission report and I think we've seen that experience in other states, so that was part of our thinking as well. Then finally during the drafting process we reached out and received significant feedback on the tax structure and the allocations from the Board of Equalization.

So we tried to engage them during the drafting process to make sure that they were able to provide their feedback to us before the initiative went final. The final point I want to make, this dove tails with something Drew just mentioned, we're also mindful that we want to provide some measure of flexibility for the Legislature with respect to the allocation of the tax revenues over time. And so, that is what lead to the provision that does allow the Legislature to reallocate the money after 10 years.

And in addition to that, we do provide that the Legislature may, by a two thirds vote, amend the initiative consistent with the purposes and intent. And those are my prepared remarks. I'm happy to answer questions.

Well, based on stakeholder input there were a few preferences that we put in. The community reinvestment money, obviously, a portion of that money, 50% of that account needs to go to qualified nonprofits to assist communities that have been disproportionately impacted by prior drug policies. So that's one preference that was built into the initiative.

With respect to youth education, treatment and prevention, we do fund programs to reduce drop out rates in schools and high schools. And that money is supposed to be prioritized, obviously, to schools that have higher drop out rates than others. So there are areas in the initiative where we specify a preference.

With respect to the Legislature's role I would say that the Legislature could by a two-thirds vote, further define various terms within those programs. So if we use a term, for example, a system navigation services is a term that is used in the community reinvestment bucket, it's not defined. The Legislature would have the ability to define that.

Right, and so the way the 60% bucket works is the money that goes into that is actually allocated both to the Department of Education and to the Department of Public Health. And so that money then goes to-
Precisely.

Well, I appreciate the question, Senator, and certainly, it's a difficult issue and there aren't any easy answers to it. With respect to the initiative, at the time we were crafting it, we did have guidance from the federal Department of Justice. Eight points of federal enforcement priorities, and we stuck very closely to those. We made it a point of emphasis, to ensure that the initiative put a structure in place that met all of those federal enforcement criteria.

So we were protected, at least under the Cole Memo, the Ogden Memo, to the extent that those applied. And then what we also did in the initiative, which is somewhat unique with respect to initiatives, is by giving the Legislature the ability to add additional amendments, additional protections, we gave you the ability to add those types of protections to the extent

they become necessary to protect, to the extent we can, against federal intervention. Some of this is a matter of simply the supremacy clause. There are things that the federal government can do that we cannot prevent at the state, and that's just a reality of our structure. But we did give you the flexibility to address some of those concerns in the future.

I know you've talked before, earlier this morning, about the concerns about an all cash business. We can't solve the banking problem, obviously that's a federal issue. But what we did do is, we were mindful of that. We have provisions in the initiative that require minimum security requirements for retailers, for distributors throughout the chain,

to try and recognize the fact that this is an all cash business. We give the regulators the authority to impose additional requirements at the regulatory level to prevent carjacking, as something you mentioned, or other security breaches. And then of course you have the ability to add additional requirements to that.

Taking your last point first, I've certainly been not involved in any discussion about trying to challenge that. In light of, I think we are about up to nine states, that have now legalized recreation use of marijuana. We use the term legalize, we are actually decriminalizing at the state level. And to me that's a significant difference, because although its not legal under federal law, we are not compelled, as California, to continue making it illegal here in California.

We've chosen not to, and so, part of that decision of course is that local governments and state governments can't be compelled to enforce these federal laws. We have made a different choice, that's how I sort of-
That's the way we framed it, yes.

the tax rates, whether they're accomplishing the purposes of the initiative and then it's within the Legislature's authority certainly, I think, to require that there be additional over sight over how the money is been allocated and spent. Nothing in the initiative defense fund.

Well, I think, taking the tax piece of that first. What the initiative does? And again, we consulted with BOE in crafting the tax section is it explicitly empowers the Board of Equalization to determine the method and manner of payment of the tax. So the tax rate may become effective January 1st, 2018.

But if the infrastructure was not in place to immediately begin collecting those taxes, the BOE has regulatory authority to delay collection of the tax until such future time as they feel they are prepared to do that. So the initiative actually, it does already afford that authority. With respect to delayed implementation beyond January 1st,

we anticipated that there may be some desire to delay that implementation date. That's why we include a provisional license as one of the types of licenses. So if the regulatory agencies aren't fully prepared to issue full 12-month licenses by January 1st, they have the flexibility to issue temporary licenses as a bridge prior to full licensure.

And I think that's actually consistent with one thing that the initiative does which is require by September 1st of 2017 that there is a public, essentially a public information outreach program that is implemented in the state to inform the public what is permissible under the initiative and what's not. And that would include, of course, what the plan is for implementation on the business side.

Well, I was just kind of following up on that question. The Bureau of State Audits actually has specific audit authority to review the activities of the various licensing agencies. The legislative analysis is required under the initiative to report back to the Legislature with respect to

Put your right hand over your heart. Ready, begin. I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with and liberty and justice for all.

Thank you, Madam Speaker. Today, I am honored to present in the back of chambers, Dr Terrence James Roberts, one of the Little Rock Nine, one of the nine children that integrated Central High School in 1957. Terrence Roberts was born in Little Rock Arkansas to Margaret and William Roberts. He first attended segregated schools like Dunbar Junior High School and Horace Mann. In 1957, he along with my uncle and eight other children, young people, they were all teenagers, volunteered to attend an all white Little Rock Central High School the next fall, helping to desegregate one of the nations largest schools.

On September 4th, 1957, the Little Rock Nine made an unsuccessful attempt to enter Central High, which had been segregated. The Arkansas National Guard, under orders from the Governor and an angry mob of about 400, surrounded the school and prevented them from going in. On September 23rd, 1957, a mob of about 1,000 people surrounded the school again as the students attempted to enter. The following day, President Dwight D Eisenhower took control of the Arkansas National Guard from the Governor and sent soldiers to accompany the students to school for protection. Soldiers were deployed at the school for the entirety of the school year.

Although they were unable to prevent incidents of violence against the group inside, many of them were not able to graduate from the school. Because the next year Governor Faubus closed down all schools in Arkansas so that no African American student could go to school in Little Rock, Arkansas. Mr. Roberts then matriculated to California and graduated from Los Angeles High, my Alma mater, Roman. He then continued his educational prowess and received his PhD. I know a lot of times on this floor, I bring up the Little Rock Nine.

I bring up my uncle. For me, I knew him personally, and I think for every member here on the floor, you get an opportunity as we talk about living legends today. This is an actual living legend. This is an actual person in flesh and blood who's in the history books here on our floor today who as a teenager, as a teenager, changed the world. So we should always remember that as we make decisions of what we're going to do on this floor. That we too can change the world and remember what those nine young people did in 1957, Dr Terrence J Roberts.

Madame Speaker, members, on behalf of the Women's Caucus, I rise in strong support of ACR 6 recognizing February as Black History month. I want to personally welcome the former Assemblymembers of the 47th District, Assemblymember Amina Carter and Cher Brown, who are with us today also.

As we honor and reflect on the accomplishments of African-American leaders in the fields of politics, education, science, and entertainment, we cannot forget our collective role in the fight for equality and justice. Justice takes many forms. Economic justice providing that regardless of where you start, you have a path to the middle class. Racial justice, making sure that regardless the color of your skin, you're treated fairly and with dignity.

Environmental justice, ensuring that where you live does not dictate your right to have clean air to breathe and clean water to drink. Too often, I know that justice may feel as if it is lacking. As many of our diverse communities still face many challenges, challenges that often bear a disproportionate burden on African-American and other minority communities.

This why we must remember that equality and justice are not static markers in the road of our democracy. We must consistently tend to it. Following the example of many of the great leaders that are recognized during this month. The struggle continues and we must ensure that we do not become satisfied with only partial progress but rather equitable opportunity for all the people of this state.

I would like to close by congratulating the Black Caucus on its 50th anniversary. And, encourage my colleagues to take time this month to reflect on, not only the rich history of the African-American community, but on our role in the struggle for justice. I ask for your aye vote on ACR 6.

Thank you, Madame Chair, and this may sound like Senator Beall and I are working together, but I will give you a practical example. I worked several years in the City of Los Angeles. I left as Director of real estate. I've actually built a detention jails facility in the City of LA. There was a time when the City of Los Angeles allowed police departments and fire departments to help when we got a bond from the citizens. The elected officials decided what the parameters were to be for particular police station.

They allowed the police captains and the fire captains to kind of manage the construction project and what we ended up with was a mess, a lot of the police stations didn't come in on time or on budget, probably most of them and so the Mayor and the City Council decided that they would take it out of their hands and they would allow only the Department of Public Works, because what happens is, with implementation, with known conditions construction projects, things can go awry in a lot of ways.

And the thing that bothered the elected officials, the people that were elected by their constituents was once they decided the overall idea of what that fire police station would be, it would go drastically the other way. As I look at all of these projects, because one of my question really is about if the BSCC and all the construction that we're doing, even that Committee we talked about. I don't think I heard about having an engineer that would sit with you to tell you whether or not for example this list of 10, 7 and 9. From my experience, all of them can have visitation. All of them can have in-person visitation.

And you can require that, whether it's a dollar amount or whether you force them to do it within the parameters of what you were told they needed to do. It can be done and it can be done quickly. Even on the in construction part. I don't know what an establishment phase means, but it sounds like it's earlier than drawings or working drawings. If you do the working drawings, you can definitely, you can definitely make the changes that are needed that this Committee wants done right now. If during construction phase, you can do change orders.

You can make changes and I'll leave you with this. If we knew for example, the jail we built, if we had known that having the property room next to the cells and the venting together. That when you put in 3 or 400 pounds of marijuana in the holding room, that it would have an effect in the cells, a happy effect. We would have had a change order fairly quickly. Understood. By us now having engineers who can explain that, I think if you look at the projects that have gone forward since then, they're on time and on budget and when things go awry, they go back, which I think with this Committee is talking about they go back to the contractor.

And they either have to eat that amount or we have what is called callbacks and I don't think you have callbacks in any of our state construction projects, whereby if they don't follow the parameters of what we want, we can either hold the money or we can pull money back and make sure that we get exactly what we want and so I just need to know, do we have anything like that in the BSCC? Do we have anything like that in the state where we have people overlooking all of these construction projects that we do to ensure that the state and more important, the voters get exactly what they want?
So should you have more power of this construction or somebody else should have more power of this construction project? Because we're talking a lot of money.

Well, you have most of the public safety assembly, sub five years, so you're almost there, obviously something we will be taking up and I think there still is this question as to whether new regs were even needed in relationship to Title 15 and of course, we have the additional factor that is the state that's paying for this construction. Senator Mitchell.
I pledge allegiance, to the flag of the United States of America and to the republic for which it stands, one nation under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.

Members it's a great honor to join with his family, so many of his friends are here to honor this great man. I, was a student activist in the 70's, and certainly we all looked up to, Tom Hayden at the time for many reasons his activism, his courage, his willingness to speak truth to power.

It came as somewhat of a shock in 1981, when I heard that he was going to the consummate outsider wanted to be the inside, run for the state Legislature was a surprising thing to hear. And not necessarily understandable. As the pro tem emeritus spoke earlier, he talked about how polarizing he was when he served in the Legislature.

For those of us who observed up close the campaign in 1982, it was as polarized as it could ever be. And, there were some things of note that I wanted to Observe at this time that many people in the establishment, even in the Democratic establishment thought that he was radioactive. And they were afraid to get even close to him.

Even in a picture with him saying anything positive about him. And I know, that he and his campaign folks were wrestling with that. A view of how to get people to understand that he was a thoughtful person and that he had an important story to tell.

And I thought, that one of the acts of courage at that time, maybe not remembered today, was the biggest establishment leader in our state. Had the courage to step up and author a letter in his magazine that he put out. It was that person was Edmund G Pat Brown, the Governor of our state.
And he said this, if I paraphrase. He said I'm retired now from public office, so I can speak bluntly. Tom Hayden is a good man but he's been given a bum rap.
This is a 24 page magazine.
We've all been in politics a long time. We've seen a lot of these things. But one of the special things about Tom and I know his friends and family. I can connect as he was a very genuine person.
And he understood back then the power of authenticity. And so I'd like to close my remarks by reading something that Tom said in his own words in 1982.

On the whole and proud to having been consistently committed to justice for so long. And I'm a wiser and more experienced and more patient person as a result. Like yourself probably I would like to rewrite some chapters in my life, but we can only learn from our mistakes, not erase them.

I'm not the angry young man I was in the 1960's. But I'm still and independent, concerned human being ready to tackle the issues of our time. My opponents have tried to exploit voter fears by distorting my past. They refused to acknowledge that I changed in any way in the past 20 years.

Instead they dredge up distorted quotations from long ago using the same tactics perfected by Joe Mccarthy and Richard Nixon. Please remember that the New Deal in Social Security were called radical in their time as was our American Independence Movement. What we need today is confidence in new directions not fear of change. Robert Kennedy used to say quote, I'd rather light a candle than curse the darkness, unquote.

That's how I feel. This pamphlet tells the true story of the past two decades. After you read it I hope you will give me a chance to keep that candle of hope alive for all of us. Sincerely, Tom Hayden.
I thank you for allowing me to be a part of the remembrance of his impactful life. His activism and care for all of us, for all of humanity lives on.
Thank you, Madam Chair, I just wanted to, as a co-author of this bill, I want to thank you for your leadership on this.

As somebody who comes from a community that had to undergo bankruptcy I can tell you our parks were the ones that took the first hit. And then, secondarily my city manager, one of my town started off as somebody who was working in parks and rec.

So those kind of, I think, jobs where you're out in the community, serving people are also a great way to introduce young staffers to the world of public service. So I was going to move the bill, but it's already been done by my colleague, Mr. Bonta, so I will just chime in with a me too.
He said friends my book of life as an involved American citizen now spans 22 years.
Without objection.

And again, I found this fascinating over the weekend. It was a letter to the editor that ran in a different state, but that everyone's, I think have been talking about. And I think these ideas are still out there, which is why it's so important to look at this. So this was a letter to the editor in Utah.

Here's a problem with the equal pay being considered by the Utah Legislature. Traditionally, men have earned more than women in the workplace because they needed to consider, they were considered the primary bread winners for the family.

It's simple economics. If that happens, then men will have a even more difficult time earning enough to support their families. Which will mean more mothers will be forced to leave the home, where they may prefer to be, to join the workforce to make up the difference.

inviting the Public Safety Committee to participate. Although my Committee is familiar with issues faced by minors involved in the juvenile delinquency system, some of us are not familiar with the challenges faced by victims with child abuse and

neglect that find themselves in the juvenile dependency system for obvious reasons. A child who suffers abuse or neglect is more likely to be arrested as a juvenile. So it's important that our three committees, Public Safety, Judiciary, and Human Services become well versed on how youth who straddle the two systems can better be served by both.

I look forward on learning about the experience of dual status youth and the challenges they face and to the testimony we hear today, from county representatives who have innovative local programs. I hope to learn how we can use these experiences to develop best practices and possibly introduce legislation in the future.
I want to thank the witnesses, and the Committee Members for taking the time. Thank you.

I'll do it much better this time. Good afternoon, thank you Assembly Member Stone for organizing this hearing. And most important, inviting the Public Safety Committee to participate. Although my Committee is familiar with issues faced by minors involved in the juvenile delinquency system

some of us are not as familiar with the challenges faced by victims of child abuse and neglect that find themselves in the juvenile dependency system. For obvious reasons, a child who suffers abuse or neglect is more likely to be arrested as a juvenile. So it's important that our three committees, Public Safety, Judiciary,

and Health Services become well versed on how youth who straddle the two systems can better be served by both. I look forward to learning about the experience of dual status youth and the challenges they face and to the testimony we hear today from county representatives who have innovative local programs, I hope to learn how we can use the experiences to develop best practices,
and possibly legislation in the future. I want to thank the witnesses and the Committee Members for taking their valuable time today to participate.

Thank you. Thank you so much for providing the testimony today. Jennifer, one of the things that you've said was the data is telling us the story of our system, not of our youth, and I think even more so is telling us a story of the failure of our system, not the failure of our youth. I think that as you say moving towards our system towards diversion is extremely important. Excuse me. I want to congratulate you. You are that success story and you're right, you say that your story is not the same as the others who were with you. There's something about you. You're now a father, you're a business owner, you're a leader. You're married, you've got a wife.

So you've got great responsibilities, but what I love about the panel is that you're not just coming to tell us about a problem and telling us how to solve it. You're saying I lived that and I'm telling you what can be done. You gave a five very specific things and I think that going back to what Jennifer said about data and data, it's not going to tell us what we're doing because clearly we have failed our youth. Clearly, and we're not going to, we can't study it more to say how we're going to fix it. We wanted see where are the problems and let's talk to the people we actually failed. You succeeded, but there are others who haven't.

But your five specific points I think need to go in a record that's how we need to start, stop calling law enforcement as a first resort, that cannot be the first resort, you're right as parents I'm not going to call police when my son acts up, or if he runs away or anything else. I'm going to try to figure out other ways, but just going down the five that you gave I commend you for that because, I think right there, that's our plan right there and I thank you.

I also want to thank you for coming to testify today obviously, it's good to hear your viewpoint, especially for the panel here and for the people listening. I came to this work of public safety in 2012 and onwards and Mr. Stone. Knowing nothing about it. In my first meeting, it's one of the first meeting I've ever had on the was from private prisons, who came in and show me both anecdotal and statistics that showed that they could determine how many prison beds they needed, in 10 to 12 years by the number of third graders that could not read at third grade level.

It showed me then that this prison industrial system is not only broken, or more important, it may not be broken, because it's set up to feed into the school to prison because of this new President deportation pipeline, we need to figure out ways to stop this train from rolling. I'm glad you're here and i don't want to condense it down to one thing, but what struck me was. They just need one factor to determine a multi $1 billion prison plantation system and I would like to be able to focus some of our efforts towards our policies, our procedures, and even our money into one thing.

Jennifer and Blade, I love that name Blade. You two are very articulate, you're smart, you're able to get your education spite of people telling you can't use pencil, you can't read, you do not have access to proper education that most youth get. Do you believe, having a good pre-school having a good base education may have helped you to be able to sit here right now. Is that one of the factors? Out of all of the pediments that you've had to experience there had been some guiding light that got you from there to here, would you say that being able to educate yourself or being able to take that step further.

Is that something this panel talks about on the floor, about putting more money in early childhood education making sure our young people are able to not only to compete in the future, but able to read, write, if you look at most of the people that are incarcerated, they have a very difficult time with basic math skills and being able to read, and so I believe this system does not help in your educational prowess, it in fact bodes to make sure you do not succeed in that, which further perpetuates young people from being in the juvenile justice system. So from your perspective, what was the significant thing that got you from there to here?

And so, I think that's why we're even more invested in making sure that we are recruiting women Into the professions. That historically have been seem as male dominated. That tend to have higher rates of employment or rates of payment. So we know we have to work it out for us. And I'll also just say like on the heels of this.

That I am introducing a new bill, AB168. To help close the big gap, that says you cannot ask what someone has made before, when you are interviewing them. And if they ask, you must be able to give them a salary range, that is appropriate for that job. So that people have an idea of where to begin and negotiate from.

And to know that their past salary, has not been a factor in weighing that in. I know like many of us, I have worked in state government. And know that often times women will have to take time out of a job. And even though I was a social worker, in a pretty woman dominated field. Often times men were the supervisors.

Because they had been around longer or hadn't taken time off for family reasons. So we know we have work to do which is again why we're convened here today. And our first panel is going to look at, we're going to welcome Lauri Damrell and Nancy Kishner Rodriguez from the Commission of the status of women and girls.

To discuss the work that the Commission has done. They've been very active in this. There's a report that has been prepared. I'm sure all we've all looked over. And now are very interested in hearing what they have to say. And if I could just have, please have a seat.

And I am surprised that even after all the attention we've given to it, we are now, instead of closing the gap, it is still widening. And that's something that I'm looking forward to hearing from our panelists, our witnesses. Thank you.

They need to make sure to support their families and allow the mother to remain in the home to raise and nurture the children. If businesses are forced to pay women the same as male earnings, that means that they will have to reduce the pay for the men that they employ.

And as even more women enter the workforce, that creates more completion for jobs, even mens' jobs. And puts further downward pressure on the pay for all jobs, meaning more and more mothers will be forced into the workforce. And that is bad for families, and thus for all of society.

It's a vicious cycle that only gets worse the more equality of pay is forced upon us. It's a situation of well-meaning intention, but negative unintended consequences. We should encourage our Legislature to drop this whole notion. Let the marketplace determine what free market forces will prevail.

It is not the role of government to dictate to business what that should pay anyway either with minimum wage or equal pay for men and women. So these ideas are still out there, right? That women would much prefer to be at home and are not active members of the workforce.

And so, unlike other places in the country, we do believe it's the government's job to make sure that everybody has the opportunity to be able to support themselves and their families. And so first witnesses please.

Thank you. My name is Nancy Kirschner Rodriguez. And I am proud to be the Executive Director of the California Commission on the Status of Women and Girls. And I will just add a few comments. The Commission has key areas that are mandated for us to focus on.

One major one is gender in the workplace and employment, and it was through the leadership of our commissioners, of course, including Assemblymember Garcia and Commissioner Damrell that we really decided to focus on implementation, and look at ways that we could effectively enhance what's happening.

And so, of course, this task force is key. And a lot of our, a lot of our work is focused on improving economic security for women and girls, and in that measure, families in our great state. The distinguished group that this task force includes makes it all the better, I think.

Because we really have people that we believe might not otherwise accept, perhaps in a legislative setting, be working together. And at that time, they might be testifying on something. So it's really, I think from that perspective, it's very important.

And I just want to take this opportunity, since I know that Assemblymember Rodriguez mentioned it, and another area that the Commission is very focused, it does really have to do with the wage gap, is the area of STEM or STEAM.

(Are they going to take questions?) All right, let me just, so you've been looking at this closely, and you're committed to it. If you had a magic wand, what is the one thing that you would do that we would all wake up tomorrow, and know that we had more parity in the state?

And I think that one of the reasons I asked and I'm sure all of us have done probably right or wrongs. Doing right alongs with officers with both of men and women I mean there is just, I've been with woman officer who has been able to go run right up on a porch with a group of men and go into a house that I instinctively know it would not have been the same easy path for a man just because of societal defenses and posturing and all those things we do.
And I'm sure we'll be seeing a lot more of you as we go forward with this.
What is it for men?
Which is a huge issue. Men have traditionally been paid more in law enforcement. And we know there's an incredible under-representation of women working in the law enforcement field.
So we're excited to hear about your progress, your challenges and your initiatives to try to achieve this great goal we're all working towards.
