Good morning, Madam Chair and Senators. I've been asked to provide you with a brief overview of the recent efforts California has made to reduce its inmate population. You should have a handout called Impact of Recent Criminal Justice Policies on the State Correctional Population. And my presentation has three components.

First I'll provide a history of the federal court oversight that has led to the reductions in the inmate population. Second, I'll discuss recent policy changes that have allowed the state to make these reductions. And finally, I'll present a chart to illustrate the size of these reductions. On page one, you'll see an overview of federal court oversight of the state's inmate population.

In 1995, a federal court ruled that the states' provision of mental healthcare to inmates was in violation of the 8th Amendment of the US Constitution. This case is now known as Coleman v Brown. Similarly, in 2005 a Federal Court ruled in a case now

known as Plata v Brown that the state's provision of medical care to inmates was constitutionally inadequate. In 2006, the plaintiffs in the Coleman and Plata lawsuits filed motions to convene a federal three judge panel,

to assess why the state was unable to provide constitutionally adequate care to inmates. In 2009, the panel declared that prison overcrowding was the primary reason why the state was unable to provide adequate care. In 2010, the three judge panel ordered the state to reduce the population of its state owned and operated prisons to 137.5% of their design capacity.

And in 2014, the panel ordered the state to develop and implement various population reduction measures, to achieve and maintain compliance with the cap. If you turn to page two, you'll see that the state has used and continues to use various other means in addition to the court-ordered measures,

to reach and maintain compliance with the cap. These include housing inmates in contracted facilities, because contracted facilities don't count toward the capped population. And constructing additional capacity in the state-owned and operated prisons to increase their design capacity and therefore, increase the number of inmates that the state is allowed to hold in these facilities under the cap.

And finally by enacting several policy changes that have allowed the State to reduce its inmate population. And along with several voter approved measures, I will discuss these policy changes on page three. And specifically, I'm going to talk about five policy changes. The first was the 2011 Realignment, which limited who could be sent to state prison,

so instead requiring that certain lower level felons serve their incarceration terms in county jail rather than state prison. It also required that counties rather than the state supervise lower level felons when their released from prison. Second, Proposition 36, which was approved by the voters in 2012, changed California's Three Strikes law to impose a life sentence on

a third felony conviction only in cases of serious or violent crimes. It also allowed for re-sentencing of inmates who were serving life sentences under California's Three Strikes law, for a non serious, non violent felony. Third, Proposition 47, which was approved by the voters in 2014,

reduced penalties for certain non violent, non serious drug and property crimes and allowed people who were previously convicted of these crimes to apply for re-sentencing. And fourth, as I mentioned, the three judge panel ordered the state in 2014 to implement various population reduction measures. These included expanding inmates' eligibility to reduce their prison terms through credits that inmates earned from good behavior.

Creating new parole consideration processes for elderly inmates and non violent second striker inmates, and expanding parole eligibility for medically incapacitated inmates. And the fifth and final population reduction measure I'm going to talk about today is on page 4, and that is Proposition 57 which was passed by the voters in November of 2016.

And is expected to allow the state to further reduce its inmate population through expanding inmate eligibility for parole consideration. Increasing the state's authority to reduce inmates' prison terms through credits that inmates earn through good behavior and participating in rehabilitative and educational type programs.

And mandating that judges determine whether youth be subject to adult sentences in criminal court. And on page five, you'll see a chart which illustrates how these policy changes have affected the state's correctional population. The shaded portions of the columns show how the inmate and parolee populations have declined since 2011.

And the dashed lines show what CDCR estimated these populations would be absent the various population reduction measures. So between 2011 and 2016, the state's inmate population declined by 21%, and the parolee population declined by 52%.

Absent the various population reduction measures that took place over this timespan. The inmate and parolee populations were both expected to each be about 34,000 higher than they actually were in 2016. And this concludes my presentation, I'd be happy to take questions at the appropriate time.
Yes, part of the decline is based on, as you just said, realignment,

shifted responsibility for supervising lower level felons from the state parole to county probation departments. Also, when we change certain crimes from felonies to misdemeanors, for example, the Proposition 47. You sort of cut off the number of people who can go into the prison system.
And then therefore could ever be able to come out on parole, if that makes sense.

Question to finance. There were a lot of reasons that were offered at the time for realignment. Not the least of which was the federal court order for reducing our prison population. But part of that conversation was about how our costs at the state level were so much higher than incarceration at the county level.

And at least at the time, that I recall, the numbers that were offered up was that it cost about 50,000 to house a person in a state prison. And only about 30,000 at the county level. And so what confuses me a little bit about all this,

as I hear the testimony that you've offered, where adding one or subtracting one inmate at a state prison has a $9,500 incremental cost, marginal costs. $29,000 for a contracted bed. It seems to go counter to the suggestions that at
least maybe on a simple scale that the whole idea of
realignment in terms of cost savings weren't borne out.
Right, but do you recall that comparison that was offered during the realignment debate?

All right, but that might've been a false standard in which to evaluate realignment, at least as it relates to the cost savings issue. I appreciate that there were many other elements being proposed or being suggested as the positives out of it. But in terms of the cost side, I think that's what creates a lot of surprise among folks on the budgetary side. It's like this is what we were reducing, supposed to save us a lot of money.

We're not seeing a lot of savings. You talked about it earlier. Well, if you looked at growth of the budget over time, then maybe the suggestion of a billion or a billion and a half and savings didn't take into the full context of what we were facing.
But at least in terms of the per capita costs, or the per inmate costs, it seems to have been a little bit of an illusion.

All right, the last question I had was looking at the salaries, benefits, and retirement number that has grown so substantially. Could you break down those costs into those categories? How much of that 1.1 billion increase in the last five years is relating to retirement obligations?
And how much of that is related to the category of salaries and benefits?

All right, because that then gives us some sense of what we have some control over, right? Given current court cases and the like. The retirement obligation is not something we have any control over. But the salaries and benefits, 719 million is something that we do have some level of control over, right?

Those are all subject to collective bargaining agreements, right? So when we approve collective bargaining for these agreements, last year as I recall, is that right, for this category of employees. That those collective bargaining agreements are now built into that $719 $1 million increase, right?
Okay, very good. Thank you, Madam Chair.

Good afternoon, Madame Chair and members, Dawn Koepke with Mchugh, Koepke, and Associates here today. Actually, before you on behalf of three different clients. Slightly different issues. Crime Victims United of California.

Starting with Crime Victims United, certainly appreciate the comments to today with regard to victims, and support for victims, definitely appreciate that and look forward to being more involved in the discussion going forward as part of the sub-committee process.

Just would want to note a couple of things on their behalf. Found they are supportive of evidence based rehabilitation programs. And really have been talking a lot more the last couple of years about focusing more on a wrap around service, really intensive services.

Both inside the facility and outside. We've met with the secretary on a few occasions to talk about re-entry programs and models that we feel very strongly work very well. That really focus on those wrap around services.

And also have a measure of accountability attached to them for that particular individual whether it be in terms of accountability to their actual programming, and not just being in a position where they're just checking the box to gain the benefit of that for parole.

But really actually investing that and we appreciated the comments of the panelists today who really have demonstrated that that is possible, to take that accountability for themselves to their victims and to the benefits that the policies that have changed Recently will provide for them.

We would also, that said, just note that we are concerns just generally in terms of the policy discussions and debates, whether it be here in the capitol or at the ballot box, just a lack of discussion in more significant way about victim's impacts. Not all victims are created equal in terms of how they approach their victimization.

I think that that's a really important thing to highlight. And so we really just would encourage the full Budget Committee, and certainly the Subcommittee that will review these in greater detail, to take that into account and certainly consider that.

Specific to a couple of budget items we would note that the Governor's Budget does propose cuts to the victim witness assistance program grants. And that's of great concern. That provides a lot of wraparound services, intensive services, comprehensive services, for victims.

And so we would just place a placeholder with the Committee on that particular piece, as well as other things around ending funding for the Internet crimes against children untasked forces, which is of great concern as well. And we'll certain follow up on other items, as well. And, in terms of the other two clients, just wanted to briefly mention we also represent the child abuse prevention center.

It's an organization here, in Sacramento area umbrella organization, working with child abuse prevention councils in this state and family resource centers. They over the last number of years since realignment have seen an increase in terms of the individuals or families they're serving who have incarceration in their history.

They've been doing some great work in that space and so to the comment about looking upstream a little bit more around prevention both for the end result and dealing with and helping those families that are struggling with, incarcerated family members.

But also on the front end to avoid the victimization that some of the panelists perhaps alluded to today on the early side of life with child abuse and neglect. And so, we would also put a plug in to the subcommittees for additional look at child abuse and neglect prevention funding to kind of help to deal with some of those issues in a very proactive way.

There's a lot of great work being done in that space. And then, finally, just with regard to the education component of this. We represent the California Council for Adult Education as well as the California Adult Education Administrators Association who are also working more collaboratively with CDCR on and their Superintendent for correctional education, Dr. Brant Chote, on working more collaboratively with the K12 adult education system and providing wrap around education services.

Basic skills as well as short term career training for those that are coming back into communities. Again, though, I think overlying all of these clients' interests comes down to funding and the ability to make sure the programs put into place are certainly including a measure of accountability.

But also providing funding so that there's that access. Madam Chair I'd like to thank you for your indulgence over the minute and I appreciate working with you all as we move forward this year. Thank you.
I appreciate it.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker and members. As Chair of Public Safety, I rise with my colleagues today to adjourn in the memory of Officer Lucas Chellew and all the other fallen peace officers who put their lives on the line, day in and day out, to make our community safer. While the loss of a life is devastating under any circumstances, a line of duty death is one that strikes a particular chord in my conscience, in my heart, and the work we were elected to do as legislators. A line of duty death is a death that occurs during or as a direct and immediate result of an on duty incident. When our police officers are sworn in, they take the oath to perform the duties that put their lives at risk on a daily basis for the protection and safety of others.

Thank you, Madame President, members. I respectfully ask that we adjourn in memory of Michael Foley, a Deputy Sheriff for Alameda County, who lost his life in a tragic accident while on duty last week. Mr. Foley was struck and killed by a prisoner transport bus in the parking lot of the Santa Rita Jail in Dublin. Mr. Foley was truly committed to serving the public. He was the Deputy Sheriff for the Alameda County Sheriff's Department for the last 10 years and that was after serving with distinction for 30 years with the Concord Police Department. Alameda County Sheriff Greg Ahern called Mr. Foley, one of the hardest working deputies in the department who often volunteered to work overtime.

Alameda County Sheriff Sergeant Ray Kelly said that Mr. Foley was dedicated to protecting his community and quote, embodied what's good about law enforcement, unquote. Mr. Foley was raised in Concord, was a star athlete in Concord High School. Before joining the ranks of peace officers, he had a brother who is also a police officer in the East Bay. Followed in the footsteps of their father who served as an Oakland Police Sergeant. Mr. Foley began as a cadet in 1976, was sworn in as an officer in 1978. He worked over a wide variety of assignments including patrol, traffic, swat, and as a school resource officer. He retired from the Concord Police Force as a Master Police Officer in 2007.

He was a kind of officer who went above and beyond to help others including his fellow officers. As Sergeant Kelly said, this is a hard carrier and a hard job but to do it for 40 years takes a special kind of person, and Mike was that special person. All those touched by his life will never forget him, Sheriff Ahern said, he's a role model and a great example for others to follow. Our hearts are broken. Mr. Foley is survived by his wife Tammy, son Michael, and daughter Tonya. I want to express my deepest condolences to Mr. Foley's family.
The communities and neighbors he served, and to all those officers who served with him. They lost a true public servant. Thank you, Madame President.

Thank you for the opportunity to speak with you today on a matter of critical importance to our students, to our state and to our future. We're honored to join our forces with those of so many others in speaking about that future of the California State University and how we can make it and the other segments more accessible and affordable for all Californians.

Will there be a means testing as part of this system? We've heard about the FAFSA Foundation or basis for this program. And let me remind you of some of the major problems with the FAFSA especially relating to students who may have had a drug offense.

To the best of my knowledge, this is still federal law. It was law passed number of years ago around even very low level non violent drug offenses. Simple possession. That would make you ineligible for federal aid.

Now, how that works if we have the basis, the FAFSA basis if you're denied any federal aid for somebody else who is in your financial situation, the aid is quote on quote "available", which was the language used in the report that we're talking about today. Well, that's not available to you, because of your offender status.

Sure I can take a crack at that. First of all, I understand why the authors of the LAO report made the assumptions that they did. You have to make some assumptions and have a baseline for a conversation. I agree with you that that assumption is not likely to hold, but presumably in future iterations, we can explore different models.

My name is Mike Miller from UC Santa Barbara. And I think that we do have a hang out coming around with some programming that I want to talk about. In the interest of time, I'm going to move straight to page four and I want to introduce a concept an innovative new financial aid approach

that we've implemented at UC Santa Barbara that we are calling the UCSB promise scholar program. Traditional financial aid programs, look at eligibility on a year by year basis. So low income students are forced to make a decision on whether going to attend with only a promise of one year worth of funding. Our promise scholar program, it looks that financing higher education as a multi-year approach and

it offers our incoming freshmen a $120,000 over a four year period and our chance for students, $60,000 over a two year period. There is a one page handout outlining the promise scholar program. There's a couple points of product I'd like to mention, one, being that 82% of our promise scholar are first generation college students.

The average income for our promised scholar population is just a little over $30,000, so it's a very needy population. And through this approach which is in its third year our students are really thriving. The cumulative GPA of our promised scholar population, which is about 240 students, is currently at 3.23, and

we're retaining our students and we're hoping to, at the end of the fourth year, we're really hoping to see the results in our graduation rate. So I'd love to talk to you a little bit more about the multi year messaging and how powerful that is. When Paul was testifying about the LAO report he mentioned the importance of messaging and

I think that it's sending letting the students know that they qualify for $120,000 over a four year period is a really powerful statement and it bridges all the financial aid programs together so we include the Pell Grant, the Cal Grant program, which in my opinion is still the premier state-funded financial aid program in the country.

And we also include our University grant program, so I'd love to talk to you a little bit more about that later on. The next programm that I want to outline is what we're calling financial crisis response team. And essentially, this is a program that mirrors the Georgia State program that was outlined in the background document for this hearing.

It's really designed to identify students who are in danger of having to drop out or stop out due to a financial difficulty. We take a really unique, holistic approach to identifying these students and coming up with a long- term solution so we're not just throwing money to the situation. We are connecting them with campus resources that they may need such as academic advising,

financial literacy training, budgeting and sometimes student mental health services if necessary. We also provide emergency loans that are due have to be paid back in the academic year, but that are interest free and that the maximum grants awards that we offer is about $4,000 for students. I'm on page six, we've like most campuses.

We're are concerned about the issues of food security. So we've created a program called Food, Nutrition, and Basic Skills and essentially, what we're doing is we're trying to address that the food and security issue by educating students on issues like nutrition, food preparation through live demonstration on campus, grocery shopping, budgeting.

We're doing a great deal of CalFresh advocacy so we're linking students with that benefit. We are also teaching them and showing them how to maximize their financial aid including student loans and work study. And finally, I want to highlight on page seven, we have a program called re-entry program and what we're doing with this program is we're reaching out the students who were closed to graduating but had this drop-out or stop-out,

and what we're finding is that in most cases this was they left the University due to a financial difficulty. So we're reaching out to them and providing them with one-on-one academic counseling and financial aid counseling to provide them with a clear path back to UC Santa Barbara. So I know we're short on time so I'll stop there and would love to answer any questions that you may have about those four programs.

Members, I just wanted to quickly say, since Mr. Gutierrez is from, his fire station is from my district, when I went back to meet him, how humble he is, I said, he said, it's a pleasure to meet me, I told him it's an honor to meet him. When I talked to him about what he did and how we need to do more, he said, that's what we do every day. It's what we do every day, so, again, we have a hero in our midst right now.

Good evening. Chairman McCarty, Chairman Medina, honorable members, thank you for this opportunity to speak with you. My name is Kevin Weir. I'm a Professor of sociology just down the street at Cal State University, Sacramento.
And I'm an associate Vice President of the California Faculty Association representing 27,000 faculty, instructional faculty coaches, counsels and librarians on all 23 campuses at the CSU.

We appreciate the work done by the Committee staff and the Legislative Analyst's Office in laying gout the groundwork for this discussion. As they note in their reports, there are numerous approaches to this discussion. The LAO evaluated debt-free public higher education, for instance.

But there are also differing proposals circulating around the state and around the country. Some of them eliminating tuition altogether, some providing living expenses, some targeting different student populations. We at CFA have long advocated for the good health of this system, and for our students' fundamental needs.

Every year we fight for the CSU to have its budge request fully allocated by the state. This year that means urging all of you to invest an additional $182.5 million to this year's used based budget above the Governor's January proposal.
In the past, we've sponsored legislation to Institute an oil severance tax as a way of securing a dedicated funding stream for higher education in this state.
Thank you, Rich Bagley.

Do we need to know off the top or maybe the stuff can provide to us the amount of acres that we have for the state, and which are federal, which are state owned, which are private, which are, can we get that? Because I just think when we look at doing the comprehensive plan, we need to know all those numbers, and what is the CFIP program? I'm trying to Google around and I don't think it has anything to do with Fling, but that's what I got.
It's a competitive grant?
And is that only for private landowners? Or, is it for public as well?
Only for private.

Before I take any more questions, I want to take a quick second to welcome our Senators to the Committee. Specifically, Senator Hertzberg, our chair in the Senate side, who's helping to put this together. We've gone through the first panel and we're doing Q&A of the first panel.
Okay. Mr. Bloom.

And just to make a snarky point, not that I'm known for that, but I think that's a great bill that Mr. Bloom ran, and I think it models after how we threat other water contractors, and we see how well that's worked in Oroville. So, I think, whatever we do, we need to put extra teeth into this and make sure we have plenty more oversight hearings like this. When we pass good legislation, we make sure that its intent and purpose is followed through on.
But the contractors still need to pay for the upgrade to the infrastructure.

I was just going to say, Senator Hertzberg, that it remains a huge problem with people not being able to have contracts resigned and it's also not just with the forestry but with the Raglan too. People are going back to open burns because plants are closing down because their contract haven't been renewed because it costs more, but, at some point, state I think, need to step in to be able to assist with that in a more meaningful way.
So and we've had a lot of mills also close here, so if that's part of the process.

We're sponsoring legislation to place a moratorium on fees and tuition across all three segments of public higher education in California to give students and their families the needed breathing room from the ever-increasing costs to attend college, most recently the skyrocketing campus-based fees.

We recently published a paper called Equity Interrupted. I hope all of the members have gotten a copy of it which breaks down the past 30 years of disinvestment in the system, and how that disinvestment is impacting our students, especially those who are low income and students of color.

Very recently, we hosted a forum here in the Capital where we were joined by Chairman Medina as well as, by Assembly Member Ting to discuss the salient issues in the paper. And to begin the discussion of where we go from here.

So we didn't come to this discussion today with a set of solutions or a set of criticisms, but rather, a willingness to join in the debate, the debate about the details of the policy and the fiscal conversations that must follow. So our day to day experiences with students inform our position and also our role.

We want what's best for them to learn and develop into California's future. And as noted our students represent, excuse me, they face many challenges. 1/3 of them are the first in their families to go to college. 75% already work more than 20 hours per week. One in five are food insecure.

It is this notion that we must constantly remind ourselves of the dangers and sacrifices law enforcement make. Not only when disastrous accidents or senseless tragedies occur, but each and every day they serve their communities. I ask that we adjourn in memory.

And one in 10 face homelessness as was mentioned in part in LA over port. As we've shown in Equity Interrupted in this paper, the student population in this CSUs today is very different than it was 30 years ago. And this impacts their time to a degree. This impacts their preparation.

And as these numbers go up, time to a degree for instance, so do the costs. We heard a little bit also about parent contribution. When we have students in this CSU that are coming from low income working families, the parental contribution level just can't match what it use to be in the past.

An example that we heard in the panel last week was a working family whose expected parental contribution was $552 a month and that was also the mother's entire salary. So we as an organization remain committed to the wisdom of the master plan laid out so many years ago.

But every year, it seems we move further away from that vision. Today's conversation is a welcome return towards that vision. We see public, free public higher education as an achievable goal, but as the LAO report shows getting there is more complex than it may seem at first blush.

There are many questions that have to be answered at the outset of this discussion, because there are nuances that need to be addressed or else we might design a solution to the wrong problem. So some of the basic questions that might drive very different policy discussions are what we're grappling with at CFA.

So here's just a few of them; What's happens to tuition? Is it eliminated or is it kept at the same level but off-set? Who will be eligible in the new system? So far, we're only talking about full-time students but we should be talking about including part-time students. Do we impose unit caps or minima?

Will there be time limits? What about graduate programs and teaching or nursing credentials programs? Does it apply only to resident students of California? Is there a minimum GPA that we will require? We've heard some conversation about living expenses, we all know the cost of college is much more than just tuition and fees.
For a federally controlled substance that is actually a simple possession of that, which is now legal in California and several other states, that bars your ability to receive federal financial aid.

We've seen very recently in the last month, a reduction in the number of applicants from people of undocumented status, DACA and Dreamers, for fear of presenting themselves to the federal authorities. There are implications to using that system.

So, these two examples suffice to show that there are winners and losers in these decisions. So, in closing, I want to bring your attention to the work being done by some of your colleagues on this and related matters.

Assemblymember Rob Bonta is carrying AB-1038 which would create a nine member blue ribbon Commission on free public higher education in California. We're co-sponsoring this legislation and believe it's a critical first step to asking and answering some of these basic questions that we've been grappling with and that we look forward to working with you on.

Assemblywoman Dr. Shirley Weber has authored AB 1464 and we're supporting that, because we know that as we think through these issues, we must commit to maintaining the overall quality of education. AB 1464 would increase the number of ten year line faculty, which has been on a 15 year decline.

And lastly, as I've mentioned earlier, Assemblywoman Sharon Quirk Silva has recognized in her Student Protection Act AB 393, and we at CFA agree that students should not pay more only to receive less.
So, thank you again for the opportunity to speak today, we look forward to being part of the discussion moving forward and I'd be happy to answer any questions.

I'd just like to thank the Chair for pulling this Committee together and the staff and all their work on this. I like all of my peers sitting up here, I think, very interested in this topic. As somebody who is a native Californian and a long-time lover of the Sierras, and spend a lot of time there, have been horrified by what I've seen taking place in the forests. In addition to being a property owner up in the mountains and having spent thousands and thousands of dollars taking trees off of my land. And now looking at perhaps having an acre lot without a tree left alive on it. It's devastating and I know it's devastating for the forest, for people who live up there, for the animals that no longer have a habitat. I think it's imperative that we develop a real strategy and plan on this as we go forward. And again, I thank the Chair for pulling this together.
Kevin Weir.

So a couple of thoughts. First of all, a lot of people do go to the community colleges for the initial couple of years and then transfer obviously to the CSU and the UCs and if If things are free out of the gate, they may not spend those two years locally and at lower cost. They might go directly to a four year institution.

So I think we could expect an increase in enrolment due to that under certain scenarios. I would also suggest that we've been searching for ways to increase and to fund enrollment growth for years. We know that there are 10s of thousands of students who are turned away for lack of ability to serve them.

So part of the expansion in budget. We're still not at the level of funding that we were before the recent recession. So our ability, our capacity, is not where it should be. So we know that there's demand out there and then we have a third piece, which is the Public Policy Institute of California.

Which has, I think they're now in iteration three of their report talking about where we need to be as a state with the number of college graduates that we have in 2020 and 2025, and we are perpetually, you know, a million short.

So, if we're going to do our part in higher education to provide those on public higher education to provide those, then we have to be talking about enrollment growth, in order to achieve those goals and that's for the economy, the entire state.
Thank you, Mr. Chair. I'm interested in following up on this issue of staff leaving for other jobs. Is there any factual data on exactly where people have gone and what those other jobs are?

All right, well, I'm interested in the fact. And I've seen this issues of the salary spiral where public agencies steal people, call it what you want, from other departments for jobs that they are paying more.

And I know as we deal with the MOUs and state employment, this issue does come up. But I would be, district chairs, interested in and actually we're getting the actual facts on where these people have gone to getting what jobs at what pay so we can understand that foundational issue.
I'll wait.

Thank you. My questions are around BreEZe, but also the program Maximus. And now, those two work together, and I don't think you went over that, that was issue four, I think, issue four? But just that for those boards participating in BreEZe, will the public be able to see if somebody's participation in Maximus? And how will those two programs work together?
Okay, and as SB 1441 had you guys make the standards for this, what data are you using on substance abuse treatment participation?
Okay, so you wouldn't have information on how long somebody participates in a program? Or how many times you're able to repeat a program?

On vertical integration, are we ready to- Mine deals more specifically with the issues around addiction and we got rid of the diversion program that's gone now. We're setting up the health and wellness program. And so, I'm just wondering, and we're talking about the opioid addiction, we're overprescribing, but on the physician side, if a physician is arrested, how soon does the Board find out about that and then what is your recourse?
Have you seen a difference between when we had a diversion program and when we didn't on rates?
And what's your timeline for setting up the new program?

Always tough to follow Mr. Rapp. Jeff Vaca representing Riverside County Superintendent of Schools and the 23 school districts superintendents in Riverside County. I just want to quickly touch on some points that came up today.

I think it's fair to say that we share the concerns of the Committee regarding the deferral. I also want to point out that we are very much in strong support of further investments In teacher recruitment and retention. We believe that the classified grant teacher program is a one example where some additional investments can be made. We look forward to working with both, you and Mr O'Donnell on that.

Then lastly, Assemblymember Irwin raised the issue of county, the county's role in terms of working with districts on LCAPS and LCFF. We'll provide additional information at a future hearing, but we work extensively with our districts, not just to approve or disapprove LCAPS but to make sure that they are making sound decisions and have the data by which to judge, whether their strategies are effective moving forward. Thank you.

I'm Kyle Highland on behalf of Oakland Unified School District. We would just like to express our, echo the support expressed for the Early Childhood Care Education in the Governor's Budget. Thank you.
Karen Lang on behalf of Mayor Edwin Lee and the city and County of San Francisco in support, thank you.
Thank you, Mr. Chairman, Members of the Committee.

Keith Dunn here for the Self-Help Counties Coalition. I'll be very brief and just tell you that the Self-Help Counties Coalition, now 24 members throughout the state, save hundreds of millions of dollars utilizing this authority. If you want to look at providing reforms that deliver projects faster,
save money, and are good for everyone in the State of California, this is an easy one. I'd ask for your aye vote, happy to answer any questions. Thank you.

Melanie Perron, Legislative Director for Caltrans. Good afternoon, members, chair. We are in strong support of AB28 and express our appreciation to the author for carrying this important legislation. Since 2007, we have seen good results with this delegation authority.

It has allowed us to deliver projects faster, which then allows us to approve more projects, which ultimately benefits job creation and the economy. As the chairing -- as the author has indicated, that without the ... authority by March 31st, we would have to reapply to the federal administration for this authority, and we would not like to see that happen. So we would request your aye vote.

Thank you, Marina Wiant with the California Housing Consortium. I'll be brief since the Committee is well aware of the deep affordability crisis that the state is suffering from. But I want to note that together both this Bill with SB 2 and the couple of housing funding measures that the Assembly has, together still do not make up what the investment the state had towards affordable housing development was back in 2008, and today, we're in a crisis that is even deeper where we have incomes, incomes are lower, the state's number one in poverty, and our own HC director has claimed on the ground this is a crisis that no one has seen yet. I urge your aye vote today, thank you.
Laura DeValencia, representing the American Planning Association, in support.
Steve Walker on behalf of the Alameda County Transportation Commission and the Napa Valley Transportation Authority in support.
I'd love to see it.

Hi, good afternoon, I am Jennifer Alley with the California Association of Health Plans and today, I will be giving you CAP's feedback regarding the draft proposal. The DHS came out with regarding the network adequacy standards. And I would just like to acknowledge that DHCS has conducted numerous stakeholder meetings and

we really appreciate their effort and would like to thank the department for their hard work on this effort. The proposal that's before us establishes time and distance standards based on three county designations, as you heard earlier, and that's rural to small, medium, and large and that's based solely on county population.

And while we support creating standards based on the uniqueness of a county, we think that this approach does not sufficiently measure or reflect access differences through an entire county. We think county size and population density are extremely important

to be taken into consideration when developing the requirements that my members will be required to adhere to. For example, we heard about San Diego earlier today, San Bernardino is the same. It has a very large county with a small urban area and then the majority of the county is rural.

And so it would be very difficult for a plan in that county to have one access standard with the different geography that exists within that county. And so, like my colleague from LHPC stated earlier, we think it is important that the population be classified,

it should include some density and geographic factors and to allow us to identify alternative access needs to build the network at the onset of the process, rather than trying to have a base standard and then submit a request to have an alternative access need met. Plan support access alternative modalities for

access specifically in rural counties who may not have specialty providers available. That includes the use of tele-medicine. And again, including that the use of that in building the network from the onset of the process because it's a critical and effective tool to ensure access for beneficiaries in rural areas.

And we suggest that the department could use location of the tele-medicine porter hub which would be where someone would go to access tele-medicine be used to calculate the time and distance standard rather than just where the provider is located. But, some of the specialties that are identified in the departments proposal are not suitable for tele-medicine.

For example, ear, nose, and throat, orthopedic surgery, and cardiology. And we request that for those specialty provider types where telemedicine is not suitable or inappropriate that the department consider establishing the frontier standard that you also heard about earlier today. There isn't anything that prohibits use of the California medical service study areas

which are used to determine where professional shortages exist in medically undeserved in rural populations. And so, MCAP members believe that time and distance standards should be applied according to designations that reflect differences in service area based, again, on population density, provider supply, and geography.

MCAP believes that the time and distance standards for specialist should account for member utilization and member supply so that we can actually comply with the standards. Our members are concerned that the course specialist list includes providers that are extremely short supply and/or otherwise do not typically contract with plans.

In situations where plans cannot meet, the baseline time and distance requirements for specialist alternative access standards should be allowed, and we again think that it's important to recognize the alternative access needs at the onset of our network development. The implementation of the network adequacy standards is important to help ensure that Medi-Cal Managed Care enrollees have access to necessary services.
MCAP and its members look forward to continuing our hard work with DHCS and the Legislature to successfully implement future requirements.

Thank you Mr. Chair and thank you to the Committee for diving into this issue. Which is one that I know what worried a lot of folks who follow the issue of student success. And there is a real disconnect, I think, for a lot of families and a lot of kids. When they go through their high school experience, they are getting the grades and

then wow the big door they get admitted to colleges and the big roadblock comes up that creates a barrier to tens of thousands of kids succeeding every year, and I know there has been an effort to try and the way that- Agenda has been set up to figure out best practices and ways in which the colleges can deal with this,

the challenge that they're facing, it is like they are at their front door now, what can they do about it and that's all preferably appropriate and I have as a member of the board of trustees at the state universities in here in the Legislature support it, these innovative efforts and funding efforts that the Governor has contributed to through his budget.

But there is a big disconnect for kids and their families to understand what the heck happened here?I thought I was doing everything right. And all of a sudden now, I am not college ready? And there's the whole question of whether or not what is college ready is really a determining factor of being a successful person with a college degree,

and in fact, you alluded to that earlier in your comments. I mean, for many, you used some example, a math concept. What you say, poly, what was it? Okay, I didn't know what the heck you were talking about, okay? Which I love, because it's like now.

Okay, okay, that's a fair comment, and I'll let my constituents be the judge of that. However, the polygons or whatever, what does that have to do with advance, what was that? What was this? Polynomial factoring, okay. What that has to do with being a successful psychologist, or a sociologist, or someone who is accomplished in the area of art or political science or

a whole host of other fields in which we award degrees. But you said something very important earlier. You said there is an imperfect alignment between what the high schools think that they should be doing and what the college faculty think that they should be doing.
That's a short phrase with big impact. And you know what? If you're right, it has almost nothing to do with money. Because so much of what we talk about is always about are they getting enough money?

But if you have high school teachers not teaching the right thing that college teachers think they should be, that's a huge problem, huge problem. And I guess what surprises me is that why we are not more on top of that if that's the issue. But that's not about innovative program in dealing with remediation at our front door of our colleges.
That's a huge communication problem. And is it really, I mean, I assume you said it because you believe it. What efforts are being done to deal with that?

My understanding is that the CSU trains 50% of the teachers that go into our public schools. 50%, so they're training the teachers about how to be good teachers, how to teach English the right way, Math the right way, and all things in between. And yet, you are saying that they're failing to do it right.
When they go down and they teach in our high schools, that they're not teaching the right stuff. I mean that's a huge-

Thank you, and congratulations to both of the institutions for your good work. And I know from personal experience on the board of the CSU that you have many leaders. Chancellor White on down that are very passionate about trying to do everything they can to remove this barriers to student success and your programs are examples of that.
Certainly the Bridge Program at Dominguez Hills is something would be very proud of.
President Hagan, I wanted to as you heard earlier in the hearing, bringing it back to where this problem originates, the analyst who spoke earlier suggested that one of the main reasons

not the only reason that we have this problem is the imperfected alignment between what the high schools are expecting of the kids. The area of math and English and what the college faculty are expecting.
President Hagan, would you be courageous enough to address that point?

Thank you for that and you spoke about the partnership efforts that you've been involved with and those are really, really valuable. I don't know, maybe it's anecdotal, maybe you have survey work but, my guess is, is that most of the kids when they find out they have this issue are surprised.
That they're surprised by it. Do you, would you agree or disagree with that? And is there any data put there that could underscore whether or not the kids saw it coming?
Is that grade inflation? Is that the root of this?
It's not your intention or mine, but it's trying to get to the heart of it.
I do think that the kids are surprised. That they think as you have said they've done everything right. And yet now they're being said, they're being told. There's a roadblock here.
And we know from they that, that is a significant roadblock because the kids that have to go on a remediation their not finishing at the same level at all right.
I don't disagree with you but thing is as if you're getting an A in the math course or an English course.

And then you are, you don't do well in the test, for this entrance exam and then you're surprised. I get where pencils and pens and those things are important, but I just don't want our kids to be surprised. And part of what we're trying to figure out here is that, and I know that no one likes to give Cs or Ds. There's lots of pressures that go into, from all different sides.
But we're trying to get to the root of it. But the idea that kids come into our University system and then get surprised with remediation is not a good thing.
Got it, fair enough. Mr. Chairman, I'm going to have to leave. But I thank you so much for your Committee work on this.
It's a very important issue.

Thank you, good afternoon Mr. Chair and members, Dawn Keopke with Keopke and Associates, on behalf of the California Council for Adult Education education and California Adult Education Administrators Association. Both entities focused on k-twelve based adult education here in California. Our adult schools in California, have been working,as you may know, under the new adult education block Cramped, working with our community college partners, other community based organizations for the last few years on adult education.

Developing pathways from K-12 adult schools and into community colleges, career opportunities, and beyond, and one of the things I would just urge the Committee to consider. As part of the discussion is the value that adult schools provide in terms of working with adults who perhaps need additional basic skills assistance, high school equivalency. As well as working with our immigrant populations to provide. Cultural needs there, in terms of citizenship, ESL and others that are also a pathway to addressing some of the issues discussed here today.

So I'd really encourage the Committee to keep adult schools in mind as you deliberate this year on a host of bills on these issues. They are again, working very collaboratively across the state with their community college partners and really trying to fill a need there when it comes to adults. I would just also note that with regard to that the challenge for them has historically over the last number of years been with funding. For maintaining capacity in the adult schools to meet those needs, so just understand this is not the Budget Committee, but just as it relates to filling the gaps and meeting those needs. Funding is a critical issue for them. So, thank you, and appreciate your consideration.
Good afternoon, I'm first up it looks like.

Good morning, good afternoon, Mr. Chair and Members of the Committee. Again, I'm Matthew Allen with Western Growers Association. We appreciate the opportunity that you have provided us to speak about pesticides and the Protection of Children's Health. Our Association represents farmers who provide 50% of our nations fresh fruits and vegetables,

including half of the nations fresh organic produce and 99% of the nations tree nuts. As such we strive each day to grow and delivery a safe and secure supply of nutritious food for California, our nation and the world. Our members include not only farmers but also grower processor companies.

These companies grow and then process fresh produce before they shipped to restaurants, grocery stores, and other retail outlets. I want to stress that the out set that farmers prioritize maintaining a safe and healthy environment for their workers and for the surrounding farm communities which includes local schools. Maintaining that level of safety is absolutely critical from both the human health perspective and from an operational perspective.

To that end, farmers are diligent in making sure that pesticides are applied according to the law and because they also live and work in the same communities. It is a legal requirement of all growers and certified applicators to apply pesticides according to their label requirements. The labels are developed after a very lengthy scientific, and regulatory process by both the USEPA and the EPR, including comprehensive risk assessments to ensure that workers,

by standers, surrounding communities and the environment are indeed protected. In fact California remains the only state that has a complete second level of review that builds upon the review by the US EPA. Furthermore, the existing scientific research and review process, account for potential off target movement of the product in labels and instruct operators to apply products in a manner that avoids drift.

The potential for drift is modeled and the appropriate label restrictions are implemented in order to mitigate against this potential exposure. Applicators and growers are also trained to apply pesticide in a manner that avoids exposure and they use utilize equipment that allows precise and target applications. Western Growers is necessarily concerned about the proposed DPR regulation on pesticide use near schools.

Because a review of the data demonstrates that growers and applicators are applying crop protection products according to their existing label requirements and that those requirements are working as designed to ensure safe use and mitigation against potential risk. The process that was used to create those regulation appears to discount the fact that

real world data shows that the combination of current labeling, training, science and regulation is effective in protecting the our schools and school children. In 2013 the National Academy of Sciences conducted a program review DPR and came to the conclusion that the department provides a level of precautionary protection beyond what science indicates is necessary to assure safety.

Western Growers is also opposed to the quarter mile buffer around public schools and child daycare facilities for aerial and spray blast applications or crop protection products. The quarter mile buffer would be a statewide standard and doesn't recognize But there are unique situations where flexibility is required or should be granted.

Uniform buffers are problematic, as supported in a recent 9th Circuit Court of Appeals opinion, which affirmed the position of the US EPA. Which stated that uniform buffers are not an appropriate standard for the use of crop protection products. Furthermore, the existing scientific research and review process accounts for potential off target movement of a product. And labels instruct operators to apply products in a manner that avoids drift.

The potential for DRIFT is scientifically modeled and appropriate label restrictions are implemented in order to address and mitigate this issue. An arbitrary one size a buffer does not reflect specific items like influencers like wind direction, physical barriers and

also a lot of new technology that our growers continue to use and are bringing more more into the field. Things like electrostatic or magnetic spray Machines. We also believe that the annual and application-specific notification have the real potential to cause unnecessary concern and confusion for schools and child daycare centers.

When the annual notification and application-specific notifications are received. These notification requirements are also impractical and inflexible when we kind of look at how our operations work on a daily basis. As an example, the 48-hour application specific notification does not recognize the daily

challenges growers routinely face when responding to or planning for forecasted weather events. Crop protection products are selected and applied in response to pest pressures, and again weather events, costs, logistics and many other factors in order to safeguard the crop from loss or to impede the spread of disease.

It is critically important to be able to respond rapidly to the unique nature of each pest or disease problem in order to reduce the likelihood that additional applications need to be made. The 48-hour notice restriction ties the hands of the grower and puts California farms in a position of not being able to implement their pest and disease management plans.

In closing, we believe that the existing federal and DPR registration and regulatory processes that utilize science to determine and address the risk of each pesticide product via the label, are working as intended. The result of this rule is likely to be many acres of land coming out of ag production in California.

However, we do advocate that additional training and education about proper detection tools is always beneficial for both growers and schools. And that more substantial conversation really needs to occur regarding school site planning decisions and citing schools in agricultural zones. I want to thank you again for the opportunity this afternoon.
And I welcome any questions.

Yeah, that's a really a good suggestion and point. From our members' perspective, there's this concern about notification. Because when we talk about just kind of regular pesticide use, but also when you're actually applying a A fumigate, which is more harmful, it has more potential for exposure.

They actually have a special notices that go out for that specific purpose. And it's more of a warning. We're worried about the issue of over notifying on issues. And we're not really sure actually how to get around that.

That's also a problem with the annual notification. We can look at certain commodities, growers that actually move through lease agreements, different properties throughout the seasons. They might not know where they're going to be in the following year. And so, their annual notification deadline in the proposed regulation, they wouldn't necessarily be meeting that every year.

Because they're not sure where they're going to be based. So, there's some operational issues we're concerned about. About how to overlay that in to meet the intended goal of making sure that Pesticides are indeed being applied appropriately, protectively.

But we also don't want to create undue concern to schools and child day care centers. Because there will be a lot of notifications going out routinely. And we're not quite sure what the benefits are going to be there.
Because there's going to be a cost benefit analysis that's going to take place.

I would say that it's not meaningful. And back that up when you actually look at the data. When we look at the 2014 pesticide analyst report and we actually see that when we're looking at schools, children are not being exposed to ag-pesticides when their on campus, 2014.

Based on the condition of the HCBS waiver and current state law, specific ratios for service coordinators to consumers were established and Regional Centers must meet those. Currently, Regional Centers are not able to meet those requirements.

We definitely appreciate the 17 million that was in the budget last year to address this. It will bring in roughly 200 of those service coordinators, which leaves us about 400 left that still needs to be filled in order to bring us into compliance. So, we are requesting that additional 34 to bring us into compliance.

It's essential that we meet this case load ratio requirement in order for us to continue to receive federal funding for the HCBS waiver. Currently, right now, we receive over $1.4 billion in our state, and it's imperative that we continue to remain that federal funding.

More importantly, case load requirements need to be met for the health, safety and well being of our state's most vulnerable and for their families. So, on behalf of the 700,000 constituents that we represent in the State of California, we would ask that you respectfully appropriate the $34 million.
Evelyn Abouhassan with Disabilities Rights California, echoing the comments of my predecessors.

I'm glad to see that the Committee has rejected this proposal. Just on a personal level, a people level. Less money means less services for people with disabilities. And less services for people with disabilities means less integration.

Less success both in employment and in life, so while we're talking about equity amongst centers. That's one piece of the whole but the other piece of the whole is what does this mean for people with disabilities who aren't getting services if the ILCs aren't fully funded?

Thank you, and each of you are very good in your comments and mine's might be directed more toward of the chief. And I'll just say at the onset that what you're doing sounds real encouraging. And I'm glad to hear it, and what I'm probably going to ask you,

I don't want you to kicked out of Chief of the Police Association, but this whole issue of racial anxiety. I call it passive-aggressive racism. Whereby a group says they're not racist, but their actions, their policies and procedures and the way they do business is, by all means, is racist and it keeps a group of people down.

And that's what we heard from Miss McGill. It's really institutional racism, it's something that's inbred. So if you think a certain group are criminal races you go after them. And as she said you have just as many Latinos shooting African-Americans, and

just maybe the institution itself on how do you change that? Yes, we have people like President Trump that says he's friends to the blacks but he believes in stop and frisk. We have the number of cases of petty theft are going up. And it seems like I'm getting inundated with policies and

laws that want to send this back to basics, which is lock them up and thrown away the key. And all these things that we put in about recidivism programs and community-based policing, all of that gets thrown out the window as soon as things get tough to do. And so how do we, when it seems like its systemic in the department, how do you change a department culture?
And turn that around when you have people like, that are embedded or wedded to the way things are done from the status quo.
And I'm glad Ms. O'Malley's here.

I'm getting a lot of, as Chair of Public Safety, we're started to get a lot of bills to kind of want to unwind Prop 47 or 57. A lot of it's using human trafficking, rape, things of that nature, they'll talk about sodomy and say look, we need to collect more data, for example.

And we're going to include all the misdemeanors in there, a shotgun approach to crime fighting. And hopefully, we'll catch more rapists in that. But in the meantime, there's nothing in there about rehabilitation or some of the things that you're talking about doing, even with your, but to people who are sex offenders and
trying to really get to the systemic problems of that and do you see that as a trend to try to unwind what we're all kind of working on right now?

Yeah and I'm glad Mr. Harold reminded me about the fines and fees that the court has. If I remember right we had an estimate and maybe other, Ms. Lee or Mr. Charles can remember the court was looking at maybe 10 or 11 $1 billion worth of fine and fees that had been uncollected and I have made the recommendation that they go ahead and collect that to help fill their budget gap for which the court said they couldn't do it, it's almost impossible. I then recommended that maybe they hire a private sector group to go out.

Not knuckle breakers, but some people that would do some of the things that you'd talk about. I figured $0.10 on a $1 was a whole lot better than zero on the $1 and even at $0.10 10 cents on the $1, that's $1 billion, which means we've just have covered the court costs, but then they realized we had this problem. The money is going to all these different pots. So the problem that Ms. Lee is talking about, putting all the money in one basket, actually makes a whole lot of sense, and probably we could have moved that idea a lot further along If we knew that all the money would go to the court.

The courts didn't want to do it because they collected all of that money, not all of it comes to them, so which self-fulfilling prophecy. Why would you do this if you're not going to collect the money or the money doesn't come to you and you do all the work and so I would love to revisit that again, to look at the fines and fees that aren't collected, but more important look at the people who have inability to pay and figure out a way out of payment plan or if we just not going to get their money, just like in banks, they will write it off.

And some of it we may just have to write off instead of just keeping it on the books over and over again, because that even is an administrative cost, to keep logging it on over and over again, and so, I think it would be a good idea to revisit, how we actually collect all the fines and fees, and obviously make it more equitable for people of color and people who are disadvantaged.

Good afternoon Madam Chair members Dawn Koepke with Koepke and associates on behalf of crime victims united of California. Appreciate the opportunities just to make a couple brief comments and with echo and the comments made by the prior panel DA with regard to victims. The need for support for victims. I think it would be good to get data.
And it's not my own impressions or what feedback I get or yours but we have some real hard data.
You would agree on that.

Mr. Chair and members, Tiffany Whitman with the SEIU California. We're here today to request an appropriation of $34 million general fund, effective for fiscal year 2017, 2018, for purposes of increasing service coordinators at Regional Centers, In order to become into compliance, federal compliance with case load ratios.

There's been salary freezes, there's been recessions, other financial hardships. Among that, the core staffing formula has not been updated since 1991, which is extremely problematic. Regional Centers are currently funded at a much lower rate than what they actually pay their service coordinators.

In order for Regional Centers to be competitive within the workforce, often times they hire fewer staff in order to compensate their employees appropriately. In 2015 ARCA estimated that there would be roughly 600 new positions that needed to be created to meet federal compliance.

Redonovich, yeah, that's right, okay, good. Excuse me, good afternoon. I said next was in opposition, I apologize Good afternoon. Matthew Allen with Western Growers Association. Jaqueline Barosia, LAO.

We generally agree that there our policy merits to the continuations of these aspects

just make sure we understand how the proposal takes that into account.

We'll continue to look into this proposal.

And we're happy to work with your staff to work on cost estimates of those various options.
Jacqueline Baroisa, LAO.
