at the Le Say estimates in comparison to actual data trends, and we raised no concerns currently. We'll provide updates if needed in May. One thing that we would like to note is, to the extent that these projections vary, that could also affect the projected cost for the counties and the state as well.

Yes, good afternoon, my name is Caroline Shue from Legislative and Laws Office. This afternoon, I've been asked to give you an overview of 1991 realignment and particularly how the termination of the IHSSMOE affects the fiscal structure that was implemented in the '90's.

So, the Sargent has just handed out a figure which attempts to simplify the 1991 Realignment Structure today. And I'm going to walk through that at as higher level as I can. So, big picture as you are familiar. The State realigned, which essentially meant transferred responsibility for

a number of social service and health programs from the state to the counties. Both administration of those programs, as well as some of the financial responsibility, as well. So, when the state did this in the 90s, it increased the vehicle license fee as well as the sales tax to support the increased cost that was being shifted to the counties. Today, counties receive about 75% of overall vehicle license fee revenue,

which was about $8.1 billion in the most recent year. In addition, the counties receive a one-half cent sales tax, or one-half cent of the sales tax, which is about $3 billion a year. Can you repeat that again?

Sorry, I missed that. Sorry, so the vehicle license fee revenue dedicated to 1991 realignment is about 75% of the overall rate which equates to about $1.8 billion. And the sales tax is a half cents sales tax and that was about $3 billion in the most recent year.
So now, I'll walk through the chart.

So, the first thing that happens in the 1991 realignment physical structure is that the base is funded. Typically, what that means is counties receive the amount that they received in the prior year for the various programs. That follows from number one on the chart here on the left hand side and the revenues are allocated across the various programs based on the amounts they got in the prior years.

Then growth is allocated to the counties according to a series of steps. The first step in the growth calculation follows number two on the chart. So, first sales tax growth is allocated to the key slope sub account, which then is transferred to the social services sub account.

The social services sub account includes IHSS, a portion of Cal Works foster [UNKNOWN] services, as well as some other smaller programs. The amount of sales techs growth as allocated to the caseload sub account is based on the increase in costs for those programs in the prior two years. So in the current year, 2016-17, county's are receiving growth that occurred between 2014-15 and 2015-16,

so the growth that county's receive for these programs is alleged. Next number three the remaining sale sex growth after the key sealed of account and vehicle license plate growth is allocated to the CMSP account, which is the County Medical Services Program which transfers into the health account.

Then the remaining sales tax growth, if any, and vehicle license fee revenue growth goes into the general growth sub-account which is allocated according to a series of formulas which you can see after the number four here in the chart. There are a couple of things that are not clearly displayed in this chart.

This isn't how the 1991 realignment fiscal structure looked in 1991. The state has made a series of changes. Over the years to this fiscal structure. most notably some of those changes occurred over the course of the IHSSMOE including the creation of the child poverty and

family supplemental support account, which you see at the very bottom of the flow chart here. What also isn't clear from this chart is the growth, which is calculated in arrears, as I already mentioned. Moreover, in some years the growth in the VLF and sales tax revenue may not actually cover the complete cost of growth in the programs for the counties.

In only the case load sub-account, does the state continue to track Any unfunded growth year to year. So,if the sales tax growth isn't sufficient in a particular year to fund the increase cost, the State will carry that amount forward and growth in the next year will first cover those prior years growth amounts. So, as already has been mentioned and as you are well aware, there's a significant fiscal implication for

counties in transferring their responsibility from the state to the counties for the original cost sharing relationship that had been covered by the general fund over the course of the IHSS MOE. Not only will this create a significant cost increase for the counties, but as I mentioned, the realignment fiscal structure won't account for these costs until 2018-19.

And moreover, counties won't receive cash on hand from the 1991 realignment until 2019-2020, due to the way that calculations are done within realignment. So, for a number of years, counties won't receive any funding through realignment to pay for these increased costs. And moreover, when they do receive sales tax growth through

the 1991 realignment structure it will not be sufficient to cover the full increase that will have paid for over those years. Moreover, because the growth in the case of Suffolk County will be so large due to an increase in cost in IHSS, It is very likely that the downstream programs,

those below the caseloads of account, won't see sales tax grow for a number of years. As a result, the growth to those programs would be tens of $1 million lower that they would've been had the MOE continued or no change had been made. The final impact is that the child poverty subaccount,

which is used to pay for CalWork's grant increases, won't grow as quickly as a result of not receiving growth and sales tax revenue. And as a result, the general fund will bear a higher cost to pay for the maximum family grant repeal that was passed last year. So, in a report that we issued just this week or

last week, we talk about some of the considerations the Legislature will need to take into account when thinking about how to move forward in a short, medium and long term for counties. In the short and medium term, the Legislature could consider providing one-time grants or grants to counties to cover the difference in costs.

Potentially these grants could be ramped down as additional growth under 1991 realignment starts to ramp up. In the long term, however, the Legislature may need to consider whether or not the cost sharing ratios between the state and the counties needs to change for the IHHS program. And we would emphasize that when rethinking these cost sharing ratios,

it's important to consider the relative level of fiscal control and programmatic control that the counties have. And help that guide how much fiscal responsibility they have for the program. So for instance, one of the options that we lay out is were the state to take on the costs associated with the new minimum wage increases that were passed during the IHSS MOE.

As well as the federal overtime requirements, that would change the cost sharing ratios from 35, 65 county, state to 32% county, 68% state. And would be associated with about a $200 million general fund cost in the budget year.
We'd note that you'd have to adjust these ratios every year, because those costs are going to be different, depending on the year.
But that there are different ways to try to mitigate the impact on counties in the short and long term.
With that, I'm happy to answer any questions.
Sure, so to revert to the old 1991 realignment cost sharing ratios would mean

that counties bear 35% of IHHS costs, and the state bears 65%. Were the state to decide that the state would cover the cost associated with increases to the minimum wage, as well as federal overtime requirements. Then those ratios would need to shift to 32% for counties and 68% for the state.

That's about $200 million in the budget year. And we would just note that those ratios would need to be adjusted every year. Because the costs will vary and the relative cost share will have to change to accommodate that.

That's one of the options that we lay out in our report. We do recommend that the Legislature consider how to think about these cost sharing relationships differently under the changes that were made over the course of the IHSS MOE. One of the things we do recommend and not just provide as an option is for

the state to change the cap on wages. So right now, counties are responsible for any wages above $12.10. We would recommend the Legislature change that cap to be whatever the minimum wage is in a particular year to reflect the change in the minimum wage schedule that happened over the course of the MOE.
That would not require any funding in the budget year, but would require additional state funds in future years.
We do not have that. CSAC might be able to help you with that.
There have been some years where the base has not been met, yes.
For almost all of the programs, their base is reset to that lower amount.
Then the amount by which the sales tax growth is short for the Caseload Subaccount is rolled over to the next year.
The Caseload Subaccount is unique in that the state continues to roll over the unmet growth and costs for those accounts.
And so in the next year, the first call on the dollar, as it were, goes to that unmet growth from the prior year.
The amount of growth available is how much people are shopping this year.
But it is going to pay for increases that occurred last year as compared to the year before that.

The calculation for the increased cost to counties will not flow through from a funding perspective until 2018, 19. And the cash on hand for counties won't happen until 2019, 20. Because, essentially, we have to wait until the end of the year to see how much sales tax growth there is.
And then we can allocate it to the counties.
Right, they will incur the costs in the budget year. But they will not get the money until three years after that, through the realignment structure that exists today.
My name is Kristina Bas Hamilton. I represent UDW/AFSCME Local 3930. We are a 94,000 IHSS providers in 21 counties throughout California. Prior to the Coordinated Care Initiative passing in 2012,

UDW Bargain 21 different contracts with 21 different counties. As a result of the 2012 Budget Act which passed the CCI, we were able to launch a pilot. So, simultaneous with the actual healthcare component was a pilot

that transitioned the pilot counties from county-level to state-level bargaining. And for the 7 pilot counties, UDW represented Riverside, Orange and San Diego. What we're seeing now with the Governor's action eliminating the CCI is the transition back from the bargaining relationship,

being with the new IHS statewide authority going back to the local bargaining relationship that existing prior to 2012, and so that those three...those seven pilot counties are now back to bargaining with their local public authorities. And so, the impact for us is negative in

that we've always sought to be bargaining at a state level. The IHSS statewide authority, under its 2012 charge, was bargaining two separate contracts. One with our organization and the other with our colleagues at SEIU, local, actually SEIU. And so, what we were trying to do was eventually get all the counties to get there, and

with the Governor's action, we are now reverting back to where we were prior to 2012. This doesn't make any fiscal sense for this state because, the way that the prior relationship, or now the current relationship will be, is that we bargain locally with county public authorities. Which means that the decisions that are made at the county level in terms of wages and health benefits,

the state has to automatically pay a matching share to that amount. Which means that they have no physical control over the growth in which is in health benefits and so it would be the most physically responsible thing to do for the state.

To be able to control unilaterally what changes happen with wages and benefits for this very large group of workers. So, we just really want to emphasize that and we would like to propose and would very much urge your support to go back to where we were. And to not only have a It's for 7 pilot counties but in fact for all 58 counties.
And to not only have a It's for 7 pilot counties but in fact for all 58 counties.

Sure, so we can give you the details on a program by program basis. But just to speak broadly the mental health, a portion of mental health services were realigned in 1991 and you're correct that If the case load sub-account were to take up all of the sales tax growth to pay for the increased cost of IHSS,

the only growth left for the other programs would be vehicle license fee growth. So, the growth flowing to these downstream programs would be tens of millions of dollars lower than it has been over the course of the MOE. The 2011 realignment realign behavioral health which has some overlapping programs with the mental health sub-account. 2011 realignment is in no way affected by this proposal so

the funding the counties receive for behavioral health will not be affected but the funding that they received for this portion of mental health that was realigned in the 90s would be affected and reduced in the tens of millions of dollars.
So, the Child Poverty sub account was

created largely to support grant increases in CalWORKS. And so, when the Legislature passed last year, the repeal of the maximum family grant, the plan had been that as revenues increased in that sub-account, the cost of the general fund for repealing that rule would go down.

As a result of terminating the IHSS MOE the costs to the general fund won't go down as quickly because there won't be as much money in the child poverty sub-account. And moreover, that there will be a delay in future grant increases because this is the sub-account. That supported CalWORKS grant increases to a large extent.
It has been used to provide CalWorks grant increases in the past, yes.
So, you're correct that had the CCI never been implemented, and

all of the cost increases that have occurred play out the same way over the past five years. Counties would have been responsible for this $600 million over the past five years. Importantly, though, the revenues would not have kept up over the past five years. In fact, we estimate that the revenues likely would have only covered,

I think, about a third of the costs, had the MOE never been in place. So likely the state would have taken some sort of steps to mitigate the impact to counties, or taken different policy choices so as not to leave the counties responsible for such a large share of cost that wasn't being funded through these mechanisms.

Jenny Bellow with the LAO. Just one point of clarification on the CalWORKS grants question you had earlier. The cost of living adjustments are the grant increases that were provided out of the child poverty and family supplementary support sub account. That was a way to provide grant increases that were not funded by the general fund.

So the fact that there wouldn't be enough funding in this account to automatically provide those grant increases in the future from this account, wouldn't preclude the Legislature from taking a separate action to provide a cost of living increase that is reliant on the general fund.

I should have clarified and thank you for the question. In response to what Mr. Cate said, we would only want to see statewide bargaining with a Understanding or statutory provision that the counties would have no responsibility for

wages or increases in wages and benefits that they don't bargain. That doesn't make any sense. And in fact that's the reason why we're arguing we should change it because the state doesn't have that ability to control those decisions. And so I think that would answer that concern.

Thank you, Mr Chair and members, Tiffany Wayne with the CIU California. On behalf of our combined 500,000 IHSS providers represented by SCIU Local 2015 and AFSCME UDW, we respectfully request collective bargaining for all IHSS providers be shifted from the county level to the state level. The current piecemeal bargaining structure has been nearly impossible for IHSS providers in the county bargaining units.

Or those that were even in the bargaining statewide authority to reach any type of contractual agreement. When IHSS providers can't earn a living wage, they're forced to seek employment outside of the program. Further exacerbating the shortage of long term care workers. Leaving our State's IHHS consumer population vulnerable to workforce shortage.

Our proposed consolidation will allow the state to control all future decisions relative to IHHS wages and benefits. And thus control program costs, which is extremely important. Currently, the state must fund wage and benefit increases that are negotiated by counties without any state input. Statewide bargaining would allow the state to better manage the IHSS workforce and improve service delivery.

It would also eliminate duplication and inefficiency. So for those reasons, we respectfully request you transfer the employer responsibility for collective bargaining for all IHSS providers from county level to the state. We had with us today, roughly 70 IHSS providers, and unfortunately,
they had to get back home to care for the clients that they serve. So you will hear from some of our members today.
But I did want to express that we had roughly 70 to 75 members here today to share their stories with you all, thank you.

And that's not the chart I got. That's the point I'm making, that's not the chart I got and it doesn't explain it that way. That's why I asked, give me all the details because the chart I got basically blamed the corrections officers, for the fact that you needed increases in your budget.

Yes, yes, Caitlin O'Neil, Legislative Analyst's Office, good afternoon, Madam Chair and members. We don't raise concerns specific to CDCR's information security proposal, however our office did take a cross-department look at information security proposals, which I'd be happy to Summarize the recommendations for you right now.

So the Governor's Budget includes $14 million and 58 new positions across 12 departments to strengthen information security in the state. And we found that the state's current approach to strengthening information security relies on individual departments to come forward with proposals and lacks a strategic leadership.

As such, it's unclear whether the 12 proposals that are included in the Governor's Budget collectively represent the state's most critical security risks. So in light of these concerns we make two recommendations; first we recommend that the Legislature direct the administration to prioritize high vulnerability and

high sensitivity security risks for future budget requests. Specifically we think that the Department of Technology should take a strategic leadership role to ensure that future budget proposals that come before the Legislature are focused on the state's most significant.

And pressing information security needs However, we recognize that the Department of Technology will not likely to have time in this budget process to do such a comprehensive analysis. So, our second recommendation is that the Legislature direct the department to report at budget hearings on whether the current proposals address reasonable
information security vulnerabilities that also involve sensitive data.

My comment's more of being able to complete the task and get it done. When we first got here, back in 2012, when I was chair of this illustrious committee. One of the first things that came across our desk, was a $500 million judicial's computerized system, that I believe still has never been done, but we spent half $1 billion to try to make it happen, and because each court wanted their own system and a whole myriad of other different problems, we never, more important, tax payers never got what they wanted. No one took the blame, so I appreciate anyone who said that we needed to have a centralized area where someone will be held accountable.

But most important we contract out and these individuals never complete the task and we never prosecute them, we never go after them. We never sue them, we get our money back. It's just oops, I guess we don't have it, and I'm getting that same feel here that you're asking for money to do some technological fix for cyber security, which I think every department in the state should be concerned about, but I don't get the feeling that one entity will be in charge and take the brunt of the responsibility if things go wrong, if we don't get what we want out of this and so can someone give me some assurances that eight years from now, I'm not sitting at this Committee, talking about how we just spent x amount $1 million across every department.
And we're now another half $1 billion in the hole with absolutely nothing to show for it.

being proactive, government, we're not pretty good at that, at looking at a problem, seeing it in the future, but I just would like for you to take that in consideration in your analysis.

A quorum is present. Would the members and our guests be on the rail, and the gallery please rise. We will be led in prayer this afternoon, by our sister Chaplain, Michelle Gorman, after which time, please remain standing, we will be led in the pledge of allegiance, by Senator Wieckowski.

Madam President and members, thank you. Good afternoon. I hope everyone's having a wonderful Monday here in the capital. I'm here to present SR 20, which recognizes the month of March 2017 as problem gambling awareness month. For many, gambling is a means of entertainment. Unfortunately, some take gambling beyond mere entertainment. It can develop into an unshakable addiction similar to alcoholism and drug addiction.

Thank you, Madam President. Much like alcoholism, and drug addiction, and addiction to gambling can have a negative impact on an individual's mental and physical health. Problem gambling knows no bounds. It affects people irrespective of race, gender, or even economic status. It robs people of their life savings, and it tears families apart. Problem gambling is seen as a hidden disease because those who suffer, do not always show symptoms, and too often those who need help, do not seek it.

People with compulsive gambling problems feel that they must keep playing to recover their money, a pattern that becomes increasingly destructive over time. SR 20 is intended to educate people about problem gambling, it also recognizes public and private organizations that serve help to those with gambling addictions, and it provides valuable information on available treatment options and support available to assist problem gamblers and their families, I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
I just like to thank my colleague from Sacramento for the support for this resolution and the members for their support today. Thank you.
My name is Reggie Collins from California Trout, and we're just registering our support, especially for the fish passage and multi-benefit land use language in there. Thank you.

Hi, thank you, Mr. Chair, Russell Nowak on behalf of the California Association of Recreation and Park Districts and Mid-Peninsula Regional Open Space District, in support. Thank you, sir, very much. Good morning, Mr. Chair and members.

Members, Jeff Vaca representing the Riverside County Superintendent of Schools and the 23 school districts in Riverside County. We also support the CSESA request, although Riverside County Office of Education would not benefit from that request, we are one of the higher funding counties. And I just want to state that we view the services that we provide, we don't view them as being optional.

We view ourselves as being a critical component of the statewide accountability system. That you're going to hear Mr. Sapp and Mr. Daniels talk about in the next panel. We have teams that are in districts all the time. Helping them, and developing their LCAPs.
And when we send and LCAP approval letter, and we provided an example for each of you, we don't just say we approve the LCAP. We provide them with suggestions. We help them to interpret the data.

We provide them with guidance moving forward, because we like to consider ourselves as that entity that is best prepared to provide that technical assistance within Riverside County. And we want the conversation yes to be about prudence and cost containment, but at the end of the day, it's about what do we need to do to help close the achievement gap and

help our students be prepared for college and career by the time that they graduate from high school? And that's the approach that we take and that's the conversation that we would like the Subcommittee to have. And that's why we continue to oppose the Reserve cap. And we would like to see the deferral go away if revenues are available, thank you.
Kevin Aslanian, California Welfare Rights Organization in support. Thank you.

Good afternoon, my name is Kevin Aslanian. I'm with the Coalition of California Welfare Rights Organizations and we work with the offices throughout the state and we've been hearing another complaints from offices, that veterans come in today their offices homeless and we found out that part of the reason that they're homeless is because the general assistance of many counties are limited to three months. Even though its three months, in LA County it's 12 months, but they still have a work requirement during those 12 months.

And if they don't meet the work requirements, they will be sanctioned. So the work requirement is still applicable. The counties also under this bill have six months, if the decide that they don't want to extend veteran's benefits and thank them for their service, because they served our country for 12 months, they could back out of it within six months. We urge you to vote aye for the veterans of our country, thank you.

Good afternoon, Kevin Aslanian, Coalition of California Welfare Rights Organizations. Dr, Arthur said, this bill basically would extend the 48 months to 60 months about 35 states and more than 35 states out of the 50 states, already have a 60 month and many of them are red states, so I'm not sure why California is behind that.

And this change was made in 2008 during the recession, and it's about time to go back. And the other point I want to make is that, we looked at the numbers and the average stay on welfare's about 25 months for every person, on average. So only about 760 families hit the wall of the 40th month, so this would cost about $1.5 million a year.
Kevin Aslanian, Coalition California Worker Rights Organizations, I will concur with the previous testimony, thank you.
Phil McGavin with Coalition for Clean Air. We support including the air quality monitoring as important part of the permit. Thanks.
Bill McGovern with the Coalition for Clean Air in support, financial assurance needs to be strengthened.

Thank you Chair and members. AB 248 is a straightforward measure, that requires applicants for the renewal of a hazardous waste facility permit. To submit the permit for review at least two years, rather than the six months-

treat, store, or dispose of hazardous waste. Unfortunately, there have been longstanding issues with the department, including an external review finding that permit decisions were not timely. Exposing a lack of management structure resulting in poor program performance.

These issues as well as others led to the establishment of the DTSC independent review panel. An entity created to make recommendations regarding improvements to the departments operations. Two of those recommendations were to require permit applicants to submit their applications two years prior to their permit expiring, as well as to establish accountability mechanisms.

AB 248 accomplishes both of these goals. The opposition has argued that it is still too early to act given the IRP is still compiling recommendations. However, the lack of clarity around the future authorization of the IRP and its impacts on vulnerable communities make it critical to act now.
Here to speak in support of this measure, is Ingrid Brostrom from the Center for Race, Poverty, and the Environment, and Jessica Prieto from East Yard Communities for Environmental Justice.

Yes, the intent of the bill is not to disrupt the permit review process but rather, to start the review earlier, that's the entire of the intent. And we certainly will work with the stakeholders so that those requesting the permits are treated fairly and justly.

And finally, about the work incentives, what happens if you have earned income? They reduce your benefits, and then your food stamps go down. And I've talked to families where their net gain is about $2 an hour and this would basically make it worthwhile to work with pay, actually. Thank you. I urge an aye vote.
Okay, the Department of Toxic Substances Control is responsible for the administration of permits for waste facilities that transfer,
Michael Arnold on behalf of the cities of Oxnard and Redondo Beach, thank you.

Mr. Chairman and Members of the Committee, Paul Gonzalvez representing the cities of Lakewood, Norwalk and the South Coast Air Quality Management District, and in the interest of time, I'd just like to thank the Center for its leadership on this issue and ask for your aye vote. Thank you.

Thank you, Marina Wiant with the California Housing Consortium, we're proud to be co-sponsors of this important measure. I wanted to thank the Assembly Member for his leadership on this issue. His commitment to innovative solutions to help solve the crisis backwards housing policy that has gotten us in to this mess. And measures like AB71 will help reverse that and make a big step toward solving the problem.
We urge your support.
Sharon Rapport with the corporation for supportive housing in strong support.

Good morning, Sharon Rapport with the Corporation for Supportive Housing. Data show homeless people, particularly chronically homeless people, are extremely expensive to MediCal. Generally, comprising over half of a hospital's frequent user population, people experiencing chronic homelessness incur between $30,000 and $75,000 per year in publicly funded healthcare cost.

These individuals have poor health outcomes dying on average 30 years younger than their housed counterparts. Data also shows supportive housing affordable place to live with services promoting housing stability, works and homelessness among chronically homeless people, while also saving publicly funded healthcare dollars.

To achieve any cost savings to our health care system, homeless people must get connected to housing first. AB 74 would create the Housing for a Healthy California Program. And I think Assembly Member Chiu talked about the essentials of that program. Counties would have to tie these rental subsidies funded under the program to services funding that will now become available under MediCal.
Marina Wiatt with the California Housing Consortium in support.

Thank you Mr. Chairman, and that's very kind and thank you, Senator Moorlach for the opportunity to appear in front of the Committee today. I am Roger Dickinson, the Executive Director of Transportation California. Our coalition is comprised of a group of transportation stakeholders including business labor,

industry associations, construction organizations and planning agencies. Our members and thousands of employees are at work throughout California everyday. We support SP1 and urge you to vote for it. Mostly developed nearly 50 years ago, the state's transportation infrastructure has supported decades of economic and

population growth that helped propel our state to become one of the world's leading economies. But over the last 2 decades we have watched our transportation system decay to the point of being unreliable, and in too many cases simply unsafe. This year's massive storms as pointed out by Senator Beall have only exacerbated the deterioration.

We, like millions of our fellow Californians, worry that without a solution such as SB1, conditions will only get increasingly worse. In fact today, 10 of California's urban centers have pavement conditions that rank among the nation's most deteriorated, including the top three in the country, San Francisco-Oakland, Los Angeles-Orange County, and San Jose.

Simply put, California can no longer provide a safe, suitable and efficient transportation system. We're falling further and further behind, with available funding manifestly insufficient to repair our aging infrastructure and prudently provide new capacity to meet existing and growing demands.

Everyday, millions of Californians also find themselves stuck in gridlock. We've all experienced it. Whether they are in their own or transit vehicles, they lose precious hours of productivity or family time, up to 100 years, 100 years it seems like that,

100 hours a year, or more per Californian are sacrificed to congestion. It doesn't matter where you live, Northern California, Southern California, the Central Valley, congestion is simply always a fact of life. Not only does gridlock steal people's time, it impairs our economy.

Efficient goods movement within our state and out of the state to the rest of the country and beyond is directly linked to the state's ability to generate jobs and remain competitive. In 2010, nearly 1.5 billion tons of freight a day moved on California's highways. The Federal Office of Freight Management estimates the amount of freight move for

more than double between 2002 and 2035. We need both increase capacity and significantly greater maintenance of our system if we are to meet the economic requirements of California and the nation. Not only will SB1 helps us fix our roads, reduce gridlock and help us move goods across our state, it will also generate 18,000 good paying skilled jobs for

each $1 billion invested in new infrastructure activity, including jobs created directly within the industry, as well as other economic activity that will be stimulated throughout the state. For all of these reasons, Transportation California strongly supports SB1 for system preservation, maintenance, and investment.
Thank you Mr Chairman.
Good morning, Mr. Chair and members, Cesar Diaz, on behalf of the State Building and Construction Trades Council, in support. Thank you, sir.

Thank you so much. John Arriaga, on behalf of the Transportation Agency of Monterey County, the Board of Supervisors from Monterey County, City of Salinas, the League of California Cities Latino Caucus, thank you.
Felipe Fuentes on behalf of the Associate General Contractors of California, both chapters San Diego and the California Chapter, in strong support.

Jaclyn Berosi with the LAO. With regards to the budget we've looked at the projections of their caseload hours per case and other cost drivers and raise no concerns at this time We will provide updates as the estimates are updated in May. With regards to the CCI, we recently released a report looking at the overall implications of the termination of the CCI, and then subsequent elimination of the IHSS MOE, both fiscal and policy.

And in this presentation, I'll discuss both the fiscal and policy implications. So for the first policy implications on page 10 of the agenda, we note that as the administration has noted, the elimination of the IHSS MOE will result in the shift of over $600 million of cost back to counties.

This, as a result, represents a number of short term and long term considerations. Mainly because the traditional funds that counties rely on, 1991 realignment revenues, won't be enough to cover this immediate increase in cost. The administration is, to our understanding, currently in negotiations with counties to find ways to mitigate some of these financial challenges they may face.

As for the Legislature, there are a number of ways that you could also provide relief. In the report we outline, one specific recommendation is changing the current cap on wages and benefits. Currently, counties are responsible for wage and benefit cost that exceed $12.10. One option is to perhaps link the cap to statewide the minimum wage of that current year.

I do have a colleague with me that can talk more about the technical aspects of any relief that would require changes to 1991 realignment funding structure. But overall, this determination of the IHSS MOE, will thus present a number of fiscal challenges to counties, given the fact that the realignment revenues will not be enough to cover the immediate cost shift,

and that also has implications for their future sustainability of revenues. Moving on to the policy considerations that this then brings up is, in a practical sense, nothing changed with regards to the administration and overall programmatic aspects of IHSS due to the CCI.

However, through our research, we did find that there was improved coordination and communication between county administrators and health plans. And this then, in some cases, did manifest itself in expedited reassessment and assessments for consumers. So if the Legislature were interested in either maintaining or further enhancing and

building off of some of these initial outcomes, there are a number of ways in which you can do so. One, is perhaps just providing funding to continue some of these coordinations that did occur under the CCI. The administration does signal to some form of support for this, the policy merits. And that, it is encouraging counties to continue the current practices that were in place under CCI, yet there's no funding attached to that.

So that's one way in which the Legislature could continue some of the improvements we saw in CCI. On the other end of the spectrum of potential ways to build off of some of these improvements is perhaps pursuing a more fuller robust integration of IHSS under managed care plans, and that can take multiple forms.

It mainly depends on the level of authority and control the Legislature Deems fit for managed care plans, which then is determined by what aspects of the IHSS program do you think should be preserved, and maintained, and controlled by the state or the counties.
With that, I'm more than welcome to take any questions regarding the fiscal or the policy implications of CCI you may have.

Good afternoon. Karen Keeslar. And I appreciate it you saying Keeslar, until I married him, I said it and I spelled it wrong too. I'm with the California Association of Public Authorities, their Executive Director, and wanted to touch on a couple of things.

This is not a proposal, this is an operation of current law, and the administration's presentation that it's not a cut to IHSS consumers or providers is true in terms of the operation of law. But there is an underlying threat that is legitimate at this program for

public authorities, for example, when you unwind and terminate the MOE, then we go back to where we were in 2011. We have 56 counties in the state that have public authorities in the rural areas, we had received a 60% cut in funding in 2009.

Because ours got cut in 2010 and 2011. We had about a dozen public authorities in the state by 2011 that their total budget, federal state in county was under $100,000. So the reality for us is that we return back to us an unsustainable amount of money and

it's been through the MOE that the counties have been able to subsidize the public authorities and to keep us going. So we're really in jeopardy if this does not get addressed. I also want to say and reinforce what Director Kate has said about the CCI needing additional time.

We were just starting to see some pretty exciting partnerships between public authorities, counties, and the health plans. It took us a long time to figure out our dialogue in a medical system interacting with the social system. But, for example, in Riverside, they were able to get the health plans to agree to be paying a differential and higher wage to IHSS providers, providing back up services.

They were doing things in partnership with the unions and talking about training and other things that were very exciting, those things just starting and so disappointing to see that potentially stop. I want to just mention one thing about the proposal from this house to potentially mitigate the disaster that's facing the counties.

Which is to say that we really appreciate the thought and the energy that's being put into addressing the disaster that occurs with counties, with public authorities across the board. This is just an absolute disaster. So we defer to CSAC, they are the leader but want to let you know that we're very,
very grateful that great thought is being given in to how to mitigate the situation.
Hello, good afternoon.

Mr. Chair, Members of the Committee, my name is Kristina Bas-Hamilton, I work for UDW, AFSCME Local 3930. We have many members in the room here today, I have the absolute privilege to represent them in this building. Get up and I love what I do everyday.

And today I'm here to tell you that our members overwhelmingly would love to see collective bargaining be transitioned permanently for all counties from the county level to the state level. And what I mean is prior to 2012, prior to the CCI, we bargained for

our wages and benefits with the county local public authorities. So you had 58 different bargaining sessions, bargaining committees, bargaining agreements. And in 2012 as part of the CCI, we were able to include a pilot that as each of the seven counties

transitioned into the actual medical service component of CCI. They would also see their collective bargaining transition to a new state entity. Unfortunately, the Governor's action, in addition to all the things that folks are talking about, eliminated the Statewide Authority. And so, we've reverted back to the local bargaining that we were doing pre-2012.

We would like to see re-establishment of state level bargaining for all counties as of July 1st. We believe that this makes the most sense, not only for our members, because right now the system is chaotic. It's not uniform. You have different wages in different counties.

Depending on, basically, what the environments in those counties are, the generosity of the benefits, it's a very unfair system and separate from that is that most fiscally responsible for the state to do because in the present system the state has to pay regardless of what the agreement is that is agreed to locally.

So the state has no input on that. And we all know that wages and benefits account for the vast majority of spending. So from a peer physical perspective it makes the absolute most sense for the state to have direct control over those mechanisms. It is illogical for the state to continue with the system that it has.

So we think we were going in the good direction. We want to keep going in that direction and have it before everyone. Rather than the one foot in, one foot out system we have in the last 18 months. So I want to reiterate TS thanks the committees recommendations in terms of

adopting this we think that this is absolutely the right thing to do for everyone involved. I want to thank for your leadership on this and thank you for allowing us to come and speak today. Thank you. So the most important thing I do want to introduce, it is also my pleasure to introduce my
sister here her name is Isiea Palmer Islam she is a SEIU local 2015 member from Salonga County. She is a IHSS worker and she is here to testify also. Thank you.

Devin Anderson on behalf of San Mateo County, we are of course, one of the seven CCI pilot counties, very dismayed at the ceasing of the program, and we respectfully ask that that be reconsidered also accordingly opposed to the IHSS cost shift. Thank you so much.

Good afternoon. Michelle Gibbons with the County Health Executives Association of California. We represent local health departments throughout our state. We are opposed to the Governor's elimination of the IHHS MOE, as well. The elimination that would have dire impacts on the resources made available for both public health services and healthcare services to the indigents.

So public health services including infectious disease control and prevention, STD control and prevention as well. In addition, chronic disease, obesity prevention, and efforts on a variety of other public health issues. In addition on the indigent care side, as you know there's many threats to the Affordable Care Act right now, and an anticipated increase in the number of uninsured individuals returning to the county responsibility.

And so these are resources that are desperately needed to help provide a level of services and care should those individuals return. And for those reasons, we remain opposed to what the Governor is doing, and we thank you for your thoughtfulness as the Assembly as well.

Kelly Brooks on behalf of the Board of Supervisors of Santa Clara and Santa Cruz County. Santa Clara County estimates that the cost shift related to the Governor Association of the In-Home Supportive Services MOE is $60 million. Similarly, Santa Cruz County estimates that the cost shift is going to be $3 million. Both boards are opposed to the action to eliminate the IHSS MOE and just want to take the opportunity to thank staff for all the work they put into today's agenda, thank you.

Karen Keeslar, not taking another bite at the apple, representing other clients. The Los Angeles County Professional Peace Officers Association for [UNKNOWN]. Clients also in Los Angeles like the Association of Los Angeles Deputy Sheriffs and so forth. Here in Sacramento and Merced, there are two public employee unions and then the public employee union for San Luis Obispo, very, very concerned.

And in Los Angeles, they're talking about across the board cuts in every department including the DA where we represent the DA investigators. Sheriffs potentially are being laid off right now and this just makes it worst. In Los Angeles, this is a $220 million hit that cannot be sustained without impacting public safety. So, we really appreciate on behalf of the unions that I represent your work on this and mitigating the county impact. Thank you.

Jacqueline Barocio, LAO. We've reviewed the numbers and raise no concerns at this time. It is also our understanding that the department, I think in a couple of months will be releasing a report, an update on FLSA and upon the releasement we'll also evaluate that and let you know if anything changes.
Karen Keesler with the California Association of Public Authorities, and

I want to take an opportunity to circle back to where we were at, a year ago and the implementation of the FLSA, counties, public authorities, our union friends, the consumer advocates, all of us were pretty freaked out about an overwhelming task. We asked for the Legislature to weigh in on a number of things, and

what you've very helpfully did was to have dialogue with administration, and a path got slowed down, and the disaster we thought we'd see, didn't happen. I really want to commend Director Lightbourne for what he's done with his staff and with the implementation changes, in terms of timeline,

additional instructions I hadn't expected a year ago at all that we'd see such a small number of violations. But to reinforce Mr. Bean's point, in representing public authorities we're part of the process at the county level. There's is a partnership that is required from the states directions,

and evaluating whether an exemption qualifies. And it's difficult to get to yes, because the exemption category is very narrow. And so we don't hear a lot of stories, but we hear few compelling ones where we have no way to get to yes where those consumer situations are compelling. So, we appreciate the recommended action, and hope that you vote today for our proposal.

Hi, Kristina B. Hamilton with UDW asked me again, want to thank the department for their work on electronic timesheets. This is a major success to get to this point, it's taken a really long time. Thank you Mr. Chair. I had some questions for Mr. Soublet. You mentioned earlier, was it 28 companies are currently testing self-driving vehicles now?
