Okay, sounds like you were talking about how the autonomous vehicle, the self-driving cars act, that they tend to drive very conservatively, almost granny-like, I think you said.
We do raise one note, is that we continue to encourage the Legislature to codify and establish in statute the exemption policies to ensure that they reflex the priorities of the legislative members.

Today I stand, today to adjourn the memory of Dr. Theodore T Fortier, Sr. Dr. Fortier was born in San Diego, California, on August 15th, 1926. Son of Louis Philippe Fortier and Esther Louise Walker, the youngest of eight children.

He had an array of interests that ranged from airplanes, baseball, golf, jazz, travelling, and a passion for art, etymology, which I believe means the study of words. And a thirst for always educating the young and those who aspired to become dentists.

Dr. Fortier attended San Diego Union Academy, Pacific Union College, and graduated as valedictorian from Howard University Dental School in 1957. After graduating from dental school, Dr. Fortier decided to move to Los Angeles to take his dental boards.

Upon passing his boards, he opened his first dental office on Vernon N Weston in my district. And for the next 50 years, his very successful dental practice was a pillar of the Crenshaw community. He was President of the Los Angeles Dental Society and the Angel City Dental Society.

He served in the US Army from 1945 to 1947, where he was awarded an honorable discharge. He served as President of the Crenshaw Chamber of Commerce. The Crenshaw YMCA and was also very active in the Kiwanis Club, and served as its President for a couple of years, along with serving as President of the Vector Control Board.

He was on staff at the USC dental school and taught dental material classes to future dentists. He was awarded the Humanitarian of the Year Award by the YMCA, and received a dentist of the year award by Howard University.
His knowledge of airplanes and his fascination with the Tuskegee Airmen prompted him to be recognized as an honorary member of the Tuskegee Airmen.
He leaves behind his wife, his son, Theodore Jr., grandchildren, Taylor, and Ted the third, and a host of cousins, nieces, nephews, and a community of family friends, he'll be sorely missed.

His greatest passion was teaching young people about the necessity of a good education, life, setting goals, and the importance of good health, giving back to the community and supporting the future generation.
Senator Jennifer Kuhn, from the Legislative Analysts Office.

I wasn't going to talk about the specific budget proposals that you've heard. You're going to hear much more about those later this morning, as well as in your subsequent hearings. I thought what might be most helpful given it's an overview, is to focus on these areas that the chair actually mentioned in the opening comments, access, affordability, performance, and infrastructure.

I'm just going to make a few comments in each of these four areas. So starting with access, on figure one, so you should have our higher end analysis before you. I'm just going to reference several figures that are in the report. You can see on Figure 1, page 4 the higher ed system in California.

The 1960 master plan for higher education believed at the time that it was making sort of an ideal combination of decisions regarding access mission and costs. The Legislature ever since this plan has continued to be interested in access, mission, and cost. The master plan, conceived at UC and CSU's admissions policies would be aligned to the eligibility pools.

The master plan asked UC to draw from the top 12.5% of public high school graduates, and CSU to draw from the top 33%. The data that we have today as of 2015, UC admitting 13% of public high school graduates,

that's the data that we have, and CSU admitting 30% of high school graduates. So then we don't actually have what pools they're drawing from but we do know just the aggregate the numbers out there that they're admitting. To give you some context 15 years ago, UC, admitted 12% of high school graduates.

So it hasn't changed that much and it's--if it were actually pulling from all of the top students, it would be meeting the master plan goals. CSU 15 years ago was admitting 18% so notably smaller chunk than it is today, so effectively CSU is drawing presumably from a much larger pool today, again, than it was earlier. The state's been interested in this and so it provided some funding for the Office of Planning and Research to do a study to see,

well could we get more refined data and see what is UC and CSU actually pulling from. That data was supposed to be available in December. So you might, it's not yet available. You might just want to, in a subsequent hearing, discuss when the results will be available,

if they'll be available on time for you to make your enrollment and budget decisions this year. For transfer students, the master plan design that you would take your GE courses with a certain GPA, and you would be able to go on to UC and CSU. And UC says this is what's happening today. Every eligible transfer student's being admitted somewhere in the system.

CSU was saying that about 10, 000 eligible transfer students are being turned away, so we are recommending that you go ahead and fund enrolment growth for CSU and target it to transfer students. 1% for example, would be 3600 additional transfer students that would have access to CSU. If CSU were to raise tuition by 2.5% it would have enough money to both cover this cost and cover some other costs that are in their budget.

Now presumably you're not going to be thrilled. What do you mean raise tuition to try to fund enrollment growth? But as you go through the session you're going to realize how difficult the choices are for you this year with CSU's budget. Non resident enrollment has been a big issue.
And I think you'll talk about it quite a bit this season. On page six we have some data regarding it. There's also some data in your agenda. For the sake of time I'm going to skip right over it.
But we're happy to talk more about it as the season goes on. So the Legislature's remained, obviously, interested in access. So over the last few years, it's taken actions to try to expand access.

So for example, one thing it did a few years ago was to create a pilot program in the community colleges that would have them pilot bachelor's degree programs. There's also been some interest in changing CSU's eligibility pool, so more students could go directly to CSU. There's been concerns among the segments. On the one hand it's mission creep for this segment or mission creep for that segment.

We would suggest is that if there is a change to mission or to eligibility, given that there are implications for eligibility, for cost, for potential equality and for ripple implications on the other segments, that you just be thoughtful, take your time, deliberate comprehensively, on what the impact to the entire system would be. So turning to affordability, just as a recap, UC has a highest tuition among the three segments.

Right now it's roughly $12,000 for a full time student. For CSU, full time it's roughly 5,500 and for community colleges it's a little bit less than 1,500. For UC, if you are to compare them to similar public institutions, they're high. Still lower than private universities by far but high on the public side.

For CSU they're much lower than their comparable public institutions. And community colleges remain the lowest in the nation, about one-third of the national average. There are some students that pay this full fee costs, the full tuition level. So if you're seeing you're paying that full tuition cost,

you're covering about 52% of the total education cost. If you're paying the full fee at CSU, you're covering 36% and at community colleges, 17%. These don't include federal grants, federal tax credits, deductions, savings plans that are intended to benefit primarily middle income and upper income folks.

If you turn to page 12, figure five, you can see financial aid programs for California students. The state's financial aid programs tend to be grants and tend to be focused on tuition. And about 60% of UC and CSU students get full tuition coverage under a state program.

At community colleges it's about a little bit less than half of students, but about two thirds of the units taken. So the Legislature has been interested in the last few years particularly in the Assembly about expanding state funding for aid. And we've been asked in the past, well what are some options for how the state might want to do that. And the two options we've repeatedly offered have been on the Cal grant area.

So one of the keys we tried to do is to focus on what are remaining areas to access and, remaining barriers I'm sorry, to completion and then try and to get aid money directed as closely as possible to what those barriers are. So there's some concern that low income students are still having to work too much or take on too much debt to complete their programs. And so one way you could address that is by increasing your Cal Grant Access Award which is for financially needy students to effectively cover living cost.

Another option is that non-traditional- Yes, exactly, it's a portion of the Cal Grant Bill that goes for living costs, yes. Another option would be for your non-traditional students who right now aren't entitled to a Cal grant because they're too old,

they take some time off between high school and community colleges, to expand the number of awards you have for them. Right now there are some of these financially needy non-traditional students who in a state program are getting neither money for education or for living. There's far more applicants than the state has for awards. Turning to performance, the state the last few years have been interested in profiling performance during the budget conversations.

Segments now have requirements to collect data Create targets, report outcomes, so just wanted to highlight some of those. On page 16, you can see the outcomes for UC. Unsurprisingly, UC has the best student outcomes among the three statements.

They take the most prepared students, tend to be ranking highest in our class. For the CSU, you're going to hear a lot talk about grad rates. You can see from this table if you look at the six-year grad rate for freshmen applicants,

they had set a goal a few years ago of having 54% of their students graduate in six years and they beat it. They had 57% graduate within that time period, and they have goals to improve, 62% a few years from now growing to 70% by 2025. Now having said that if you look today, there's still more than 40% of students who want to graduate,

who aren't graduating at CSU and we know that about 25% of students, so one in four aren't making that to junior year. So they're starting out as freshmen again and just not making it to year three. So some reasons to be pleased and some reasons to still be vigilant.

For community colleges, you can see their outcomes on page 19, and again there's some promising news and some not so promising news. So, if you were to look at their progress getting students from a remedial course to a college level course, they're doing better today than a few years ago.

For example in math about several years ago 2010, 11 data they had about 29% of students moved from a remedial to a college level math course. And that's increased over four year period of 33%. But at the same time they're getting more students from remedial to college level courses,

they're getting fewer students to actually complete their programs. So if you look at their total program completion rates, a few years ago it was 49%. It's dropped to 47% and has dropped for both prepared and unprepared students. So if you actually turn back to CSU, in addition to looking at performance we've also just been looking at the measures.

And if the measures themselves are giving the Legislature what it presumably intended. Right now the state has two efficiency measures. One is an excess unit measure. 120 units is what you need to graduate. Anything above that would be a measure of inefficiency.

A student somehow isn't seamlessly making it through their four years or six years. So what you can see here, we think the measure is a good one of efficiency. You can see for CSU, despite many efforts to streamline transfer, for example, it actually slightly missed its goal for transfer students,

just made its goal for freshman students. But at 140 some units, students are still, on average, taking more than a full extra semester to complete their programs. The other efficiency measure is just right above here, the funding per degree, and if you look at the targets, the goals, they are to receive more funding per degree as time moves forward.

So we don't think this is, neither we, nor the segments think this is a particularly good measure of efficiency. Think both of us would like to work with you to see if it could be swapped out with a more meaningful indicator, something like cost per student or cost per degree. Finally, on performance, the state law has expressed interest in measuring outcomes for college graduates.

So presumably, college made a difference. We should be able to see that manifested in what happens to students once they leave the schools, but the state right now doesn't have any of these measures for graduate outcomes. So we're encouraging you to think about adding earnings by segment and

campus, as well or instead of, an income mobility measure by segment or campus. One or both of these, we think would be a good complement to the existing performance measures. So, turning to the last big area of infrastructure. So you might recall in 13, 14 for UC and 14, 15 for CSU,

the state made a significant change to how it financed capital at the universities. Prior to this time, the state put a measure on the ballot. Voters, if they approved it. tate went out, sold GO bonds,
paid the debt, serviced, UC/CSU came, we approved their projects. We sold the bond, covered the debt serviced. When the state made this change, it took what the state was paying for

debt service on behalf of the segments, rolled it into their main appropriation item. I think the thinking of the Governor at the time was that if we as a state, rolled capital and operations together, the segments would have more incentive to manage and maintain their properties wisely, because now they'd have a lot of tensions with their operations program.

We only have a few years down the road though, and there are a few issues that are emerging that we just wanted to call to your attention. The first is what it means for the state these days to approve a project. So for example, last year's issues in many projects, you effectively approved them. CSU turned around and said, well, I don't have enough money in my budget to fund all those projects.

And so, funded a subset of them. This year, they're coming before you resubmitting some projects they didn't fund with some new projects, submitting more than they think they realistically can fund this year.

So it's calling into question, what does it mean for the state to approve a project? Does it mean it will be funded that year, a few years from now or never, depending on if the segment's priority has changed. The other big issue is this Governor doesn't want to have another state GO bond,

but the Legislature in some cases has expressed interest it does and a future Governor might and what would happen if there was another state bond? At that time, we would have to consider from both the state and the segment's perspective. It'll be very awkward to figure out how to fund the new bond.

Should it be outside of their main item, inside their main item? Should we re-calibrate their main item to take out what we put in and pull it back out? The final issue on, I think the governor's idea, again was that if the money's pulled together, the segments again will manage and maintain their properties wisely, but

it's still a bit of a concern about who is responsible for maintenance, because even this Governor has funded some maintenance for the universities outside of the main item and both segments are requesting more money to fund maintenance outside their main item. In addition to this, we're in the well-advanced season of an economic expansion.

Most main stream economists think we'll go another few years. So in this kind of environment, we would have hoped that given the size of the maintenance backlogs, they'd be gone by now. And I think the evidence says, they're either the same or bigger than they were at the depth of the recession. So, this doesn't seem to be a great signal that properties are being managed better or more wisely than they were before.

So, just issues to think about. The last issue is on the community colleges facilities. Prop 51 passed, it provided 2 billion for community college facilities. The Governor as you heard has a proposal to approve 5 projects, 7 million the first year.

They total 182 million in total funding through all phases. The Community College Chancellors Office asked for 29 projects to be approved. 71 million in funding the first year, about 700 million total. So if you were to go at the governor's pace, it would take you more than a decade to get out the Prop 51 money.

So, we think that's too slow. Too little, too slow. If you were to do the chancellor's office, you would get it out in just three or four years, but it might be asking a little bit too much to do all of this projects within that time frame.

So normally, when we do the voter guide, we assume you sell the bonds over five years. It'd be great if the Governor gave you a plan to sell the bonds over five years. If he doesn't, you might decide that you just would like to do the plan yourself and decide how you want to allocate this money over time and approve more projects this first year. So, I'm happy to answer any questions.

We think there is. You can signal your interest and you can both approve the projects, and it's in the budget. And by virtue of that, you're sending a signal. Bond should be told to cover the cost that you've approved. He'll ultimately sign the budget that you've approved.

So the community college that get's rather straight forward, it's a regular part of the project process. Now, he does have to work with the treasurer who actually sell the bonds, but you can signal very strong intent and he can implicitly agree by signing a budget.
26, and you also said that most of the crashes that have occurred have been others hitting those self-driving cars.
But do you feel, in general terms, that the companies are acting responsibly in how they are conducting these tests?
And have any of them resulted in injuries?
And so you mentioned a couple companies, and you said 600,000 miles driven?
2 million miles, is that 5 million miles, is that-
Right, and was there a deadline in that legislation as to when that work that you're doing was to be completed?
Okay, so that's about two years behind schedule?
What does that mean, certifications?
Some might suggest that that might apply to the regulatory side, too. But I appreciate your insight, thank you very much.

We are excited that Medi-Cal is rolling out new programs, like the whole person care pilot and the health home program, to fund services that help get chronically homeless people connected to supportive housing, and help keep them sustainably housed. However, based on data, we also know that services alone no matter how good those services are or how intensive they are, do not allow someone experiencing chronic homelessness to get healthier or to stop using acute care services.

The bill requires a rigorous evaluation, which HCD will spearhead in collaboration with the Department of Healthcare Services. While we know what Medicaid cost savings are in other states from moving people from homelessness to housing stability, we do not have good data here in California about MediCal savings. The evaluation findings would also help the Legislature decide whether to continue the program after five years.

So we greatly appreciate the Assemblymember Chiu's leadership on this issue, and we urge your aye vote. And with me today are Dorothy Edwards and Emily Martinique. And they're going to talk a little bit about their experience with supportive housing.

Hi, Michelle Gibbons with the County Health Executives Association of California. We represent local health departments throughout our state. As CDPH has mentioned, we do greatly appreciate the partnership that we have in ensuring that the use of tobacco is decreasing in our state. I know there was a question earlier about some of the programs that are happening at the local levels and so I just wanted to address that briefly.

At the local level, we do campaigns aimed at various age groups. Right now, I think campaigns aimed at teen use and prevention are really taking up. We also are a provider of tobacco cessation classes, and so forth. And then, there's some work being done even with stores to try to limit the availability of tobacco products in the stores.
So, this is just a small snapshot of how we're utilizing those funds and we look forward to continuing the conversation and continuing the partnership that we have with the state.

Madam Chair, would you mind if I made one additional point on this before we move on? I know it's clear to the Committee, but reiterate that we are under a three judge panel court ordered cap. So to the extent that we are not utilizing this capacity or re-purposing it, in the long-term that could reduce the number of offenders that we can house in CDCR facilities.

And I mention that because the use of this facility and all other CDCR facilities is also leading to our ability to return inmates from out of state. So while it may not be ideal housing, I think the department is looking for some creative ways to make best use of it as possible and it does allow for the return of inmates from Arizona and Mississippi and potentially further away if we're not able to use the capacity within California.

Madam Chair and Members, Gregory Kramer on behalf of Planned Parenthood Affiliates of California. We'd like to thank the author for this resolution. We align ourselves with the comments made by Health Access, but as you know, Planned Parenthood is on the chopping block as part of the ACA overhaul, and so we are a safety net provider.

We provide services to all folks, but especially women, and by sending folks off of the ACA, they go to safety net providers like us. But if they wanted to defund us, they'll end up in emergency rooms or with no coverage, so we urge your support. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker, I always rise in proud recognition and encouragement of HR 14 today, and thank my colleague from Richmond for bringing it forward. Permission to read, Mr. Speaker? Without objection.

The primary mission of the social work profession is, to enhance human well-being and help meet the basic human needs of all people with particular attention to the needs and empowerment of people who are vulnerable, oppressed and living in poverty. A historic and defining feature of social work is professions focus on individual wellbeing in a social context and the wellbeing of society. Fundamental to social work is the attention to the environmental forces that create, contribute to, and address problems in living.

And I think this preamble to our code of ethics perfectly sums it up. That is not enough to talk to somebody about how they're feeling what their issues their facing but it's up to us to also from the context in the environment to which every person can reach their full potential. Social work is also on the same month as Women's month.

Social work was a profession that was started by women way back on the turn of the century. People like Ida B Wells the first black social worker. Ida Cannon the first medical social worker. Who went out when people were first being discharged from the hospitals

and discover the tenements and the terrible living conditions people were facing, and knew that if we didn't address that, we could never help people with their health. This is a longstanding profession, and I think in this time, when we're looking at an environment that many people are feeling afraid, when we don't know what's going to happen.
The social work profession is the one, of the 650 social workers out there that will truly go out there and be the soldiers for justice as we work to create this more perfect environment. Thank you.
Thank you. Mr. Speaker and Members, today I present to you HR-24, recognizing the Girl Scouts of America on their 105th anniversary, and on the 100th anniversary of their cookie sales.

The Girl Scouts were founded by Juliette Gordon Low on March 12th, 1912 envisioned to be an organization that would prepare girls to meet the world with courage, confidence and character. In the 1920's, Girl Scouts continued to expand its reach to more and more girls.

They launched one of the earliest Native American Girl Scout troops in 1921, a troop specifically for Mexican-American girls in 1922, and soon after, established the first Girl Scout troops outside of the United States in China, Syria, and Mexico. Since its creation, over 50 million girls have participated in the Girl Scouts during their childhood, and

that number continues to grow as scouts continue to inspire, challenge, and empower girls everywhere. Another thing the scouts are famous for are their cookies, the largest girl-led entrepreneurial program in the world. Just ask my colleagues from Sacramento and Richmond.

The sales of these cookies teach five skills that are essential to leadership, success and life. Goal setting, decision making, money management, people skills and business ethics. Through the sales of these cookies, girls learn that there is no limit to their success. As they utilize the skills they learn in cookie sales, any goals they set are achievable.

Currently, there are 3.2 million girl scouts, 2.3 honorary members and 880 adult members. This includes myself, as I was brought in as an honorary member this year during my community swearing in ceremony. During Women's History month, it is critical that we recognize the women educators,

scientists, women in the media, and of countless other professions that discovered their passions and talents as Girl Scouts. This mission continues today as the Scouts promote the ideals of acceptance, understanding, cultural awareness and tolerance.
Thank you for the opportunity to speak recognizing an amazing institution.
Yes, Mr. Speaker, I ask that the first roll be opened for coauthors and I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Just as someone who's been on the other side, as a Emergency Appearance Coordinator for the City of Los Angeles and having to fill out disaster action reports, and waiting for that money to be reimbursed, either from the federal government or from the state government, it can be very frustrating. I went through the 92 civil unrest and the 94 earthquake, and we're talking millions and millions of dollars that we needed.

And a host of floods from 88 to 94, we used to have floods. I know it sounds strange now, but we used to have a lot of floods and a lot of sand bags. And to wait for the reimbursement, and especially when we had really difficult budgets at the local level can really be frustrating. So hopefully you take that in your consideration to close the gap of when you can refund everyone, because it's really important.

Just real quick, sounds like you need to get some information to one side, like we're talking apples and oranges. I'm not certain, but it's seemed like it'd be resolved real easy if we understood or both sides understood what information you need and what information you have and what you're giving to one another.

Thank you, Mr. Chair, members of the chair community, Keith Dun on behalf of the Self Help Counties Coalition. AB 28 will authorize self help counties and other counties throughout California to continue to participate in a program that has saved millions of dollars in time and delivering critical infrastructure projects here in our state.

If we don't get this bill signed by March 31st, we're going to fall out of compliance and it's going to cost the state of California and each of your counties tens of millions of dollars. So I'd ask for your support.

Good morning chair, members. Melanie Perron, Legislative Director for Caltrans. We are also in support of AB 28. We have seen a median time savings of 10 months on environmental documents. These time savings equal cost savings.
Christopher Sanchez with CHIR, the Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights, in strong support.
Christopher Sanchez with CHIR, the Coalition for Human Immigrant Rights, in strong support.
Madam Chair and members, Andrew Antwe here on behalf of Los Angeles mayor Eric Garcetti. Urge your aye vote.
Cesar Diaz with the State Building and Construction Trades Council, also in support.
Ronald Coleman on behalf of the California Immigrant Policy Center, here in strong support, thank you.

Laura Ayala with the Department of Finance. The Governor's Budget. So regarding county eligibility administration funding, the Governor's Budget maintains the same level of funding for 2017-18. As provided in 2016-17, this augmentation of $655.3 million total funds, 217.8 general fund was agreed upon by the administration in the County Welfare Doctors Association for

both fiscal years to address the increase workload associated with the ACA. And as my colleague from DHS mentioned, that is, we're hoping that a new budgeting methodology is implemented to address the county admin allocation in the future.

And regarding, or do you have any questions on that? So, regarding the cost of living adjustment trailer bill, this proposal which is consistent with the past eight fiscal years amends the Intel language and stature of dispense of the cost of leaving adjustment for counties in 2017-18.
The counties will not receive a [UNKNOWN] However, they will receive a 655.3 million augmentation for ACA workload.
Tiffany White with the SEIU California in support of the proposal for $240 million to go to eligibility workers.
We currently represent over 20,000 eligibility workers and with the uncertainty of the ACA this funding definitely will help ensure that our most vulnerable will keep their services, thank you.

Mr. Chair and members, Rand Martin on behalf of the AIDS Healthcare Foundation, here in support of the AIDS Medicaid Waiver Proposal. AHF has been operating a program like this for many years, are currently operating at an excess of a 20% deficit. They are passionate about the program, the know it works, it's cost effective, it keeps people in their homes, and they will not abandon the program even though they're losing money on it, but it does mean the money is coming from somewhere else. They do not want to be in the position of helping the State of California meet its budget when they're having trouble meeting their own. I urge you to support that proposal. Thank you.
Ryan Spencer, on behalf of the California Academy of Family Physicians, we'd just like to echo the comments that were made by the panelists from the California Medical Association.

And also add that the Academy Family Physicians represents over 9,300 family physicians, residents, and students. These are primary care physicians. And primary care is usually the first point of access to healthcare for many individuals. And just a reminder to the Committee when you're considering the appropriation of these funds,
to remember that the ACA appropriation, ACA provider increase that was intact is no longer. And so please consider than when you're actually deciding how this money should be used. Thank you.

Good afternoon. I'm Jennifer Alley with the California Association of Health Plans. We support the administration's proposal to keep the three pieces of the CCI going. Our members are very invested in the counties where it is and have seen some successes. And we also support any transitional plans or innovative ideas that are going to help streamline care coordination across the spectrum that are sustainable. Thank you.

Peter Hansel with CalPACE for the State Association of PACE Programs. Many of you are familiar with the PACE, Program of All-Inclusive Care for the Elderly, representing 11 programs statewide serving about 7,000 very needy seniors who are kind of at the high-end of the scale, and overlap with the population served by the CCI.

We're part of the coalition that submitted the letter that is referenced in your agenda. I do want to support all the comments that Mr. Morris made. In terms of the role of PACE in the CCI, just want to point out that PACE is included as an enrollment option for beneficiaries in Cal MediConnect, the dual eligible portion of the CCIS must been described,

but it is not included in the enrollment process for the other two components of the CCI, and we're not really sure why that is the case. PACE is a managed care, fully-integrated program serving many beneficiaries that could benefit it, including the ones that have to make an enrollment decision or become enrolled in a managed care plan for their long-term supports and services. So we urge that that issue be given consideration on this item. Thank you.

Jaclyn Berosi with the LAO. It is our understanding with the department that as was mentioned prior, there were efforts originally stake holder meetings etc, to plan the universal assessment. They have received some form of data from UCLA, yet it's not to the level in which they can fully form an assessment tool.

It's still very preliminary and requires the going through and analyzing everything. With regards to any continuation, we do know that there are some advocate proposals, that are proposing that. I know they're in the process of perhaps getting estimates, and working with the department.

As we debate the cost of delivering and maintaining our infrastructure, there's no better way to save dollars than to continue this program. AB 28 is the fiscally sound measure which will allow us to complete program, deliver our infrastructure early and on time.
We're able to approve projects quicker, therefore we're able to deliver projects quicker. This allows us to create jobs and help the economy. Just ask for your aye vote.

Dawn Koepke of McHugh, Koepke & Associates on behalf of Crime Victims United of California, also in strong support. CVUC has long advocated that the term nonviolent, non-serious is a misnomer, largely, because the crimes that are actually deemed violent and serious are a small subset that are specifically mentioned in the penal code. All others, just by the fact that they're not explicitly mentioned,

as we were doing this bill last year, got all the way through the process. As we can, I think, all acknowledge, the war on drugs has not been a raving success. Prior to 1997, the way we're presenting this law was already in effect which says that if you commit a small drug or

alcohol offense in the State of California, that you would be allowed to go to a diversion program pre your trial. If that went okay, then you would continue on. After 1997, we decided to get tough on drugs. We put in this clause that people had to do the plea, go to trial, and then they can go to the diversion program.

In which case, the charges would then go away. But we have found for our immigrant population, that felony was used then to deny them citizenship and also to be used for deportations. So we think the time is even more critical now that we correct this wrong and allow people to go back to the ways we

did it before where there was no evidence that it was incorrect at the time to do a pretrial diversion program. So people make a small mistake but they're able to go to a diversion program. Hopefully they successfully complete that. And then they go on with their lives without worrying about that charge being held against them later on.

I think the last thing we want to do is to penalize people for trying to do the right thing and turn their lives around. We think that's a good common sense law, and again especially in the light of what we're looking at right now with deportations and denying people immigration. This becomes even more pertinent to us today.

So I'm here to answer any questions, and we have with us here today, witnesses in support. Among them Kathy Brady with the ILRC and Jeanette Zanipatin from MALDEF and I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you, Mr. Chair. So now we move on to AB 413, which deals with the issue of domestic violence. AB 413 will allow survivors of domestic violence to submit recorded evidence of their abuse to a court of law without requiring a survivor to obtain permission to record that abuse. In California, we are a two party agreement to record conversations.

So this law goes a step further to allow another tool for those who have been survivors or victims of domestic violence. AB 413 will allow the judge the discretion to determine the reliability of such recordings and to have the final decision on whether or not it's admissible.

Under current law, a survivor of domestic violence my submit recordings without the consent of the abusive party only if the domestic violence crime amounts to a violent felony. The most heinous crimes are already covered. But we know that in 2015 of the over 162,000 domestic violence related calls for assistance...

I respectfully understand your concern. I respect 99% of the officers that give their lives every day, die for a lot of citizens here, and only in this room but outside this room. And protect the public and serve.

My concern, for this is a hate crime, that this bill isn't tailored enough to that 1%, for which these young people are screaming out in the hall about. That 1% that don't do you justice. That have done some things that have caused that anger in the community.
And that anger is real, and visceral. I don't think it rises to where it becomes a hate crime. I can't change the fact that I'm African American. You can change the fact that you're blue.

You're not born blue, I'm born black. At the end of the day, people who hate me, because of my color, hate me whether I'm the President of the United States, or I'm law enforcement or not. They just hate me.

If I ended up in a Klan rally, I'm not going to make it out of a Klan rally. Even criminals will tell you who's your natural adversary. They want you to protect their family's at home while they're encarcerated. They want you to make sure that their kids get to school everyday.

We have to at some point understand that law enforcement right now really does feel hurt and maligned. And we need to bring that trust back in the community. This bill it comes out as a Select Committee that I have done for the last two years on civic engagement participation, both as a city councilmember and then as an Assembly Member. Sometimes our lack of ability to get people engaged has been particularly troubling to me especially on a local level. And when I looked at data and saw that in 2012 there were more people voting for

American Idol that they were for the President. I think that's appalling and doesn't say good things about our democracy. There are a lot of people looking at this issue, I worked with the Secretary of State on this, our Chief Justice on this because for goodness' sakes if we don't have 12 jurors of our peers our entire justice systems falls apart.

Having people engaged in civics and in their government I think is of utmost importance. So, out of the K through 12 civic participation task force out of our work, out of the work with the Secretary of State as well as the Chief Justice one of the things that we thought we get really do, and I've gone around and talked to high schools all over my district.

I do a young legislatives program. I think we must do whatever we can to get young people involved early. What this bill proposes to do is to develop a seal of civic engagement on a high school diploma. We have asked the State Board of Education, they have come up with some

guidelines right now to develop a criteria that needs to be done by 2019. And now as we go forward, I'm going to ask them to do that in consultation with the social studies teachers as they go forward on that, we think that makes sense. And I have talked with a lot of social studies teachers around the state, so that in essence is that the bill we've had other seals for diplomas, we think this is another good thing to get kids involved early,

want them to work for something and understanding the importance of civic engagement. And we have here with us Mr. James Schwab who is with the Secretary of State's Office. He's the Legislative Director.

Thank you very much. Out of 172 democracies in the world, we rate 139th for voting. We can do a lot better than that, and this is a bill that even Mr. Kiley can get behind. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Mr. Chair, members, Nancy Chaires Espinoza with the California School Boards Association.

I want to begin by trying to provide a little bit more clarity. I think it's easy to get very emotional and rightfully so about what happened to the student who just testified. First off, if all that this bill did was preserve the right of Native American students to wear Eagle Feathers or other adornments related to their Native American religious practices,

we wouldn't be here and certainly CSB would not oppose such a bill. Unfortunately, the language in the bill does a lot more than that. It introduces new terms which are vague and legally undefined and that's really the crux of our concern about what it would look like to actually implement such a thing.

I'd also like to back up and just clarify what's been cited multiple times in the analysis, the example for Elk Grove Unified School District. So I am wearing my CSBA hat, but I happen to also be a school board member for Elk Grove Unified. And for purposes of clarification, and I understand the analysis was based on erroneous news reports. A student was never denied the ability to participate in his high school graduation.

So despite the fact that he wore a kente cloth stole that was against school policies at the time, which have since been changed, he did participate in his graduation. There were other aspects of that, but I certainly won't defend and were mishandled, practices have been changed since, but I think it goes to determining the extent of the problem here and I heard the testimony.

I still am not sure that a problem exists that we need to solve. The other example that was cited in the analysis was in Clovis Unified in which, in my opinion, the district misinterpreted current law, and appealed, and there was a remedy that was provided speedily in time for his or her graduation. So again, that doesn't speak to me about a situation where statute needs to be changed. That's a situation where the law is actually working as intended.

That said, let's see, to move on. As stated in our letter and was said previously, school districts already do, as they should, allow tribal artifacts and adornments to be worn. That is current law. A lot of what is in the bill is restatement of current law, including the amendment that is suggested in the analysis. We have no concerns about that.

The difficulty is in introducing new terms like cultural or ceremonial, which first off, are not necessary in order to meet the goals of the author and the supporters, but they open up districts to legal liability. If we were to ask around the room, what is a cultural adornment?

What is a ceremonial adornment? We would probably, each of us, come up with a different idea of what that means. And unfortunately, that's the situation that our school districts will find themselves in. So absent the very narrow circumstances in statute that allow us to limit hate speech or

something that obviously would incite a disturbance, we're very limited in our ability to be subjective about what can and cannot be allowed and in free speech parlance, that is a discussion of content versus manner of speech. What that means is, if we allow graduation stoles that are not related to honors that we confer,

that are academic or co-curricular, we either allow them for everyone, or we allow them for no one. Under this bill, we would lose our local discretion to make that decision about a no adornment policy. So, for example, if we had a student who wanted to wear a graduation stole in the pattern of a Confederate Flag, we would have to allow that if the student made an argument based on culture.

Wrap it up? Absolutely. I will wrap up by saying, we've reached out to the author and I would be happy to continue to extend that offer to try to find something that is more workable. I believe it is possible to simply restate in law that under the religious language, that what they want should be allowed.

Melanie Cuevas on behalf of Oak Park Unified School District. We thank the authors for their diligent work on this bill, we believe it's going in the right direction. As the transportation amendments stand now we're unable to achieve those requirements so we'd like to see that cleaned up and tightened up but otherwise we're in support.

Ginni Bella, LAO.

Thank you, Mr. Chair. Ginni Bella with the Analyst's office. This is one of 14 different IT security related proposals before the Legislature this year. They'll be heard in various sub-committees, and we've reviewed the proposal and

we don't raise any particular concerns with this proposal on an individual basis. However, we did recently release an analysis that took a more comprehensive look at the whole package of the 14 proposals. And these proposals, as our understanding, largely were driven by the Department, at the department level, and reviewed by the Department of Technology which is helpful, but we found to lack a strategic front end approach.

One where the Department of Technology could use their oversight of the whole entire state and make sure that the proposal that are before you are the ones that are the most critical and present the most vulnerable systems with the most sensitive information so that you're making your funding decisions based on the ones that have been vetted to be the most serious.

So going forward we do recommend that the Department of Technology take a more strategic leadership role, do some of that front end driving of the proposals that are before you so that you ensure that the ones you're considering are the ones that are most critical.

Mr. Chairman, Senator Monning. Carl London here on behalf of the Alliance Supporting Persons with Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities, and I just want to make a brief comment on issue number four, related to the housing oversight matter, and the one thing I would just urge the Legislature in particular, LAO and finance to contemplate is, what mechanisms need to be in place to add an element of supervision on how these funds are going to be spent locally.

We've seen discrepancies in the past, where contracts and consultants have been paid inappropriately, and all of us are interested in the most efficient use of funding within the system. So we'd like to just ask you folks to consider an element of oversight from all of you as well, as to how this takes place and how we're going to watch this spending for housing that occurs in the local communities, that the department is talking of. Thank you very much.

Absolutely, yeah, thank you, Mr. Chairman. Here on behalf of the Lanterman Coalition and your analysis correctly reflects the letter that we put into the Budget Office, it's got 20 different logo letterhead on the letterhead. It's a group that represents providers, consumers, family members, many others, a broad base supports throughout that community. And the points were reflected, I'll just run through these really quickly. But number one priority for us, looking at the developmental centers is that we look at closing them as expeditiously as we possibly can and efficiently as we possibly can.

Just to be clear on that, nobody in the Lanterman Coalition is insensitive at all to the needs of the people coming out. But I do want to at least stop for a second and make sure that we're all talking about the same thing. Because there's some concern that, sometimes, and I've even listened patiently to discussions we've had here relative to people's health care needs, and residential needs, and other needs as they move into the community. I handed out earlier a chart, that is a page right out of the Department of Developmental Services fact book. And what I'd like you to encourage you to do is to look carefully at the numbers and the populations that are described here. For example, I'll just pull one out here in the lower left corner there's 397 people with profound levels of intellectual disability in the state developmental centers. Today there are 8,400 of those people living in the community. Likewise if you look in the lower right corner where you look at people who have three or more special conditions or behaviors, there's 250 in the developmental centers.

There are 2500 or 10 times that living every single day in the community. So I think our point in raising that is to remind you and others that as we look at this overall system we don't look at it as a bifurcated system. We look at it as a pot of funds serving this population and that as we look towards closing the developmental centers we learn some lessons from the past that we don't do necessarily what we did when we closed Stockton, and Camarillo, and Agnews, and Lanterman. There is a discussion of transfer trauma for example in the movement of people. We closed Camarillo in one year in order to move the property over to CSU to develop CSU Channel Islands.

All the population in that place were moved and they were moved to other facilities, mostly state facilities in that case. But some were moved into the community and we did it very successfully. By moving people of the community, we gained in the state because we'll recapture federal funds, which we are not doing in the units that you correctly have noted have been decertified. The other thing is that we would ask that the funds that as these developmental centers close and as those assets remain, that those be used to fund people in the community, including those in the developmental centers, but also the remaining community. We've had a nice 10 year run prior to last year's increase of no rate increases for the community while we continue to support the developmental centers at a rising cost per person because of the overall plant costs and costs there. So our point there is that these funds do need to follow people into the community, but they need to follow everybody in the community and that we don't lose the asset and the operating dollars permanently.

I think overall, just a reminder everybody in the developmental centers today is like the people in the community in that they all have an IPP in place. Just like people in the community, through the Regional Center, you are supposed to have an IPP. An individualized plan that is your plan for what you want to happen in your life to make it as fulfilling and as interesting as possible. Nobody's different in that regard. We have the same disabilities as we've noted on paper. So overall I think the Lanterman Coalition's concern is that we not just close these down. Spend every dollar possible transitioning people into the community and then leave nothing at the end of that for the community. We see that as an asset that can be used to continue to serve people under the Lanterman Act in California including those in the community. Thank you for your time.

Yeah, we haven't done that really well in the past. We'd ask that you and other members step in this time and let's do it right. Let's move and consider this as holistic system, taking care of this population, all of them. And not just the remaining 800 who just happen to have a different address than everybody in the community. There's people living through out the community day they have exact same problems. There are many twins out there and we struggle every year to fight for funding every single year. This is an opportunity to make a full transition and allow the department to lead that, but we think they need our guidance, we haven't done in the past.

Hi, Carl London representing the Alliance Supporting Persons with Intellectual Disabilities. Just a brief comment on Item 18, actually. One thing I would urge there that I think our system hasn't done a really good job of doing overall. This is not a critique of a department or any specific player, but is to involve employers in the discussion of employment. I think we often aren't reaching out enough to the people who are asking to put our people to work and I think we just have to go out of our way either through policy or through actual practice of getting groups like CalChamber, CalRestaurant Association, Grocers to come to the table and talk to us about employment and tell us what they need to make it work for them.

Because that's who we're asking to put our people to work. That's the only comment I'd make. That's a self-criticism of the system, not anybody in particular in this room and certainly not the department, but I would urge that whatever we do. As a policy lends we start adding employers every time into these conversations. Thank you very much.
I'm sorry that measures, Mister-
I will give you reconsideration.
Without objection, we can have this decision.
Mike West, District Council 16 in support.

Madame Chair and members, Jenna Price on behalf of the California League of Conservation Voters. Honestly, I would like to leave it, almost for Mr. Blumberg, with what Mr. Blumberg stated. The reality is that we've got ice caps and glaciers that are melting at more rapid paces than any scientific projection has ever noted before. We have sea level rise that right now is anticipated at 36 inches above current sea level by 2100.

We're talking about upwards of 500,000 people on the coast right now that are going to be displaced. That's critical infrastructure that Mr. Berman mentioned. Not just roadways, but we're talking about pipelines. It's upwards of billions of dollars right now in fixes. Mr. Gordon, when he passed this in 2014, recognized that something needed to be done right now.

If we don't continue to allow for a database to going forward, we don't have the guidance. We don't have the planning that can be offered to local communities, jurisdictions, and organizations that are focused in helping these areas of most and greatest need. I think without this resource, California can face even higher costs to repair homes and infrastructure that could have been saved with proper support and planning. So we ask that you continue and remove the sunset. Thank you.

Thank you, I just wanted to say, and if we haven't moved the bill yet, I'll move the bill. Thank you, Mr. Berman, for this bill. I think we only make good policy decisions when we have the data to support those. So sea level rising, sea level not, we need to know so that we can take the proper intervention. So I'm strongly in support and move the bill.
... Thank you. I'd also just like to thank you for this piece of legislation.

As somebody who represents an agricultural region, we realize the importance of making sure that water moves out to the sea because if not, all that sea water comes into the Central Valley where we destroy our entire agriculture economy. Because if you have the intrusion of saline water coming in it disrupts the entire system. So, there's a scientific and very basic need for water to be able to flow out to the ocean.

And also, I'd just like to say, I think this kind of legislation helps protect the watersheds, as my colleague from Santa Cruz talked about. And in addition to providing the kind of recreational opportunities that so people are so, I think hungry for in the State of California.
And then additionally, I'm just really excited that a new water project taking place in my district where we're actually doing underground storage of water.
So there's exciting things happening, and I think your bill goes along way to saying that we don't have to pick one or the other. We're innovative enough, we can do it all.
Hi, good afternoon.

I'm Will Barrett with The American Lung Association in California. In 2016, our organization, The Lung Association, published a report finding $15 billion in health and climate change damages per year in California due to passenger vehicle pollution that came in the form of asthma attacks, emergency room visits, heart attacks and premature deaths.

Fortunately, our state's clean car rules are working and having a dramatic effect on cleaning up the air and they're poised to continue to do that. Clearly, as noted, we need assurance that the rules and technologies needed to deliver real world, clean air benefits, as promised by the manufactures, are being experienced in communities all throughout California as expected by our regulators.
AB 582 would advance this goal and ensure that are health-based policies are working to deliver cleaner air for all Californians. We urge your support, thank you.
Victoria Rome with the Natural Resources Defense Council in support.
Thank you. Good afternoon, Victoria Rome, with the Natural Resource Defense Council. Also in opposition for the reasons stated by Mr. Jones. Thank you.
Again, Victoria Rome with NRDC in support.

Merging with the Bay Area, things that we've been at odds for forever. We're finding out ways to work collaboratively because we know the underground storage of water is the most cost-effective way to do. And we've got enough room underneath us to fill up about five or six dams.

Thank you Mr. Chair and members, Nick Louizos on behalf of the California Association of Health Plans. Thank you for holding this hearing. Health plans are very concerned about the underlying costs of drugs and the impact that those are having on premiums and out of pocket costs for our consumers. And that is why the health plans that choose to use pharmacy benefit managers value those relationships. There's no requirement that a health plan use a PBM. But if a plan does not have the internal capability of performing those functions, they will sometimes go out and contract with a pharmacy benefit manager. And the reason that health plans value that relation is that in those cases, they use a PBM to drive down the costs of drugs, particularly when faced with manufactures that have patent protections on their products.

So health plans use them because they save the plan money and they save our consumers money. Now we've heard a lot of talk about the processes and mechanisms that are put in place in order to design an affordable product. And we would just submit that if there are those that are concerned about a lot the contortions and back flips that the payers have to do in order to create an affordable product, then we ought to focus a little bit more. And what we believes is the underlying cost of that and that is the other underlying reason of that which is the underlying cost of the drugs themselves. Thank you.
Brief question, thank you, Chair. I noticed that there's couple of vacancies on the board by Governor. Has that been a problem over the last six years, where the board members haven't been appointed?

Issues at the board level? And what are they?

Thank you, Mr. Chair. Ginni Bella, with the Legislative Analyst's Office.

Good morning, Rachel Aylors with the Legislative Analysts office. Yeah, so if you look at the bottom of this figure for the flood management you'll see 395 million, and the chart doesn't show any proposed appropriation for 17-18 because this reflects what was the Governor's Budget proposal in January. But in the past few weeks, he has made a request to the Legislature to expedite this funding and appropriate it.

Some of the comments that we would just suggest thinking about. He's requesting an immediate appropriation of all of this funding and he's given you some sort of basic categories for which this would go, some kind of broad categories of types of projects. And while the Legislature doesn't have the authority to itemize specific projects,

you do have the authority to talk about what regions of the state you want the funding to be spent in or what types of projects. So, we would just suggest that you make sure that what the Governor is proposing reflects what you think the priorities for these funds are, and also that you think about putting those statutorily in the budget act to be sure that you have oversight over how the funds are spent and can continue to monitor it.

And we also haven't heard a case to be made for why those funds need to be Allocated immediately. Why they couldn't go through the regular budget process or even be phased in over years to be sure that you're meeting the priorities that you need.

Yeah and in fact, the bond language specifically says at least for the 100 million that is intended to be used outside of the delta has to be for multi-benefit types of projects that all seven environmental restoration activities benefit. Fish and Wildlife, so emergency repairs of levies kind of wouldn't fall in that sort of category. Some of the delta funding here, some of the 295 million can be used for emergency repairs but

as we've spoken about because of the longer term bond funds aren't usually for emergency repairs. The Governor has repurposed some general fund that was provided in the current year budget to be used for emergency repairs so that is kind of on hand.
But yeah, typically bonds aren't for emergencies.

Hard to tell at this point. Based on what you guys have seen? Yeah, hard to tell at this point. And it was 100 million originally, and so there's a little bit more room besides the 50 he's originally redirected,
potentially, but I think estimates are still coming in at this point.
Good morning, members. Today I'm here to talk about AB 200.

This is a simple little district bill, having to deal with the Reclamation District. Reclamation District 1614 operates 11 pumping stations in the central neighborhoods of Stockton. We do that for the 24 hour runoff, storm's coming, we need to keep that water pumping so the city, internal Stockton doesn't flood.

The current pumping capacity, the two pumps that combine 10,000 gallons per minute, it's just not sufficient for the 24 hour runoff. And so about 10,000 people using Prop 218 taxed themselves to replace one of the largest pumps, the Wisconsin area pump. They taxed themselves and raised over $1.175 million under Prop 18, hoping to get the state matching funds to be able to do the other half.

They have applied three different times for grants to be able to fund the rest of that, and have been unsuccessful so far. So this budget ask is a simple bill that says these folks have taxed themselves to over $1 million. The total cost would be covered by what the state would kick in, as is common, and we respectfully ask to help keep us safe from flooding.
I have with me Dan Schroeder to be able to answer any comments.

I just thank all the members, thank Mr. Schroeder for coming up. Thank my constituents for taxing themselves and ask respectfully that we invest in the infrastructure in one of the oldest cities in California. I ask for your aye vote.

Thank you and good morning. I'm Michelle Gibbons with the County Health Executives Association of. California. We represent local health departments throughout our state and we're here in strong support of AB725 today. Tobacco-related illnesses are the leading cause of preventable deaths in the United States.

And according to the most recent data from the Centers for Disease Control, of the roughly 480,000 tobacco-related deaths per year, 41,000 of those results from second hand smoke. And studies have also shown some exposure to tobacco smoke in the outdoor area is just as harmful as the back of smoke in any indoor areas as well.

And so local health departments are strongly support of that efforts to really improve the health of our communities. And we recognize that this State Parks and Beaches are often frequently, or frequented often especially by children and families. And so we applaud the member today for this measure, which will reduce secondhand smoking exposure to visitors. And we would strongly urge your aye vote, thank you.

I do want to thank you for bringing this to our attention. I think that just as the statement was made earlier, hate crimes are wrong, in any degree, against any group for specific reasons related to that group. I also appreciate the comments made by the ACLU about the presence of law enforcement where our children are. One of the things that you said initially was it's the first step in protecting all students in California.

Without a doubt, and I think I could speak for just about everybody in the Legislature, that's primary for us. We want to protect all children. My big concern with this is using public funds, and it's been mentioned earlier, for private institutions.

We've talked about some of the other places where it has been done successfully. But that for me is one of the biggest concerns. The issue of calling, it was commented about calling the police with immediate threat versus having law enforcement around our children while they're in school.

And I think we need to find that, the right balance between the two. In the evaluation, there was also the discussion that existing law requires that if police are called, then they need to be reimbursed afterwards. So maybe that would be another way to look at this to try to find ways to protect the children, because that's got to be our primary concern.

But to find ways that were not necessarily allocating sum certain for private institutions from public funds. And that's my biggest concern. But calling police with immediate threat, versus having a law enforcement always present, how do you find the balance?

I think one of the things I appreciate about this is that it's a protection for our seniors. I think that they often become the victims and I appreciate that, although we couldn't see it from where we're sitting, we received these and I appreciate that you did bring the props. Is there something specific, since I did mention our Seniors, something specific that will be used to make sure that our Seniors are protected from these unscrupulous practices?

Mr. Medina, thank you so much for bringing this forward. Without a doubt for too many years San Bernardino and Riverside County have suffered from a lack of judges. San Bernardino specifically has had to close many of their courthouses, requiring many of the litigants to travel long distances to get to a more central courthouse. So I applaud you on this, and I am in full support of this.

Thank you Mr Chair and members, and thank you to your Chief Counsel for her great work on the analysis. I present to you AB 535, which eliminates the unjust exclusion of people with felony convictions from jury duty by reinstating their civil right to jury eligibility. At any given time in California, nearly 300,000 people are incarcerated for a felony conviction.

The vast majority will complete their sentences and return to their communities, joining hundreds of thousands of people who are preemptively barred from jury duty. And disproportionate percentage of these people are African American and Latino. The blanket exclusion of all people with felony convictions,

without the individualized consideration afforded to all other citizens during the jury selection process, perpetuates harmful and inflexible generalizations about formerly incarcerated persons. With one out of every six African American men incarcerated in the United States these wide sweeping assumptions have damaging consequences on an entire demographics of people.

In 1974, Californians approved Prop 10, which restored the right to vote for those who have been convicted of a felony. Restoring their right to simply be eligible for jury service, should be treated the same and is long overdue. If the ultimate goal of our justice system is to rehabilitate those who are returning to our communities, then we must not continue to punish them and limit their rights of being fully contributing members of society.

Ultimately, AB 535 will present the opportunity for empowerment, the encouragement of civic duty, and increased commitment to government procedures, and more engaged, law-abiding community members. With me today, I have Susan Burton, founder and Executive Director and Tiffany Johnson, associate director and community organizer for A New Way of Life,
which is a leading organization helping formerly incarcerated women with reentry, housing, and other services and programs. Thank you, I ask for your aye vote.
Basically gives you the right to appeal to the Governor's office and now all of them are immediately approved.
Right now, I'm trying to get what's before me.
Thank you. And I echo what the rest of my colleagues have indicated. Congratulations on your 20 years of sobriety. And on being an upstanding citizen, I think that's an important phrase.
But thank you also for the work you do with all the other women, thank you also. Because it isn't just doing for yourself, but making sure that you bring up the others who've also served their time.
Otherwise, it's a life sentence. You're told you're going to serve 15 years or whatever the number is but in the end, it becomes a life sentence.

And this is a great step, making sure that we're not serving life sentences when we're not supposed to be serving life sentences. I think that this is an important bill because in the end, society loses if we don't have a good diversity in the jury box. So I'm in strong support of this, thank you for bringing it forward.
All right, and I thank everyone for the comments, and especially their questions.

I think the great equalizer in all this, in the judicial system is this, the part about voir dire. I mean, it's interesting you have both a prosecutor and a defense attorney, a public defender and a defense attorney sitting together. Yeah.

And even in our discussions, as the budget chair will tell you, last year the Governor reduced the amount of preemptive challenges which I fought. I fought, screamed, and hollered about [UNKNOWN], I was about to give my life blood to ensure that we didn't, because I felt it was a disadvantage to the public defender, and

when I mentioned it to The defense attorney on this side, he said, no, it's a disadvantage to the defense attorney, and so it tells you how equal the voir dire process is in letting people in who perform a felon, that ultimately will be the place where we can insure that people are open minded.

Just like police officers, we do not exclude them because they may have predetermined understanding that criminals that they prosecute, that once they're in jail, they're bad forever, but we don't preclude them from being on juries, so we shouldn't preclude people who have been part of the system from being on juries, so I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
Christopher Sanchez with CHIRLA the Coalition for Immigrant Rights in strong support.

I think the proposal is good policy. I think that we do need protections. Because we are living in these extraordinary times. Where people, landlords do feel they have this license to discriminate, and to harass, and to intimidate. I have volunteered with a number of legal aids.

And we know that through legal aids, that's where most of our tenants go for assistance. As my colleague has indicated, the policy of 12 times, it is something, the proposal, up to 12 times. And perhaps it could be six to 12 times putting it in the hands of a judge. But having said that I do think this is a necessary piece of legislation. I think it is good policy, thank you.

Yes, again, my name's Jeannie Merrill Policy Director for California Climate&Agriculture Network. We're a coalition of sustainable and organic act organizations and we're pleased to support SB 276 which makes an important fix to last years SB 859 by clarifying the Healthy Soils and SWEEP programs are not apart of the bills on rest reporting medication requirements.

I'm going to speak very briefly to the Healthy Soils component of the fix. The Healthy Soils Program provides incentives and demonstration projects. Project funding for on farm projects that reduce green house gas admission and improve soil carbon sequestration. The program supports climate smart act practices like the garden of cover crops,

the use of mulch, compost, the planting of trees and neutrals. All which provide multiple economic and benefits to our air and water and polity. And then, let's fix SB 859, requirements for the stymie, the development of Healthy Soils Program and

new initiative as swell as SWEEP make it undesirable for farmers and ranchers to participate. Which is some of the opposite but we need to do right now. In terms of being able to meet our climate change goals. And we urge your support.

Kevin Aslanian Coalition of California Welfare Rights Organizations, co-sponsoring the bill. This is a bill that would make education which leads to self sufficiency, and it uses positive incentives rather than negative incentives. And therefore, we support this bill and urge an aye vote. Thank you.

Thank you very much Madam Chair and members. I'm glad to be with you here today to present AB 223. This will provide the counties of San Joaquin, Sacramento and Alameda the opportunity to create a pilot program that would provide tailored services for youth, who are affected by the criminal enterprise of human trafficking.

A growing issue around our state, and this issue came to me when a meeting with my DA and her staff about what are the issues that we're grappling with and how can the legislation help? So one of the things is there, there's not really good, we've gone after the people who buy and sell our children, but when we take somebody out,

when we have a survivor, we don't have a good place to help them, and this is a life that people are not by most times any actions of their own find themselves in. And so is not as easy as going to get some counseling once a week, people need to wrap around safe places to go. And they also need to not to be have access where somebody can go in and remove them right back into the same streets that they came from.

So this will provide this full wraparound services between these three counties. These are close enough that they got a woman from someone King County, maybe will go to Alameda County just so that the same people who have put her out in the streets don't have that same access to pull her out of a treatment program and put her right back again. So we think this is a really good place to start.

In my former life I was Director of Real Estate for the city and we had a lot of vacant land. And sometimes we had some tragedies. We've had rapes, we've had drug dealers on those vacant lots and they happen to belong to government.

Until we started turning them into urban farms, we weren't able to reduce the amount of crimes that happened on those lots. And so this is really important especially for the private sector. Obviously, liability issues are enormous and we need to do a lot more than we have.

And like my former boss used to say, you can't spray paint fruit and vegetables. And so, this is a great way to clean up urban areas that may not be as affluent or may not have the type of acreage that's used for farming, and I think we should do more of that in urban areas, so thank you for bringing this forward.

Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman and members. I'm pleased to present SB 346, the Computer Science For All Cleanup Bill. This is bill is response to the Governor's singing message of Assemblywoman Benitez's bill from last year, which was AB 2329. That bill required the Superintendent of public construction to convene an advisory panel to develop recommendations for computer science strategic implementation plan to ensure every student in California has access to computer and science education.

That bill inadvertently limited the discretion of the State Board of Education and had technical issues related to the appointments to and staffing of the advisory panel. This bill addresses those issues, it expands the discretion of the state board and it resolves the technical issues relating to the appointments in staffing, and it also pushes the implementation back one year, so every stakeholders able to prepare for the successful implementation of this computer science strategical implementation plan. The bill is supported by the tech industry, has by parties and coauthors and there is no known opposition, and I respectfully ask for an aye vote. I am pleased to be joined by Andrea Devo of Tech Net, supporters of the bill.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. AB 149 will require defense counsel to inform their defendants that accepting a plea in a subsequent felony conviction will have several collateral consequences. These collateral consequences include, but are not limited to, ineligible for

enlisting in the military, ineligible to own or possess a firearm, loss of federal financial aid if the felony was committed while the defendant was receiving financial aid, and potential diminished parental and child custody rights. According to the New York Times, fewer than 1 in 40 felony cases now make it to trial,

as compared to 1970, when the ratio was 1 in 12. As a result, there are far more plea bargains taken now than ever before. Oftentimes, defendants are not fully informed of the consequences of accepting a plea and being convicted of a felony. AB 149 will ensure that this essential plea is provided prior to the acceptance of a guilty plea. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

That was brought up during the hearing, and we just want to keep this moving and make sure that all of those are addressed. Most important, they're very, very good cogent ideas that will make this even better. So I want to thank everyone that participated in this.
