Thank you Mr. Chair remembers I'm very happy to be here before you today, to talk about a very serious issue facing our country and especially our state. Today I'm presenting AB186 which will allow a pilot program to allow a certain amount of counties up to 10, to be able to permit for safe injection sites for a very small demographic of people.

People who are addicted to drugs and who are using in public places who are either homeless or certainly on the verge of homelessness. Heroin and opiate overdose in the United States is on the rise. According to the CDC, in 2010, nearly 2000, 4000, I'm sorry,

new cases of HIV were attributed to unsafe injections. Heroin overdose and mortality in the United States has nearly tripled between 2014 and 2010. The same New York Times report that 125 people die every day from overdose of heroin. We need to know the public crisis it is rather than treating it like a criminal issue. In 2013,

California hospitals treated roughly one overdose every 45 minutes and on average, nearly one Californian dies from an accidental drug overdose every two and a half hours. AB 186 will increase access to treatment and services for an extremely vulnerable population. Again, these are people who are homeless, near homelessness and suffering from addiction.

This approach has been around the world and nearly 100 facilities worldwide demonstrating a number of personal and public health benefits while having no negative impact on overall use or drug related crime. These go in, people find that overdoses reduce, deaths reduce,

the use of people using in public goes down, the amount of people going into treatment goes up. These are folks who were going into our ERs and our jails on a rotating basis. They are people costing hundreds of thousands of dollars every single year to our local municipalities. We have treated this like a criminal issue.

I think it's time for us to start treating this like the public health issue it is. Systems start treating people a little bit more compassion rather than just judging them after the fact, when we lock them up or they lose a limb to infected abscess. These sights, are a place again where we would give all the power to the local control for them to be able to decide if they want to have a site.

It is going to be an area that already has a large concentration of people using in public areas, which would make sense. Nobody is going to get two bus transfers to go across town to use at a site. It is somewhere that people are already publicly using. When people go into a setting they';; will be able to safely use. The people there will have narcan

on site to be able to quickly administer, to prevent overdoses. There is no evidence of overdose in any of the supervising injection sites around after the administration of naloxone. You're also able to then be able to, if somebody is suffering from domestic violence, or if somebody is newly homeless, or if somebody has a bad abscess, be able to refer quickly to a treatment facility.

So, the idea of these, a safe place for people to go to be able to be treated with compassion, a safe place, reducing infection, reducing HIV transmission, increasing people going in to treatment. We have witnesses with us here today to speak in support and we hope that you give us new full attention thank you.
Sharon Rapport with the Corporation for Supportive Housing, in support.
It's a pilot that right now has eight counties, and we will extend it to 10 in a pilot for four years.
Presently, we will allow up to 10. These counties have given some indication that they would like to be included, and so these are the first ones who have been included in it.
It's in the bill, but it is San Joaquin, Mendocino, Humboldt, Los Angeles, Alameda, San Francisco, Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, that's what we have. It's a quiz.

I understand and I will let our experts speak about the success rates and the data that he has studied. But I will say, when one of these goes in to be permitted, you'll have to get buy-in from local law enforcement and we have set some general parameters thanks to the chair and some of the amendments they offered to set general good neighbor parameters around that. But every one of these will have some kind of public process in their localities to be able to setup those guidelines and I don't think, let you speak more about it, but there's any evidence that these turns into just, these are generally attached to some kind of treatment facility. Again, these are places that are generally within a five block radius of where there is already a large concentration of people publicly using drugs. And then I'll let you speak to success rates.

We have general guidelines right now. I wanted to leave a lot of that up to local control. We start mandating every aspect of it, I think we take away from what might be different in San Francisco then what might be different up in Humboldt County, two very different locales. But certainly, the idea is that there will be no, I mean, drug trafficking is off the table. People, that is in no way associated with this program.

In most places in the word they also find that law enforcement actually refer people there. If you somebody out using in a public area I say hey, there's a safe place for you to be able to use, I would get in mind more of a blood bank type facility than a club of any kind.

What we do know is in the last, since 2002, Alameda County, LA County, San Francisco, have doubled the deaths from overdose from opioid addiction. So it's not like we are encouraging it. We are saying we acknowledge it's going on, we think providing a safe place for people to use, with clean facilities that have healthcare professionals there to tell them, I don't think you're just some bum that I'm going to step over or see in jail, that you're somebody that I care about. We're going to provide you a safe experience and hopefully refer you on to treatment

Yeah, this is just one step in a continuum, right? It is one more tool in the toolbox that I think we need to treat addictions, I've shared. I've worked in addictions for 10 years early in my career. I saw the endemic go from heroin, to crack cocaine, to methamphetamine, and now we're back to opioids and heroine again. Treating this as a public health issue I think is just imperative. It has not been successful treating it like a criminal issue.

There's just some things we can't control. I mean people are using. We're saying here's one tool to keep them safe a little bit longer, with hopefully a higher chance that the're going to get into treatment. And not be using needles in playgrounds, or a kid stepping over them as they've overdosed in an alley. That's not compassion to me.
We're accepting the amendments and thank you very much for working on it so hard.

They will be in a safe place where they will be able to use the drugs that they would otherwise be using on the streets where they would have no option for treatment. They would have no option for an abscess or domestic violence, or anything else they might be using from. They would go into a place, they would stay until they were comfortable, and yes, they would leave and some of your arguments are the same ones that were raised around medical marijuana and then recreational and we find ourselves, where we find ourselves. I mean the idea just to tell somebody that if they want to be used safely that the requirement then is to go into treatment, you wouldn't have the kind of success rates that you have in programs around the world, where people are actually safely using and at some point hopefully getting into treatment.
If they had a car, they would probably use there.
I certainly appreciate your perspective.

Would you like to hear from our addictions specialist? Because, and I know that the problems in Fresno County with heroin addiction are astronomical. So, I know that you're well informed of the problems in your own area. Dr., would you want to respond?
If I could help for a second Mr.Patterson, when people are basically using-

Thank you. So in my experience with working with people who are using, when they initially use, I think that's the concern that you're talking about, when people kind of nod out for a little while. Heroin addicts will refer to using as getting well. There will become a time after the initial euphoria where they will then be able to go out and function, which is kind of the track of a heroine addict. It's not like you're getting drunk and then you stay intoxicated for hours on end. It is a different kind of experience.
I think we've answered that, Mr. Patterson, multiple times. I'm sorry if it wasn't to your satisfaction.
Exactly, yeah, that-

In terms of the liability, the legal analysis that we've done from the Drug Policy Alliance, it's similar to the liability that cities already carry for operating health care clinics and other programs. This wouldn't necessarily be an additional issue of liability above and beyond that and once programs are authorized under this legislation, it provides some protection for the participants and the program operators to address some of that issue. What we do know from the experience in other places such as in Vancouver, what happened in Vancouver was the regional health department covered the liability insurance for the program and just incorporated that into their liability coverage for all of their health facilities and so it was a small additional piece given that they're already covering healthcare facilities that have these issues.

Yeah, correct. We've gotten this question before and so, we've asked around to some of the larger facilities around the world, and none of them have had this sort of liability lawsuit that we're aware of, that have increased their costs.
We have among the clients who, they use Vancouver site, 18% engage in a detox, 57% started an addiction treatment and 23% have stopped using injection drugs altogether.

No one is saying once they go into treatment that they never use again either which is not the nature of addiction. But that they took that step I think speaks to Miss Walder's issue that, if you're there and there's a compassionate person, you're much more likely to take that next step when you have that relationship already developed.

And so far, anything we've looked at, it hasn't risen to the level that we thought it was something that we needed to include. Certainly local municipalities, when they are drafting their own ordinances, they could look at that and we can certainly look at that going forward.

Thank you, I would just say we have the same issue with bars. Places that people go and drink and the issues with alcohol far surpass anything else in the amount of drunk driving and deaths that we see. So it has not risen to any kind of level, again, these are people who are already using in other kinds of manners.

Thank you Mister Chair and thank you to everybody for the thoughtfulness that everybody put into this and again I know this is not an easy topic. Addiction Is not pretty, addiction is not easy, and you know, if we could wish it away. You know, if the world were wishes, we would do it, but it's not, it is messy, it is complicated, and Mr. Chair, when you talk about those lives that are saved, I would grant you that, that's multiplied, because every one of those people that has a family member who, has probably struggled for a decade to try to get them into help, and pray for that day, when they finally decide that the time is different.

We know that a large percentage of our homeless drug-using people on the streets are veterans. That we've, for one reason or another, turned our back upon. We are not saying that this is a panacea to treat all of addiction, but we are saying it is a harm reduction model. It is a model that says we have a giant problem. This is just one component in the continuum of care, where we can meet people with compassion, with safety, and to offer them services, and hope to live for another day. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Good afternoon, Sharon Rapport with the Corporation for Supportive Housing. For the last six years, my organization has administered a program we call The 10th Decile Project. It's really looking at the top 10% of highest-cost hospital users in Los Angeles County. We partner with 15 hospitals, 7 clinics, and 7 homeless services providers in this program.

And the intent is to really, for those who are homeless and extremely high-cost hospital users, to give those individuals rental assistance and intensive services to help them reduce their hospital costs. Based on our hospital data, our program participants were incurring about $63,000 a year in hospital costs, two-thirds of which were born from inpatient hospitalization.

They were all on Medi-Cal. These individuals were not going to the emergency room because they wanted a warm place to sleep, they were going because they suffered from very acute healthcare conditions. Over 88% had more than one chronic medical condition that brought them to the hospital.

Within one year of moving these individuals into supportive housing, they were able to reduce their inpatient admissions from seven inpatient admissions per year, to one. They were able to reduce their inpatient days from 25 to 5. After the participants moved into housing with these intensive services,

they were able to reduce their hospital costs by 79%. When taking into consideration the costs, the rental assistance, and the services, that translated into $40,000 reduction in costs to Medi-Cal. Our 10th Decile Project is not unique, we see from the last 25 years, study after study.

Published in journals like JAMA and Health Affairs that supportive housing reduces health care cost significantly. Because of these data we now have the whole person care pilot in 18 counties. We're going to be receiving whole person, I'm sorry,

Health Home Program next year in almost 30 counties. And those two programs will pay for the services homeless people need to get housed and stay stably housed. But we know services alone, no matter how intensive or quality these services are, don't allow anyone experiencing chronic homelessness to reduce their hospital costs, or get healthier.
For these individuals housing is scarce. We greatly appreciate Assembly members choose leadership on this bill and I thank you.

Thank you, members, Sherry Daley with the California Consortium of Addiction Programs and Professionals, representing over 12,000 professionals in the field, 500 agencies and sober livings, and 300 schools throughout the state. We are supportive of the bill. We started this Committee hearing today talking about one end of the continuum, which is someone who is not likely to be entering treatment, or may not know about treatment or its benefits, and now we're talking about the opposite end of the spectrum where somebody has successfully completed treatment, or is seeking a place to live a clean and sober lifestyle.

Our issue with these bills in the past has been that they tend to run afoul of the Fair Housing and Americans with Disability Acts. This is a unique and progressive approach to the situation. Allowing quality sober living homes who wish to be recognized to come forward, meet a agreed upon list of standards that is approved by the national authority in this area. To register with an organization approved by the state Department of Healthcare Services, and to provide some minimal training to those who both own and operate and at least one person who lives in the sober living. The costs associated are low.

$195.00 a year to register and that covers the expense of going out and doing an interview, looking at the facility. Make sure it meets the requirements, responding to complaints, coordinating with the Department of Healthcare Services. So it's a very affordable measure for both people who participate and also for the State of California. It's really important that sober living be available in our communities and that we reduce the conflict between sober living and our local governments. Sober living allows people to have a better chance of not relapsing. It reunites families and it makes communities safer. I would urge you for a aye vote.

We would like to make sure that that information is available to researchers from other organizations. Our concern is when you have the discretion in a place that has tilted to those who are more towards gun control forever.

We have a concern about that. The folks that are running the California Research Institute have never come up with any sort of a document. That has showed the validity or the usefulness of firearms in society.

Everything has been tilted and that's why we have great concerns. And if this bill were to say, we're going to make this available to all academic researchers, to all of the organizations that want to conduct research. We don't have a problem with that.

What we do have, is when somebody gets to pick and choose as to who is qualified to do research. For those reasons, we are in opposition of the bill. And would like to remove our opposition if that is a consideration that would be taken up by the author. Thank you.

Melanie Cuevas on behalf of CAST, the Coalition to Abolish Slavery and Trafficking. CAST is the first US organization to exclusively serve men, women, and child survivors of human trafficking, and our comprehensive services include shelter, legal case management, and we also a 24 hour hotline throughout California.

Our policy work is based on our underground experience, and today we are one of three sponsors in support of AB 900 to ensure that victims of human trafficking are eligible to receive compensation for lost income. Each client that CAST serves receives information about the Cal VCP process and support in applying for VCP.

Traditionally our clients receive payments for things like medical services, mental health services, and relocation expenses. According to current statute, crime victims can also recover loss of income as a direct result of their crime. However to our knowledge no human trafficking victim has recovered loss of income.

Current regulations require an applicant to support their claim with a letter from the employer. Requirements presume lawful record keeping, and cooperation of employers. No victim of human trafficking has the formal documentation required by current statue. At it's heart, trafficking is about the exploitation of human beings for commercial purposes.

This means that lost income is frequently a victim's greatest category of economic loss and to be made whole, victims need to recover income they lost while being forced to work. AB 900 provides needed clarifying language ensuring that BCP has expressed guidance on its ability to compensate victims and

ensuring that survivors are able to receive compensation for income lost that is a result of their being trafficked. Lost income includes income lost during trafficking, and we cite existing California statute on how to calculate lost income, including the $70,000 lifetime cap.

I cannot tell you how much AB 900 would mean to every trafficking victim, who would now know that the system recognizes their commercial exploitation. On behalf of the survivors we serve, we respectfully ask for your support.

Thank you, Mr. Chair. AB 785, also known as the Disarm Hate Act, closes a gap in current law that permits individuals convicted of violent hate crimes to possess and acquire firearms within 10 years of their conviction.

While existing law generally prohibits violent misdemeanants and others convicted of misdemeanors that involve the use of or threaten the use of a firearm, the list of misdemeanors actually prohibiting individuals from owning or possessing a firearm overlooks Penal Code Section 422.6.

A provision that makes it unlawful to use force or threats to force, to willingly injure, intimidate, interfere with, oppress or threaten another person based on that person's race or ethnicity, religion, nationality, disability, gender or sexual orientation.

The observed result is that existing law prohibits people convicted of crimes like assault or battery from owning guns for 10 years, unless they were convicted of a hate crime, for committing the same acts on the basis of bigotry.

AB 785, the Disarm Hate Act, would help keep weapons out of the hands of those who have demonstrated dangerous propensity to escalate bigotry into criminal threats and violence by preventing people who have been convicted of a violent hate crime misdemeanor from possessing or acquiring firearms for 10 years of conviction.
This bill would responsibly address threats to our state's plurality, some big words I can't pronounce, pluralistic values and reinforces the promise that California's safe and free for all.

I respectively ask for your aye vote. Here to testify are Ari Freilich on behalf of the Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence, and Amanda Wilcox on behalf of the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence California chapters.
Thank you for catching that.

So it's not, this hate is not stopping. And while I probably couldn't ban everyone from carrying a sword. Its, it just tells you it is serious and the hate that people have, obviously, using a firearm makes it a lot simpler.
But we also need to, not only get the weapons out of their hands but we probably need to start working on making better citizens. So, I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Thank you Mr. Speaker, and members. I'd like to first start out by saying that I accept the Committee amendments. I do. So this is one of my favorite topics to talk about, two of them combined together. Trying to increase food security and decrease things going into the waste stream. This bill simply clarifies and creates the Good Samaritan Food Donation Act, that clarifies what kind of foods can be donated and if they're past their due date, we clearly know one in eight Californians are still hungry.

One in four children are hungry. And retailers and manufacturers and restaurants are still telling us that they throw away about 40% of their food that they could possibly donate because of the fear of liability, so this clarifies a lot of that issues. And again, we hope to take things out of waste stream and get them into hungry people's bellies, keep California strong. And I have people here testifying in support.
Currently, it's, for the, currently people feel they have to use an intermediary, and this allows them to also just give directly on those windows issues.

Thank you very much. Just help for passing this bill again, and achieving two, I think really good goals for California. Increasing hunger security and decreasing food waste. And I don't know about the rest of you, but when I see that reduce thing in this grocery store. I go right there. So I think we can be a little bit more flexible with our due dates. I ask for your aye vote.

Thank you Senator, Chair and Senator Lara. Members, I'm presenting SB-378 on behalf of Senator Portantino. In recent years, California cities have increased their efforts to address the issue of human trafficking, gang activity, and violent crime.

However, in limited circumstances, where these activities run in conjunction with a business holding a liquor license Local law enforcement and city officials often lack the tools necessary to quickly deal with problem businesses that pose an imminent danger to the health and safety of individuals while at the same time protecting the business' due process rights.

This bill authorizes the Director of alcohol beverage control, by a temporary restraining order, to temporarily suspend or condition a license when in the opinion of the Department of ABC, the actions is urgent and necessary to protect against an immediate threat to the health or safety that is related to the operation of the licensed business.

This bill establishes a method for local officials to formally request that the Director seek a temporary restraining order, which provides an avenue for city law enforcement and local government to help identify the most egregious cases. To protect businesses' due process rights, this bill requires any proceeding

brought under this expanded authority to conform to the existing requirements of the code of civil procedure. Lastly, this bill directs ABC to adopt regulations to ensure that they use this new authority in the most appropriate manner. This bill closes a problematic enforcement gap by allowing ABC to address problems,

license businesses within a time frame to protect the surrounding communities. Today, I have Jonathan Feldman from the California Police Chiefs Association, the bill's sponsor. And Tim Cromartie from the League of California Cities to testify on the bill's behalf. I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Thank you Mr Speaker, members. Today I present ACR33, which declares the last week of March as the state wide week for Latino Education Advocacy. As we know Latinos are the largest minority in the State of California. In fact they make up over 50% of all K through 12 students enrolled in public schools.

Despite the progress in recent years, Latino students still have among the highest high school dropout rate, lowest scores on achievement tests, and the lowest college enrollment rates among their peers. Access to quality education has become more difficult in recent years, the Latino community is losing the battle to keep our focus on educational equity, and academic attainment.

Latino students are still living in racially segregated communities with high poverty rates, where schools have fewer resources, fewer staff, and fewer programs. Where parents feel the burden of language barriers, that prevent them from understanding how exactly they can help their student, their child. Many of our students are straddling two cultures, two worlds, and are uncertain where they fit.

They're trying to fit to a society that has not completely accepted them because, they are the family or members are somewhat different. Many Latinos students are trying to decide who they are and where the education can take them. To address these critical issues and to ensure strong future, the lead organization the Cal State San Bernardino,

is hosting one of many national and international projects, that address the Latino advocacy and Latino literacy. Today on March 30th 2017, Cal State San Bernardino will host its 8th annual lead summit. Summit will be presented under the direction of Dr.

Enrique Murillo, over a thousand people will attend and it will be viewed by millions. The competitive strength of our nation will continue to depend, to a large extent, on the positive, educational opportunities, and outcome of our students. We want to promote a broad-based awareness of the crisis in Latino education,

in order to enhance the intellectual, cultural, and personal development of our communities educators, administrators, leaders, parents, and students. That is why today I present to you ACR 33 to declare the last week of March for Latino Education Advocacy. Thank you and I respectfully request an aye vote.
Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I would request that the first roll be opened for coauthors.

For some of us we were the farm workers, for myself, I was picking onions and grapes as a young girl. Tomorrow, as we enjoy this holiday, I just ask that we acknowledge all of those who are still struggling, those farm workers still struggling for those rights that we all enjoy and take for granted. Cesar Chavez is a true inspiration, a true American hero.

As many of you know, he founded the United Farm Worker's with the Dolores Huerta 1962. 1968 was the largest boycott of table grapes. He tried to bring attention to the pesticides being used, the conditions of farm workers, and

the fact that there were no bathrooms, no shade areas for these workers. He led marches, he led boycotts, he led hunger strikes. Many of us know about those hunger strikes. The first one was in 1968 where he fasted for 25 days.

1972 he fasted for 24 days. Finally, in 1988, he fasted for 36 days. Cesar Chavez, as you all may know, went to 37 different schools before his eighth grade. When he finished eighth grade, he then quit school to help his family because his family had been swindled out of their family property and had to move.

He moved to a little town in San Jose called Salsipuedes, which means "leave if you can". He knew that the only way out of poverty was through education. It was hard work for the parents, but it was important for their children that they be given an opportunity for good education.

During his last period of fasting, he continued to be concerned about the injustices. He continued to be concerned about the suffering of the farm workers, the arrogance of the powerful. He saw the defeat in many of those who for so many years had been struggling with him. Permission to read.

This is what Cesar Chavez said after his last fast, and we know he never completely recovered from the last 36 years of his fasting. "I pray to God that this fast will be preparation for a multitude of simple deeds for justice. Carried out by men and women whose hearts are focused on the suffering of the poor, and who yearn with us for a better world.

Together all things are possible." HR 25 asks us to learn from Caesar Chavez's life. The mission of nonviolence, of social justice, and selfless service to others. Thank you and I respectfully ask for an aye vote.
Thank you Mr. Speaker. I'd urge an aye vote and ask that the first roll be opened for coauthors.

Thank you very much, Mr. Speaker and Members. Today I rise to present AB 413 which will help protect victims of domestic violence. California is a two-part permission recording state. We're only 1 of 11 in the country who doesn't allow victims of domestic violence to be able to record somebody's conversation without their permission if they are threatening them.

Thank you very much. I appreciate that my colleague from Big Bear's remarks. And I think this is just one more way that we can make the justice system support people who are trying to escape a violent situation, and I ask for your aye vote.

Thank you Mr Speaker, I rise in support of HR 18 and I want to commend my colleague for bringing this to the forefront. As a member of the California Legislative Black Caucus, as the chair of Public Safety, I understand now, probably more than ever, that love must trump hate.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Today I, excuse me, today I rise to adjourn in the memory of my close friend, Ray Richard Quinto, who passed away February 28th at the age of 77. Ray's list of accomplishments are nothing short of impressive. He had a distinguished military career, enlisting at the age of 17, serving 10 years of active duty with two tours in Vietnam as a combat medic, and I pause here to remind us that yesterday was Vietnam Veterans Day and I honor my friend, Ray, in addition for that. He also served 26 years in the Naval Reserve as a training, executive, and commanding officer.

He also spent an additional 26 years in the Veterans Administration Department of Medicine and Surgery, as Chief of Research Operations, and 17 years at the VA Medical Center in Loma Linda. Ray had a commitment to community as an active board member for various non-profits. Such as the American Red Cross, American Cancer Society, Kiwanis Club of San Bernardino. This commitment was recognized with a congressional Excalibur Award, the Citizen of the Year award by the League of Women Voters in San Bernardino. Along with his professional success and dedication to community service, his most prized accomplishment was his family. He shared the value family with all who knew him.

And his selfless and compassion for others was apparent in his interactions with family, friends and anyone who met him. He leaves behind his wife, Pat, the love of his life whom he married on Christmas Day 57 years ago, as well as his loving sisters, Leola and Vicky. His legacy will be carried on by his children Marlene, Christina, and Ray Jr., as well as his seven grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. We will all miss Ray's wisdom, his dry humor, his love for the community, but most especially, his love for his family. Thank you for the opportunity to adjourn in the memory of my friend, Ray Quinto.

billion debt in these funds as of 17-18 is that right? Okay, and how is that changed over time?

Okay, well at least for my colleagues, I guess let me give you my observation on this. I think it's relevant, especially today. Because a lot of people feel that we should be putting a lot more money into transportation infrastructure, and I don't disagree. But here we have a case where the voters approved money for transportation.

And in typical circumstances the general fund would pay off those obligations. But instead the administration and or the Legislature in their wisdom, has done the shuffle and have substituted general fund for the weight fees which would have gone directly into transportation.

And its this issue of maintenance of effort which is a big potential, big flaw in this proposal that was announced yesterday. Where we're going to provide money for transportation, for local regional state enterprises. And rather than going for transportation they can just be a back fill for existing spending. And thereby not really increasing the fund at all.

But actually creating a kitty that can be used for other purposes. So here we had a case where we thought we were creating new money for transportation, and instead we find that it really wasn't all new money because they were taking wait fees, so there was a reduction of money that would've gone for transportation.
They took it away. On one hand, they got something. On the other hand, they took it away. And this is very problematic in my point of view.
And it's reflected here in a very small way.
But it is in a broader context of the debate that's going on today and yesterday is relevant.

I want to thank the LAO for their study. Obviously, I haven't had a chance to read it all yet, even my speed reading while you're talking is a challenge. But I thank you and I think this is worthy of more discussion and I support the chair's observation that this is a significant policy issue. And while we always like to be efficient in our work, I would encourage us to have our Committee,

our appropriate Committee, look at this in more depth. In this study that you have completed, one of the things that always worries me is that we always seem to be a little bit behind in our elections processes in terms of responding to what the voters need and desire.
And the reluctance of counties to do anything different. And as my crystal ball says that I like 450. I like what it's trying to do, absolutely. I think it's a great step forward.

But my own crystal ball says that, at some point in the not to distant future, every voter is going to have an ID that's going to allow them to vote electronically. And that how we view voting today is going to be archaic, whether it's at a polling place or at a vote center or a vote by mail ballot, to have it be put in this thing called the mailbox.
And I wondered if you addressed that or looked at that issue at all in this report.
Got it, but it's not covered in here, I haven't missed in my speed reading.

Because one of the challenges that we have is, and we just heard a report on technology a few minutes ago. And the challenges of new technology and implementing new technology is that there's a big fear factor about change with new technology. The security, the implementation, all the things that come out of the implementation.

And I worry a little bit that without a state role there, hopefully smarter and better in figuring how it can work, that the counties are going to be very nervous about going there. Because of the investment, maybe the unproven nature of it, because it's new and different.

And that while the block grant may provide something in regards to something that's proven on how we know how a vote by mail works. It's not that complicated to think about how a vote center will work but with a voter ID and with that kind of technology involved, I wonder and I worry about it, that's all.

That's our state goal. Counties may be interested in cost issues, we'd like them to share our goal about getting as many people to vote as possible. But we've seen how reluctant they have been to adopt the whole vote by mail process when that's actually an efficiency. And yet, because it's change, they've been reluctant to push vote by mail.

Look at LA County as a good example of that. They're way behind the state in participation on VBMs. Yet, it's been clear that it's actual an efficiency if we could get everybody do it. So, there is a slow adoption problem out there.
But once again I, thank you for this report and I support the chair's recommendation that we get our Committee actively involved in this question.
Hello again, Dorothy Johnson with CSAC.

Again, also with my cursory review of the LOA's report, want to thank them for putting forward the suggestion. I will say again as a preliminary comment, sometimes block grants only help those counties that already sort of have the means to implement the end goals of the program or the requirements. And unfortunately that may not achieve the overall goal of creating more consistency in voting practices and equipment throughout the state.
So just want to add that, but we are encouraged, I do agree with many of the good points raised by the LAO in their study. Thank you.

And that we must guide our communities with peace, compassion, and a heightened sense of cultural unity. For many of us, when we protest, we really don't understand the importance of non-violence and we should understand that more now that any time before.

Because when you have to stand there, in your own self, against people putting fire hoses on you, dogs on you, kicking you, cussing at you, screaming at you, and you hold your own for a cause, that's a real hero, and that's what's the true meaning of non-violence.
And I hope that we not only commemorate this time, but remember what we truly need to stand for, is to protest non-violently. Thank you.

Good morning Mr. Chair and Members of the Committee. First of all, I want to thank Senator Galgiani and the co-authors of this measure for bringing this measure forward. I want to thank the chair and the Committee staff, for all the work that they've done. And have all done a terrific job in trying to correct

the problems that was created last year by some legislation. And we are very, very thankful for that. I want to emphasize some of the points that Senator Galgiani made and that is, that the problems that were presented were in the context of entertainment memorabilia.

And yet the bill cut a much broader swath, taking in folks that were not contemplated. We did not represent the client group of seven auction companies then, and wished of course we'd had the opportunity to come before you then, and try to address those problems. But again, this Committee is doing a terrific job and the author, and looking to rectify those issues.

So, the bill really addresses and does not seek to undo the efforts made by last year's legislation to address entertainment collectibles, but rather to leave those provisions alone and move forward with excluding those items that are commonly sold by our client but that have not demonstrated any issue.

I also would like to point out, and that was again not part of last year's legislative record, but we want to ensure that it's this year's legislative record that as Senator Galgiani mentioned, there are not only general provisions in the civil and criminal code to address these kinds of issues. But that there is a specific statute addressing the auctioneer and auction companies,

and that was legislation authored by Assemblymember Tom Hannigan, back in the 90s. To our knowledge, there have been no issues by either consignors or by consumers or auction companies, for that matter, where that law has been found to to be ineffective in protecting consumers in that regard.

For the Committee's benefit, Allen Michaan, who is President of Auctions By the Bay, and who operates as Michaan's Auctions of Alameda, is here to address some of the problems that have been created by the legislation last year, so that it provides some greater context for the Committee.

Thank you Senator for bringing this bill to us. And I agree that the legislation that was enacted probably went too far. But I am still struggling with some of these issues. Principally on this issue of lack of evidence of any fraud.

I mean you guys are projecting that there's been no problems anywhere. Is that really the case? I think I've recalled paintings that have been forgeries, even in the Vatican. So I'm trying to reconcile.
I recognize that some of this older art, it's impossible, and that certainly seems totally unworkable.
But we are sensitive to consumer protections.

Senator that's a good question and if I can take a shot at responding. We'll stipulate that there is certainly, has been in the art world, fraud from time to time. The question is was it to the level of being rampant as it was presented on the entertainment collectibles, and is the existing statute that is in place or

the statutes that are in place sufficient to address those concerns? So some of the provisions in the Antique Act or excuse me, the Auctioneer's Act, requires for instance, that they place a bond with the Secretary of State. There are prescribed and prohibited acts that are laid out that deal

with how an auction company goes about advertising. What they may represent, what their duty is to the consigner in terms of paying them their money at the end of a specified time, how they can, when they have to deliver the goods to the customer, etc.

And so what we are asking for here is that Given that there is certainly are going to be occasions where there is art fraud out there, but that there are already both practical and contractual issues, and business practices that address that.
But that there are also statutory prescriptions and prohibitions that have successfully addressed this issue.
And then where there are issues, there is recision and there are ways of getting the customer's money back.
So does this legislation not apply to individuals that may be selling something privately?

It will not deal with a one off, but in other words to the extent that Senator Galgiani brought her issue up, if she were to want to sell a painting that she had and do it through an auction company, or she was in the business of selling these kinds of signed goods. Then she would be required to provide the certificate of authenticity and be subject to the penalties.
Under current law? If she was doing this as a private individual, she wanted to sell it to me. I got a great painting. Seen it, it's beautiful.

She would be able to do so outside the provisions. If however, she was selling this to a dealer, and a dealer was selling it on her behalf, or she was consigning it, to an auction house, and people go to an auction house because the auctioneer has an audience of people who are interested in them.
I understand that, but to be clear, what you're doing here doesn't apply to an individual. The law that was put into affect-
And nor does your bill 579 apply to an individual.
Great, and one final question if I may Mr. Chair.
Of course. Which is who enforces, I know you've asserted that there may be some problems but it's not a proliferation of fraud, who prosecutes this,
and who prosecutes this type of crime, civil prosecution or criminal prosecution?
There's a criminal prosecution, this would violate the penal code, so that would be number one, but there are also civil remedies.
And those civil remedies exist in the civil code but they also rest under the auctioneer's statute.
Okay, and do you have any kind of record of how many cases in either case have occurred in the last 10 years?
Okay. Anybody else have any kind of-

What I can do in terms of the auctioneer's statute is, so that we've run a LexisNexis, but I have not completed that search, so I have not been able to go through the cases. But I can tell you that it is not hundreds of cases,
but rather, a handful of cases that I've been able to identify, thus far.

All right, Mr. Chairman, I don't know if your staff has looked at that issue, and if there's anything to put on the record that they might have, any kind of proliferation of this problem that they've uncovered, it'd be good to have that.

Mr Chair if I may respond to Senator Glazer. Senator I have tried to frankly, disprove my theory that the problems are limited and we have searched as I've mentioned both in terms of FBI data, we have found none. We have looked through the news articles to see how

much of a problem this is in terms of news articles that would identify this. And as I mentioned to you previously, we've begun to look through LexisNexis. But we are not seeing a lot of hits coming back, in terms of that this is a widespread problem. I would not want to come before you and lose my credibility, and
say to you that there isn't a widespread problem, if in fact we had found something to the contrary.

One thing Senator Wilk let me say this, I'm not going to be familiar with this sport memorabilia. That's I'm just curious. But in the art world, there are If you're looking at European art there are guilds that have through the centuries become expert in

antiquities both signed and unsigned who are able to ascertain the age. Is the canvas of that time, is the oil of that time, is this the stroke of the artist, et cetera. There are also organizations in the United States who specialize in single artists. So there's an organization that just authenticates Calders and both paintings and mobiles.

And so there are organizations that do that, particularly when the item is a high end item. Both the buyer and the seller will hire their own representatives to make sure that they're. Consistent with each other in terms of that the artist and the value of that item.

Yes. Paul Woods Consumer Attorneys of California. This is a serious problem obviously. The Berkeley tragedy and the Folsom tragedies speak for themselves. Nationwide, 33,000 people have been, between 2003 and 2007, were injured in balcony and depth collapses. Initial inspections have proven to be not entirely effective in capturing these problems. The Berkeley problem was completely enclosed under a socket of the building, and wasn't detected until the balcony actually collapsed. More intensive inspections, more frequently done. As these projects age, we think it's extremely important and we support the bill. Thank you.

Great. Thank you, Mr. Chair. I'm pleased to present this bill which would streamline the handle allocation process by allowing but not requiring the California Department of food and ag to remit funds directly a fair conducting live racing or a JPA involved in live racing.

Under current law live racing fees are collected from fairs, remitted to the Department of Food and Ag and then deposited into the fairs and exposition fund through a time consuming administrative process. Food and Ag reappropriates those same funds back to the fairs. This process can be cumbersome and ultimately delay necessary funding for California fairgrounds.

The Food and Ag is expressing interest in using this money to support the fair racing circuit, but unfortunately lacks the clear statutory authority to do so. This bill provides that authority. It has no opposition.

Thank you, Madam Chairman and members. First of all, I'd like to thank the Committee staff for the thoughtful analysis and continuing work on this issue. California presently has eight veterans homes as was noted by the prior presenter. There are 2,600 beds for aging and disable veterans, these homes fall on the division of California Department of Veteran Affairs or Cal-Vet. AB 1365 would require Cal-Vet to submit their yearly financial reports regarding the veteran's homes, not only to the Legislature, but to post them online, as well.

Additionally, this bill requires Cal-Vet to review the use of these each of veterans home every five years after the initial 20 year period to determine how best to use the homes and their assets in the future. Last month, the Little Hoover Commission released it's report. A new approach to California's veterans homes, outlining the housing needs of our veterans and the needs to properly evaluate the present structure based on data gathered. The California veterans homes serves, these eight California veterans homes, serve about one tenth of 1% of our veterans yet, they represent 82% of the budget for Cal-Vet.

To review of data collected would allow for an informed decision about how best to serve our veterans. AD 1365 would add much needed transparency and flexibility in the pursuit of meeting the housing needs of our veterans by regularly making informed recommendations for each home, with added benefits to support more veterans in need. Here with me to testify on behalf of this bill is Carole D'Elia, the Executive Director of the Little Hoover Commission.

Actually so they work with us. I have to compliment how much time they spent with us sometimes when we're looking at an issue, we find hostel departments and they were absolutely the opposite. They worked with us, they sat down with the finance people with their budget people who helped us try to understand, and I think they appreciated knowing that we are people who do this, look at budgets and try to decipher things, and if we were finding it difficult, that this wasn't out of line to be asking.

When I had a conversation with Dr. Imbasciani, CalVet secretary he looked at it more in terms of, are there other models that I could look to, such as the State hospital's, the CBC are where they actually do kind of show you how much we're spending per facility and so i don't think they were opposed.

We looked at the different costs per level of care not individual veteran and it's really hard and that's again why we were advocating for more transparency because even though Yountville is a property that we have long paid for, the maintenance costs are outrageous. So even though we're not paying on debt service for the construction, we're paying to maintain a facility that is falling apart. Different homes have different staffing challenges, hiring the right people and they have different staffing levels so.

Our report does in the appendix show, this is what it cost per level of care but it's hard to say you know, is this one home more efficient than the others because there's so many different variables, and you have again, on the reimbursement side of things, and these are other areas that we address in the report that don't necessarily relate to this specific bill, but just in the way we charge veterans. So we looked at other states, we can't really be as efficient as other states because we have set up out military veterans code to charge veterans not the cost of care, but a certain percentage of their income.

And so as where another state may prioritize someone with a 70% or more service disability, which will bring in a lot more federal dollars, we don't do that, and again, that's not the nature of this bill but, I'm just trying to kind of give an idea of how hard it is to understand what the cost of carriers per facility, and we did do it on the level of care level, but we didn't do it in the sense of this one is more efficient than that one.

There's 2,600 and 10 beds that are authorized via the budget, but we serve more than that because over the course of the year some passed on, some moved out and so we're serving more than that number, but that's the number of beds that are authorized.
I know it's not a question, but the average is about 117,000 per veteran that is being spent.

With the opioid epidemic and the eve of Prop 64 funding coming in, the need to expand capacity has never been greater, and the per bed license fee and the overall license fees are dampening on the ability to create capacity particularly in counties that haven't opted into the waiver or are rural in nature.

We'd also like to know how much of the total amount in the Roth fund is spent on enforcement and if there's any way that fines and penalties could be looked at so that the bad apples in the system can contribute more to that licensing fund rather than spreading that increase for staff amongst the good programs.

Addiction treatment comes in all different sizes and shapes in California. We have little mom and pop places that are safety net in many counties that are six bed and under, and really these types of 110% increases in licensing fees directly impacts their capacity.

We'd also like to explore the idea of perhaps making a longer licensing cycle for the good apples who have no or little infractions on their site visits. Maybe stretch theirs out to three years, four years so that the cost to staff is less and the cost to the licensees is less. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. Chairman, Keith Dunn on behalf of the California Apartment Association asking for your support.

Hello, my name is Susan Little. I'm with the Environmental Working Group and the Environmental Working Group is a sponsor, excuse me, the Environmental Working Group is a sponsor of AB 1316, primarily because it allows California to follow the lead of 10 other states and require universal lead testing of children. We've heard of a lot about the effects of lead exposure and lead poisoning, but I wanted to emphasize at just some very recent studies that came out, reiterate that, not only does it cause damage to children, but the children who are exposed to lead when they're young Then showed that the demonstrable decline socio-economically in terms of their IQ when later in adulthood.

Those effects continue with them for many decades. In addition, we also found that studies have also shown that lead does its damage very early and fast. Nearly 73% of lead is absorbed into a child's bones within the first three weeks, first several weeks of exposure, and its appearing that that's really sticking with them. So in order to safeguard our kids we need to be sure that we're addressing their lead exposures early before the materials lasting effects take hold and the data is not clear but it appears that only a small minority of California's children are screened for lead.

One report sited in the analysis indicates that only 5% of the children overall in California are screened. The truth is, is that we really don't know how well we're identifying the kids who are lead compromised, and we don't really know where the lead is exactly. A recent reuters study found that an at least 29 California neighborhoods children, had elevated lead rates of at least just high as that in Flint, Michigan, and one of the zip codes analyzed had nearly three times that rate. Other states do much more to protect their children from lead than does California.

As I mentioned, 10 other states and the district of Colombia, require universal lead screening of children. These states have a much better chance of identifying kids who elevated lead levels. We'd like California to join the movement to providing lead screen to all of it's children and we urge your support for this measure, thank you.

All right. Thank you, Mr. Chair and Members of the Committee. Before I begin, I want to note that I accept the committee's proposed amendments, and I appreciate Committee staff for it's thoughtfulness, thoughtful analysis of this bill. AB 700 establishes a uniform career ladder that recognizes higher levels of education for substance abuse disorder counseling, including classifications for counselor's certification.

Substance use disorders, or SUDS for short, are complex problem with biological, behavioral, and social dimensions, and there are an estimated 2.5 million persons with diagnosable SUDS receiving treatment throughout California alone. The State Department of Health Services indirectly oversees certified SUD counselors through it's oversight of three certifying organizations.

These or these organizations has its own level of education experience required for its certification. The problem here is that there are no state uniform standards for counselor certification. AB 700 seeks to address this matter by establishing a uniform career ladder for counselor certification that recognizes higher levels of education for substance use disorder counseling to be maintained by the Department of Healthcare Services.

Such uniformity would not only protect the public from confusing and inconsistent career ladder but also would ensure that California meets the evidence based national standards for SUD counselor certifications. I respectfully ask for your aye vote. Testifying on behalf of the sponsor, the California Association of Alcoholic Drug Educators, is Lowrie Phelps, the Organization's Executive Director, and Ben Salazar as President of the Board of Directors.
I respectfully request ask for your aye vote.
As amended.

Mr. Chair. Nick Brokaw, here on behalf of California Academy of Audiology, in support. We thank the Assemblywoman for her leadership and commend her for her efforts to modernize the program. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. Chair and members. Nick Louizos on behalf of the California Association of Health Plans, regrettably in opposition to Assembly Bill 595. Let me start by saying that we do appreciate the sentiment that a healthy competition is good for consumers. California's market is both competitive and healthy.

Our association for instance represents 49 health plans covering 28 million lives in all lines of business. With 23, excuse me, with 2.3 million enrollees including 1.4 million enrollees in Covered California, our state's individual market offers competition and choice. With 11 health plans participating in the exchange, consumers can easily shop for coverage and compare prices.

Our issue with this bill isn't whether public authorities have some role in mergers and acquisitions. Indeed, they already have a role. In fact, in approving recent transactions, the DMHC has required extensive undertakings on the parties involved, including my member health plans.

Our opposition then is based primarily on the vast scope of the bill and what we view as a vague and broad standards that plans and regulators would have to meet in order to obtain prior approval from a state regulator for transactions. As currently drafted, Assembly Bill 595 discourages reasonable new investments in health care that are intended to create efficiencies in economies of scale.

From our read of the bill, even a relatively basic consolidation or transfer of assets within the same corporate family could trigger prior approval from state regulators and hold back innovative investments. We believe that this is an intensive amount of work for relatively little value. AB 595 also institutes unreasonably high hurdles for mergers and acquisitions.

As only one example, the measure expressly requires that regulators find in fact, that a merger proposal itself will lower prices before the merger or acquisition can be approved. Which consumer prices? Prices that doctors charge health plans, prices that hospital systems charge health plans, prices that drug companies charge health plans, or are we talking about premiums?

If we're talking about premiums or other prices, the language fails to take into account the reality of the health care market. It fails to take into account potential increases in utilization, provider rates, government mandates, rising drug costs. All of these things together impact consumer prices in a short and long-term.

So we believe that codifying unreasonable standards will make conditional approvals under this bill inevitable, thus placing the plans that are contracted provider groups and consumers and limbo. And actually, the conditional approval provisions in this bill are treated in a somewhat interesting way in one section of the bill. The regulator must take, make a series of findings that, again, from our perspective, we view as unrealistic in order to approve or conditionally approve a transaction.

And in another section of the bill, conditional approvals are only allowed if the parties of the transaction agreed to prevent, not mitigate, but prevent things from happening that may or may not happen. So we have a question of how that sequence would unfold. Okay, my time's almost up.

I just want to say that we appreciate the author's amendments which resolve one issue, but again, the bill applies to vast, vast majority of the market. And if there is a demonstrated issue with the merger, we are willing to have a discussion. A version of this bill was purposed last year in the Senate when a series of planning, carry of mergers were being proposed.

Some of those mergers were blessed by public authorities, other mergers were not. So I bring that up because we do have a process in place that allows some to go forward and some not to go forward. And unless, it's a demonstrated problem that we are missing, we relatively, respectfully, believe that no action is required at this time. No further action. Thank you.

Thank you for that question, Assemblymember. Obviously, the amendments that were offered yesterday are being reviewed by our membership. As of today, we're straight opposed to the bill. I think you have to pass the test first of whether we think action is required in this area.

And we would argue that number one, the DMHC already has authority in this area. When a plan wants to merge, consolidate, etc, it's considered the material modification of their license. So the Department of Managed Health Care already has authority in this area as a modification to the license to review and take action in this area.

Number two, federal authorities sometimes get involved in these actions. The Department of Justice has weighed in on a couple of mergers, and those are on hold right now. So at this time, we fail to see what further action is required in this area especially considering since California has a relatively healthy and competitive market.

Mr. Chair and members, Steve Carlson for California Government Affairs Council for CTIA Trade Association for the wireless communications industry. Wireless technology has revolutionized how we communicate as Senator Hueso has indicated, yet even as these new uses of wireless technology or innovate and adopted. There has been an unprecedented growth in mobile data usage which has grown over 2,300% since 2010. There are 1.5 million more wireless devices than there are people in California people love and depend on the networks.

To commit these demand carriers have been investing billions of dollars since 2010, 177 billion In 2015 alone more than 32 billion nationally on their networks. However, the advancement can't come first enough for today's data driven consumers. So we're working to enhance infrastructure to maximize the performance of today's fourth generation wireless and prepare for the next generation of connectivity as Senator Hueso indicated 5G. Small cells will strengthen, existing 4G networks while serving as the building blocks for 5G.

They are as so much else in technology is, far faster, smaller and better than the technology that has preceded, the infrastructure that has preceded them, but for California to maintain it's position as the high tech leader of the nation, it is critically important that policy makers take action to remove unnecessarily obstruct barriers to innovation investment while balancing municipal interest, we believe 649 does that, and in finding that balance, we ask that you consider the compelling public benefit Californians will receive from 5G, including improved public safety services, like next-generation 911, immersive education, traffic management systems, tele-medicine, just to name a few.

We're also complete a comprehensive poll on the issue, and the data has been very clear that most Californian's agree the vast majority want 5G, believe it is important to invest in 5G and support streamlining the process to improve wireless communications. The consulting firm Accenture did a report this year and showed that 5G deployment will drive $500 billion of economic growth, create 3 million jobs and produce 160 billion in benefits and savings. Through smart community solutions, lowered energy use, reduced traffic congestion, and fuel cost and improved public safety.

Specific to California communities, the economic benefits of 5G over the next several years will, in large cities like LA, create nearly 37,000 jobs and an increase GDP of approximately 6 billion, but it doesn't only apply to large cities. It will also benefit small and rural areas of the state for example the economic benefit to Sonoma County is projected be more than 4,600 jobs and GDP increase of $765 million.

The stunning gains of 5G technology will be headed a fraction of the public cost to previous infrastructure investments. Unlike other infrastructure projects like the interstate highway system and others, this one will cost taxpayers next to nothing and will be almost completely paid for by private investment. Carriers as you will hear the other witnesses talk about need a uniform and certainty way of proceeding without interfering with the community's legitimate interest to protect their communities. Yeah, good morning. Susan Riggs with the ASPCA, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Setting aside, for a moment, the predatory nature of this lending practice, we're really concerned that dogs and cats are being treated like.

Automobiles that can be repossessed and parked somewhere. The lending company is not in the business of taking care of these animals. They need constant care, not to mention the love of the family that they had been living with. So we're really concerned about that.

And I want to mention, there's an issue that's been raised that somehow banning this practice would limit the ability of folks with little or no credit available to them to have a purebred dog, but that's absolutely not true. There are multiple, multiple rescue groups that are very specific

to pure bred dogs where a person, if they really want a pure bred dog, can go and get that dog. And certainly from the ASPCAs perspective we would prefer the dog be rescued rather than to get a pure bred dog and have it turned over to a shelter.
So thank you very much.

Yeah, so the contract explicitly says in the case of default that the lending company will repossess the animal. The reality is that the value of a dog or cat when it is purchased from a pet store when it's two months old is very different than a dog or cat that is a year old. And so, the value actually declines during that period of time.

And so, the ability to resell that animal is very, very limited at that point and obviously the lending company, again, is not in the position to take care of and be responsible for an animal. That's just not their business practice, obviously. And so the alternatives for them in the market are pretty limited, unless they want to start their own kennel, so.
Yeah, if you don't mind.

From our perspective, the rationale for prohibiting it altogether is that it's wholly unnecessary. There are alternatives in the market and this particular alternative, it's predatory in nature, it really preys upon a certain demographic. It is anti-consumer protection. So we want to prohibit it for that purpose.

And there are other structures available to give for families that want to have a dog but don't otherwise have access to credit to get a dog or a cat. And so, we just feel like it's wholly unnecessary to open up this realm that is detrimental across the board to consumers, to households, and to the pet.

And then, that dangerous situation is not hidden behind a settlement agreement unnecessarily, especially when that. Dangerous situation has a likelihood of repeating. So what we're talking about is dangers that pose a public, We're talking about public policy to be able to disclose information that will help the next litigant, or the next person who is injured.

Okay, when the protective order is done, at what point is it, you talk about the affected persons who can then request the information that is the subject of that protective order, at what point is that done? Because, if there is a lawsuit filed, and initially the plaintiff doesn't have the name,

the correct name of the tire manufacturer, for instance. And the title of the case is Mark Stone versus Eloise Reyes, but does not include the rest of the defendants, how is it that the next person will then know this is a case about a defect in a tire,
to be able to find that information, and then ask that it be disclosed?

to then make the determination whether it's something that should be disclosed?
So the next plaintiff who's injured, how would they find this information?
And my question is, the next person who is injured by that defective product, how do they know to ask the question, where is this information lodged?

Sure, good morning Chairman, Senator and Members of the Committee. My name is Daniel Mclaughlin, I'm the founder of the One Purpose School which is an elementary school in San Francisco's highest crime neighborhood, Bay View's Hunter Point. We are trauma central.

Last year we had three lockdowns from gunshots directly across the street. We've had stabbings on our front steps. We call Child Protective Services all too frequently. 94% of our students are qualified for a free or reduced lunch.

55% are African American. 40% are Latino. Our students are not statistically supposed to succeed and they're certainly not supposed to do what we want them to do, which is to go to and graduate from college.

And we get ahead of potential problems with our students with an integrated multi-tiered early invention approach that includes early socio-emotional assessments, comprehensive socio-emotional curriculum, and tight relationships among teachers, providers, and critically, on and off site mental health providers.

The result of our work is that we didn't counsel out or expel one kid last year, and we haven't expelled or counseled out one kid this year. 80% of our kindergartners read at grade level last year, 80%. This is the sixth school that I've founded since 2001 serving low income kids of color. I'm absolutely positive that the multi-tiered approach that we use is what allowed us to get these amazing results for our kids.

The challenge that we had was the huge amount of effort required to coordinate with various service providers and I think that the bill will make this substantially easier, allowing us to serve more kids more efficiently. So I want to thank you for your role in supporting the bill, and I'm happy to answer any questions the Committee might have.

Thank you, Mr. Vice Chair and members. Mike Bellot on behalf of the Professional Beauty Association. Senator Bradford has articulated the need for the bill. The legal distinctions between peace rate and commissions are complicated. And are getting more complicated as we move along in terms of case law.

Commissioned people were typically in salons. To me, the basic distinction between piece rate and commission is the piece rate worker is paid for producing the piece. They don't have client contact, they're not sales people. The classics are perhaps people in agriculture, people in auto technicians that sort of thing.

The salon stylist is a sales person as much as a stylist. They are selling their business, and best evidence of that is when they move typically the people move with them to the new salon. There were classically paid by Commission, but when the piece rate decision came out,

there were legal distinctions that were complicated. All this does is clarifies that a Commissioner arrangement is acceptable along the standards that the Senator articulated. It was negotiated precisely with stakeholders, especially our friends in labor and the plaintiff's bar, for which we are quite appreciative. We would ask for an aye vote.
