to transparency of charter schools is vital to ensuring tax payer money is being used to the benefit of the students and not to enrich school administrative staff. Every school in California that receives public funding needs to be held to the same standards of accountability for the best interests of our children's education.

AB 1478 will help address this issue and restore public trust by ensuring that charter schools must comply with the same open meeting. Public records disclosure and conflict of interest laws that govern all other public schools and school districts.

These laws are the Robert M Brown Act, the Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act, the California Preparatory Fact and the Political Reform Act of 1974. In my district, which is why I'm involved in this so deeply is, I have the Miramonte School which had some sexual problems where a teacher was molesting kids.

In addition, I have the solarity school in my district, where administrators are paid over $400,000 to administer the school. So, for me it's a personal thing, but it's also something that's happening within my district. And I think accountability would've been very important to ensure that in addition after talking to both Charter and CTA about this bill.

It became very clear that both entities, and I repeat both entities believe in transparency, accountability. But like many things when you're having a debate on the how, it can sometimes be very difficult. And as I've told both entities, when I went through a very difficult divorce where we were just screaming at one another.

My ex-wife and I talking about which schools I should send my kids school to, we kind of look to the side and realize our kids were crying because we were hurting them more. Even though our goal was to get them into a good public school or into a good private school, even though that discussion puts forth the benefit, because we were fighting and arguing we were making their life a living hell.

And so, I plan and I wish I could, because the way these meetings are set up we can't have CTA here. We can't have the charter on the other side and even the governor's office who has done some things where he's vetoed some of these bills. I'm in conversation with all three, so that ultimately, because this body has been favorable to this before,

that we get this to a point where we finally get it signed by the Governor. And as you hear from the testimony today, I think you will hear that everyone on all sides of this issue and including conversations I've had directly with the Governor about how we can get this done. You will see that if we all work together, we will ultimately do that.

I believe if we had a different format of support versus opposition, if we had a format of support as amended, we could have all three entities talking about this, so could further make that happen. So with me here today to testify and support is Seth Bramble, from the California Teachers Association, and I respectfully ask for your aye vote. Thank you.

Mr Chair and members, Seth Bramble here on behalf of more than 325,000 members of the California Teachers Association. We now represent actually more than 7,000 charter school educators in the State of California, and we're proud to co sponsor this important proposal. Charter schools are public schools that were established with a promise.

We will give you the freedom to innovate and you will show us some results. Like light houses they were placed, where maybe we can do something a little bit different. And we might learn something that we could apply across the entire system of public education.

I was excited to hear several years ago from the Division Director at Oakland Unified about a system that he called knowledge transfer. This was their charter school's division where the principals in charter schools and the principals at traditional public schools would come together.

And they would share best practices. That's what was intended here, lessons Learned. But the people cannot learn from this innovation if the people's business is conducted in private. The establishment of charter schools was not us, the public, yielding control to the agencies that serve us. To the contrary, we insist on retaining control. And on staying informed.

Having secret and private meetings about how tax dollars are being spent is not innovation. It does not benefit the system and in fact, it has resulted in a number of horror stories which I'd be happy to share with you, if you want to hear some of the details.

The bottom line here is what this bill is saying the charter schools is do what you want, but do it out in the open where everyone can see. Truly what this bill is saying is dream big and think outside the box. But don't abuse the public trust and spend that money on our students, spend that money on our kids, we urge your support.
Somebody else is pushing the button at the same time I'm trying to push it.

Mr. Chair and members, Rand Martin on behalf of the California Charter Schools Association. So there are three points I'd like to make this, is it evening yet? Number one is there are four laws that we're talking about in this bill.
Three of which the California Charter Schools Association supports.
We support the Brown Act or Bagley-Keene, depending on your structure. We support the California Public Records Act, we support the California Political Reform Act and
make no mistake that the Political Reform Act is the central conflict of interest law in this state.
The other laws that we talk about are not the core conflict of interest laws the PRA is and we support it and we think it should apply to charter schools.
The piece that we get stuck on is Government Code 1090.
I want to point out something that the consultant wrote in the analysis today, which is really compelling, I think, to our argument.
She talks about why Government Code 1090 was created.
And says, mindful of the adage that no man can serve two masters. The section was enacted to ensure that public officials making official contracts not be distracted by
personal financial gain from exercising absolute loyalty and undivided allegiance to the best interest of the entity which they serve.
If you are a board member on a non-profit charter school board,
and you're there to serve the best interests of that board. And part of serving that best interest is perhaps being able to arrange a low or no interest loan.
Or being able to lease a facility that you own for a dollar a year.
That's serving the best interest of that entity. And to take that right away from them by imposing Government Code 1090 is
a direct contrast to what 1090 was intended to create in the first place.
Yes, it works when you're talking about a City Council member or a school district board member.
The person on a City Council should not be in any kind of financial relationship with a city on who's board they've been elected to.
But when you're on a non-profit board, and many of you, I'm sure, have been on non-profit boards, you know what's required of you, expected of you.
It's not just to go out and raise money, it's also to make sure that you do whatever you can as a board member to keep the doors of that facility open.
When you, not you personally, but when the Legislature and the Governor deferred payments to schools and school districts during the worst of the recession.
School districts were able to go out and get bridge loans at 2 and 3%. We were able to get bridge loans at 14 and 15 and 16%.
If we were stuck with that as our only alternative, we would have been shutting doors right and left across the state.
But we had board members who were willing to step up and do for that school what needed to be done. We should be applauding that. We should not be taking that right away from them.
And that's exactly what 1090 does.

The other three laws, absolutely let's put them in place, we agree, we like them we think they are appropriate. But let's not harm charter schools by taking away their ability of board members to do what they need to do. The last point I want to leave you with is a political one.
As Mr. Jones-Sawyer indicated, the Governor has vetoed this bill.
On three occasions, this bill has been vetoed, with 1090 in it.

Now I'm not going to say the governor's going to veto it again, but if past is prologue, there's probably a good chance that he would veto this bill. If you and we, and Mr. Jones- Sawyer want to get this accomplished,
let's get it accomplished with three of the laws that are the most important laws to protect the public interest, and the school's interest.
So we encourage you to not move this bill forward with 1090. We do have another version, you'll hear, we expect eventually, coming from the Senate that deals with exactly these issues.
But does not take away the ability of our board members to serve the best interests and their loyalties to the charter schools.
We urge your opposition to this bill today, thank you.
I can't speak on what has happened in the past. What I can tell you right now, I've had direct conversations with the vetoer.
I can't tell you more because we're going to try to get to a path where he will feel comfortable to sign.
In collaboration with both CTA and charter that we're all talking about it so we all can get to a yes.
I know you know it's always hard to try to get everybody to a yes but I think we can.
Mr. Kiley this is what I would say. If we, on our side, the green carpet side works out a solution, it will all come together.
I believe that I need to work with everyone. I used to work for a rich, white Republican mayor who gave millions of dollars in computers to Los Angeles City Schools.
I would not want to prevent Dickerin from ever giving computers, who is also someone that supports charters.

If someone has land that they want to give, not just for a dollar year but for free, we need to work out some language to protect them. Because we should not stop anyone whether you want to give it to charter school or to public school, we should work very hard to ensure that.
Some of these can be easily done by maybe even just creating a corporate board that is not involved in the day to day.
So those are the kind of discussions we need to have about how we can get beyond this,
this 1090, or even the 1091.
Which kind of allows that a sibling or someone can go ahead in
the official capacity work, but let their other business work. But I don't want to give Donald Trump and his family an opportunity to do what they're doing right now, so I don't want to discuss that.
I'm want to stay with 1090, which is how we ensure that individuals who do not follow the proper protocol or

financially benefit from this, how do we make sure that doesn't happen? The things that happen with Solarity If this bill, as Mr. Gloria had been enacted, it probably wouldn't have happened. That's why we needed to get this done sooner than later.

Mr. Kiley, that's part of the negotiating process. I'm not going to say anything right now because we all need to get in the room and talk about it and not put a stake in the ground right now which could compromise the entire negotiation.
Like you said, I'm just working on the bill before me which is about charter schools.
I see. Mr. Chair, may I respond to his question as well?
Quickly, so your point is well taken. What happens now is that school districts will arrange with charter schools to impose additional laws through a memorandum of understanding.
That would continue to happen.

This would only occupy the three or four provisions that are in the law. Anything beyond that they would be able to continue. So they would be able to do something beyond what the Legislature has decided.
In this bill.
Mr Thurmond, if we ever debate this again, I will come up with some new stories to tell you.
We totally agree but we need to get there, without at the same time taking away the ability of board members to do good for the charter school.

So the corporation's code was brought up in the testimony in support of the bill earlier. And the corporations code was I believe not accurately characterized as for corporations only. It's actually to protect the public interest because non profits are there for the public interest.
They're not for profit corporations that are making money, they are there to protect the public interest,
and so there are all sort of laws written into the corporations code for non profits,
that limit what you can do in terms of self dealing transactions.

And it goes right to the heart of making sure that board members cannot become rich on the back of a nonprofit, and a lot of that nonprofits are living off of public funds just like charter schools are.
And so the need to protect the public interest and be,
responsible fiscal stewards of public dollars cuts across beyond charter schools. So we think there are lot of ways to do this without ripping away the entire
ability of a board member, to provide this kind of financial protection for a charter school.
Mr Chair, if I may having a financial interest does not mean it's self dealing transaction,
does not mean that you're having a financial interest that makes you rich off of the back of the non-profit.

It may mean that you have some kind of a contract it may mean you're an employee of that organization. It does not mean that you're pleasing that organization or that you're making a lot of money at the back of that organization.
There's the provisions on self dealing transactions have a lot of limitations on
the process you have to go through in order to have that kind of transaction approve by the board. Same kinds of limitations that are in 1090,
except that 1090 is an absolute prohibition and you cannot be on the board.
You can recuse yourself, you are not supposed to be engaged with your other board members in trying to negotiate a contract that might have some, that you might have some involvement with.
You have to recuse yourself from that vote.

And it has to be, and this is stated in the law, it has to be in furtherance of the best interest of the organization on whose board you sit. That 49% is, with all due respect, is not the core issue when we're talking about
the effect of the corporations code, on protecting against self dealing.
I respectfully ask for your aye votes, so that I can get to the work of fixing this problem.
Thank you, Susan Little with the Environmental Working Group in support. Thank you.
Randy Pollock on behalf of the Water Quality Association and the Pacific Water Quality Association in support.
Thank you, Mr. Chair and members. I would like to to start off by thanking the Committee staff for their work on this bill and accepting the amendments shared in the mock up.

By creating the Bilingual Teacher Professional Development program. This program seeks to accomplish two goals, increase the number of bilingual authorized teachers in California and to upgrade the skills of already authorized bilingual teachers who wish to return to bilingual settings. In November of 2016, Proposition 58 was approved by nearly 75% of the voters, indicating an immense support of multilingual approaches in California public schools. The passage of the Proposition offers a unique opportunity to provide dynamic programs for English and non-English speakers alike spurring more bilingual and immersion programs throughout the state.

While the growth in this sector of education is clear, California is dealing with a growing issue of a teacher shortage. This is true especially when it comes to those who are authorized to teach in bilingual classrooms. The Commission on Teacher Credentialing has noted the the decline in the number of bilingual authorizations, declining from 2,100 almost 2,200 in the year 2003, 2004, to 733 in the school year 2013, 14. This is occurring as our state's classrooms continue to become more diverse. AB 952 is an important step not only to address the state's teacher shortage, but also offers a tool to train our teacher workforce to fully take advantage of newly found flexibility under Proposition 58.
Here to testify on behalf of the bill are Dr. Karen Kadiero-Kaplan with the California Association of Bilingual Education, and Martha Sarragoza-Diaz with California Together.

Good afternoon, Mr. Chairperson and members. My name is Martha Sarragoza-Diaz and I'm representing Californians Together. As Assemblywomen Reyes indicated, AB 952 is addressing the issue regarding California's currently bilingual education teachers shortage. We are proposing to do this through the development of a bilingual teacher professional development program. We believe that high quality professional development will yield an increased number of bilingual teachers in a Shorter period compared to the four, five years of a traditional teacher preparation program.

Because this program, the professional development program, would be targeted to two types of persons, those who are fluent in another language other that English who already possess a teacher credential and who's interested in teaching in a bilingual program, and persons who already have bilingual authorizations, but may have only taught in English only classrooms, but who are also interested in teaching in a bilingual classroom. Also, AB 952 assures high quality professional development because it calls for the development of standards for this program.

Additionally, AB 952 provides criteria that must be meet by a consortia who is interested and providing the professional development. A consortium would be comprised of the eligible entities that have been identified in the bill, which would include a school district, the County Office of Ed and IHE, a professional or non-profit organization with an expertise in English learners, or community colleges. Lastly, we recognize that this may not be the only approach in increasing the number of bilingual teachers, and therefore, we are asking CTC to take a look at other pathways to increase bilingual teachers, such as looking at what it would take to develop a career ladder for a bilingual ECE pair of professionals.

Or look at developing a career ladder for students who have obtained state seals of biliteracy and may be interested in seeking a bilingual authorization, a teacher credential plus the bilingual authorization.
Yes, we believe that this is a very realistic and practical approach.
Because the LCFF goes for professional development in general, this would be targeted for bilingual individuals seeking and wishing to teach in bilingual programs.

Although the Local Control Funding Formula does make concentration and supplemental grants for English language learners, this does not directly address issues with a number of bi-lingual authorized teachers, in the State of California. In order to best use the resources at our disposal, it is critical that we have trained instructors, who can best utilize the resources. In addition, this bill is not just for students that do not speak Englis, but it is also for students, for all students, as many immersion programs throughout the State of California are used by students.
And it does help all students even those who are in English primary households.
I respectfully ask for aye vote.

I'm going to be so fast. Mr Chair and members, my name is Seth Bramble, I'm here on behalf of the California Teachers Association. We are co-sponsoring Assembly Bill 699 to protect our students. As educators we do care deeply about the well-being of the students in our schools, in our colleges, throughout the state.

Bottom line here is teachers, yard duty, supervisors, other school staff, we don't want to put them in a position where they have to make a decision that might interfere with immigration's customs enforcement agents, because they feel this responsibility to protect the students. So, that's what we're talking about here.

that reflect and embrace the diversity of our students of their families. And also the rich language and cultural assets they bring to our communities. Not only do you urge your support but I did bring with me a speech language pathologist from Southern California who has a very brief story about an incident that occurred at her school session.

We too support the common services made. But from a process issue, planners are the ones that implementing and processing these permits. And as the way the bill is written currently there's a lot of language in the bill that Isn't workable for us. There are terms in the bill that don't translate into the planning world.

And so, moving forward, we need to make sure that if we are asked to now process these ministerially which we are opposed to doing, but as the bill is written doing that we need to make sure that the terms as such as only requiring one single administrative permit, what does that mean?

They've solicited comments for streamlining the process of 5G. I don't know if, to us it seems that the timing of the bill is unnecessary. Can we wait to see what is put forward at the FCC level rather than going ahead and doing something specific in California? The other issue is that, we understand that the technology is new and it's just being deployed.

It's not in every jurisdiction yet. They haven't been to every jurisdiction. So it seems to us that the bill attempts almost to solve a problem that doesn't largely exist. And rather than anticipate the potential problems through legislation, we would suggest, and we can discuss this more, but we would suggest that we ask OPR to put forward

streamlining processes, such as a model ordinance and guiding principles that planners can use to help streamline this process. We want to streamline it too. We want to be able to provide certainty to the carrier and we need certainty from the carrier as well. And so I think being able to look at it in other ways

where we can all come to the table and all find a solution that works for everybody is something that we're open to, but we aren't open to completely taking away on any authority of local governments to be able to work with carriers on this issue.
So, we can't help but wonder, like the comment was made, who will be next?

As we gather for the final day before we take leave, let us bow our heads and join in prayer. Lord you have blessed us beyond measure and granted us an opportunity to be the voice of many. I pray that you will guide us along your path so that our collective sacrifices can become the freedom for others.

In our quest for equality, remind us of the cry for equity. Help us to search for the best in others as we play for their success, their joy, and their celebration. And as we take leave we pray for traveling mercies for all and a renewed spirit on our return, Amen.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Assembly Bill 493 strives to ensure the protection of undocumented immigrants when they seek to cooperate with law enforcement on any crime. Currently such individuals are only protected when reporting or assisting law enforcement with investigation related to hate crimes. This bill merely expands protection for hate crimes, to any and all crimes, and thereby promotes social responsibility for everyone residing in our state. AB 493 supports open cooperation with all individuals with law enforcement, an important component to our state's public safety. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Austyolophus, whatever, which is housed in a Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History. I am proud to say that it is there and it's there for all Californians and all members here to come to my district and view what it actually looks like and what it does. Thank you.

There's no question that our roads need to be repaired. There's no question about that. We can't just sit here and do nothing. We can't sit here and point fingers.

We can't sit here and say we've already paid the repairman. To use the metaphor used earlier about the leaky roof, the roof is still leaking. And if we simply say we already paid, just because we want to blame somebody else, resolves nothing.

The roof is still leaking. It is now causing problems to the carpeting. Whatever damage there was before is still there. And in addition to having to fix the roof, you're now having to fix the inside.
Take out the carpet and take care of everything else inside. The roads are still in disrepair, they have to be repaired.
We've got to do it now, the longer we wait, the more it's going to cost us.
We must take care of this now, and I urge an aye vote.
It was a comment.

I just first want to say that I appreciate the Director's comments about the delayed implementation of AB 1863, which we worked on for the last several years, and Dr. Wood was our champion on that issue. I think we could probably debate how many clinics might take advantage of adding an MFT as a billable provider.

As our health centers would say, in layman terms, to open up a rate, and to change their scope to their rate is a big deal. So we would probably argue that it wouldn't be as many clinics, it wouldn't be a thousand for sure.
But again, we appreciate, we do hear those concerns. We still are opposed to the delayed implementation of AB 1863, the need is out there.

The initial implementation date in AB 1863 was January 1, 2017. So unfortunately, we do have clinics in a position where they, in anticipation of that implementation date, have went out and hired MFTs

and now, they're kind of stuck. We can also argue about whether or not that was the right thing for them to do. But they see the need, they have the patient population that need those services, so they've gone out and done that. So all that being said, we also recognize that the Department is trying to play a balancing game here.

They have a, you know, a tough task, so we would, at this time, urge that this body adopt the staff recommendation to adopt the modified trailer bill language to make clear that it is a no sooner and no later than date,

not just a no sooner than date, which we believe, as currently drafted, is open ended. So we appreciate this Committee and the staff's time on this issue. It's an important issue for our members. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President and members. I'd like to ask the Senate to adjourn in memory of Joseph Ovick, a long time and beloved educator in the East Bay, who died suddenly last week. He was a true giant in the East Bay education community, Joe worked to improve schooling for our children for 45 years.

He served for nearly two decades as Superintendent of Contra Costa County Schools, his legacy running much deeper than the many honors and awards he won over those years. After first being appointed to the Contra Costa County's top education post, Joe was elected and re-elected four times, a testament to his good work and popular standing.

He won the hearts and minds of generations of students, parents, and staff, a true champion of our public schools. Joe was one of those rock solid community leaders whom people looked to for guidance and inspiration. Fittingly, his hometown, Brentwood, named a school after him.

Karen Sakata, the current Contra Costa County Superintendent of Schools, said this about Joe. Quote, "he was down to earth, warm and sincere, and he truly cared about public education and kids, and kids always came first. Every decision he made was what was best for the students of Contra Costa County," end quote.

Joe started out as a substitute teacher, teaching at a school for severely handicapped children. That was his foundation, compassion and care for the most vulnerable. He would specialize in special education, directing programs in Santa Clara County and, starting in 1985, in Contra Costa County.

He started a scholarship specifically for B students, the kids who are hard working but may not be getting into top colleges. After he retired in 2014, Joe created the Ovick Family Institute to conduct education policy research and provide scholarships to students.

Joe will forever be known for his generous spirit and his passion for creating educational pathways to students who may not otherwise have had that opportunity. I want to express my deepest condolences to his surviving wife, Debbie, his sons, John and Bjorn, and four grandchildren.
And, of course, to the students, parents, teachers, and administrators who will miss him very, very much.

unless we have the adequate bed space in which to refer people who are suicidal to be able to get treatment, we continue to do things that kind of help us feel better that we're doing something. But doesn't really address the underlying issue of a lack of resources, a lack of bed space,

Good afternoon, Mr. Chair and members. Dorothy Johnson with the California State Association of Counties and also speaking on behalf of my colleague from the League of California Cities. We were opposed, but with these amendments we are pleased to remove our opposition.

Good afternoon, Dorothy Johnson with the California State Association of Counties.

My colleague from the League of California Cities also asks to have his comments align with mine. We respectively do oppose this measure and we would note this is markedly different from the Mullin measure introduced in prior years, which would expand it to properties of greater value. Nonetheless, this measure is still problematic. Our counties, three-fourths of them are seeing less property tax revenue today than they did pre-2008 Recession.

We believe this measure could have very negative consequences for some counties, some counties could benefit, and that's why we believe the decision should remain a local decision to reflect local fiscal conditions and local service demands. We've seen over the many years since Prop 60 and Prop 90 have been in effect, counties have adopted ordinances, they've rejected them, they've adopted them and renewed them.

Again, all based on the local fiscal conditions of the counties. There is a companion measure, which I know is not before you today, and while we appreciate the opportunity for the voters of California to make this decision, we believe that the voters of these specific counties that would have to change their ordinances should be the ones making the decision, if not the Board of Supervisors.
So for these reasons we do remain respectfully opposed, thank you.

Thank you, my name is Susan Little, I'm a Senior Advocate with the Environmental Working Group. And I'm here today to let you know that the Environmental Working Group supports AB 483, a bill which, among other things, requires the Department of Toxic Substances Control to test soil at many general aviation airports for the presence of hazardous waste, especially lead.

A very worthwhile portion of this bill addresses air pollution around these airports. But I'm here today to address the potential contamination of soil by fallout from the airport's emissions. Leaded fuel is still used to burn piston aircraft, the kind of the aircraft that fly in and out of general aviation airports.

But exposure to even small amounts of lead such as that found in soil or household dust can also cause harm especially to children. The University of North Carolina evaluated relationship between children's blood lead levels and their proximity to general aviation airports. The study found that children who lived within 500 meters of an airport had notably higher blood levels than children living farther away.

AB 483's proposal to test the soil at General Aviation Airport is a good first step to identifying the presence of hazardous waste, such as lead at the airports, and then safeguarding the children and adults who lived in the surrounding communities. We'd like to thank Assemblymember Bocanegra for his leadership on this issue, and for introducing this bill. Thank you.

Will Barrett with the American Lung Association of California. I want to also thank the member for bringing this forward to protect local public health and understand any impacts from these near neighborhood sourced pollutants. Thank you.

Hello, I'm John Caldwell on behalf of the California Hotel and Lodging Association. We're not going to oppose. We have some concerns with the bill, concerns we shared with the staff and the sponsor. But first members, just a little background regarding what's been said.

Human trafficking is a world wide problem, and the hotel industry has been taking an active role in fighting it for years. In 2015, Bradley Miles, he's the CEO of Polaris, a group that Committee analysis identifies as a leading anti-human trafficking organization, wrote about the proactive steps to confront human trafficking that the hotel industry is taking on.

Wyndham Hotel Group, which is Days Inn, Super 8, Howard Johnson, quote, deepened its partnership with Polaris in 2014. Over 10 years ago, in the late 2000s, Carlson, which is Radisson Country and Suites led the industry as one of the first major hospitality companies to speak out against modern slavery and sexual exploitation of children.

Miles continues, Polaris develop to training curricula for Hyatt hotels and then training and now training 45,000 employees across the globe on human trafficking. Hilton, which is Embassy Suites, Hampton Inns, and Starwood, and Sheraton, and Weston, all tackling the issue. And in 2014 the American Hotel and Lodging Association Educational Institute partnered with End Child Prostitution and Trafficking, ECPAT to develop an online training program for hotel employees.

It's a 30 minute course that provides hotel, and staff, and managers with the information they need to identify and respond to the crimes of human trafficking and commercial sexual exploitation of children. The training is free to all of the members of the California Hotel and Lodging Association. Last year, Ms. Garcia authored a bill to require mandatory training for hotel employees.

We were working with her when the bill got held up on suspense. Earlier this year, we were contacted by Senator Toni Atkins about her interest in Ms. Garcia's mandatory training of hotel employees. We've been working with her. The result is SB 270, which we strongly support as does the leading anti-human trafficking group, Polaris.

And we believe we've worked out some of the financial, fiscal problems that resulted in Ms. Garcia's bill being held up in suspense. So our concern with this bill is that while the sign that's being put up here, we think the sign, it'll do little to combat human trafficking. It causes a great reputational risk for hotels, motels, bed and breakfasts.

I mean this is a notice that was designed, this is according to the statutes, this is a notice that was designed for adult bookstores, bus stations, truck stops, massage parlors. The notice, it's at the bottom of page two on your bill, it's obviously aimed at victims of human trafficking. But in the context of a hotel lobby, what it conveys is that there is human trafficking going on at this hotel.

That's a devastating message for our customers. We're told that we can just say the state made us do it. The state made you put up the sign. Well, in other words, our argument is the state is now saying that human trafficking is going on at this hotel. That's hardly reassuring. Then there's the argument that every hotel will have it, so no one hotel will look bad.

But that assumes people go to a lot of hotels. I mean, I kind of, our clients would like that a lot of people go to hotels, but that's not necessarily the case. And people from out of state will see the hotel they booked online. So we've talked to the author and sponsor about our concerns, and we prefer not to oppose efforts to fight human trafficking. It's important to us. So we've suggested different approaches that the sign be at the back of house, aimed at employees and subcontractors.

Then we suggested that it be aimed at transient locations that do not have employees but we're willing to work with it. But as you can see, the industry is very involved in this and we think the best approach and as does Polaris, the best approach is training of employees. We're going for a mandatory bill on that, we're supporting a mandatory bill on that. And we believe this sign is not in any of the recommendations of the groups, and it will just cause reputational risk for our clients.
There wasn't actually a question there, so I'm going to stop the back and forth. Mr. Kiley, do you have a question?

I do want to thank the author for bringing this forward. As the Chairman said, this is an epidemic that needs to be addressed. And I applaud Mr. Caldwell, I applaud the efforts made by the industry, that is really important. My question is, in the past how has enforcement been done? We know we have the requirement of various establishments, emergency rooms, various establishments. How has that been enforced in the past?

Well, I mean, statutorily there's not a lot there. What we've done is we're ahead of it ahead of the curve here, we're obviously doing it voluntarily worldwide. But I mean, are you talking about the language that's in the statute?
Talking about the language from the prior, the way the law is now. We have a number of establishments that are required to post notice. So I'm asking the author or the sponsor.
I think it's an important bill.

That's the only.

Planes that burn leaded aviation gas, or avgas as it's called, are the transportation sector's primary contributors to leaded air pollution. Avgas's lead not only pollutes the air, but it also pollutes all that it lands on. Lead does not break down but instead accumulates in soil and water, and can be absorbed by plants. As we know, lead is a neurotoxin. Exposure to large quantities of lead can cause kidney and brain damage.
We also want to thank the department for their collaboration in getting the funding and making it available to local health departments on the grounds for the use of this drug. Thank you.

Local health departments are working on the grounds to tackle and address the issues that are arising through this epidemic. And we are looking at this, as a public health epidemic as well, and so, we think that the funding would go a long way in terms of education at the local levels and to address this.
This is absolutely essential. And also I read in the Wall Street Journal today that competition is fierce and growing, even Kentucky has a cyber haller now. So, we firmly support the bill.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker, I also rise in strong support of ACR 34, and thank my colleague for bringing this forward. I think many of us who have worked in this field and worked with these families understand the stark situation people feel, hold. And I would also just like to speak from a Social Worker's perspective this is an issue that we have studied, and studied,and studied and realize that there should be about

a social work ratio of about one social worker to 15 children. A lot of times when these cases come up and we go back and we look and we see that there was one social worker to a 100 children or 75 children. And they're expected to close those cases and turn them around quickly.

So I have been very strong support of this as we work to protect children, but at the same time we need to be able to make sure we provide the resources and to be able to provide the structure for people to actually do their job. There's also another thing called title protection, a lot of people can get a job as a CPS social worker and have no training whatsoever as a professional social worker. That's something that we've talked about for years.
And so, I hope these next couple of years we can actually take some real steps to keep our children safe. I thank you, and I ask for your support on ACR 34.

Thank you Mr. Speaker and members. Today I rise to adjourn in memory of Karen Smith and Jonathan Martinez who were tragically gunned down at North Park Elementary School in San Bernardino this last week on April 10th. Karen was a devoted educator and a 10 year veteran of the San Bernardino Unified School District.

She took pride in developing, nurturing and lasting relationships with her special needs students. A rock for her family, Karen was a mother of four and grandmother of three. Jonathan Martinez, special needs student, was standing behind his teacher.

He was just eight years old, was gunned down and died a few days later. Although he had endured heart surgery and other challenges presented by Williams Syndrome, he is remembered as always smiling an jovial. As was stated at a press conference last week, he was joy.
He shared his playful curiosity and overall love of life with both his family and all whom he met.
Both of them left us too soon and will not be forgotten.

In the wake of this tragedy, I have been extremely proud of the way that the community has responded. Our first responders, our teachers, our school leaders, parents, students and the community. When tragedies such as this occur, it really reveals the character and resilience of our community, and I am so

proud to say that San Bernardino is as resilient and as strong as ever. Finally, this tragedy occurred as an escalation of domestic violence. As we remember Karen and Jonathan, I ask that we also ensure
to take action to empower those who are victims of domestic violence and abuse.
Allow them to speak up and I ask that we also stand with them.

Good morning Mr Chair and members, Bethany Armstrong, on behalf of the county Health Executives Association representing Local Health Departments, urge your support when it turns on suspense. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam Chair and Committee Members. I'm Bill McGavern with the Coalition for Clean Air. And here to speak in support of Section 4, the Clean Warehouse program that you've been discussing. As you're aware SB 1 included a last minute provision that exempts certain trucks from certain air quality standards.

That's going to make it harder to reduce air pollution from goods movement in many of your districts. This provision will help some to reduce that air pollution by creating a zero, near zero emission warehouse program, so that in the districts that have a lot of goods movement with a lot of diesel emissions associated with that, they'll be able to get some cleaner equipment.
So we thank Senator Leyva and Senator De Leon for pursuing this.

AB1088. Thank you, Madame Chair. And I'd like to start off by saying I was accepting the Committee amendments. And thank you for the chair and the Committee for all their work on this. As we all know, over the past couple of years, our state has taken on to be the leaders in energy efficiency, whether it be our policies, infrastructure, vehicles, all kinds of things. One of the issues, and especially around people's living.

You can't drive down the street without seeing solar on people's rooftops everywhere, and all kinds of good things going on. But the one segment that hasn't had a lot of attention is the multi-family dwelling residents and we also know that there are millions and millions and millions, tens of millions of Californians who live in apartments, multi-family housing.

So, what this bill does is we will direct California Energy Commission to coordinate with the public utilities and all the relevant stakeholders to come together to come up with some goals. We're not defining what those are going to be, but be able to come up with some ideas about how we can address this issue

and also develop a website that says, you can go on to look if you're a landlord or if you're somebody who can go on and look for all kinds of good ideas, in places that are already out there for things you can apply for. We just really think that we need to, as we continue to make California the leader in clean energy, we can't forget about low-income folks.

We know that utility bills are a huge cost for a lot of very poor people and so we feel it's our responsibility to do whatever we can to reduce those. And with me today I have Maria Stamas from Natural Resource Defense Council to speak.

Yes, just again thank everybody for all their work on this. Again, you've heard what the bill does and of course what it doesn't do is set concrete requirements with concrete numbers attached to them. So we'll appreciate as go forward to continue to address people's concerns. We never meet our goals if we don't include multi-family housing. I ask for your aye vote.

our districts are telling us that it's really the homegrown efforts to get teachers from the community. Yes, Dan Kaplan with the LAO. I'd just like to add one thing. If I understand your question correctly, you asked what is more effective? Is it a grant program or a loan forgiveness program?

A lot of studies are often somewhat challenging because they look at each of these programs in isolation. Now, there was one study that looked at law student enrollment at NYU. And I know this differs from the teacher workforce, but it basically randomized those individuals entering the program and offered some a loan forgiveness option, and some an upfront grant to pursue a less lucrative public sector career.

And what it found was those students who were given the upfront grant model where they did have to repay the funding if they chose to leave the public service within a certain timeframe were more likely to go into the public service route.
So, from this, the design of the program was somewhat interesting because it does allow us to see what kind of nudges can be most effective.

Thank you Madame President. I'm pleased to recognize Hall of Fame Jockey Mike Smith. Pound for pound jockey's are thought to be among the greatest athletes of the world. Think about it, they sit on top of a 1200 pound animal.

Going about 40 miles an hour, holding on with a little more than their big toes. It's pretty remarkable and today we have with us one of the greatest jockeys in the world, Mike Smith. Mike was the son of a jockey. He started riding at the age of 11 in his native New Mexico.
At the age of 16, he took out his jockey's license and began a career that would take him on the ride of a lifetime.

a last to first finish that left even his trainer Bob Bafford in a loss for words. Mike is a great ambassador to the sport, and he's demonstrated a lifelong commitment to advancing the rights of his fellow riders.

Thank you, Mr. Chair and members. I present to you AB 1115 which authorizes a court, in it's discretion, to grant expungement relief for a petitioner, previously convicted of an offense, included in AB 109, also known as realignment.

In 2011, Governor Brown signed AB 109 which authorized individuals convicted of a non serious, nonviolent, nonsexual offense to serve their sentences in county jails, and or under local supervision if they met the specified criteria. One of the impacts, we have seen, as a direct result of realignment has been the steady decline of recidivism rates.

Since 2011, recidivism dropped from 67% to 44%, without any substantial threat to public safety. Additionally, both the severe overcrowding in our state's prison system and the cost associated with high rates of incarceration, have also significantly diminished. In order to build upon our statewide progress, it is crucial that we continue to remove barriers

to those who have served their time and demonstrated a willingness to become contributing members of society. Whereas current law already authorizes a court to grant expungement relief for individuals, conviction of a realignment offense. Those who were convicted of the same offenses prior to 2011 are not eligible. AB-1115 simply extends the opportunity.

Again, the opportunity for those who have successfully completed their supervision, paid full restitution and proven their commitment to reentry, again, to apply for expungement relief. The courts still have the final determination of whether or not the individual is granted expungement relief.

And only after a lapse of two years following the completion of the petitioner's sentence. Ultimately, AB 1115 will help further reduce recidivism, providing a pathway to successful rehabilitation for those who are dedicated to becoming productive and law abiding members of our community. With me today I have Hillary Blout, Staff Attorney for California for Safety and Justice.
And Susan Burton founder and Executive Director of a New Way of Life. Thank you, and I ask you for your aye vote. I move to vote.
Are the, where are we now?
Witnesses in opposition?
Okay. And are there any other witnesses in opposition? Are there any questions from Committee Members?
Thank you. Any other questions? You may close, and if you want to answer.
Okay. We have a motion. Move the bill.
Okay, the Chair's going to recommend an aye vote, and

now let me put it in this context of my counterpart on the Senate side. We've had serious discussions about the prison system in general. And we believe that during the time when we had three strikes and a lot of harsh penalties, we started building prisons.

And, in respect to Mr. Quirk, we built prisons and engaged with private industry. And no one ever asked, what if there was a day when we would be into reentry and rehabilitation? Why should we build all these new prisons?

Why should we send prisoners out? We just did it based on the fact that we were in a, we're going to lock them up, and everybody up, and throw away the key. And we never looked back. Well, we saw what happened.

I'm of the opinion we should go ahead and look at over the next 10 years, what if we were to close a prison. Obviously if you get rid of the private ones but put together a plan where we believe that reentry programs work.

And you will need fewer space for people in prisons. Why aren't we putting together a plan to close, at least one prison, and so I want this that not only do we need this to put that in place but I also know, you, myself and all of us here.

There is no guarantee that we'll be here in 2018, 2020 or 24. So, if you don't put a marker in place to try to make a change in CDCR in a way we deal with this. If you don't put it on the record like you're doing here now, no one will pay attention. And if we're gone, then no one will pick up the mantel.

And so, it's very important that we actually do give every department goals that they need to achieve. I think it's an admiral goal that we can try to achieve, without it they're not going to do it to be honest with you. And something will come up and it'll be another excuse, another excuse.

Even this if we get and go through I think we'll be back in four years and say why haven't you done it, because you also have to do the carrot and stick and accountability measures, which this body is now starting to do. And so it's very important that we start the process of looking at our whole

entire prison system in the way we house people and come up with a different strategy. But most important, start to shrink the amount of space that we use for that, and I'll leave you with this. When I first got on this Committee, I was on public safety chair sub five. The private industry came to visit me and told me that they needed 50,000 new beds within 10 years.

And they could it, they could accurately tell me and it was based on the number of people that couldn't read a third grade level. So I recommend it, why don't we build, why don't we teach those young people how to read and then we can build new colleges and universities and figure out how many college seats we have.

Well those individuals have been to my office and I've been here almost five years and they haven't come back since. So I think once we change the dialogue and change our mindset, and stop being negative and put our whole force behind re-entry. You may have to come back with another bill to close even
more facilities so we can save even more money. So, this chair's recommending an aye vote.
We will now go through all the measures, including those on call, for add-ons and changes.

Thank you Mr. Chair, Ryan Spencer on behalf of the bill sponsors the California Podiatric Medical Association. I think the Chairman kind of summed up the bill quite well, but I will just kind of reiterate a couple points. It does focus on two primary issues, one is the allowance of Podiatrists to treat leg ulcers, especially those that move from the ankle up to just below the knee, and also allows them to perform other procedures that are directly related to the foot and ankle if they're given the appropriate privileges by the hospital medical staff.

This bill was developed in a very thoughtful manner to acknowledge the years of improvements in education of training of podiatrists. This includes four years of medical school, and now three years of residency, which is up from the one year from decades ago. That is vastly similar to that of an MD and a DO. We do recognize that there are still some stakeholders that have interest in the bill and we'll continue to work with them as the bill moves forward, and so, I'd appreciate your aye vote, and thank you for your time.

Sure, good afternoon, I'm Victoria Rome with the Natural Resources Defense Council and we're here in here support of AB 287. This bill provides a collaborative, common sense and community based approach to a problem that has been vexing transportation officials for six decades. We believe the bill would create a process for affected communities, transportation officials and legislators.

So representatives of this body would have a seat at the table to collectively design a solution that addresses critical regional mobility issues while protecting our environment and communities. NRDC helped develop and supports one such proposal as was mentioned, the Beyond 710 plan.

A comprehensive, multi-modal, cost effective approach to enhancing mobility and increasing transportation options in the West San Gabriel Valley. So we believe, as Assembly Member Holden said, that this bill helps align our transportation future with the goals that we've set
and with, really, people's mobility needs as we move forward with things like car sharing,
transit, complete streets, biking options, and better options for pedestrians. Urge your support, thank you.

Chair and members, Reed Addis on behalf of CALSTART, a California based non profit that focuses on fuel and vehicle technologies, we're in strong support today. California's been a leader in transportation, vehicle fuel technologies and in particular, set up robust strategies around how many electric vehicles need to be on the road. That leadership has provided billions of dollars of investment into California and over 12,00 direct jobs from that EV production. However, it's not easy to just have a customer show up at the lot or look online and buy an EV. Therefore, the state has invested in rebate programs to try to help incentivize the customers to do so, as my colleague mentioned right now, we have the CVRP program as that.

What this bill does, we think, is it allows the state to put forward a new program that is stable, creates a clear market signal, and ultimately allows the manufacturers and the dealers to advertise and provide clear direction to customers that they can receive a tax benefit when they go and buy the car. We think that's a good policy. We think that will help us as CDRP transitions out. We think it's the right way to go in California. We also want to be clear that not only does this policy help when it comes to new cars that are EV, but as the Assembly Member pointed out, what's new and interesting for us, as well in this policy is that it focuses on used cars for low to moderate income individuals in California.

Now, I'm going to really focus in on the moderate income individuals who currently today do not have a program they can access. We think this bill goes a long way in allowing them to go and access the used car market. For those reasons, we're in strong support today, thank you.

And Mr. Chair just to be clear, just that there's no confusion, we have CVRP right now, this is CVRP 2.0, CVRP, which is a rebate program, we'll be changing this into a tax exemption program instead, which we believe is a little bit better and provides more certainty, which is better moving forward when it comes to the purchasing of new vehicles as well as for the dealers to be able to do what they need to do to have that certainty that they know that they can advertise. To consumers, understanding that there's going to be these not rebate, but incentive there.

And it also opens the program up to those who are buying used vehicles, because low and moderate income folks, many of whom I represent can't get into this program. If we're going to reach our goals in the future, we have to have buy-in from low and moderate income communities in order to reach that 15% goal by 2025.

Part of what we envision in regards to the assignability Is the ability, if there is in the program, if we get to the point where we have a pre-qualification because we do have to remember that we have income limits on whether or not you qualify for the current CVRP, and that would also hold true in this bill under this program, but that there would be some type of pre-qualification program envisioned in this that would allow you to then go to the dealership and assign that tax credit to the dealer, because you have been pre-qualified. It would have to be under a pre-qualification scenario.

Thank you, and I thank everyone and their comments. Obviously I want to let you know that you've been heard by the Committee. Even though I am a coauthor as the authors of the two bills from both houses. I have a real concern with implementation. And I've expressed this to both authors as someone who comes from local government

which I'm always concern about us people up here in Sacramento and Washington, creating the laws and then forcing it down to local levels. So making sure that this works is extremely important, because if it doesn't, if it's not funded properly, if the counties aren't on board, if we don't have some kind of understanding of the best practice in the way to do this

It will fall under its own weight, either through resources or through costs. And so I want this to move out of this Committee with the understanding and the hope that both the authors will continue to work with not only the business community in this area, but also law enforcement, so

we can craft something that when it hits the ground running, but most important it actually works. because as we're debating all of the policy implications here, ultimately if it doesn't work at the local level, we'll all be in trouble. The reason this is so important to me for this to work is

because ever since I became chair of public safety, then before then I was chair of budgets of five. I've been to more prisons than I ever wanted to and I've seen more African Americans and Latinos incarcerated. I understand that maybe the 13th amendment freed African Americans, but there's a portion in there that criminalizes individuals and denies them their right.

And the prison plantation system right now that we have in place in California, where we incarcerate more black and brown folk is very disturbing to me, and even to the Governor, who's expressed it to me on several occasions. And so we need to come up with some methodology that does not criminalize a whole sector, a whole group of people, and

continue this discrimination that we have within our legal system. I'm not putting it on bail bondsmen. I'm not putting it on law enforcement. I'm not putting it on the judges. I'm not even putting it on the Legislature. But we all share in the reason that it's the way it is now.

And until we do something to turn that around in an active, positive way, and just to sit on our hands and do nothing, I think is also a crime. And so that is why I became a joint author, but I also want to make sure that we get it right. And even my colleagues on the other side hope that they

also join in with us to make this an equitable system. So that, obviously, we do not, and I repeat, do not want to let out violent criminals on our street. The author has assured me that, that is not something that they want to do.

And maybe we even don't need to put in more money to go after the 7, 8,000 that are out there, and update those methodologies to bring them in. And I'm not adverse to doing that. But at the same time, a mother, or a Latina who's

been picked up, accused of a crime, is now separated from her five kids. And then the grandmother, Abuela, has to put up her home, and then we find out later after a $100,000 bail, they're now in debt for 10 grand. We've got to fix that.

We've got to figure that out, especially when innocent people are let loose. And I would ask the business element of this, the bail bonds folk, to please join with us in coming up with ways that if innocent people are let go, they are not further criminalized financially for the rest of their lives.

And I think that's just where the authors are getting to, that we don't continue to do that. And my offices have been wide open to both sides, and I've talked to both sides. I think both sides will want to come up with a equitable solution. If we stop butting heads, I think we can come up with something that we all can live with.

And so I would definitely want this to pass out. There will be several discussions as it moves forward. But I've gotten the assurances from the authors that we will continue dialogue. With that, the Chair's recommend, first, I need a motion.  Madam Secretary, call the roll.

And we would like to work with somebody to work on Legislation that would perhaps provide incentives for pet stores to do that. Thank you, I understand what you and the families who've been affected are trying to get to. This vehicle is not the way, I mean, in a lot of ways it assumes that immigrants are not law-abiding and to put that out there, we need to dispel that, one.
Two, for example, I have a bill asking that law enforcement officers do not turn over law abiding immigrant members of California.

If they see a crime and report it, if they're a victim of crime that they can report it without the fear of being turned over to ICE agents or the federal government to be deported and so they can be law abiding citizens. I think that's the way to go.

And I believe some amendments have been made even in some of the language for what we call sanctuary cities to ensure that we do not allow felons to remain here illegally. This bill assumes that with a sweep of one hand that most immigrants are not law abiding, I think that's unbelievably wrong and not the message that we want to send out.

And in fact I believe even the data you have, if you say you want to get rid of felons who are immigrants, you probably would get most of that data. But if you talk to most Californians who believed that we need to protect the law abiding immigrants in this state, you get exact opposite of what you've got and most Californians do.

We want to ensure that every Californian, no matter what the immigration status is protected. I also serve a large Latino community and they are scared to death. And bills like this, are a detriment, an unbelievable detriment to us being able to move forward to have good immigration laws.
Unfortunately, you chose this vehicle hopefully you understand now that we need to move in another direction where we embrace the people that are here and we come up with Federal immigration laws.

AB 1578 will help ensure the successful implementation of these laws and forthcoming regulations. Safeguarding the years of work and progress our state has made, and most important, it ensures that the will of the voters are not undermined. Specifically this bill portrays Californians who are operating in compliance with our state laws by providing that absent a court order.

Let me say that again. Absent a court order, local and state agencies including regulators and law enforcement shall not assist in any federal enforcement against state authorized medical cannabis or commercial and not commercial marijuana activity. Ultimately, AB 1578 provides law abiding Californians the privacy and

protections they deserve while preventing the mismanagement of local and state resources which are funded by our tax dollars. With me today I have Lynne Lyman, state Director of the Drug Policy Alliance. Annette Dion Fontaine, Vice President of the Berkeley Patients Group. Thank you, and I respectfully ask for an aye vote.

Can I close? You may close. Okay, thank you. It's a little perplexing to me, and in many ways because I went out of my way to ensure that this was not a confrontational bill. And even though it's labeled Cannabis Sanctuary bill. What brought this to me really was just about 134 legal medical Cannabis facilities in Los Angeles.
They're already approved and regulated. There are 1,444 that are illegal. In my mind, why are we wasting our time on 135 when you got 1,400 you could shut down.

1,400 that I want law enforcement to work with the federal government to close down. I've encouraged that but for some reason we're kind of focused on this 135 that are legal In Los Angeles and trying to shut them down and that's what I'm worried about, that the federal government is expending its resources.

Not to go after the ones that might, if we were to do a percentage, probably a higher percentage of them, are doing some of the illegal stuff that my friends in law enforcement are talking about. I think very few of them their being regulated have gone through a very long and intensive vesting vetting process.

Probably, don't have that problem at all.. But we're going to expand our resources to take care of those 134 or 35 when we could make a dramatic impact on those 1400. And again, the reason you have a court order is to stop over-ambitious law enforcement from going in to go after the legal ones. But, if a legal one is selling illegal drugs, if it's too close to a school, if it's doing something in violation.

Get a court order, it's a legal business, just like you would do with a legal business. Does not preclude the federal government from getting a court order to do it. None of this precludes law enforcement from doing what they need to do. And so it bothers me that it's being portrayed as I stick

in our finger in the eye of the federal government or even Jeff Sessions, if he comes this way, there is an Attorney General that holds the tip of the spear that may push back. Push back, not go after. We're here to represent Californians and the laws here.

And we're here to make sure that legal businesses in California are able to move forward and be productive. And then the last thing, we're going to make some changes as you know props, and Mr. Lackey will tell you, Prop 64 has come out, the five authors of the medical marijuana but

we have some concerns and we're going to make those concerns very clear in the trailer bill language. And I feel comfortable that we will be able to address a lot of that in the trailer bill language.

But I will tell you this. As it comes to individuals who were incarcerated because of cannabis and marijuana now that it's legal, you want to continue to punish them. That's a no, that's a no starter with me, absolutely.

So I know that's nothing to do with this bill but was brought up as being connected to this bill. But people just like people were in bootlegging some very famous families were in bootlegging. And now, they become presidents, their family becomes presidents of the United States,

we aren't holding them back because their family used to be involved in an illegal activity become rich, and famous, and powerful and political. We should not hold back because they're African American and Latino. We should not hold them back because at the time that was the only form of commerce they could participate in.

And so in fact, we should bring them into this business because it might be something they may have some actual experience in and could do very well in. And so we gotta stop continuing to punish them for that. And so with that, I respectfully ask for an aye vote.
We will now go through all measures, including those on call. Madam Secretary, call the roll.
This meeting stands adjourned.
Yes, good afternoon, Matthew Allen with Western Growers Association, we're also opposed.

Heather Harrison, with the California Assisted Living Association, we're oppose unless amended To the recent amendments that kind of flip flopped the disclosure timing. We believe the disclosure is now kind of backwards in the bill. We've been talking to the author's office, originally it required disclosure upfront to consumers about the referral agency fees the language in the bill now requires the community that the resident the senior moves into to make that disclosure with ink in order for it to be a value it needs to happen before the fact that after the fact. Thank you.

Chair and members, Reed Addis on behalf of the California Wilderness Coalition in support today. We think Senator Allen's bill is a good policy, because we do actually believe that this recreation should exist. We think there should be parks for this type of recreation,

we also think it's appropriate to have these facilities on federal lands and managed properly. However, having said that, I think we would all agree that this type of recreational activity is loud, it's dangerous, and it does create environmental problems. And so, therefore, we need to have an appropriate management system in the State of California to deal with that.

10 years ago we worked with then Senator Steinberg on the last reform measure. We spent a lot of time dealing with the funding and the grant programs, but at the same time we were very concerned about the management of the existing facilities and the type of writing that was occurring.

Move forward 10 years, and what you'll see, and it's being handed out to you right now, is that unfortunately, there is still riding that is occurring outside of designated trails, and occurring on very sensitive habitat.

Just like the rest of us, if we go to a state park and there's a pedestrian trail, there's certain rules, and when we go off those trails, we're not allowed to do that and there's enforcement measures. All we're trying to argue here, in particular in these state facilities, is there needs to be better conversation measures and better governance.

And we think Senator Allen's bill does that, and we think it allows for stronger conservation measures. We also think the governance reform in the bill is appropriate, and allows the appropriate set of agencies to make sure the writing is occurring in a way that's sustainable and doesn't harm the environment.

Good afternoon, Chair and members. Marina Wine with the California Housing Consortium. At the beginning of this legislative session, CHC, along with Western Center, CRAF, and Housing California, put together a policy framework of the steps the Legislature needed to take to have a comprehensive approach to the housing crisis.

In addition to significant investment in affordable housing measures such as this one, are essential to ensure that the land in the state is available for the housing that we need developed. That's one of the reasons why CHC is a big supporter of this bill, and we urge your support today.

Good morning, Chairman and Committee Members. So, I'm with American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to the Animals. And, as the author mentioned, we've been doing a lot of work in Los Angeles counties, specifically with our safety net program. And what we do is, we work in conjunction with the County of LA. Actually, have staff cited at two county shelters where folks commonly relinquish their pets.

And so, we have staff there intervening, asking them if there's barriers to their pet ownership and why they're relinquishing? One of the most common reasons cited is housing issues. And a lot of times that has to do with evictions, financial evictions and a lack of alternatives in the market that are pet friendly.

So, this is one option to promote pet permissibility through our affordable housing sector that we're creating here, through investing in state financed affordable housing. And I'll add, as a former housing official, I've heard from many of my housing colleagues, former housing colleagues and I think this is probably the experience of author as well, in his former professional experience.

That many of you are very familiar with the barriers to get in folks that are chronicle homeless off the streets and one commonly cited barrier to getting people to move into permanent housing situations is, they don't want to relinquish their pets that have been a companion with them on the streets. And so this gives an opportunity through many of the funding sources that are really focused right now on the chronically homeless populations.

This gives them the opportunity to keep the pet that has been a companion with them, kept them safe on the streets. To stay with them, that's provided them comfort and safety and so this was a real good companion item to the funding sources that we have available to the state right now. Thank you.

This is a program that's been successful at the K-12 level. We believe that it also ought to be extended to community colleges. As he mentioned, been successful at LAUSD, be good at community colleges, thank you.
Mr. Chair and Members, Dawn Koepke, Mchugh Koepke and Associates, on behalf of Crime Victims United, also in support.

Caliph Assagai on behalf of the California Public Defenders Association also in respectful opposition of this measure. This bill's essential effect will be longer sentences, more prison time for individuals who commit crimes. This sounds good, but it's been proven that longer sentences are not a greater deterrent. And in fact, increase recidivism in the State of California.

We want a system where people actually come out of the prison system reformed, rehabilitated, and improved. And under this bill, extending the time that people are in prison is only going to reduce the incentive to take advantage of rehabilitation programs. And other programs that might address their issues and allow them to return to society as better people.

We have a choice, clearly we've chosen to put people in jail. But we have a better choice and a more important choice to decide how they come out. And longer prison sentences, less incentive for rehabilitation is going to produce worse results for public safety when these individuals return to society. And for that reason, we are opposed to this measure.
Thank you. Any other witnesses in opposition?

Good afternoon, my name is Brian Hanlon, I'm the co-founder of Carla, the California Renters Legal Advocacy and Education Fund. Thank you for considering SB 167, the Legislature passed the Housing Accountability Act way back in 1982, the year of my birth, and has amended it 15 times since then. In 1990, 27 years ago, the Legislature substantially expanded the HAA and included a preamble that sounds like it was written yesterday.

It reads in part, the lack of affordable housing is a critical problem which threatens the economic, environmental, and social quality of life in California. California housing has become the most expensive in the nation. The excessive cost of the state's housing supply is partially caused by activities and policies of many local governments which limit the approval of affordable housing, increase the cost of land for

affordable housing, and require that high fees and exactions be paid by producers of potentially affordable housing. In 2001, the Legislature again amended the HAA and dropped the word affordable from findings, why? Because the problems that once afflicted the least of us now afflict the most of us. Today, the Legislature is again confronted with amending the HAA.

For 35 years, many local governments have thwarted the will of Legislature, violated the HAA, and worst of all, have created a housing shortage that is both acute and chronic that immiserates renters and aspirational homeowners throughout the state. On a personal note, as a renter, as a moderate income earner, as a not so young person who wrestles with the effects of the state's housing shortage every day, I implore you to shrinking the Housing Accountability Act and make good on the promise of California.

The YIMBY, or Yes In My Back Yard movement, consists of mostly renters in their 20s and 30s who are locked out of home ownership, struggling with rent, or living with housemates when we want to start families. We know that our housing struggles are not the result of impersonal economic forces, or lack of individual effort, but derived from bad laws and bad policy decisions that have restricted housing growth for decades.

In short, we are angry and we vote on housing. We are not asking for public assistance, we are asking for the Legislature to make its own housing laws enforceable so that California's construction trades people may build the future and construct a state affordable and accessible for all of us. I'd be happy to answer any questions that you might have of SB 167, especially the need for
a heightened evidentiary standard, expanded attorney's fees, and the HAA analysis for provost housing developments. Thank you.

I'm Will Barrett with the American Lung Association in California. Will Barrett with the American Lung Association in California. The Lung Association has a long history of commitment to the advancement of zero emission technologies and reducing vehicle miles traveled as a pathway to improving public health. Last year, the Lung Association released a report showing that the passenger vehicle fleet in California represents about $15 billion in annual climate and public health impacts.

These asthma attacks, hospitalizations, and premature deaths would be greatly reduced through the conversion of the fleet to zero emission technologies, as well as a reduction of vehicle miles travel. We appreciate the Senator's effort to bring the role of zero emission technologies into the discussion of autonomous vehicles as a way to advance clean air climate and healthy communities together.

And we feel that this should be a strong focus of the Advisory Committee going forward. So we look forward to working through the ways that we can drive the greatest clean air and climate benefits, as this new technology matures and some of the questions that Mollie referenced are answered going forward. In our criminal justice system across the board. And for me, that has brought the issue of DNA to the floor.

And we're going to talk about that in this bill and one other bill today. But it is about how we can use the current tools that focus in on those that are really committing heinous crimes to bring justice to our community.

So the first bill that we're talking about today SB 757, would require people who are convicted of illegally paying for sex to provide DNA samples to law enforcement for identification. And also requires that those who engage in illegal prostitution with a minor to register as sex offenders.

In a recent study conducted by the Oakland Special Victims Unit, it was found that 85% of unsolved homicides in the city involved a prostitute. 85% of unsolved homicides in the city involved a prostitute. Furthermore, 260 minors were rescued from prostitution in 2014 and 2015 alone. And this is not a problem that's just regarding Oakland residents.
