Thank you, Madam Chair. SB 781 is a DNA evidence bill, and as you're all now pretty familiar as you have been before even this hearing about the issue of DNA collection for felony crimes. As you may recall, a few years ago we reduced a number of
felonies to misdemeanors, which limited our ability to collect DNA.

Assemblyman Cooper had a bill in that regard over the last couple of years. I sat on this committee with some of you when we heard the Cooper bill, and I was curious as to whether or not the DNA from those decriminalized crimes had led to any arrests and catching the bad guys,

and the Attorney General's Office informed us that in a three year period, 1,396 crimes were linked to DNA samples taken from those non-violent offenses that we've now decriminalized. 1,396 and that's from the California Attorney General's Office.

Of those 1,396 crimes, 394 were serious and violent crimes against persons which included rape, murder, and robbery. These crimes included 196 rapes, 54 murders, four attempted murders, one assault to commit rape, and one kidnapping with intent to commit rape.
It's imperative that we do not limit an effective tool that's historically been used by law enforcement to arrest those that commit these violent crimes

and that's why I brought this bill back to you today. I'm pleased to have with me the District Attorney of Alameda County, Nancy O'Malley, also Mark Jasper. Mark is the grandson of Sophia McAllister, who was a victim of senseless violence. He's here to share the story about how DNA evidence helped bring justice his family.
And if it's okay with the chair, I'd like to invite Mr. Jasper to present testimony.

But it was not offered up as an alternative when my bill, similar to this one, was presented last year. I think the staff, the Committee consultants have maybe threw Senator Leno a list of those examples here. And I'm happy to share it with the Committee, if that is appropriate.

Thank you, Mr Chair and members. I present to you AB 359, which closes a significant loophole in existing law, regarding use of jailhouse informants. Current law places a mandatory cap on law enforcement payments to jailhouse informants for providing testimony in a case. However, this cap is limited to cash payments and does not include other benefits like special housing, gifts, or sentencing leniency.

In addition, the cap does not apply to payments or other benefits received to jailhouse informants for their participation and intelligence gathering. Just last year, the U.S. Justice Department launched an investigation into Orange County. Several high-profile cases that many of you may recall,

where undisclosed informants received hundreds of thousands of dollars for information and testimony in multiple cases spanning across six different counties. The absurdity and the amount of tax dollars and special treatment that these jailhouse informants can benefit from is concerning in itself.

But what is even more troubling is the credibility of informants and the subsequent evidence and testimony they provide. A report by the center on wrongful convictions at Northwestern University School of Law found that informant dependent prosecutions are a leading cause of wrongful convictions in capital cases.

AB 359 addresses this issue and a gap in current law by extending the existing monetary gap cap to $100 for all benefits given to a jailhouse informant and for their participation as a witness providing testimony and for any intelligence gathering. This bill also ensures greater judicial transparency by requiring detailed documentation and

reporting of criminal information regarding the use of every jailhouse informant. Ultimately, AB 359 provides supports, defense, and defense information crucial for the fair determination of cases in which an informant was used, helping to reduce the number of wrongful convictions within our system.

With me today, I have Professor Andrea Natapoff. Yes, sir. I got it right, good, Associate Dean of Research at Loyola Law School. And Bruce Lisker, who, at the age of 17, was wrongfully convicted of the murder of his mother in 1983, based in part on the testimony of a jailhouse informant.
Professor, you're first.
Pull the microphone, the microphone, just pull it towards you.

The monetary part was making sure no one becomes rich off of being an informant, and that was the intent. how we can weave in, I feel confident we can work in the language. And both representatives will tell you, I work hard to ensure that we come to a common ground on anything, whether as Chair or an author of a bill. So I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
Thank you, Mr. Chair and colleagues. Assembly Bill 493 is legislation that seeks to ensure the protections of undocumented immigrants when they seek to cooperate with law enforcement on any crime.

Let me repeat that. When they seek to cooperate with law enforcement on any crime. Currently, individuals are protected when reporting or assisting law enforcement when investigations related to a hate crime. This bill merely expands protection from hate crimes to any and all crimes and

thereby promotes social responsibility for everyone residing in our state. The need for this extended protection stems from those individuals who for instance have been victims of a crime and were detained then ultimately turned over to ICE by local police for merely inquiring about their police report.

By providing expanded protection, this bill encourages immigrants who are victims of crimes, witnesses to crimes and others who have information on any criminal investigation to report and aid, I repeat, aid law enforcement. AB 493 supports open cooperation with all individuals with law enforcement,

which is an important component to our state's public safety. Ultimately, this bill reassures that if you are undocumented, you can still cooperate and assist law enforcement without fear of penalty or punishment. I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
Christopher Sanchez with Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights in strong support. We'll be getting our letter in soon. Thank you.

and law enforcement can work together to make our communities safe. And so I am obviously honored to move this forward. But I think in the big picture it will, it's an important piece of legislation to help everyone outside of here understand not everyone but
everyone in California wants to have a safe state. Thank you, I respectfully ask for your aye vote.

Okay, want to make sure my witnesses were here. Thank you Mr. Chair and Members of the Committee. AB 1250 establishes specific standard for user personal service contract by counties and cities. Current law require

state agencies to show how contract outsourcing or achieve savings, not caused the displacement of civil service employees and ensure that contracts are worded through a publicized competitive bidding process.

Decision counties are currently exempt from these types of accountability measures. While cheaper services and employee layoffs may appear to save dollars in the short term, the savings are often illusory with hidden costs that are not accounted for and or diminished services that require cities to ultimately rehire permanent staff to provide the outsourcing.

Given the scarcity of tax dollars and the right of the public to demand to receive quality public services, cities and counties should be held to meaningful standards of due diligence. And I would like to add as someone who worked for the City of Los Angeles for 25 years I've been involved in over $1 billion worth of contracts.

I've had some that were very successful and some that were not so successful because I think we did not have the type of cautionary things that are in this bill. I personally, and I probably have more experience than most of the people that are elected right now, dealing directly with government contracts at the city level.

And it's unbelievably important to have this oversight. My office has also received several inquiries from interested stakeholders about this bill. Those we have not heard from, we are willing to hear from them. This is about making this work at the local level and any amendments or

suggestions to make the bill better as we move forward, I as the author, as you know, is willing to hear it. But we would love for it to move out of this Committee so we can continue the discussion because ultimately we want to make government more effective and efficient.
I respectfully ask for your aye vote. Testifying in support are Michelle Castro with SCIU California and Michael Kaufman from the County of Los Angeles Internal Services Department. Is he here yet?
He's stuck in security line. So I can talk real slow for a while.

I would, the only thing I could suggest if we could hear from the opponents and if that person would be allowed just a minute or two that would be fine. We can go ahead and do that. I know that's out of order but with your indulgence.

Larupa Valley, Laguna Hills, Lakewood, Norwalk, Rancho Cordova, Rancho Cucamonga, Santa Fe Springs, and Torrence. And we respectfully, and, I'm sorry, the City of Elk Row, respectfully request your no vote.

So my office has always been open. So it appears that the glitch, and I'll find out when I get back from this Committee, secure the glitch in talking to the opposition maybe in my office. But I will clear that up.

It I'm letting you know that I hear all the concerns, and some I think are very valid. There will be defiantly be changes, to the bill, so that we don't hamstring government. But I also thing at the end of the day. someone who has worked on several contracts. someone who has worked on a contract where it was $100 million at the beginning and

because of changes in the contract and things that the city missed it drove the cost up to $300 million. And that's what I'm trying to avoid. We right now, when we all came in in 2012 we all remember we came into the state

where there was a computer system worth $500 million, and to change for innovation as a lot of the opponents have said. And creativity, they wanted to do that. Well that's what the judicial system wanted to do.

After about several years of study and implementation, I dare to find you. If you can find one computer that's in this building or any building now. Because we did not do a proper cost-benefit analysis, we did not put in the precautions to have a 30 day window where if someone,

because of cost, because of material breach, that they will cancel the contract in 30 days. Because a lot of entities will let things drag on and on and on. I understand, I've been in that position where I've had a contract and it's sky rocketing across and is very embarrassing not only to the bureaucrats but elected officials to then cancel a contract.

But it's also very devastating to the bottom line budget, and so that's what this get's to, and I'm hoping that we are able to move forward. And make the changes that are needed so that we protect the taxpayers' money.

Good morning, Jennifer Baker, with the California Teachers Association, extremely appreciative of the leadership and foresight that Assemblymember Kalra has. We appreciate the direction that he's taken and think that it's an extremely effective tool to utilize the strength of our pension systems while keeping the fiduciary obligations that those systems have in line with some of the specific social directions that the Legislature might seek to achieve. CalSTRS has actually been engaging with energy transfer partners for For over a year.

We've had multiple conversations since last year with CalSTRS on this very issue, as well as a number of other issues that we're working with CalSTRS to get engaged with companies on it. And we appreciate the direction and stand in solidarity and urge your support.

It's my unfortunate role to have to testify in opposition to this measure and we absolutely believe it's important that all governments and people's recognize the horrible atrocities that happen with the Armenian genocide. So we do stand in solidarity as far as wanting to make sure that, that message is communicated. Unfortunately, this measure can have lasting impacts on the CalSTRS fund, which is not fully funded. It took us 10 years to get a full funding mechanism, AB 1469, through the legislature.

And we're still in the process of trying to make sure that our members' retirement funds are solid and secure. Anything that might potentially harm the ability for CalSTRS and CalPERS to make sure that they have the right opportunities, to make sure that they can keep our members' retirement funds secure is important. We also do want to note that I have been trying to work with the author's office to see if we can get the bill admitted into an engagement bill, which we would very much love to just support. So if there were an opportunity to still try to accomplish the goal through a different mechanism, we would be absolutely happy to do that.

The dilemma, when you move towards divestment, is that tends to be a permanent factor. The Legislature has moved forward with divestment in Sudan, for example. It's no longer one country, but yet, there's still prohibitions from CalSTRS and CalPERS' investing. So this can have long repercussions, so we would encourage engagement as opposed to divestment because this way, our pension systems will have long term capabilities of trying to engage in systemic change while also making sure that they have the ability to ensure that our members' retirement funds are solid.

Of all the people arrested for purchasing prostitution, two thirds were from outside of Oakland. So we need to make sure that we address this problem that perpetuates the system of sexual exploitation that we have. I want to thank the Chair and her staff for working with me on this bill.

My name is Angela Gilliard and I represent the University of California. We are not opposed, we have a concern position. The University supports the concept and the goals of SB 320. The UC already provides for abortion services in the benefits covered by student health plans at all campus locations. Also aligned with the goals of SB 320 UC health centers provided an array of counseling services for students including information on abortion and other options in accordance with the best available scientific knowledge and understanding. However, experts have advised that providing abortion by medication is not advisable at student health centers as a matter of safety.

For a variety of reasons, the safest approach is to have OBGYN specialists provide the service and needed 24 hour availability if complications occur. UC campuses generally do not have ob-gyn on staff, although some campuses do. UC student health services generally service the primary care home for students and make referrals for abortion services by making confidential connections with community ob-gyn providers, private clinics, FQHC clinics, and Planned Parenthood. These services are located often times within just a few moments from all of our campus locations.

Students in need of these services receives support from student health centers with planning and transportation to ensure the least disruption of academic schedules. A vast majority of student health centers in the country do not offer this service some primary care officers Office. Some primary care offices do, but not student health centers are beginning to pilot projects where OB/GYN have agreed to provide the needed 24 hour specialist back up. Student health centers are supported by student fees, adding specialists for this service would add additional expense directly for students.

We believe adding this cost to students is not necessary at this time, especially when community access at each campus location is provided in close proximity to the campus through multiple providers. I've not had a chance to thoroughly review the amendments proposed today, but we're certainly willing and able to work with Senator Leyva as we go forward.
That's right, and just a position of concern.

of Medi-Cal Managed Care patients enter our doors under the implementation of the Affordable Care Act. In 2013, folks on Medi-Cal Managed Care amounted to approximately 8% of our total clients. Again my name's Jeanie Merrill, policy director with the California Climate and Agriculture Network. We're a coalition of the states leading sustainable and organic organizations and SB 276 as mentioned establishes the state water fishing enhancement program sweep in statute.

That program is administered by the California Department of Food and Agriculture. Sweep is a unique and important climate change program. Since 2014, the program has funded over 500 irrigation management improvement projects that save water and energy on California farms and ranches while also reducing related greenhouse gas emissions.

The program funds such things as soil moisture and monitoring equipment, conversion of diesel powered water pumps to solar pumps, drip irrigation systems and more. And farmer demand for SWEEP is quite high, often exceeding available funding by more than double. And SB 276 acknowledges the importance of the program in our suite of climate change programs and I ask for your aye vote.
David Jones on behalf of the City of Pasadena in strong support of the measure, thank you.
Richard Harmon on behalf of the City of Carson as well as Mayor Andre Quintero of the City of El Monte in support.
but were looking at significant expansion over the next several years with additional infrastructure planned in Canada. So we're in support, we think this makes a lot of sense.

And, I can tell you, I will name the rides sharing company, since we've met with hundreds if not thousands of their workers, drivers, Uber, doesn't let these so-called independent business people, accept tips on the credit card, which they pay.

Although, Uber is not their employer, and Uber is not even in the transportation business, it's just putting business people on one side of the transaction together with people who want to ride in their vehicle.

If they really are independent business people, they should be able to get a tip.  If there's a gratuity involved, they should be able to receive that, and they should be able to receive that in the form that is mandated for payment by the entity that is in total control of the economic relationship, namely Uber.

It is just not fair and when you talk to these, with these drivers, all they want is more money. They want to earn more money, that's what it's all about with them. And we ought to allow them to be able to do that. Thank you.
Mr. Chairman and Committee Members. Ashley Martinez on behalf of SEIU Local 1000 representing over 96,000 state employees in strong support.

Thank you Mr. President and members. Let me speak as Isadore would want me to speak, plain speaking. Isadore is a tenacious fighter for the members, as residents of his district when he was serving here in the Senate. That's what he did.

That's what who he was at his core. That job required being plain spoken. And sometimes being tough. Trying to get to the root of the issue and trying to bring truth and justice for the work that we do here.

And he did it. And he did it very effectively. For each of us, we take different positions in our professional life, in our personal life. And we understand that where we sit and where we stand at that moment in time creates a different circumstance for

And I believe that in his heart, he looks for honesty and for fairness and for righteousness in the work that we do here for the people of California and I think he can serve in this job with those values and that prospective.
