Thank you, Mr President, members. I'm happy to support the bill today. Some of the issues that have been raised by opponents do seem to make sense to me. I hope the author will consider them as the bill moves forward specifically the implementation date to give them time for

their computer systems to tool up in a way to be responsive to what he desires. We even in state government know that these computer software issues are not easy to solve, and certainly in the private sector they have the same issues. And also in regard to the opt in again, I'm support to trust to that.

I think the number of notifications is something I hoped that the parties can get together in resolve, and given those issues, that I know the author will work diligently to work out. I'm happy to support it today.

Than you Mr. President and members, this is a computer science cleanup bill that's in response to the governor's signing message of Assemblywoman Bonilla's bill from last year which was AB 2329 That bill required to the Superintendent of public construction to convene an advisory panel to develop recommendations for a computer science strategic implementation plan to ensure every student in California has access to computer science education.

The bill inadvertently limited the discretion of the Board of Ed and had some technical issues regarding the appointment and staffing. This bill addresses those concerns, it's supported by the tech industry. Bipartisan co-authors and no known opposition. I respectfully ask for an aye vote.
Good afternoon, Matthew Allen with Western Growers Association, we're also opposed.
Ryan Spencer with the City of Long Beach in support.

Good morning. Liza Everett, representing California's 72 Coming College Districts also, we don't have an official position, but we believe that this bill is going on a strong direction. Particularly, the focus on guided pathways, thank you.
Rebecca Gonzalez, National Association of Social Workers, California Chapter, in strong support.

Good morning, Danielle Kando-Kaiser on behalf of Common Sense Kids Action, the sponsor of the bill. Common Sense Kids Action is the legislative arm of Common Sense Media deleting nonprofit organization dedicated to helping kids thrive in a world of media and technology. We empower parents, teachers and policy makers by providing unbiased information, trusted advice and innovative tools to help them harness the power of media and

technology as a positive force in all kids lives. Recently Common Sense Media released a census on children's media usage in the United States, which we shared with this Legislature and which Senator Jackson cited some statistics from. And as she said some of our census shows that kids are using up to nine hours of media usage every day,

that does not include the usage that they have at school as well. So that's nine hours of their free time that they're spending. The media content they consume and create has a profound impact on their social, emotional, cognitive, and physical development.

Innovations and technology have placed us all at a crossroads of unprecedented challenges. Parsing through the wealth of information available through digital sources has become increasingly difficult with even trusted news sources fallen victim to reporting fake news or unverified facts. The skill sets necessary to discern truth from falsehood,

and to identify bias in reporting are not limited to just one course of study. They are pervasive throughout subjects and issues. It's paramount that we develop a whole community approach which mitigates the issues that can arise from social media, reinforces critical thinking skills to discern factual content from fake news and propaganda.

And which will leverage the incredible opportunities that media and technology can provide in learning environments. SB 203 builds off the foundation, builds with the introduction of last year's digital citizenship resolution that was ACR 103 by Assemblymember Ed Chau. Which express the legislatures intent to support digital literacy and the safe and responsible use of technology in school settings.

To date, more than 5,500 educators around the country have taken this pledge to assist students in building skills that lead to better decision-making in their online activity. SB 203 is a well crafted and thoughtful compliment to other efforts in this Legislature as we work towards building a lasting and strong impact in addressing the issue of helping our students to become educated consumers of digital content. We urge your aye vote.

Thank you Mr. Chair and members. I am pleased to present to you 483, a bill jointly authored by Chair Allen to authorize $2 billion for facilities at the University of California and at the California State University. Once approved by the Legislature and signed by the Governor, this bond measure would go before the voters in the 2018 general election.

For too long, we have allowed our classroom libraries and research labs on our campuses to fall into disrepair. This bond measure will provide much needed investment in our higher education infrastructure. There's not been a higher education specific bond passed since 1994. And the bond measure approved in 2006 for infrastructure did include some higher education construction, which has since been depleted.

According to the CSU and UC, the two systems combined of capital needs of over $8 billion for short and long term projects. CSU and UC are able to provide their own funding for some construction programs through system-wide revenue bonds, but only half of their capital needs are met. This measure provides important financial backing for critical upgrades to our libraries and classrooms on our college campuses.

And I believe that voters should be given a chance to continue our proud legacy of supporting our universities and colleges. Thank you for hearing the bill, and I have witnesses from the University of California and CSU. Thank you, Senator, you may proceed, sir.
I'd appreciate an aye vote, thank you.

Thank you Chair, thank you Mr. Chairman and members. First, I want to thank the chair and his staff for their hard work in drafting amendments with my office. I will be accepting all of the proposed amendments that have been put forward. Senate Bill 806 clarifies state law, and applies new standards to ensure that-
That's correct. Is there a reference point?

So this bill clarifies state law and applies new standards to ensure that charter schools operate with transparency and free of financial conflict of interest involving their board members and their executives. The bill does five major things. First, it applies the California Public Records Act to charter schools.

Secondly, it applies the state open meeting laws to charter schools. Third, it applies the state Political Reform Act to charter schools. Fourth, it applies the self-dealing or conflict of interest provisions of the corporation code to charter schools and creates a system for school districts and other authorizers can use to enforce those laws.

And finally, it bans for profit charter schools from operating in California as of July 1st, 2019. I'm a long time supporter of charter schools. As many of you know, charter schools at their best are innovative local schools run by parents, teachers, and members of the community.

They serve in this sense operating at the neighborhood level. They are the most local part of our public education system and indeed, the most local of our local governments. This Legislature passed the law enabling Californians to create charter schools

in 1992 in order to encourage experimentation and local control in an environment as free as possible from state and school district regulations. And like all public institutions, including public schools, charter schools occasionally stray from their mission of serving students and

instead, take actions that are design to serve the interest of the adults in charge. These incidents, while relatively rare, can receive extensive media coverage. Opponents of charter schools sometimes seize the opportunity to smear the entire movement with a very broad brush. Charter schools are public schools.

They are funded with tax payer dollars and like all public schools, are accountable to the public and the communities they serve. That's why I think it's important to ensure that charter schools operate in a transparent fashion and avoid conflict of interest. Let me make a couple, go into the weeds just a little bit, and then I know I have witnesses who can elaborate on some of these matters.

But as I mentioned, this bill does apply to the state's existing open meeting laws, public records and Political Reform Act to charter schools. With limited changes in those provisions to reflect the unique nature of charter school operations. For example, some charter schools area part of a bigger nonprofit foundation.

That have missions far broader than the operation of the school. It wouldn't be appropriate to apply open meeting laws to the entire foundation, so we target those provisions only at board meetings that involve the school. Also, 806 applies to charter schools, the elements of the California Corporation Code.

Provisions that prohibit conflict of interest and adds more. It would require charter board members to recuse themselves from any vote affecting their own financial interest. And the bill puts in place a process for charter school authorizers, mainly school districts, to follow when the authorizer has reasons to believe that a school's leadership has violated these conflict of interest provisions.

These violations, if proven, can lead to the removal of board members and the termination of school employees. And if the problem is systemic, the authorizers can force the resignation of the entire school leadership. Ultimately, just as under current law, a school district could revoke a charter, and put the school out of business. This bill also bans for profit schools, and prohibits for profit companies

from influencing the selection and direction of school leadership. And it also limits the role that for profit companies can provide, serve assisted nonprofit schools for educational programs. With me today is Rand Martin, representing the Charter Schools Association. And I look forward to his testimony and your questions.

Thank you, Mr. Chair and members, Rand Martin on behalf of the California Charter Schools Association. First, for those of you who haven't been around very long, a little history lesson. This issue has been with us for about a decade. We have been working, Roger is nodding his head up there. We have been negotiating this.

Working through the various pieces of this since about 2009 and what you see today reflects a lot of that negotiation. The negotiation occurred with the California School Boards Association and the California's Teacher Association and others over the last decade. So we have made a lot of progress, to the point where CCSA actually agrees, as we have for a number of years.

That the Political Reform Act, Public Records Act, and the Brown Act should apply to charter schools. That level of transparency is critical. Some of the other things that are new that Senator Glazer has outlined in the bill are new this year but we support those as well. What it leaves us with is the one issue that has caused some

friction over the years as we've tried to get this issue resolved once and for all. And that's the issue of government code 1090. And I'm going to speak a little bit about that, but my colleague here, Marcia Aaron from KIPP LA will also speak to it, because she has personal experience with it. But the important thing about government code 1090 is that it bans absolutely a charter school board member, and some executive staff,

from participating in financial actions that accrue to the benefit of the charter school. So if you have a board member who has taken out a second mortgage on his home, and to help keep the doors open, under government code 1090, that board member would be prohibitive from doing that. Or would not be able to serve on the board, or if he did, it would go to jail.

A board member who has a facility that he could lease to the school for a dollar a year, would be prohibited under government code 1090 from doing that. Those are the kinds of people that we want to have on our boards of directors. Many of you have sat on nonprofit boards of directors.

I certainly have over the years. And I know the demands on us, as board members, is to do everything we can to keep that entity alive. And sometimes that goes beyond just raising funds. It also goes to taking extraordinary actions to make sure that the doors were open.

When the state was in the depths of the recession, and the Legislature and the Governor were seeking deferrals on payments to schools, including charter schools. School districts were able to go out and get bridge loans of 2 and 3%. Charter schools were able to go out and get bridge loans of 13, and 14, and 15%.

So of course was not appropriate and not helpful. And so, we had board members who were willing to step up and keep charter school doors open until the recession ended and the money started flowing again. So it's critically important that we don't take what we know is a good government measure but

in this context is an impediment and a harm to charter schools, and impose that on them. The last thing I want to point on the issue of for profit is that this is an issue we have long believed that charter schools should not be operated by for-profit entities.

We are there for the kids. The money is there for the kids. The money is not there to make a profit off of. It's great to have for profit vendors who will work with our schools and we think those should be continued.

But the operation of the school itself should be left to a nonprofit entity. We have created some firewalls though to ensure that a for profit contractor can not through backdoor means exert undue influence. And there are three firewalls in there, one that prohibits them through engaging in selecting or influencing who's on the board of directors.

Selecting, or approving, or vetoing a budget. Or supervising more than, according to the amendments that Senator Glazer has accepted, more than 25% of the teachers on staff in that charter school. So we think that both those deal with some very, very important issues.

I do want to raise one additional point because a question has been raised that I want to make sure is answered. There is language in the bill that occupies the field of conflict of interest language. In the print version it also occupies the field of open meetings and Public Records Act. In an agreement with the Chair last night we have decided to limit that occupy the field language to just conflict of interest.

That means that the authority for a school district to impose additional requirements on open meeting or public records will be restored to the school district in the context of the amendments that Senator Glazer has just accepted. So it is broadening transparency back to where it was under current law, rather than restricting it on the open meetings and public records. And I will close with that and be available for any questions when appropriate.
Mr Chair and Senators, Seth Bramble here on behalf of the California Teachers Association. We do oppose Senate Bill 806 which the author has named-

No worries, Mr. Chair. The author named this Bill the Charter Schools Transparency and Standards of Governance Act of 2017. You'll see very diverse opposition here, but this bill would more appropriately be named the Betsy Devos, Donald Trump, deregulation of corporate Charter Schools Act. Charter schools do not have to comply with many laws.

And this bill seeks to peel away the few protections we have, even in the face of a steady stream of waste, fraud, and abuse in the charter school environment. The sponsors of the bill suggested some kind of deal with CTA and that, there is some kind of agreement with three our of four of the transparency accountability provisions that apply at charter schools.

To be clear, that's absolutely not true. They're asking for special carve outs of the Brown Act as they apply to charter schools. Special carve outs of Public Records Act as they apply to charter schools. Special carve outs of the Political Reform Act as they relate to charter schools.

And we simply don't agree that charter schools are or should be, above the law when it comes to tax dollars. Charter schools receive public funding. And the sponsors need to stop telling their members that they do not have to follow the laws that all public schools must follow with respect to accountability and transparency, of public money.

We did distribute a opinion by Legislative Council that opines, not only these three laws already apply at charter schools, but so does government code 1090. The government code 1090 subjects governing board members to criminal prosecution for self dealing in efforts to protect tax dollars. It makes clear that no member of the governing board may have a financial interest in the decisions before the board.

The sponsor and the author are suggesting that the conflict of interest provisions within the corporations code are sufficient. But the corporations code allows half of the governing board to be making a profit from the contracts that they're approving. This is because the corporations code protects the corporation. While government code 1090 protects the public and protects our tax dollars.

This bill removes the requirement that charter schools comply with government code 1090. And I have to ask, why now? Last month, I did pass out this article, last month, the FBI raided the offices of Celerity Education Group, that manages Los Angeles-based charter schools.

Celerity CEO Stephanie Mcfarland signed a ten-year lease with Celerity Development. Who owns Celerity Development? Stephanie Mcfarland. The LA Times reported that this made her both the landlord and the tenant of the sites on which she placed Celerity Dyad Charter School.

And over the next few years, she revised the terms of the lease, increasing the rent that her school paid to her company. Stephanie Mcfarland was perhaps listening to the sponsors of the bill when she hosted a staff party with tax dollars meant for California classrooms. And when I say staff party, I'm talking about Hollywood. I'm talking about casinos. I'm talking about limousines. I'm talking about an open bar. We're also very concerned.

I mean I heard the author say that there's been a highlight here and there. This is a case that occurred literally three weeks ago. There's been a pattern that's outlined in a report that I passed out earlier to the Members of the Committee that documents $81 million of waste, fraud, and abuse of tax dollars in the California public charter school environment alone.

We're also very concerned about the portion of the bill that's intended to create confusion, about what kind of relationship a for-profit corporation can have with a charter school. For example, the bill suggests that a for-profit corporation cannot hire half of the teachers. Can they hire the principle?

Can McDonald's hire a McDonald's employee to be the principle of the school and then paint the gigantic McDonald's mural on the school and have McDonald's for lunch everyday? And direct the teachers to have all the students do projects where they go around town promoting Mcdonald's French fries? I know that there's language in there about they can't supervise.

What is the difference between supervising, directing, hiring, all of this is made very blurry by the language in this bill. Creating confusion in charter school law will not help us focus our resources on helping children reach their full potential. We urge your no vote.

give to a non profit, in which they are not involved. And I didn't want to leave you with the impression yesterday that you gotta seat on the board because you did this stuff. What has happened more frequently is, you are on the board already and these things come up and you step up as a board member and do it extraordinary things.

But you do it because you're a board member, not because you want to pat on the back, not because you want to seat on the board, but because you care. If you care about a non-profit, to do those kinds of extraordinary things and they cannot by state law allow you to participate in an impactful way generally in the governance.
Then most people will look for some place else to go, and we don't want those people to go some place else because they are serving us.

Mr Chairman. Senator I appreciate your sentiment. I think we're not that far apart all though I know this is not something you're comfortable with going forward with today. And the politics sometimes is the art of the possible.

And the Governor has vetoed things along the lines that which you desire twice. And now we have nothing. And in his veto message, he addressed this issue that you're raising and he said starting at. And I'm quoting now, starting at charter school requires the strong commitment of dedicated individuals willing to serve on a governing board.

And it went on to explain why he was vetoing those other efforts that go along the lines of I know that you desire. And I think that what I'm trying to do here is try to find that middle ground, where there are things that there is support for doing. So can we advance those? And on the conflict of interest, we try to be more specific and clear about ways in which board members have to conduct themselves, recusal.

That conflict of interests are very well spelled out. We create remedies for the authorizer better than what exists today, in terms of going after boards that don't act properly, as it does happen. And so I appreciate that it doesn't get to where you want to be on the conflict line. But we're just trying to find a middle ground that advances better than what is there today.

Senator, as a matter of fact, there is nothing in the statute that makes these provisions apply to charter schools. As a matter of practice, and perhaps as a matter of opinion, as Mr. Bramble has indicated. They do or should apply, based on how you read the intent of those laws. And in fact, CCSA, among its best practices, and many of the attorneys that we work with, have encouraged charter schools to comply with,

at least the Brown Act, Public Records, and Political Reform Act. But what we want to see in the law. Is it clarified, in statute, that these things apply once and for all. So we don't ever have a question again, between Mister Bramble and myself, about what applies.

So regarding that question, Dr. Pan, I hear that the Charter Schools Association recommends their folks follow some of these laws. At the same time, they also say you don't have to follow these laws, which is extremely problematic. I would go so far as to say, about 90% of the legal community would say very clearly. That what the law says, in current form, is that charter schools, in their waiver,

have a waiver from the laws that uniquely apply to school districts. That's that big blue book, the Education Code. These laws we're talking about is not in the education code. This is Government Code 1090, the Open Meetings,

Open Records, and Political Reform Act are not part of their waiver. And so, the Legislative Council, for example, we've asked over a series of years, what their opinion is on the matter to make it clear. And they've made it very clear, that all four of these laws do currently apply. We've been running a bill to try and just clarify that.
Because we feel like there's been a lot of cases, where the confusion about whether they need to follow these laws has resulted in serious cases of waste, fraud, and abuse of tax dollars.

And there has been, in alignment with Legislative Council opinion. The FPPC that does the work of enforcing the Political Reform Act has been asked this question, on a couple of occasions. And it has written letters that I can provide to you, opining that, again, charter schools must comply with the Political Reform Act. It's very much in alignment with Legislative Council's opinion.

Let us say, Senator Pan, we agree, and I think Mr. Bramble would agree with me. That we agree that the Brown Act, the Political Reform Act, and the Public Records Act should apply to charter schools. Or, should be in the statute applying to charter schools. I think where the difference is, and he can speak for himself.

There are a couple of things that we have added to the bill, that are relatively modest. And I can tell you what those are, if you want to understand how modest they are, that reflect the specific needs of a charter school. For example, under the Brown Act, you currently cannot meet with a teleconferencing capability, if you happen to be in a remote location.

What we want to provide, especially for those networks that operate in multiple counties. Is to make sure that there is real-time teleconferencing availability, for parents in the county in which the board is not meeting. So we want to make things more transparent with that provision, make sure that more parents are engaged in the process. And unfortunately, CTA objects to that, thinking that is not appropriate.

And I would agree there, that we object to that in a big way. There's no replacement for sitting in a room with folks in your community, to have this kind of open meeting. The idea that somebody, if they want to run a school in LA, and they want to run a school in San Francisco, should be able to have some kind of virtual governing board meeting is inappropriate. If you want to run a school in LA, you have a meeting in LA, where the community can get to it.

And if you want to run one in San Francisco, and you take that on to do those two locations? Then you need to have a governing board meeting in each of those locations. I think that in all three of these cases, the Charter School Association is asking for carve-out. So, just briefly on the other two.

And I understand there may be some agreement that's occurred around the Public Records Act that I'm not familiar with, so I need to get up to speed on whatever that agreement was. But in terms of the Political Reform Act, my understanding was the Association was looking to not allow someone to have their charter school revoked simply because someone refused.

Or didn't, for whatever reason, declare they had a financial interest in something that was occurring before the governing board. The idea being that, you can't be revoked for breaking the law about potential conflicts of interest? That's moving away from transparency. Just as not having a governing board meeting in the community where you are locating the school is moving away from transparency and accountability to that community. It's not a step forward, it's a huge step backwards.

I mean, we would like to clarify current law. We would like to make it clear, these are the laws that you need to follow. Any step moving away from transparency and accountability is not something we would support in a charter school environment.

And Dr. Pan? There are only, after the amendments that Senator Glazer took, there are only two tweaks left. I mean, one is the one I described. We think that expands transparency to have parents anywhere

Where in the state be able to participate, in real time, with a board of directors meeting, that's number one. The second one is what we have in the bill, and this was supported in earlier versions of the bill by the CTA. That you cannot revoke a charter school solely on the basis of a single board member failing to file their Form 700. That would be like kicking you out of the Legislature for failing to file your forms 100.

So all we're saying is don't revoke us on that. But that is the only tweak to the political reform act. And with the amendments taken, there are no tweaks to the Public Records Act. So we agree on all three of those laws. We would like to see those two tweaks in addition. And it that's objectionable to the CTA. At this point I don't know what to say.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman and members for thoughtful conversation. None of us wanted to be Groundhog Day again, where we just keep repeating the same fight to no resolution. And I think as the Chair has indicated, this does provide a lot more clarity in areas of which members feel are important, open meetings, public records, conflict of interest. On the for profit issue, I'm sensitive the Senator from Stockton on that, and we certainly had some testimony.

And I'd be willing to change, we had a closure date, as I indicated in my opening, of was it July of, what was the date?  Yeah, I would be comfortable changing that to the time for renewal Which for many for profits would extend to their five year renewal period which, I don't know if that goes 2021 or 2022 in some cases. Which I think would provide a little more comfort for those for-profits that are concerned about this change.
I would also say that I'd be supportive of changing the board member interest element to below market rate, as the Chair has suggested. So I'm happy to Incorporate that as well.

I think the newspaper publisher issues are resolved by the amendments. And I would hope that they would be, but I'm certainly open to the continuing conversation with them to see whether that resolves their concerns that they have. And finally, given the challenge, even though this hearing today

where unfortunately name calling comes into play and folks are on all sides of the issue. I think we are trying to provide some progress and I think that moving the bill forward today will help do that. And hope to, I think get 90% of the way there, to where I think we want to be. So, thank you for you consideration. I ask for an aye vote.
You want to start?

Instead, what we'd like to remind you is that your locally elected school board members routinely evaluate data, research, and statistics to inform their decisions. There's really nothing unique about the issue before you in that respect. The Local Control Accountability Plan, which was approved by this Legislature,

formalized the process by which governing boards assess the needs of their students, set goals, and select among a broad range of interventions, those that best fit the needs of their students. There's nothing unique about school start time that merits taking the decision, this decision out of the hands of those who know the student in particular in this particular community best.

Many California schools districts as have been mentioned have considered adopting later start times and after doing their due diligence and gathering input from students, parents, and employees, most of these decided that later start times were not a good fit for them. As has been mentioned, some take some initial steps to move to later start times,

encounter some difficulty, and find a need to reverse course. This bill would take that option away from them. Later start times, excuse me, the list of reasons that districts might opt not to do this is too long to get into so I'll refer you to the letters that I've submitted,

but typically student safety is the single top concern. The reason for that is that later start times leave most working parents unable to take their children to school. It leaves parents with two choices. One, you, under this bill, would leave children as young as 11 years old responsible for

getting themselves to school because secondary school, we're talking all the way down to sixth grade, we have more middle schools than junior highs in California. Option number two is dropping off your child at school at the time that you can drop them off, which is the time you're dropping them off now, when there my not be anyone there to supervise them. Both of those options present a safety concern for children.

I remind you that we are living in the era of school choice, as you are well aware from some of the previous bills. And not all children attend a neighborhood school that's within a short walking distance. And I will also remind you that people transportation resources are very much lacking in this state, so most school districts have to prioritize busing for students in in special education programs.

The only way to mitigate the impact of such a sweeping mandate and keeping kids safe for this bill to become law would be for the Legislature to provide funding for near universal before school programming. And we note that the current before and after school programming, the funding is limited as it stands under the current demand. But of course, that would mean that the children who stand to gain the most potentially from later start times

would actually end up starting their day at roughly the same time that they're starting now. I can address the proposed amendments of detail, if that's the will of the chair, but suffice it to say that they don't address our concerns. Additional start time to, excuse me, additional time to implement the bill won't

make any difference if the real world conditions that conflict with the mandate still exist in the future. Namely that parents still won't have the ability to dictate to their employers what time they're going to start their work day. The loss of one period in the school day would still be a problem for, for example, a high-achieving high school student who is trying to get in as many advanced placement classes as possible.

That still puts them at a disadvantage for competing for admission to selective colleges and universities, so even though the amendments say that the bill is silent on what is now being rebranded as zero period that's what used to be first period. So we're still pushing and we're still losing that first period of the day in the morning. We are limited as to how late we can push the end time for

all of the reasons you're aware of for other things that children need to be doing, including being home with their families, and eating dinner, and going to sleep. To recap, the research recommending later start times is certainly strong enough to warrant individual governing boards to consider it. But, studies of small groups of school districts in states far less diverse than California do not warrant the risky experiment that SB 328 asks you to undertake.

No state has ever imposed start times after 8:30 AM across all of its secondary schools. Is the most populous state in the nation the right place to test this? CSBA asks you to allow the elected educational governing board members of this state to continue to determine which interventions best meet the needs of their students and their communities, we respectfully ask for your no vote.

Mr. Chair and Senator Seth Bramble, here on behalf of the California Teachers Association, I do have to start by setting the record straight. In the last testimony I gave, I was referring to someone named Steffanie Mcfarland, who actually I know and respect. I meant to sat Vioka Mcfarland. I got corrected when I got back into the crowd. So I appreciate you guys understanding on that matter.

We are in opposition to this proposal. With our structure, we have more than 325,000 educators in the State of California and we come together in group, an elected body of 800 of our Education leaders called CTA State Council. They came together and had conversations about this.

And I would say it wasn't very controversial. In fact, nobody spoke to the desire to support this kind of a policy in the state. Someone told the story, for example of their school district having some lengthy conversations with stake holders and the community,

determining whether they were going to moving their state time, their start time to after 8:30am and deciding that would require them to purchase nine more school buses. They wanted to use that money instead to purchase counselors and lower class sizes. So, you know, I heard, certainly, the Senator say it wasn't maybe made in the best interests of kids, I guess I would say in this case it was.

They were considering whether we should have support staff on campus, etc, and it was a priorities conversation. Ultimately, any school district, community, can come together with the stakeholders and decide they want to have schools start after 8:30, we would urge your opposition to developing this statewide mandate on all schools local control.

Thank you, chair, I just appreciate the opportunity to try to explain myself further if there was some misunderstanding. My comment about zero period, just to be clear, if school is required to push it's start time back by an hour, and the optional period that proceeds that is now called zero period, whereas it used to be called first period. We are still losing what is currently called zero period, so that's what I want to clarify.

The other thing, and I understand how this could be confusing for us to say that we accept the scientific research and yet still don't want this to be a state-wide mandate, so let me help bridge that gap. We understand the strength of the research here, so what we have all been presented with is a body of research that is intended to support only one intervention.

The reason that you have locally elected governing boards is because they review the research on this intervention, along with the research on how it might benefit students to hire additional guidance counselors. How it might benefit your students to reduce class sizes, to change your pupil discipline policies, a million other things.

We consider that, in context with what that community needs, with what those individual students need, and many other factors. So that's how we take no issue with the science, but we just wish to remind you that there are many other factors to consider.

One very quick example, this Legislature's very well aware that the research is very strongly supportive of a 12 to 1 pupil to teacher ratio. But you haven't mandated that either, and the reason for that is because it's one of many potentially powerful interventions. And there are many other factors to consider.

Christopher Sanchez, policy advocate with CHIRLA. The Coalition for Humane Immigrant Rights. Proud to be a cosponsor of this legislation. I'm going to keep my comments brief because the Senator made excellent comments stating how

many parents are intimidated by the IEP process, especially when their primary language is not English. We believe this bill creates a fair process, especially ensuring that there's a quality of translation. When there is not a quality translation it's unfortunate that parents are not able to understand what they're signing.

And simple things such as accent marks are actually really needed in translation and if people don't properly put them, well then words might be misinterpreted and parents aren't knowing what they're signing. So for those reasons, we're proud to support this bill because it brings a fair and better process to the IEP for immigrant families.
Pamela Gibbs representing the Los Angeles County Office of Education and we're in support. Having the responsibility to approve school districts within the county, numbering 80, thank you.
I'm in University of California, so I wanted to-

Yeah briefly my name is Angela Gilliad I'm with I'm the Legislative Director for the University of California. And quite frankly, we've looked at this issue both last year and this year. And our office has been committed to working with Senator Lara's staff. I think we've had some very productive conversations over the past couple of years. The issue for the University and the concern with the University is currently,

students who are undocumented do not have a pathway for medical residency programs because of federal law. It is not a state law constraint. DOCA students can go into medical residency programs without an issue at this point, and so the issue for us is really finding a legal pathway.

With me today as the Dean of Graduate Medical Education for UC-Davis, and we've been here kind of awhile. So I'd like for you to be able to at least hear some of the high points of why we feel that it's problematic. But also I want you to hear that we're committed to working going forward.

Well, this one. And SB 203, which is, these both Our efforts with Danny Kando-Kaiser with Common Sense Kid's Action. We believe that this thoughtfully leverages not just past efforts but also current efforts, again, SB 203 to ensure that the best practices and

resources are being developed over the course of the next few years. And are incorporated in course work that students can use and are institutionalized to ensure that the development of critical thinking and digital literacy throughout the state is happening. We're very excited to be working with Senator Dodd on expanding our vision and creating this curriculum that we feel will fully support educators. So we urge an I vote. Thank you.

Toni Trigueiro, on behalf of the California Teacher's Associations. We believe that a successful library program not only provides a very safe haven for students, but they assist teachers with curriculum assistance, expertise in digital literacy, training, and academic research, all of which are critical in the 21st century.
For the reasons that have been stated before, and because of the length of the Committee hearing, I'm going to stop there, and ask for your aye vote. Thank you very much.
Good afternoon, chair, and Members of the Committee. I'm Michael Mcgee, with California Community College, Chancellor's Office, we're also in support of this measure, thank you.
Pamela Gibbs, representing the Los Angeles County Office of Education, in strong support. Thank you.
Kelly Brooks, on behalf of the Association of California Healthcare Districts, also in support.

Mr Chair and members, Nancy Chaires Espinoza on behalf of the California School Boards Association. This bill would force upon secondary schools in California an intervention which may or may not be a good fit for their students. I want to take one big issue off the table, CSBA does not take any issue with the science that's been presented.
Mr. Chairman, I'm going to come back to with more questions after this.

Thank you. So you've mentioned the number of conferences that have been held and the VITA the V-I-T-A events I don't see in your reports and maybe I've missed it the number of participants in each of these events. Could you speak to that?
So, if the event's being held to help someone prepare their taxes, And you have some number about a claim I guess about total tax revenue generated by the event. How is that number generated?

So you have no idea how many, because this could be a fantastically successful program, right? Mm-hm. But in terms of serving the public, you have no idea how the public was served or not served by these events. Right.
But you guys don't know?
Didn't you have somebody attend it and view it? We did. Was it a room full of 30 people? Was the room full of 3,000 people?
This report I believe I saw a number of.
Okay all right.

Again, thank you for being here, your last statement was structural reforms, and I know we're going to go there, but one of the central conclusions from Department of Finance was the operational culture doesn't seem to say structure, operations, does that mean structure to you?
And Mr. Chairman, if I may, that's in the boxes below you. Is that what you're referring to there?
Is that what you're saying there?

And has there always been these blurred lines, in your experience, between the ability of a board member or members outside of the governing board's decision making structure, to direct staff, to do certain things and allocate certain things in different ways? Was that a problem 10 years ago, 20 years ago?
So then you're underscoring Finance's conclusion about a cultural, how did they describe it, they called it an operational culture.

Okay, well, I have to say some this does surprise me, because the structure that which you have, and obviously there's some oversight that the BOE has that other cities and counties and other special districts don't have, to some extent. But if you put aside your responsibilities, the structure that's set up for you guys is not a lot different than hundreds of cities in California, how they operate today.

Where if you have a council member who says, to somebody in that city, and it's not a, what do you call it, the strong mayor form of government, which some cities do have, most of them do not, and you have a Council Member that calls down into the ranks to say to the head of planning, I need you to approve this project that's coming before the Planning Commission, which would be an inappropriate engagement by a Council Member.

They know how the city manager, the director knows how to handle that. That's an inappropriate contact, if not illegal, improper in how the structure of the organization's been created. And you're saying that, over time that has been eroded to the extent that the executive office, you and your predecessors,
have never been able to manage that interference in your direct responsibilities as the executive officer.
And you used the word pervasive, you were referring to that relationship and that interactions-
And so did you provide that? Did you write that?
This is a real dilemma for me, because I know we're going to go to the structure here and

certainly there's the appearance that board members have enacted within the rules, guidelines, laws and I know that that's a touchy subject. But I also have to say that, and I know, to the Executive Officer, you're new to this, a year, right? But a lot of times, people in positions like yours, and

maybe your predecessor made these choices, they just wouldn't let this stuff go on. That you would be informed immediately by a subordinate if they'd been contacted by a board member, pick any organization you want, public or private. Really, public or private, if someone went down in the org chart from your board above you and contacted them on any matter,
if they're doing their job right, they're going to inform the executive officer, wouldn't you say that's the case?
I'm out of here. That's not what you have me here to do. And so, I know there may be some structural changes we'll discuss, but I do see breakdowns at all levels here. And I mean it with all respect.
To who, who do they opine to? Under what circumstances?
Is there a disclosure requirement with that regard?

Sorry, Mr. Chairman, that's it. There is no disclosure requirement. Are you aware of any similar circumstance in a quasi-judicial fashion, where it's allowed, but there is no disclosure to the full body?
I understand, but there is Coastal Commission. There is all kinds of other boards that have to sit and quasi, almost every City Council in the land has issue for that matter.
And there's no disclosure requirement in your rules?

Good afternoon Mr. Chair and members, Dorothy Johnson with the California State Association of Counties. We want to express out appreciation to the Legislature and the administration for looking into this issue in the near term to achieve greater accuracy, accountability and efficiency with the state BOE. The BOE's central role was sales tax allocation to counties has been a major area of concern as of late. This is in light of the most recent state controller audit.

And the revelation that there may be millions, hundreds of millions of dollars in sales tax revenue, that's been misallocated for counties which remains open unfortunately. And in light of our close relationship between the State in terms of delivering services and program administration, we would hope that CSAT can be closely involved in the development and review of solutions,

to improve future sales tax allocation and avoid any similar problems that we've experienced. Either with the 2014 review, or again with this most recent incident. So thank you for that time and comments.
Nicholas Chavez on behalf of the Golden State Manufactured Home Owners League, in support.

Yes, Victoria Rome with the Natural Resources Defense Council here in support of SB 709 and we've done a lot of work looking at potential expansion of tar sands oil and coming into the West Coast, there is some coming in now as you may have heard,

Senator leyva, we did have this discussion and I appreciate where you're coming from. And frankly, I wish that everybody who participated in what non profits do, had that same altruism to give and give and
Thank you, Chair and members.

The amendments that were provided were basically rewriting the proposal. I am absolutely willing to talk with the Director of Industrial Relations so that we can try to work something out that includes some of what they are recommending in my proposed, in AB 44. I don't think that we have had further discussion with the Director, but
I certainly would love to have that discussion and find a way to incorporate some of what they are recommending. Specifically, the ombudsman.

On December 2nd, 2015, San Bernardino was a site of an appalling act of violence that resulted in the deaths of 14 people and dozens seriously injured. The gunman entered his work site and began shooting at his co-workers in what was later described as a terrorist attack. The trauma suffered by the survivors did not end on that day.

As this incident occurred at a work-related function, the medical claims were subject to the workers' compensation system. Countless press articles, as well as my own conversations with survivors, have revealed that the workers' compensation system in California was not prepared for the scale and scope of the December 2nd attack.

Well over a year after the attack, survivors were still reporting treatment denials. These employees have gone through secondary trauma trying to make sense of claims, paperwork, and deal with denials and delays in medical care or equipment, counseling, physical therapy, and prescriptions.

Treatment recommended by the employer-approved physicians was denied to the injured workers because of the utilization review process put in place. The employer lamented in media interviews that their hands were tied. This incident has revealed that our workers' compensation system is not well-tailored for victims of terror attacks. These were battlefield injuries involving bullets and shrapnel,

wounds with long term psychological injuries, such as PTSD. It is unclear under the existing system whether utilization review physician has the expertise to appropriately evaluate someone who has suffered injuries more likely to be suffered on the battlefields of Iraq and Afghanistan than in the workplace.

AB 44 is intended to narrowly apply to circumstances similar to the December 2nd attack. This bill would exempt medical treatment for employees or first responders who sustained injury as a result of an act of terrorism or violence in the workplace from the utilization review process.

It would also add physical or psychological injury arising from terrorism or workplace violence to the list of injuries for which aggregate disability payments may be made for not more than 240 weeks. This bill is not intended to undo our existing system but

rather to ensure that the December 2nd survivors receive the treatment they deserve and ensure that in the future, should something like this ever happen again, that employees would not be victimized for a second time. I commit to continue to work with all stakeholders to find a mutual solution. I want to end with this.

Many have said that many lessons have been learned in the aftermath of the December 2nd attack and that those lessons will prevent future delays and problems should we ever face another horrible attack. However, even with attempts at implementing an ombudsman, a nurse case manager, it is unclear that these delays could not happen under similar circumstances unless we commit to changing things for

those who suffer from a terrorist attack or workplace violence like these victims. I recognize that the amendment that was proposed basically undoes what my request was and basically puts in an ombudsman. And I sincerely hope that we can still work with amendments in the future to include some of what has been requested.

Here to speak in support of this measure, two injured employees who were victims of the terrorist attack. Ray Britain, who was Interim Division Chief for the county's Division of Environmental Health Services and Sally Cardinale, a program specialist with the county on the day of the attack. I'd like to ask that Sally speak first.
Thank you, and I think that what makes this different is the fact, is, are the facts of the injuries.
Good morning, Dorothy Johnson with the California State Association of Counties. I'll align my comments for second time with my colleague from the urban counties, thank you.
Yes. Actually today I came to say that I was not going to accept the amendments. I recognize that that is not the way it's going to go. But I do look forward to working with the stakeholders

to come to make this a meaningful bill. To extend benefits to those who are victims of a terrorist attack, to provide, excuse me, what they have suffered is unbelievable. But to actually provide benefits to them in a way that is correct.
Thank you. Yes Mr. Chair.

Thank you Mr. Chairman, members. Michael Gunning, Personal Insurance Federation. I think we can all agree that an informed consumer makes the best choices. Whether that's buying a vacuum cleaner or buying a car, getting your car fixed, information is critical. It is our belief that the Department of Insurance Regulations on steering prohibit truthful,

non-deceptive, non-misleading statements by insurers to their insurees. The regulations hinder communications between insurers and policy holders during the car repair process and therefore need to be addressed by the Legislature. This Legislature, in 2009, with Assembly woman Mary Hayashi in AB 1200,

decided how steering would be handled in the car repair process. Insurers can share truthful, non-deceptive information about the benefits of an insurance auto policy. Simply put, this body has decided and no agency regulator, or has the authority to usurp the decision unless this authority has granted that to that body.

AB 1200, as you've heard already. It says that insurers cannot require anyone to go to a specific body shop. Allows insurers to discuss the benefits of going to a shop that has a contract in direct repair program and allows communications about warranties, timeframes, repair processes.

Members, most consumers only get in an accident once a decade, this doesn't happen a lot. So there are critical questions and issues that a consumer should know before and going into this. AB 1679 outlines these issues and allows consumers to learn key knowledge about the claim process. As we've heard from Assembly Woman Burke she outlined some of those things that we discussed.

Mr. Chairman if you'd indulge me, I would like to quote from my friend Robert Petterson of Santa Clara University School of Law, who pointed out in his comments to your Committee, a broad reading of Section 758.5 is consistent with the purpose of the 2009 amendment to section 7585,

which was to assure that claimants could be fully informed when exercising their right to choose a body shop. It is also consistent with the disclosures required by paragraph three, which goes so far as to encourage the claimant to seek a second opinion. We recommend, and this is in the statute, you contact any other automotive repair dealer you are considering

to clarify any questions you may have regarding their services and benefits. As Professor Peterson points out, it's worth noting that independent repair shops are under no similar obligation to suggest that potential customers contact any other automotive repair dealer or even recommend that they inquire of their insure about the full ambit of repair benefits under the policy.

To close, in the department's opposition letter, they state, legislation in this area should support and enhance these consumer protections, not undermine them or undermine the authority of responsible entities to enforce existing law and regulations on the insurance industry. It is our opinion that they've done exactly what they state.
Undermine the authority of responsible entities to enforce the existing law, the Legislature. Please vote aye, and I thank you.

Good morning, Mister Chairman and members, Robert Harrell Deputy Commissioner for the Department of Insurance for Legislative Affairs. We respectfully oppose Assemblymember Burke's bill and would like to make a few points to the Committee. I'm joined this morning by Tony Signorelli, deputy Commissioner for consumer services and market conduct, who was one of the architects of the regulation, in case there's additional questions that need to be answered.

These are brand-new regulations, they just took effect. And generally speaking, the approach we think makes more sense for the Legislature and other interested parties is to wait and see what the impact of the regulations are. If there is a problem down the road, then the Legislature has the ability to revisit any issue that occurs.

I will tell you that these regulations were developed over a period of years with dozens of meetings with all interested stakeholders. And so, the notion that this is some sort of hastily put together thing just is not accurate. And so, we would note that they're brand new, and literally a couple months old, and give them time to take effect first. I would note that on page three, lines five to ten of the Bill,

it says that the intent of the Bill to quote supersede in their entirety, the amendments to subdivision E of section 2695.8 of title 10 of the California Court of Regulations adopted on November 9, 2016. And the supersede any provision of that regulation in effect prior to November 9 2016 that's in conflict with section 758.5 of the insurance code.

So there is a wiping out, particularly in the area of anti steering of the regulations. And let's not pretend that that is not the case. We will also note that if these regulations were not lawful and appropriate with the statutory authority that exists with the department, the Office of Administrative Law would not have approved the regs.

If there's an issue or a conflict, that is why the office of administrative law exists. Now, to pivot a little bit to more substantively, in terms of consumer impact we are concerned that the anti steering part. The new regs that clarified and enhanced consumer protections which allow consumers to

not be steered by the insurance company to the repair shop of the insurer's choice, and allows the consumer to pick the shop of their choice, would be eroded. By eliminating new protections for consumers with significantly weaker provisions, some of these protections are wiped out. This means that, for example, to make it real, some consumers will have to wait a week or

more, or will have to drive more than 15 miles in urban areas or 25 miles in other parts of the state to merely get an estimate or an inspection of their damaged vehicle. Pivoting to the labor rate survey provisions of the legislation, ultimately, the labor rate survey provisions are really about insurers not particularly wanting to pay the prevailing wage to a body shop.

Despite their currently unfettered ability to negotiate any rate they wish with any shop that they wish in the State of California. They can do that right now under the regs, they can negotiate whatever rate they want with whatever shop they want on a bilateral basis or whatnot. They can do that right now.

That's unfettered by the regs. The labor rate provisions also treat as trade secrets, some information that in fact is not a trade secret. And that would not only shield it from the public, but in some cases, shield it from the department. We don't see how that is in consumers' best interest.

Finally, it grants the equivalent of a Good Housekeeping seal of approval, the rebuttal presumption, on virtually any survey methodology. Irrespective if it's statistically valid or logically sound or mathematically accurate, and that's obviously a concern. So we respectfully, we would welcome the opportunity to speak with the author and
the sponsors in more detail about this bill, but we respectfully oppose this morning, thank you Mister Chairman.

Thank you Mr. Speaker, members. Today I present to you ACR 56, which designates the month of April, 2017 as Sexual Assault Awareness Month. And recognizes April 26, 2017 as Denim Day California. In Rome, Italy, 1992, an 18-year-old girl was raped by her 45-year-old driving instructor.

He appealed the sentence, and the case made its way to the Italian Supreme Court. Within a matter of days, the case against the driving instructor was overturned, dismissed, and her rapist was released. In a statement by the Chief Justice, he explained, permission to read?

And I quote. Because the victim wore very, very tight jeans, she had to help him remove them. And by removing the jeans it was no longer rape but consensual sex, end quote. Enraged by the verdict, within the matter hours, the women in the Italian parliament launched into immediate action, and protested by wearing jeans to work.

Thank you very much, Mr. Chair, author. I want to start off by focusing on the environmental benefits of this bill.

To start off, my name is Dan Jacobson with Environment California. I'll let my colleagues talk to some of the other key points. I'll keep my comments brief so that we can focus on any questions that you might have. The first reason that storage is so important is because we're going to need it to save some of the solar electricity.

There's a lot of talk about our over-production of solar energy right now. Our ability to store that energy when the sun is shining and be able to use that at night is critical for the environmental benefits. The second piece that this is so important is because the alternatives to storage are often times peaker plants.

As many of you on this committee know, oftentimes those peaker plants use fossil fuels that contributes to some of the worst air quality that we have here in the state. We've just completed another report talking about California's air quality, and too many of our cities are in the top 10, so we need to take action to be able to reduce that. Third, this bill is based on a model that works.

The California Solar Initiative has proven to be a success. We cannot apply that same kind of model to this technology here and help drive down costs. And fourth is we want to make sure that we can set the table for the Pro Tem's 100% energy bill. I'm sure that'll be coming soon, there's no doubt that storage is going to be a critical component to that, programs like this will allow it to happen.

Threatened with death if she tells anyone, he made her drive the car home that day. Later that night, frightened and traumatized, she tells her parents and they helped her press charges. The perpetrator was convicted of rape and sentenced to jail, but the story does not end there.

Hi, my name's Dennis Albinoni. I'm here tonight with a Family Business Association of California. We represent the cross section of family businesses from large and small. From plumbing contractors, electrical contractors, all the way up to ones that might be in commercial trucking.

One of our main priorities this year when we sat down with the board was to address and identify regulations that are confusing and don't make sense and can add costs without any additional benefit to the consumers. So one of the keys here, and I read the analysis and it talks about towing capacity.

Well, and that some of these trucks can tow x-amount. You've got the 16,000 gross vehicle weight. The only thing that changes that is whether that truck has a commercial bed on it or a regular factory made bed.

When you get an F250 that I could still tow the same amount, if I have a factory bed on it, I'm okay. But if I've changed and I take my tools, and I put them in a utility bed, then I'm now under the BIT program

and for some reason that's less safe according to things. Well there is no safety issue, it's the bed that changes it and pushes me into that category. So I think that we need to identify that, and the financial issues on BIT is one thing.

But I also think the hours of service are significant. When a plumber leaves Long Beach, or leaves San Mateo and drives into San Francisco or Long Beach into LA and they get a job, and they work on it and the plumber gets going and maybe something doesn't set as nice as it should, and it takes an hour or two longer.

Under the hours of service rules, if he goes over the time, he's gotta stop and take the rest. That's the law, but that's crazy. So we can't get home to our family. We can't get home to whatever because we have a bed that has a utility bed on it
rather than the manufacturer's standard bed. That's the difference. So there's a lot of confusion, I think, around this and that's because the law's confusing, but the bill's very simple.

And we think that, let's bring people into compliance. Let's bring those family owned businesses, plumbers, electricians, and folks into compliance and let's move forward there. Again, our goal is to try to reduce regulations without impacting the consumers, and without impacting the state
and this is one of those bills that would result in that. So for those reasons, we would appreciate your support. We support the bill and appreciate your support as well, thank you.

It's called the Altamont Pass where everyday thousands of drivers a going over that pass. Over that pass with congestion, taking hours, sometimes a pothole will shut it down for over four hours.
