So hello, everybody, from this side of the dais. I want to start off by saying that I'll be accepting the amendments suggested by the Chair. So as we all know, over the last couple years, California has created ambitious climate and waste diversion requirements. Last year, as a legislative body we enacted SB 1183 by Senator Lara

which required the state to reduce methane emissions from landfills by diverting three quarters of the organic waste that gets disposed every year by 2025. This will require significant investment in the develop of composting facilities, anaerobic digesters, and other recycling outlets to process nearly 15 million tons of material each year.

It is estimated that at least 30 to 100 large scale facilities will be needed to meet the goals of SB 1383. AB 1288 seeks to find sustainable funding sources to build the organic waste recycling infrastructure that will be necessary for local governments and the solid waste industry to meet the state's climate and diversion requirements. We are working with the industry, local government, and environmental groups

to develop the best way to achieve the organic waste goals and put less burden on repairs. This bill asks CalRecycle to conduct at least one public workshop to discuss funding strategies for new and expanded organic waste reduction infrastructure using a combination of existing public and private models and opportunities for a new statewide funding source. It is critical that we find a win-win-win situation for the environment,

rate payers, and those who have to implement SB 1383. Here with me to testify, I have Cara Martinson with the California State Association of Counties. Chuck Helget with Republic Service, and our good friend from Waste Management, Nick. Californians Against Waste. Nobody likes waste. We're against it.

Yes, please. I just want to acknowledge and thank the coalition who has been working so hard on this. It's a very complex issue, everybody has come to the table, even Waste Management, and we're excited to be able to continue to move this forward. So I respectfully ask for your aye vote.
Good evening, Victoria Rome with the Natural Resources Defense Council in support.

I just wanted to say, I did not vote for Mr. Berman's bill, and I won't be able to support your bill today. Now I have, as you've suggested, many of us have served on local governments. I served on the Stockton City Council before Detroit,

the largest city in the State of California to have to enter into bankruptcy. And part of that was a direct result of the issues of white flight, and people moving out of the downtown core, sprawling all over the farmland and countryside. Buying homes at, then we know, at very inflated prices.

When the home prices dropped the recession hit, everybody left and we were left with a giant mess. So the idea of making it more easy to develop out in other areas where shouldn't be is not something that I will be able to support.
But I do appreciate the initiative and understand that your area might be different than mine.

Good morning, Mister Chair, members, Victoria Rome with the Natural Resources Defense Council here in support. Just briefly, the bill allows for additional funding and authority to clean up not just abandoned and deserted wells, but also the production facilities that can cause environmental and public health risks and safety risks to our citizens. And we urge your aye vote. Thank you.
Yes, Victoria Rome with NRDC in support, thank you.

Yes, thank you, Victoria Realm with NRDC Yeah, just modernizing and updating record keeping so that the public has access to some of this important information is very important, and we support the bill, thank you.

I will also be brief. Jennifer Fairing, on behalf of Defenders of Wildlife. We do have concerns about the uncertainty of our current administration and the experience. And I think this will be an empowering bill to state officials to move forward with strong conservation marine policies and we urge your aye vote.

Thank you.>>Good morning Mr. Chair and members. Karen Lang on behalf of the Delta Counties Coalition. It's the five counties that ring the delta, San Joaquin, Contra Costa, Solano, Sacramento and Yolo. They've been working together for almost a decade on everything related to the delta,

when it was the BDCP and now it's the California Water Fix. Setting aside the actual merits of building the tunnels, which the counties have remained very skeptical of, there's a deep concern about how they're going to be paid for. Particularly, given the failure of the Oroville Dam, the same people that would be benefiting from the tunnels also benefit from the Oroville Dam and now, they're going to have to pay for that.

So, there seems to be a diminishing amount of revenue available unless you increase rate payer costs in order to cover the construction of both the tunnels and also the Oroville Dam repairs. We would like to see increased transparency from the delta counties, giving the fact that these tunnels are going to go through at least two of them, that can have major impacts on the counties themselves.

We want to make sure that they're not going to be bearing any costs associated with the impacts of that. We're also a little bit concerned about the beneficiary pay's principles, it's very good to hear metropolitan water district talking about that on a previous bill. We'd love to see it for the tunnels, considering some estimates I think done by Dr. Michael showed it was 20 cents on the dollar in terms of how much they're going to pay versus how much you're going to get.

And finally, I just wanted to point out to the Committee that there's an ongoing audit related to the expenditures that DWR has made so far in constructing the tunnels or being a proponent for the tunnels. I think it would be wise to take that into account when the Legislature and the administration consider the tunnels going forward. And finally, I wanted to observe also that as far as the funding that's being committed,

at least one of the proponents has been fined for the SEC for some of their accounting. So, we're also deeply concerned about when they say they can afford it, how are they really going to pay for it? Is the money really there? And if it's not, what's going to happen to the delta county?
So, for all these reasons, we're in support of the Assemblymen's bill today and ask for your aye vote. Thank you.
Chris Kahn, representing Coachella Valley Water District in opposition.
Reggie Collins from California Trout and we support.

a problem with how we store it, but nobody agrees on the solution. So our best source of being able to store and use water is underground aquifers. To be able to recharge our aquifers is probably one of the most important things we can do for

sustainability. As the law currently stands, diverting water underground is considered a beneficial use only if that water is subsequently extracted for consumptive beneficial use within a five year period. If you don't take it back out right away and use it, then you've lost your right to that water. The need to address this

conflict was recognized by the administration during discussions on the Sustainable Groundwater Management Act, but efforts at that time were sidelined. This is, again, a difficult and complicated issue, and after last time working with it we ended up to a place where we got farmers opposing so we backed away from that.
So this is another attempt to be able to address this. We are working with a coalition. Everybody's opposition at this point is well taken. We are continuing to work on this.

I am committed to finding a solution that prevents permanent damage to water basins while it protects the environment. And with me here today, I have Karen Lang from the counties, and possibly two other people I don't see sitting here now.

Okay, I'll talk slow. Just kidding. Karen Lang on behalf of the San Joaquin County Board of Supervisors. Very thankful to the Assembly woman for taking this issue on again. The last time we were before a Committee on this topic we were in the middle of a gut wrenching drought and our hope

was that we would get the legislation passed in time for the next year when we had a lot of water, which is very unfortunate that we're here when we do have a lot of water. But the county believes that with the legislation that the Assembly Member is proposing,

it would authorize them to be able to store water for more than five years. Hopefully that will get us through the next drought they believe about a million acre feet of storage that they could immediately put to use in the county, and that will help hopefully sustain them through what might be another drought.

And we've sort of, last time around, we got into a place where it was either a really big change in law or if it's just a little change because folks can already do it. San Joaquin County is telling this body that they need the legislation to be able to do this with assurance that they won't have to remove it within five years. It has huge benefits for salinity intrusion and other things of that nature.
And for all of these reasons we ask for your aye vote today. And look forward to working with the author and stakeholders.

Yeah, this part was left out when we did Sigma. This was everybody recognizes as an issue, but it's complicated, and so as you know, Sigma went through very fast without being able to deal with a lot of these issues.

So while we were telling people to manage their basins and their ground water and we're asking them to test on it. We have not provided a way for people to be able to store it as a beneficial use. The point of this bill is not to take water away from downstream, but you see articles and people screaming every day about all the water we're letting run out into the ocean.

This recognizes that at times, and again, I appreciate Mr. Manning's concern for the delta. I represent the delta area. I would not do anything to be able to harm it, but we are the apex where if the water comes in and then it flows to us then on down. And as you know down in your area, there's

no water left under the ground and it's been so taken out. This is simply the point. If they are able to store water underground when times are good, and to be able to take it out as they need it as a beneficial use. And not have them be required to say what they're going to use that for within the next five years or lose it.
That in my opinion allows more surface water to be able to go down to farmers further down the system.

Well, last year we ran in to an issue is when farmers started objecting when we were asking people with pre-1914 water rights to apply for a permit to do this. And that's where we kind of fell apart with the Ag community.

And so we're coming back at it this year and seeing if we can find that sweet spot that we weren't quite able to pinpoint last year. So, in my opinion, and this helps Ag, helps farms, this helps, I mean we all agree that overdrawing out of ground water is bad and it increases salinity, things drop.

In your district, people have to I mean the richest person's going to get that water because they have to be able to drill down as far as they can. Again, over a million acre feet of underground storage potential under our ground. We need to do everything, I think we can in a judicious way that we're not creating winners and losers.
But we're providing another option for people to be able to use water with the best resources available.

Just that we are committed to continue to work on this. I know we don't have before you right now us all singing from the same hymnal. But I guess we do all agree that water is our most precious commodity, coming out of this 10 year drought we have certainly Learned that. And this is one more tool that we are going to be able to use to manage water in the best way possible.
You can vote aye today, and then later you can take it back.
But if I don't have the votes to get it out, you'll never have that chance, right?
Good morning, Melanie Cuevas on behalf of the Viejas Band of Kumeyaay Indians, located in San Diego, also in strong support, thank you.
Steve Cruz, on behalf of the California Building Industry Association, in support.

Jennifer Williams with East Bay Municipal Utility District. We're a tweener, don't have an official position on the vote. We appreciate the author working on the issue. We know there's various approaches before you today that significant policy shifts. We encourage the Legislature thoroughly vetting those. And would like to see the bill move forward today.
Danielle Blacet with the California Municipal Utilities Association in support.
Steve Cruz for CBIA in support.
Bob Reeve, Desert Water Agency, Alta Irrigation District, and Rollin Water District, in support.
Jennifer Williams, East Bay MUD, same message, tweener, urge the bill. Move forward to keep the conversation going on all these bills.
Steve Cruz on behalf of the California Building Industry Associations, in support for the reason stated.

Jennifer Williams, East Bay Med, still a tweener. want to thank the author very much for the approach of putting the proposed trailer bill language in the policy bill, and on all of these related bills, just really want to appreciate and thank the Legislature for maybe considering these and vetting them thoroughly and we would like to see the bill advance today.

Thank you, next. My name is Danielle Blacet with the California Municipal Utilities Association, CMUA's members also support efforts to make water use efficiency a way of life and agree with enhancing the drought planning process. We respectfully oppose AB 1668 as amended on April 18th.

California water suppliers provide a vital service in the communities and are directly accountable to the customers they serve. They see first hand the impacts of drought and climate change on their systems, and work in partnership with their customers to make operational changes and encourage permanent modifications that will increase long term water use efficiency in their communities.

While the vast majority of urban water suppliers were well prepared for the latest drought, they recognize the importance of adaptation and learning lessons from every significant event affecting water supplies. In addition to the concerns raised by Aqua, which we share, I wanted to highlight an additional area for your consideration.

AB 1668 would change the law to require that water systems report the energy intensity of their water supplies and urban water management plans. We recognize the importance of the water energy nexus, as we represent energy utilities as well. But the intent of the existing statute is for the data submission to be voluntary and there's no stated purpose for the required collection of the data and

it's actually not listed as a recommendation in the Making Conservation a Way of Life report. As I mentioned, we share Aqua's concerns and we encourage this Committee and the Legislature to consider a path that both augments the current drought planning process and acknowledges the individuality in investments made by each community. We look forward to working with Assembly Member Friedman and Assembly Member Rubio on efforts moving forward.
Jennifer Williams, East Bay Med and also, appreciate the author replacing the trailer bill language into a policy bill and
urge that bill to move forward so that all the approaches can be considered.
Tim with the American Chemistry Council, for the reasons stated, thank you.

Throughout its history, Easterseals Bay Area has worked to eliminate societal barriers to people with disabilities and to connect them and their families with the resources that can make a difference in their lives.

Joining me today are Easterseals Bay Area's Chairman of the Board, Sheldon Orloff, the CEO Susan Armiger, and the Oliveri family Megan, Matt and Julia. Senators, please join me and welcome Easterseals Bay Area to the Senate Floor.

Thank you Mr Chair and members, Mike Bellot on behalf of Coalition of Deposition Services Firms which is opposed to the bill. This bill and this concept, has failed to proceed through this Committee repeatedly over the years. And there's a reason for that. It attempts to bring within the jurisdiction of the board, people who do not make the record.

large insurance companies, law firms, corporations all over the country to provide efficiency. And the problem is that, when you say you're going to subject these penalties to the same laws and regulations which apply to licensed court reporters, you have an apples and oranges situation. We have repeatedly talked to the organizations

court reporters, but when you try to apply them to this companies, they don't make sense. If you listen carefully to the testimony of the Court Reporters Board, she talked about a competitive disadvantage. That is what's going on here. This is a question of competition and we believe the ultimate effect of this,

will be to deny our companies the right to provide services to their customers around California. Interestingly, I've represented civil defense lawyers for almost 30 years here in Sacramento, and I have never once heard a complaint about transcripts or court reporting. The system works.
There is no need to extend jurisdiction of the Court Reporters Board to these companies, other than competition. We would ask for a no vote.

Good morning Mr. Chairman and members. My name is Jessica Gauger, on behalf of California Association of sanitation agencies, we are an association that represents all waste water treatment agencies in California.

We've been working with the author and sponsor on the amendments that were included in the bill last week. We think they go a long way to clarify the appropriate disposal of hydrolysate. And we appreciate that they allow individual agencies to accept this material on a voluntary

basis. So with the acceptance of the amendments we've moved to an approved position on the bill. And want to just thank the author and his staff and his sponsor for working with us to address our concerns.
Good morning, Mr. Chair and members, Connie Delgado with the California Hospital Association in support.

Thank you Mr. Chair. I'm going to thank you for bringing this forward Ms. Burke. Women have been having children for centuries with the help of midwives. Even before physicians we had midwives delivering babies

and I think as Dr. Arambula pointed out, it does come down to a woman's choice, right? When a woman chooses to have seven children at home that is her choice. We also know since the beginning of time, women and children have not always survived birth, especially African-American women.

Women of color have the highest rate of infant mortality and their own death, so I know you do not come at this lightly. I know you've been working at this for a good two years and I think we need to continue to move this forward. We know we have a problem with access around the state especially in rural areas, urban areas.

Sometimes the opposition makes it sound like midwives and are cowboys. Midwives probably are the last things from somebody who just wants to go off and act irresponsibly in the care of patient. These are people, generally, who care very deeply and are as invested in

delivering healthy babies as anybody else, perhaps more than the average bear. We don't want bears delivering babies either. So, I stand in strong support of this. I encourage it continuing to moving forward, I think on all of these issues,

we have a lot of work to do to be able to provide the access and resources that we need for all healthcare for people in California and I think this is a great step forward and I extend strong support and hope that we can all continue to work on this to find a good compromise.

Thank you Mr. Speaker, and I also applaud your passion on this Mr. Thurmond. So, I will start off by saying I will not be supporting your bill today. I stand in support of the Chair's recommendations, I've

been on this committee since I began here, and so my staff is really good at doing literature reviews and really looking at the data of what the findings are and what we have found is that there's really no difference in outcomes in looking, studying the two models, the one you're talking about.

And so for those reasons and for the reasons stated by the Dental Board, that we need to take a look at this before we go forward and see if we can actually do this, if there is a capacity out there. That I stand in support of the Chair's amendments, and I think that is a safer way to go, and to continue to go forward,
but I appreciate your passion and that's it.
Kelly Brooks on behalf of the County Welfare Director's Association and the Riverside County Board of Supervisors here in support.

I want to congratulate the member for bringing this forward, and I sincerely appreciate the support of Western Center on Law and Poverty, but your testimony was the best. I appreciate the fact that you have come forward because I think by you lending your voice to this, you let us know that success is available to so many people,

And shifting to me too mode, Daniel Savino, Association of Regional Center Agencies, also in opposition for the insertion of state process over family choice with the background checks, and unfunded mandates on providers in Regional Centers.

It seems like San Francisco, San Mateo, I mean they started back in 2003, 2005. I'm in support of your bill. It just seems that other counties, after that, then we had Alameda County, we have Santa Clara, we have Contra Costa, Marin County, San Diego, Fresno.
We're adding a few other counties. When do you believe that it would be time to present this on a statewide basis?

Thank you so much for bringing this forward. I think that education is key. If you don't know what's available to you, you can't take advantage of it. And you've given a great example how the program was there, you just didn't know about it. And I think having something like this, I appreciate you bringing this forward. I absolutely will support this.

You were absolutely correct. When I read the percentage of preschoolers that were being suspended I could not believe it.  I appreciate that the author is a teacher, and I think she understands a whole lot better than many of the rest of us, but I think even those of us who aren't teachers can recognize that there is a serious problem. I thank you for bringing this forward.
Good afternoon. Danielle Kando-Kaiser on behalf of Common Sense Kids Action. We've awarded this bill our star rating, in strong support. Thank you very much.

I like your bill, and I'm glad you brought it forward. The only thing I wasn't sure about is, it says as determined by the Department of Social Services. Do you have a mechanism on how that's going to be done?

Clearly this is something that's needed. I don't know how they can do it on the daily basis but something that is needed. If they don't provide, if they don't answer the call to give daily reports, what are the consequences?
And when they do the list, do they say if they have an opening for special needs foster child?

Without a doubt there's a need for this. Yeah. My only question, thinking out loud, is how is it going to be done? And I appreciate the fact that you're bringing the stakeholders together to figure how you put the database together and how you access.
One of the concerns brought up, the biggest concern seems to be privacy. Now who exactly is this information being released to?
I think you mentioned, but I want to ask about the opt out. Could you describe that please?

It's clear you had a witness that is also a provider and she clearly would want this service. She would want someone to seek her out and to provide information about other services, but then you have others who do not want the information. Once somebody opts out, are they taking off the list? What is the process? Once someone like the witness, if she says I opt out, I don't want my information given to anybody else. What is the procedure?
Ancillary expense, absolutely.

Thank you for bringing this common sense bill to us. It's hard to believe I was reading, to complete your time sheet, you have to take the number of steps. You have to do your math calculations, converting to hours and minutes. And then just minutes and then back to hours then to decimal version of hours, I can't believe that. I'm glad you're bringing this, Assemblymember Gonzalez Fletcher.
Well, Mr. Chair, I'm happy to move the bill at the appropriate time.

The original law does that, this Legislature did that in 1965, I believe. It established that privilege simply because it was it was recognised that for psychotherapy to operate and operate correctly there needed to be more protections to psychotherapists than the patient physician privilege afforded. So this bill does undercut that, we would object to that.
We would like to see it stricken, that is our sole objection at this point in time, we're still reviewing the bill. Thank you.

Madam Vice Chair, I just want to say that this is a very comprehensive bill, and there's a lot of things in here and it's a lot for all us to digest and I don't think anybody's worked harder than you, Senator Hill, on the staff in trying to hear everybody's side in all these things and put together a solid proposal, which I think we have before us.

I know there's still issues to be worked out, and we've heard from a number of people about that and I know you're committed to trying to continue to look for that consensus point. But all that being said, I'd be happy to move the bill.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman and members. I want to thank the Chair and the staff for working with me on this legislation. There have been amendments offered which I'm happy to accept. As many members know, there have been several tragedies involving children and dental anesthesia.

And it has spurred the need to revisit California's standards. The Dental Board of California engaged in a thorough review by a task force to look at this issue. After this review, they came back with recommendations to update the terminology, the staffing requirements,

the educational requirements, and the monitoring standards in an effort to improve safety. I'm very supportive of these recommendations, and this bill incorporates them, with one exception. There was additional an add-on when the Subcommittee made their recommendation to the dental board that required a second general anesthesia permit holder for patients less than seven years of age.

After listening to our hearing that we held a few months ago on this issue and consulting with experts, some of whom are here at the table with me, I came to the conclusion that that suggested requirement didn't have the data to substantiate and that would potentially impede access to care.

So this bill that you have before you incorporate the dental board's recommendation with chapter one provision. And I'm pleased to have with me some supporters of the bill, Gary Cooper on my left who will introduce the witnesses to speak.

I'm sorry.  I'm sorry. Anyway, as Senator Glazer said, that one particular provision, we found very problematic. Because, as he said, there isn't a lot of data that shows there's a need for that. The data clearly shows that the oral surgeons performing anesthesia in the office has been extremely safe throughout the years.

Mister Chair thank you. I'd like to say a couple things. When I first heard about this issue, I thought of it as if it was my daughter who had gone through this terrible circumstance that Caleb went through.

Caleb's family is still living with. To think about how would I feel about it, and so I struggled with that because I know the emotions of a terrible tragedy would overwhelm me. And I think that where I have struggled, where my struggles have ended is looking at the question of data.

As was mentioned earlier, the Subcommittee, the dental board, went back to try to find data that would substantiate that we had a problem here. And as was mentioned earlier, they found nine cases. And those cases were in all different circumstances.

And they found that, even in the cases where they found this tragic circumstance, there was no pattern of that it was because it was an oral surgeon doing the anesthesia themselves as a potential practice that created that unsafe circumstance.
Oral surgeons are training in anesthesiology. There are two other assistants in the room. You can not legislate against mistakes.

You can't do it, as much as we'd like to. So it is trying to take this issue that has controversy around it, where we struggled to find consensus on all these recommendations that have come out of the dental board. And for me at least it was can we get 90% of the way there, and still look for more data, look for more research to try to resolve this issue of the second anesthesiologist in the room?

And that's really what I was trying to do here with this bill. It doesn't resolve all these other issues that remain. I think we would like to, it tries to encourage and it has specificity in terms of more research and more data.
But it is trying to move the ball forward and make our dental offices safer than they are today.
Okay, that's fine. But I think, that wasn't the question. The question was with the-
All right, Senator Pan.

Senator Newman? I'd just like to say that I don't know his particular surgery center and the funding for it. I certainly respect greatly his desire, as it is all of our desires, to have the best care and the safest care for our kids. But so the issue is, is there evidence, is there data that says that the current practice model which has been in practice for decades and decades.
Absolutely, I think we all want to make good choices here for the kids. And so absolutely, I would be.

And Senator if I may I'd be happy to incorporate that in an appropriate way into the bill that we collect that data because that's what we want. We want to make good decisions based on facts, and I think what you have outlined in there is another element of this factual collection that would be of value.

Good afternoon, Susan Riggs for the ASPCA and we too are here in support. And we appreciate Senator Hill's leadership on this. We believe that, well, the ASPCA is not just an animal welfare organization. We actually run our own medical facilities and have lots of experience in this area and believe that the consumer needs to be part of this.
And disclosure and everything is very very important so that people can make consenting choices for their animals.

Thank you Madam Chair and members. Christina De Caro representing the California Veterinary Medical Association. We are in an opposed, work with the author position. We appreciate the Senator's comments about, of course, wanting to work with us.
We definitely want to work with him. We have great respect for the author. Great respect for staff, most certainly. And in fact we have been engaged in conversations.

They have been productive. The April 17th amendments I would mention, go a long way to helping us out. And we're grateful to the author for that most certainly. But we still need to lock down kind of that who, what, when, where piece and just drill down on those.
